<div class="pagenum"><a id="Page_viii">[Pg viii]</a><br><a id="Page_ix">[Pg ix]</a></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>INTRODUCTION</h2>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-cap" src="images/drop_i.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_i.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-cap"><span class="smcap">In</span> presenting, for the first time, to English readers the
greatest work of Germany's greatest mediæval poet, a
few words of introduction, alike for poem and writer,
may not be out of place. The lapse of nearly seven
hundred years, and the changes which the centuries
have worked, alike in language and in thought, would have naturally
operated to render any work unfamiliar, still more so when that work
was composed in a foreign tongue; but, indeed, it is only within the
present century that the original text of the <i>Parzival</i> has been collated
from the <span class="smcap">MSS.</span> and made accessible, even in its own land, to the
general reader. But the interest which is now felt by many in the
Arthurian romances, quickened into life doubtless by the genius of
the late Poet Laureate, and the fact that the greatest composer of
our time, Richard Wagner, has selected this poem as the groundwork
of that wonderful drama, which a growing consensus of opinion has
hailed as the grandest artistic achievement of this century, seem to
indicate that the time has come when the work of Wolfram von
Eschenbach may hope to receive, from a wider public than that of
his own day, the recognition which it so well deserves.</p>
<p>Of the poet himself we know but little, save from the personal
allusions scattered throughout his works; the dates of his birth and
death are alike unrecorded, but the frequent notices of contemporary
events to be found in his poems enable us to fix with tolerable certainty
the period of his literary activity, and to judge approximately the
outline of his life. Wolfram's greatest work, the <i>Parzival</i>, was apparently
written within the early years of the thirteenth century; he<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_x">[Pg x]</a></span>
makes constant allusions to events happening, and to works produced,
within the first decade of that period; and as his latest work, the
<i>Willehalm</i>, left unfinished, mentions as recent the death of the Landgrave
Herman of Thuringia, which occurred in 1216, the probability
seems to be that the <i>Parzival</i> was written within the first fifteen years
of the thirteenth century. Inasmuch, too, as this work bears no traces
of immaturity in thought or style, it is probable that the date of the
poet's birth cannot be placed much later than 1170.</p>
<p>The name, Wolfram von Eschenbach, points to Eschenbach in
Bavaria as in all probability the place of his birth, as it certainly was
of his burial. So late as the end of the seventeenth century his
tomb, with inscription, was to be seen in the Frauen-kirche of Ober-Eschenbach,
and the fact that within a short distance of the town are
to be found localities mentioned in his poems, such as Wildberg,
Abenberg, Trühending, Wertheim, etc., seems to show that there,
too, the life of the poet-knight was spent.</p>
<p>By birth, as Wolfram himself tells us, he belonged to the knightly
order (Zum Schildesamt bin Ich geboren), though whether his family
was noble or not is a disputed point, in any case Wolfram was a poor
man, as the humorous allusions which he makes to his poverty abundantly
testify. Yet he does not seem to have led the life of a wandering
singer, as did his famous contemporary, Walther von der Vogelweide;
if Wolfram journeyed, as he probably did, it was rather in search of
knightly adventures, he tells us: 'Durchstreifen muss Der Lande viel,
Wer Schildesamt verwalten will,' and though fully conscious of his
gift of song, yet he systematically exalts his office of <i>knight</i> above that
of <i>poet</i>. The period when Wolfram lived and sang, we cannot say
<i>wrote</i>, for by his own confession he could neither read nor write ('I'ne
kan decheinen buochstap,' he says in <i>Parzival</i>; and in <i>Willehalm</i>,
'Waz an den buochen steht geschrieben, Des bin Ich kunstelos
geblieben'), and his poems must, therefore, have been orally dictated,
was one peculiarly fitted to develop his special genius. Under the
rule of the Hohenstaufen the institution of knighthood had reached
its highest point of glory, and had not yet lapsed into the extravagant<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xi">[Pg xi]</a></span>
absurdities and unrealities which characterised its period of decadence;
and the Arthurian romances which first found shape in Northern
France had just passed into Germany, there to be gladly welcomed,
and to receive at the hands of German poets the impress of an
ethical and philosophical interpretation foreign to their original form.</p>
<p>It was in these romances that Wolfram, in common with other of
his contemporaries, found his chief inspiration; in the <i>Parzival</i>, his
master-work, he has told again the story of the Quest for, and winning
of, the Grail; told it in connection with the Perceval legend, through
the medium of which, it must be remembered, the spiritualising influence
of the Grail myth first came into contact with the brilliant
chivalry and low morality of the original Arthurian romances; and told
it in a manner that is as truly mediæval in form as it is modern in
interpretation. The whole poem is instinct with the true knightly
spirit; it has been well called <i>Das Hohelied von Rittertum</i>, the
knightly song of songs, for Wolfram has seized not merely the external
but the very soul of knighthood, even as described in our own
day by another German poet; Wolfram's ideal knight, in his fidelity
to his plighted word, his noble charity towards his fellow-man, lord
of the Grail, with Its civilising, humanising influence, is a veritable
'true knight of the Holy Ghost.' In a short introduction such as
this it is impossible to discuss with any fulness the fascinating problems
connected with this poem, one can do no more than indicate
where the principal difficulties lie. These may be briefly said to be
chiefly connected with the source from which Wolfram derived his
poem, and with the interpretation of its ethical meaning. That
Wolfram drew from a French source we know from his own statement,
he quotes as his authority a certain 'Kiot the Provençal,' who,
in his turn, found his information in an Arabian <span class="smcap">MS.</span> at Toledo. Unfortunately
no such poet, and no such poem, are known to us, while we
do possess a French version of the story, <i>Li Conte del Graal</i>, by
Chrêtien de Troyes, which, so far as the greater part of the poem
(<i>i.e.</i> Books <span class="smcap">III.</span> to <span class="smcap">XIII.</span>) is concerned, shows a remarkable agreement
not only in sequence of incidents, but even in verbal correspondence,<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xii">[Pg xii]</a></span>
with Wolfram's work. Chrêtien, however, does not give either the
first two or the last three books as we find them in Wolfram. The
account of Perceval's father, and of his death, is by another hand than
Chrêtien's, and does not agree with Wolfram's account; and the
poem, left unfinished by Chrêtien, has been continued and concluded
at great length by at least three other writers, who have evidently
drawn from differing sources; whereas Wolfram's conclusion agrees
closely with his introduction, and his whole poem forms the most
harmonious and complete version of the story we possess. Wolfram
knew Chrêtien's poem, but refers to it with contempt as being the
wrong version of the tale, whereas 'Kiot' had told the venture aright.
The question then is, where did Wolfram really find those portions of
his poems which he <i>could not</i> have drawn from Chrêtien? Is 'Kiot'
a real, or a feigned, source?</p>
<p>Some German critics have opined that Wolfram really knew no
other poem than Chrêtien's, and that he boldly invented all that he
did not find there, feigning another source in order to conceal the fact.
Others have maintained that whether 'Kiot' be the name of the
writer or not, Wolfram certainly had before him a French poem other
than <i>Li Conte del Graal</i>.</p>
<p>It certainly seems in the highest degree improbable that a <i>German</i>
poet should have introduced the Angevin element, lacking in Chrêtien;
Wolfram's presentment of the Grail, too, differs <i>in toto</i> from any we
find elsewhere, with him it is not the cup of the Last Supper, but a
precious stone endowed with magical qualities. It is true that Chrêtien
does not say <i>what</i> the Grail was, but simply that '<i>du fin or esmeree</i>
<i>estoit, pieres pressieuses avoit el graal de maintes manieres</i>,' yet it seems
scarcely likely that Wolfram should have interpreted this as a precious
stone, to say nothing of sundry Oriental features peculiar to his description.
But whence Wolfram derived his idea of the Grail is a problem
which it is to be feared will never now be completely solved.</p>
<p>The discussion as to the ethical meaning Wolfram attached to the
story seems more hopeful of results, as here we do possess the requisite
data, and can study the poem for ourselves. The question between<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xiii">[Pg xiii]</a></span>
critics is whether Wolfram intended to teach a purely religious lesson
or not; whether the poem is an allegory of life, and Parzival a symbol
of the Soul of man, hovering between Faith and Doubt, perplexed by
the apparent injustice of God's dealings with men, and finally fighting
its way through the darkness of despair to the clear light of renewed
faith in God; or have we here a glorification of the knightly ideal?
a declaration of the poet-knight's belief that in loyal acceptance of, and
obedience to, the dictates of the knightly order, salvation is to be won?
Can the true knight, even though he lack faith in God, yet by keeping
intact his faith with man, by very loyalty and steadfastness of purpose,
win back the spiritual blessing forfeited by his youthful folly? Is
Parzival one of those at whose hands 'the Kingdom of Heaven
suffereth violence'? It may well be that <i>both</i> these interpretations are,
in a measure, true, that Wolfram found the germ of the religious idea
already existing in his French source, but that to the genius of the
German poet we owe that <i>humanising</i> of the ideal which has brought
the <i>Parzival</i> into harmony with the best aspirations of men in all
ages. This, at least, may be said with truth, that of all the romances
of the Grail cycle, there is but one which can be presented, in its
entirety, to the world of to-day with the conviction that its morality
is as true, its human interest as real, its lesson as much needed now as
it was seven hundred years ago, and that romance is the <i>Parzival</i> of
Wolfram von Eschenbach.</p>
<p>Some words as to the form of the original poem, and the method
followed in translation, may be of interest to the reader. The original
<i>Parzival</i> is a poem of some 25,000 lines, written in an irregular metre,
every two lines rhyming, <i>reim-paar</i>. Among modern German translators
considerable difference of opinion as to the best method of
rendering the original appears to exist. Simrock has retained the
original form, and adheres very closely to the text; his version certainly
gives the most accurate idea of Wolfram's style; San Marte has allowed
himself considerable freedom in versification, and, unfortunately, also
in translation; in fact, he too often gives a paraphrase rather than a
reproduction of the text. Dr. Bötticher's translation omits the Gawain<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xiv">[Pg xiv]</a></span>
episodes, and, though close to the original, has discarded rhyme. It
must be admitted that Wolfram is by no means easy to translate, his style
is obscure and crabbed, and it is often difficult to interpret his meanings
with any certainty. The translator felt that the two points chiefly to
be aimed at in an English version were, that it should be faithful to
the original text, and easy to read. The metre selected was chosen for
several reasons, principally on account of the length of the poem, which
seemed to render desirable a more flowing measure than the short lines
of the original; and because by selecting this metre it was possible to
retain the original form of <i>reim-paar</i>. As a general rule one line of the
English version represents two of the German poem, but the difference
of language has occasionally demanded expansion in order to do full
justice to the poet's meaning. Throughout, the translator's aim has
been to be as literal as possible, and where the differing conventionalities
of the thirteenth and nineteenth centuries have made a
change in the form of expression necessary, the <i>meaning</i> of the poet
has been reproduced, and in no instance has a different <i>idea</i> been
consciously suggested. That there must of necessity be many faults
and defects in the work the writer is fully conscious, but in the absence
of any previous English translation she can only hope that the present
may be accepted as a not altogether inadequate rendering of a great
original; if it should encourage others to study that original for themselves,
and learn to know Wolfram von Eschenbach, while at the same
time they learn better to understand Richard Wagner, she will feel
herself fully repaid.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p>The translator feels that it may be well to mention here the works
which have been principally relied on in preparing the English translation
and the writers to whom she is mostly indebted.</p>
<p>For the Text Bartsch's edition of the original <i>Parzival</i>, published
in <i>Deutsche Classiker des Mittelalters</i>, has been used throughout, in
connection with the modern German translation by Simrock.</p>
<p>In preparing the Notes use has been made of Dr. Bötticher's
Introduction to his translation of the <i>Parzival</i>, and the same writer's<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xv">[Pg xv]</a></span>
<i>Das Hohelied von Rittertum</i>; San Marte's translation has also been
occasionally referred to.</p>
<p>The Appendix on proper names has been mainly drawn up from
Bartsch's article on the subject in <i>Germanistische Studien</i>; and that
on the Angevin allusions from Miss Norgate's <i>England under the</i>
<i>Angevin Kings</i>, though the statements have been verified by reference
to the original chronicles.</p>
<p>For all questions connected with the Perceval legend in its varying
forms the authority consulted has been <i>Studies on the Legend of the</i>
<i>Holy Grail</i>, by Mr. Alfred Nutt, to whom, personally, the translator
is indebted for much valuable advice and assistance in preparing this
book for publication.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_xvi">[Pg xvi]</a><br><a id="Page_1">[Pg 1]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK I<br>

GAMURET</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_2">[Pg 2]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>In the Introduction the poet tells of the evil of doubt and unsteadfastness—against
which he would warn both men and women; he will tell
them a tale which shall speak of truth and steadfastness, and in which
many strange marvels shall befall.</p>
<p>Book <span class="smcap">I.</span> tells how Gamuret of Anjou at the death of his father, King
Gandein, refused to become his brother's vassal, and went forth to seek fame
and love-guerdon for himself. How he fought under the Baruch before
Alexandria, and came to Patelamunt. How Queen Belakané was accused
of having caused the death of her lover Eisenhart, and was besieged by
two armies, which Friedebrand, King of Scotland, Eisenhart's uncle, had
brought against her. How Gamuret defeated her foemen, and married the
Queen, and became King of Assagog and Zassamank. How he grew weary
for lack of knightly deeds, and sailed away in secret from Queen Belakané,
and left her a letter telling of his name and race. How Feirifis was born,
and how Gamuret came to Seville.</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_3">[Pg 3]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK I</p>
<p class="ph2">GAMURET
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_i.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_i.png_1">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If unfaith in the heart find dwelling, then the soul it shall reap but woe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shaming alike and honour are his who such doubt shall show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For it standeth in evil contrast with a true man's dauntless might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As one seeth the magpie's plumage, which at one while is black and white.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet he may win to blessing; since I wot well that in his heart,  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hell's darkness, and light of Heaven, alike have their lot and part<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he who is false and unsteadfast, he is black as the darkest night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the soul that hath never wavered stainless <i>its</i> hue and white!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This my parable so fleeting too swift for the dull shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet they may seize its meaning from before their face 'twill flee,<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As a hare that a sound hath startled: yea, metal behind the glass,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a blind man's dream yield visions that as swift from the eye do pass,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught shall they have that endureth! And at one while 'tis bright and sad,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And know of a truth that its glory but for short space shall make ye glad.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And what man shall think to grip me, where no hair for his grasp shall grow,<span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In the palm of mine hand? The mystery of a close clasp he sure doth know!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If I cry aloud in such peril, it 'seemeth my wisdom well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall I look for truth where it fleeteth? In the fire that the stream doth quell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or the dew that the sun doth banish? Ne'er knew I a man so wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But was fain to learn the wisdom my fable doth ill disguise,        <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_4">[Pg 4]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the teaching that springeth from it: for so shall he ne'er delay<br></span>
<span class="i0">To fly and to chase as shall fit him, to shun and to seek alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to give fitting blame and honour. He who knoweth the twain to tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In their changing ways, then wisdom has tutored that man right well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sits not o'er-long at leisure, nor his goal doth he overreach,<span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But in wisdom his ways discerning, he dealeth with all and each.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his comrade, of heart unfaithful, in hell-fire shall his portion be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, a hailstorm that dims the glory of a knightly fame is he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a short tail it is, his honour, that but for two bites holds good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the steer by the gad-fly driven doth roam thro' the lonely wood.<span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And tho' manifold be my counsel not to <i>men</i> alone I'ld speak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would I show to women the goal that their heart should seek.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they who shall mark my counsel, they shall learn where they may bestow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their praise and their maiden honour; and the manner of man shall know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom they freely may love and honour, and never may fear to rue     <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Their maidenhood, and the true love they gave him of heart so true.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In God's sight I pray all good women to keep them in wisdom's way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For true shame on all sides doth guard them: such bliss I for them would pray.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the false heart shall win false honour—How long doth the thin ice last,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If the sun shineth hot as in August? So their praise shall be soon o'erpast.<span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Many women are praised for beauty; if at heart they shall be untrue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I praise them as I would praise it, the glass of a sapphire hue<br></span>
<span class="i0">That in gold shall be set as a jewel! Tho' I hold it an evil thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If a man take a costly ruby, with the virtue the stone doth bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And set it in worthless setting: I would liken such costly stone    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To the heart of a faithful woman, who true womanhood doth own.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would look not upon her colour, nor the heart's roof all men can see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If the heart beateth true beneath it, true praise shall she win from me!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Should I speak of both man and woman as I know, nor my skill should fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er-long would it be my story. List ye now to my wonder-tale:      <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And this venture it telleth tidings of love, and anon of woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Joy and sorrow it bringeth with it. 'Stead of <i>one</i> man if <i>three</i> ye know,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_5">[Pg 5]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And each one of the three hath wisdom and skill that outweigh my skill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet o'erstrange shall they find the labour, tho' they toil with a right good-will<br></span>
<span class="i0">To tell ye this tale, which I think me to tell ye myself, alone,    <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And worn with their task and weary would they be ere the work was done.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A tale I anew will tell ye, that speaks of a mighty love;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the womanhood of true women; how a man did his manhood prove;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of one that endured all hardness, whose heart never failed in fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Steel he in the face of conflict: with victorious hand of might     <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Did he win him fair meed of honour; a brave man yet slowly wise<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is he whom I hail my hero! The delight he of woman's eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet of woman's heart the sorrow! 'Gainst all evil his face he set;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he whom I thus have chosen my song knoweth not as yet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For not yet is he born of whom men this wondrous tale shall tell,   <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many and great the marvels that unto this knight befell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">NOW they do to-day as of old time, where a foreign law holds sway<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Yea, in part of our German kingdom, as ye oft shall have heard men say),<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whoever might rule that country, 'twas the law, and none thought it shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">('Tis the truth and no lie I tell ye) that the elder son might claim<span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The whole of his father's heirdom—And the younger sons must grieve,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What was theirs in their father's lifetime, they perforce at his death must leave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before, all was theirs in common, now it fell unto one alone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So a wise man planned in his wisdom, that the eldest the lands should own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For youth it hath many a fair gift, but old age knoweth grief and pain,<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who is poor in his old age an ill harvest alone doth gain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kings, Counts, Dukes (and no lie I tell ye) the law holdeth all as one,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no man of them all may inherit, save only the eldest son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And methinks 'tis an evil custom—So the knight in his youthful pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gamuret, the gallant hero, lost his Burg, and his fair lands wide,  <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where his father had ruled with sceptre and crown as a mighty king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till knighthood, and lust of battle, to his death did the monarch bring.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all men were sore for his sorrow, who truth and unbroken faith<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare ever throughout his lifetime, yea even unto his death.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_6">[Pg 6]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then the elder son he summoned the princes from out his land,       <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And knightly they came, who rightly might claim from their monarch's hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To hold, as of yore, their fiefdoms. So came they unto his hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the claim of each man he hearkened, and gave fiefs unto each and all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear how they dealt—As their true heart it bade them, both great and small,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They made to their king petition, with one voice from the people all,<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That to Gamuret grace and favour he would show with true brother's hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And honour himself in the doing. That he drive him not from the land<br></span>
<span class="i0">But give him, within his kingdom, a fair Burg that all men might see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he take from that Burg his title, and he held of all tribute free!—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the king was ill-pleased at their pleading, and he quoth, 'A small grace, I trow,<span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Have ye asked, I would e'en be better than your prayer, as ye straight shall know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why name ye not this my brother as Gamuret Angevin?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since Anjou is my land, I think me the title we <i>both</i> may win!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then further he spake, the monarch, 'My brother in sooth may seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet more from my hand of favour than my mouth may as swiftly speak,<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With me shall he have his dwelling—I would that ye all should see<br></span>
<span class="i0">How one mother alike hath borne us; his riches but small shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">While I have enough; of free hand would I give him both lands and gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That my bliss may be ne'er held forfeit by Him, Who can aye withhold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or give, as He deemeth rightful!' Then the princes they heard alway,<span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How the king would deal well with his brother, and they deemed it a joyful day!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And each one bowed him low before him. Nor Gamuret long delayed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he spake as his heart would bid him, and friendly the words he said:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now hearken, my lord and brother, if vassal I think to be<br></span>
<span class="i0">To thee, or to any other, then a fair lot awaiteth me.             <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But think thou upon mine honour, for faithful art thou and wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And give counsel as shall beseem thee, and help as thou shalt devise.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught have I now save mine armour, if within it I more had done,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then far lands should speak my praises, and remembrance from men were won!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then further he spake, the hero: 'Full sixteen my squires shall be,<span class="linenum">115</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_7">[Pg 7]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And six of them shall bear harness; four pages give thou to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of noble birth and breeding, and nothing to them I'll spare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of all that my hand may win them. Afar in the world I'ld fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Somewhat I ere now have journeyed,) if Good Fortune on me shall smile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I may win from fair women favour. If a woman I serve awhile,       <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to serve her she hold me worthy, and my heart speaketh not amiss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True knight shall I be and faithful! God show me the way of bliss!<br></span>
<span class="i0">As comrades we rode together (but then o'er thy land did reign<br></span>
<span class="i0">The King Gandein, our father), and sorrow and bitter pain<br></span>
<span class="i0">We bare for Love's sake! At one while I knew thee as <i>thief</i> and <i>knight</i>,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou couldst serve, and thou couldst dissemble, for the sake of thy lady bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! could I steal love as thou couldst, if my skill were but like to thine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That women should show me favour, then a blissful lot were mine!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Alas! that I ever saw thee,' spake, sighing, the king so true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Who lightly, with words of mocking, my heart would in pieces hew  <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And would fain that we part asunder! One father hath left us both<br></span>
<span class="i0">A mighty store of riches, I would share with thee, nothing loth.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Right dear from my heart I hold thee; red gold and jewels bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Folk, weapons, horse, and raiment, take thou as shall seem thee right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou at thy will mayst journey, and thy free hand to all be known.<span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Elect do we deem thy manhood, didst thou Gylstram as birthplace own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or thou camest here from Rankulat, yet still would that place be thine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which thou boldest to-day in my favour; true brother art thou of mine!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Sir King, thou of need must praise me, so great is thy courtesy!<br></span>
<span class="i0">So, courteous, thine aid be given, if thou and my mother free      <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Will share with me now your riches, I mount upward, nor fear to fall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart ever beateth higher—Yet I know not how I should call<br></span>
<span class="i0">This life, which my left breast swelleth! Ah! whither wouldst go mine heart?<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would fain know where thou shalt guide me—'Tis time that we twain should part.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all did the monarch give him, yea, more than the knight might crave,<span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Five chargers, picked and chosen, the best in his land he gave<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_8">[Pg 8]</a></span>
<span class="i0">High-couraged, swift to battle; and many a cup of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a golden nugget, for naught would his hand withhold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Four chests for the road he gave him, with many a jewel rare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they filled. Then the squires he took him who should for the treasure care,<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And well were they clad and mounted; and none might his grief withhold<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the knight gat him unto his mother, who her son in her arms did fold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Spake the woman, as woman grieving: 'Wilt thou tarry with me no more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Gandein's son? Woe is me! yet my womb this burden bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the son of my husband art thou. Is the eye of God waxed blind, <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or His ear grown deaf in the hearing, that my prayer doth no credence find?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is fresh sorrow to be my portion? I have buried my heart's desire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the light of mine eyes; will He rob me, who have suffered a grief so dire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who judgeth with righteous judgment? Then the tale it hath told a lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That spake of His help so mighty, Who doth help unto me deny!'     <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'God comfort thee,' quoth the hero, 'for the death of my father dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For truly we both must mourn him—But I think from no lips to hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such wailing for my departing! As valour shall show the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I seek knighthood in distant countries—So it standeth with me to-day.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the queen, 'Since to high love's service thou turnest both hand and heart,<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet son, let it not displease thee to take of my wealth a part<br></span>
<span class="i0">That may serve thee upon thy journey; let thy chamberlain take from me<br></span>
<span class="i0">Four chests, each a pack-horse burden, and heavy their weight shall be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And within, uncut, there lieth rich silk of Orient rare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man as yet hath cut it, and many a samite fair.                 <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet son, I prithee tell me what time thou wilt come again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That my joy may wax the greater, and I look for thee not in vain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay, that I know not, Lady, nor the land that shall see my face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But wherever I take my journey, thou hast shown unto me such grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">As befitteth knightly honour: and the king he hath dealt with me   <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise that grateful service his rewarding shall ever be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this trust have I, O Lady, that for this thou wilt love him more<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforward, whate'er the future yet keepeth for me in store.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as the venture telleth, to the hand of this dauntless knight,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_9">[Pg 9]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the favour he won from a woman, and the working of true love's might,<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Came a token fair, and its value was full thousand marks, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en to-day an a Jew were craving a pledge, he would deem enow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such jewel, and ne'er disdain it—'Twas sent by his lady true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fame did he win in her service, and her love and her greeting knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet seldom his pain found easing—Then the hero he took his leave  <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of mother, brother, and brother's kingdom, and many I ween must grieve<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since his eyes never more beheld them. And all who his friends had been,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere he passed from the land of his fathers, tho' the grace were but small, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave them of thanks full measure; he deemed they too much had done,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, courteous, little thought him, that of right he their love had won!<span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Straighter his heart than straightness; did one of his praises speak<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a full and fitting measure, then doubt were not far to seek,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ask ye of those his neighbours, or of men who in distant lands<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had seen his deeds, then the marvel ye were swifter to understand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Gamuret he trode ever where Temperance aye should guide,       <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And naught else might rule his doings, nor he boasted him in his pride<br></span>
<span class="i0">But bare great honour meekly; from loose ways he e'er had flown;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought him, the gallant hero, that none bare on earth a crown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they King, or Queen, or Kaiser, whom he deemed of his service worth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they not the mightiest reckoned of all monarchs that be on earth.<span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This will in his heart he cherished—Then men spake, at Bagdad did reign<br></span>
<span class="i0">A monarch so strong and powerful, that homage he well might claim<br></span>
<span class="i0">From two-thirds or more of earth's kingdoms. The heathen his name held great,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake of him as the Baruch, and kings did on his bidding wait,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And crownèd heads were his servants; and his office it lasts to-day—<span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">See how Christian men baptizèd to Rome wend their pilgrim way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So there was the heathen custom. At Bagdad was their papal right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Baruch as 'seemed his office purged their sins with his word of might.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From Pompey and Ipomidon, two brothers of Babylon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nineveh, the town of their fathers, the Baruch with force had won, <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_10">[Pg 10]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And bravely 'gainst him they battled. Then came the young Angevin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Baruch he showed him favour, yea, he did to his service win<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gamuret the gallant hero—And he deemed it were well he bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Other arms than Gandein his father had given to him of yore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the hero he well bethought him; on his charger's cloth they laid<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An anchor of ermine fashioned, and the same at his will they made<br></span>
<span class="i0">For shield alike and vesture—And green as the emerald rare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was his riding-gear, and 'twas fashioned and wrought of Achmardi fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">('Tis a silken stuff,) and he bade them to make of it at his will<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both blazoned coat and surcoat, (than velvet 'tis richer still;)   <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade them to sew upon it the anchor of ermine white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with golden threads inwoven was the badge of this gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And his anchors they never tested or mainland or haven fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">And found in that place abiding—But the hero must further bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' many a land, a brave guest, the load of this heraldry,       <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And behind the sign of this anchor but short space might his resting be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And nowhere he found abiding—The tale of the lands he saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the vessels in which he sailed him? If the truth unto ye I swore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On mine own oath must I swear it, and my knightly honour true<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise as the venture told me; other witness I never knew!   <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And men say that his manly courage held the prize in far heathendom,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Morocco's land, and in Persia, and elsewhere he high honour won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Damascus and at Aleppo, and where knightly deeds should be:<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Arabia and lands around it was he held of all conflict free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no man might dare withstand him, he won him such crown of fame;<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart for honour lusted, and all deeds were brought to shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And became as naught before him, as all men bare witness true<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who a joust with him had ridden, and Bagdad of his glory knew.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And his heart never failed or faltered, but onward his course he bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Zassamank's land and kingdom; there all men wept that hero fair,<span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Eisenhart, who in knightly service gave his life for a woman's smile;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Belakané thereto constrained him, sweet maid she, and free from guile.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Since her love she never gave him, for love's sake did the hero die,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his kinsmen would fain avenge him, and with force and with subtlety<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_11">[Pg 11]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Their armies beset the maiden, but in sooth she could guard her well<span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere Gamuret came to her kingdom, and her wrath on her foemen fell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the Prince Friedebrand of Scotland, and his host that against her came<br></span>
<span class="i0">By ship, ere he left her kingdom had she wasted with fire and flame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear what befell our hero; storm-driven he was that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And scarce might he win to safety, and his boat in the haven lay   <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Beneath the royal palace; and the folk they beheld him there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he looked around on the meadow, and he saw many tents stand fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Around the town, save the sea-coast, and two armies he thought to see.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade them to tell the story, and whose that fair Burg should be?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he knew it not, nor his shipmen—And an answer they straightway gave,<span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas Patelamunt; then the townsfolk a boon from the knight would crave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their speech it was soft and friendly—In the name of their gods they'ld pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">He should help them, so great their peril that in danger of death they lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the young Angevin had hearkened to the tale of their bitter pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He proffered to them his service for such payment as knight may gain,<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(As it oft shall befit a hero)—They should say for what goodly prize<br></span>
<span class="i0">He should dare the hate of their foemen? And they answered him in this wise<br></span>
<span class="i0">With one mouth the hale and the wounded—Naught would they from him withhold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But lord should he be of their treasure, of their jewels alike and gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A fair life should he lead among them!—But such payment he little sought,<span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a golden nugget from Araby had he brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dark as night were the people who in Zassamank dwelt alway—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the time it seemed long unto him that he need in their midst must stay—<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he bade them prepare a lodging, and methinks it became them well<br></span>
<span class="i0">The best of their land to give him, since awhile he with them would dwell.<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the women they looked from the windows, and they gazed on the noble knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked on his squires, and his harness, how 'twas fashioned for deeds of might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they saw how the knight, free-handed, on his shield of ermine bare<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_12">[Pg 12]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Full many a pelt of sable; the Queen's Marshal he read it fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The badge, for a mighty anchor, and little he rued the sight,      <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If his eye spake the truth unto him ere this had he seen the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or one who bare his semblance—At Alexandria it needs must be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the Baruch besieged the city—and unequalled in strife was he!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So rode the gallant hero, in stately guise and meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ten pack-horses heavy-laden they led first adown the street,       <span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And twenty squires behind them; and his people they went before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And lackeys, cooks, and cook-boys, at the head of the train they saw.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stately I ween his household, twelve pages of lineage high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode next to the squires, well-mannered, and trained in all courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Saracens were among them; and behind them in order fair        <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Came chargers eight, and a covering of sendal did each one bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the ninth it bore a saddle, and the shield ye have known ere now<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was borne by a squire beside it, and joyful his mien, I trow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And trumpeters rode behind it, for in sooth they must needs be there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a drummer he smote his tambour, and swung it aloft in air.     <span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And as naught had the hero deemed it, this pomp, if there failed to ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men who on the flute were skilful, and three fiddlers were at their side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they hasted not nor hurried; and behind them the hero came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his shipman he rode beside him, a wise man of goodly fame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And much folk was within the city, and Moors were both man and maid.<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the hero he looked around him, and, lo! many a shield displayed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Battle-hewn and with spear-thrust piercèd they hung on each wall and door.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wailing and woe was their portion; for the knight at each window saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many men lie sorely wounded, who to breathe the air were fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en tho' a leech might tend them no help might they think to gain<span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who were hurt too sore for healing—In the field had they faced the foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And such shall be their rewarding who in conflict no flight will know—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many horses were led towards him, sword-hewn and with lance thrust through;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on each side stood dusky maidens, and black as the night their hue.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his host gave him kindly greeting—and of joy did he reap his meed—<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A rich man was he and mighty, and many a knightly deed<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_13">[Pg 13]</a></span>
<span class="i0">With thrust and blow had his hand wrought when his post at the gate he found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a knight was with him, and bandaged their heads and bound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their hands in slings were holden; yet tho' sorely wounded still<br></span>
<span class="i0">They did many deeds of knighthood, nor were lacking in strength and skill.<span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Burg-grave of the city, with fair words did he pray his guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">To deal with him and his household in such wise as should seem him best.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host, he led the hero to his wife, and courteously<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did Gamuret kiss the lady, small joy in the kiss had he!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they sat them down to the table, and e'en as the feast was o'er,<span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Marshal he gat him swiftly to the queen, and the tidings bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And craved from her goodly payment, as to messenger shall be due.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'It shall end in gladness, the grief that erewhile we knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">We have welcomed here, O Lady, a knight of such gallant mien,<br></span>
<span class="i0">We must thank the gods who have sent him, for our need they have surely seen.'<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now tell me upon thine honour who this gallant knight may be?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, a dauntless hero, and the Baruch's man is he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An Angevin he, of high lineage; Ah me! little did he spare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Himself, when his foemen seeking he forth to the field would fare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">How wisely, with skill and cunning, he avoided the threatening blow,<span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And turned him again to the onslaught! Much sorrow he wrought his foe—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere this have I seen him battle, when the princes of Babylon<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their city of Alexandria had fain from the Baruch won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with force from its walls would drive him, and many a man lay dead<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the overthrow of their army, for their venture was but ill-sped.<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And such deeds did he do, this hero, that no counsel was theirs but flight:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there did I hear his praises, for all spake of this gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">As one who, without denial, had won him, in many a land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The crown of true knightly honour, by the strength of his own right hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now fain would I speak with the hero, see thou to the time and way;<span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en now might he ride to the castle, for peace shall be kept to-day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it better that I should seek him? He is other than we in face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pray Heaven it not displease him, but our need with the knight find grace!<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_14">[Pg 14]</a></span>
<span class="i0">I would that I first might know this, ere the rede from my folk I hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I show to this stranger honour—If it pleaseth him to draw near,<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, how shall I best receive him? Shall the knight be so nobly born<br></span>
<span class="i0">That my kiss be not lost, if I kiss him?' 'Nay, hold me of life forsworn<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he be not of kings the kinsman! Lady, this word I'll bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">To thy princes, that they shall clothe them in raiment both fit and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stand before thee, in due order, ere yet to thy court we ride, <span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the same shalt thou say to thy ladies—In the city he doth abide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will ride below, and will bring him to thy palace, a worthy guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no fair or knightly virtue shall be lacking that noble breast.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But little space they delayed them, for the Marshal, with ready skill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Strove that all in such wise be ordered as should pleasure his lady's will.<span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But soon did they bear to the hero rich garments, he did them on,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this hath the venture told me that their cost should be hardly won;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thereon lay the anchors, heavy, and wrought of Arabian gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so had he willed. Then the hero, who fair payment for love had told<br></span>
<span class="i0">A charger bestrode that 'fore Babylon a knight rode, for jousting fain,<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From the saddle did Gamuret smite him, and I wot it hath wrought him pain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If his host thought to ride beside him? He and his gallant knights?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, in sooth they would do so, gladly—So wended they up the height,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dismounted before the palace; and many a knight stood there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each, as was fit, had clothed him in raiment both rich and fair.<span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his pages they ran before him, and each twain they went hand in hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in marvellous fair arraying he saw many ladies stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen, her eyes brought her sorrow as she looked on the Angevin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So lovely was he to look on that he needs must an entrance win<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the gates of her heart, if 'twere anguish or joy that within he bore,<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' her womanhood 'gainst all comers had held them fast closed before.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then a space did she step towards him, and a kiss from her guest she prayed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, herself, by the hand she took him and they sat them, both man and maid<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a window wide, that looked forth from the palace upon the foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a covering of wadded samite was spread o'er the couch below.   <span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Is there aught that than day is lighter? Then it likeneth not the queen!<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_15">[Pg 15]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Yet else was she fair to look on, as a woman should be, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But unlike to the dew-dipped roses was her colour, yea, black as night.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her crown was a costly ruby, and thro' it ye saw aright<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her raven head. Then as hostess she spake to her guest this word,  <span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That greatly she joyed at his coming, 'Sir, Knight, I such tale have heard<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of thy knightly strength and prowess—Of thy courtesy, hear me fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would I tell of my sorrow, and the woe that my heart doth bear!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'My help shall not fail thee, Lady! What hath grieved, or doth grieve thee now,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I think me aside to turn it, to thy service my hand I vow!         <span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I am naught but one man only—Who hath wronged or now wrongeth thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">My shield will I hold against him—Little wroth shall thy foeman be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then a prince he spake out courteous, 'The foe would we little spare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did our host not lack a captain, since Friedebrand hence must fare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He defendeth afar his kingdom—A king, one Hernant by name         <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Whom he slew for the sake of Herlindè) his kinsmen against him came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And evil enow have they wrought him, nor yet from their strife forbear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he left here full many a hero, and among them, Duke Heuteger<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his gallant deeds of knighthood, and his army, hath pressed us sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They have skill and strength for the conflict. And many a soldier more<span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With Gaschier of Normandy came here, and a hero wise is he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many knights hath he brought to this country (and wrathful guests they be):<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kailet of Hoscurast. All these hath he brought upon our fair land<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his comrades four, and his soldiers, the Scottish king Friedebrand!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, to the West, by the sea-coast doth Eisenhart's army lie,<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And their eyes shall be fain for weeping; nor in secret, nor openly<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath one seen them, and failed to marvel at their grief and their sorrow sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since their lord hath been slain in battle with the heart's rain their eyes run o'er.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the guest courteous spake to his hostess, 'I would, an it seem thee right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shouldst say why thy foeman threaten, why they seek thee with war-like might!<span class="linenum">400</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_16">[Pg 16]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast here many gallant heroes, it grieveth me sore to see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy land thus with hate o'erladen, for woe must it bring to thee.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Wouldst thou know? Then, Sir Knight, I will tell thee—A knight did me service true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fruit of all manly virtue his life as its decking knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gallant and wise was the hero, and his faith as a goodly tree  <span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was fast-rooted, and none so courteous but were shamed by his courtesy.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And modest was he as a woman, tho' dauntless and strong, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a knight e'en as he free-handed ere his day never land might know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(But they that shall come hereafter, other folk shall their doings see.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">A fool was he in false dealing, and a Moor, as myself shall be;    <span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his father's name was Tánkaneis, a king of a kingly heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his son, he who was my lover, men knew him as Eisenhart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">That for love's sake I took his service, as a woman I did not well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It hath brought me but lasting sorrow since no joy to his portion fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They deem I to death betrayed him! Yet such treason were far from me,<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' his folk bring such charge against me; and dear to my heart was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far dearer than <i>they</i> e'er held him. Nor witnesses here shall fail<br></span>
<span class="i0">To speak to the truth of my saying, if it please them to tell the tale.<br></span>
<span class="i0">His gods and mine, they know it, the truth—I must sorrow deep<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since my womanly shame hath brought him a guerdon I needs must weep!<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thus he won in my maiden service much honour by knighthood fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thought thus to prove my lover; his deeds did his worth declare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my sake he put off his harness (that which like to a hall doth stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is a lofty tent, the Scotch folk they brought it into this land),<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then e'en tho' he bare no armour his body he little spared,        <span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he held his life as worthless, many ventures unarmed he dared.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the matter so stood between us, a prince who my man should be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Prothizilas did men call him, a bold knight, from all cowardice free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode forth in search of venture, and evil for him that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there, in Assagog's forest, his death in waiting lay.          <span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a knightly joust he met it, and there too he found his end<br></span>
<span class="i0">The gallant knight who faced him—'Twas Prince Eisenhart my friend.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For both of the twain were piercèd with a spear thro' heart and shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, alas! poor woman, must weep for that fatal field.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_17">[Pg 17]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And ever their death doth grieve me, and sorrow from love shall grow,<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And never henceforth as my husband a man do I think to know.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then e'en tho' she was a heathen Gamuret he bethought him well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That a heart more true and tender ne'er in woman's breast might dwell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her purity was her baptism, and as water that washed her o'er<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was the rain that streamed from her eyelids o'er her breast, and the robe she wore;<span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All her joy did she find in sorrow, and grief o'er her life did reign—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen she looked on the hero, and in this wise she spake again:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'With his army the king of Scotland hath sought me across the sea,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the knight was son to his uncle; yet no ill can he do to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If here the truth be spoken, that is worse than the grief I knew   <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For Eisenhart's death!' and sorely she sighed that lady true;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a glance thro' her tear-drops on Gamuret shyly fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her eyes to her heart gave counsel, and his beauty it pleased her well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And she knew how to judge a fair face, since fair heathen she oft had seen,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the root of true love and longing it sprang up the twain between.<span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She looked upon him, and his glances, they answering sought her own—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she bade them to fill the wine-cup, had she dared, it were left undone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she grieved she might not delay it, since to many a hero brave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who spake with the maids this wine-cup the signal of parting gave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet her body was e'en as his body, and his look did such courage give<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To the maid, that she thought henceforward in the life of the knight to live.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he stood upright, and he spake thus, 'Lady, I weary thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too long methinks do I sit here, I were lacking in courtesy!<br></span>
<span class="i0">As befitting true knight and servant I mourn for thy woe so great,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lady, do thou command me, I will on thy bidding wait.              <span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherever thou wilt, there I wend me. I will serve thee in all I may!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lady she quoth in answer, 'I believe thee, Sir Knight, alway!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his kindly host the Burg-grave, of his labour would nothing spare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest the hours of his stay be heavy; and he asked if he forth would fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ride round the walls of the city? 'The battle-field shalt thou see,<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And how we would guard our portals!' then Gamuret courteously<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_18">[Pg 18]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Made answer, he fain would see it, the field where they late had fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the place where brave deeds of knighthood had by gallant hands been wrought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And noble knights rode with him adown from the palace hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some were wise, some were young and foolish,—So rode they around the wall<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To sixteen gates, and they told him not one of them might they close<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since Eisenhart's death called for vengeance—'So wrathful shall be our foes<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our conflict it resteth never, but we fight both by night and day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor our portals since then we fasten, but open they stand alway.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At eight of our gates they beset us, true Eisenhart's gallant knights,<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And evil shall they have wrought us; spurred by anger each man doth fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The princes of lofty lineage, the king of Assagog's ban!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there floated before each portal a banner, so pale and wan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a piercèd knight upon it. When Eisenhart lost his life<br></span>
<span class="i0">His folk chose to them this symbol, as badge in the coming strife. <span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'But against these arms have we others, wherewith we their grief would still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus shalt thou know our banner; 'twas wrought at our lady's will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two fingers in oath she stretcheth, that never such grief she knew<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Eisenhart's death hath brought her (true sorrow for heart so true),<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so doth it stand the semblance of our queen, on a samite white <span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Belakané in sable fashioned,—Since against us they came in might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(To avenge him for whom she sorrows) so she looks from our portals high.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And proud Friedebrand's mighty army doth to eight of our gates stand nigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Baptized men, from o'er the waters. A prince doth each portal hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And forth from the gate he sallies, with his banners and warriors bold.'<span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'From the host of Gaschier the Norman, a count have we captive ta'en,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And heavy methinks the ransom we may hope from that knight to gain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He is sister's son to Kailet, and the harm <i>he</i> to us hath done<br></span>
<span class="i0">His nephew I ween shall pay for! Yet such prize have we seldom won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here have we no grassy meadow, but sand, thirty gallops wide       <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Betwixt the tents and the trenches; here many a joust we ride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And further his host would tell him, 'One knight, he doth never fail<br></span>
<span class="i0">To ride forth, a fair joust seeking. (If his service shall nought avail<br></span>
<span class="i0">With her who hath sent him hither, what boots it how well he fight?)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Proud Heuteger is the hero, of him may I speak with right          <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_19">[Pg 19]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For since our besiegers threaten there dawneth never a day<br></span>
<span class="i0">But before the gates 'neath the castle, that knight doth his charger stay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And oft from that dauntless hero many tokens we needs must bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he smote through our shields at his spear-point, and costly their worth and rare<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the squire from the shield doth break them. Many knights 'fore his joust must fall;<span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He would that all men may behold him, and our women they praise him all.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who is praised of women, one knoweth that he doth hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">The prize in his hand, and his heart's joy in full measure shall aye be told!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But now would the sun, grown weary, its wandering rays recall;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas time that the ride was ended—Then he sought with his host the hall,<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the evening meal was ready; and I needs of that feast must tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas laid in a fitting order, and knightly 'twas served, and well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen with mien so stately she unto his table came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Here stood the fish, there the heron) and she counted it not for shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">To ride adown from her palace, that herself she might be aware     <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If they cared for the guest as 'twas fitting, and with her rode her maidens fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Low she knelt (and but ill it pleased him) and cut as it seemed her best<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the knight a fitting portion; she was glad in her goodly guest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she filled for him the wine-cup, and care for his needs would take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well did he mark, the hero, her mien, and the words she spake. <span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his fiddlers sat at the table, and over against the knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was his chaplain: with shy looks shamefast, he spake to the lady bright:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'I looked not to find such welcome as, Lady, thou gavest me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too much must I deem the honour! If rede I might give to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then to-day I had claimed naught from thee save was due to my worth alone,<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor adown the hill hadst thou ridden, nor such service to me hadst shown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, Lady, if I may venture to make unto thee request,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let me live but as best befits me, thou dost honour o'ermuch thy guest!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet her kindly care she stayed not; for she stept to his page's seat<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with gentle words and friendly she prayed them to freely eat,  <span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This she did her guest to honour: and the noble lads, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare goodwill to the royal lady. Nor the queen methinks was slow<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_20">[Pg 20]</a></span>
<span class="i0">To pass where the host was seated and his lady, the Burg-gravine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she raised the golden goblet, and she spake as should fit a queen:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now unto your care I give him, our guest, and I rede ye both      <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the honour is yours, to hearken, and do my will nothing loth!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she bade them farewell, and she turned her, and passed to her guest once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose heart for her sake was heavy; and such sorrow for him she bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her heart and her eyes they answered, and they spake to her sorrow yea!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And courteous she spake, the lady, 'Sir Knight, thou the word shalt say,<span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And whate'er be thy will, I will do it, for I hold thee a worthy guest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now give me, I pray, dismissal; if here thou in peace shalt rest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of that shall we all be joyful.' Her torch-holders were of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And four tapers they bare before her, so she rode to her fortress-hold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor long at the board they lingered—The hero was sad, and gay,    <span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He was glad for the honour done him, yet a sorrow upon him lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that was strong Love's compelling, that a proud heart and courage high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Can bend to her will, and gladness shall oft at her bidding fly.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the hostess she passed to her chamber, yea, e'en as the meal was o'er;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a couch did they spread for the hero, and love to the labour bore.<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host to his guest spake kindly, 'Now here shall thy sleep be sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt rest thro' the night that cometh, to thy need shall such rest be meet.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spake to his men, and he bade them they should hence from the hall away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the noble youths his pages, their couches around his lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">Each one with the head toward his master, for so was the custom good;<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And tapers so tall and flaming alight round the chamber stood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ill did it please the hero that so long were the hours of night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the Moorish queen so dusky, had vanquished his heart of might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he turned as a willow wand bendeth, till his joints they were heard to crack,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The strife and the love that he craved for he deemed he o'er-long did lack.<span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart-beats they echoed loudly, as it swelled high for knighthood fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he stretched himself as an archer who bendeth a bow amain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so eager his lust for battle that sleepless the hero lay<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_21">[Pg 21]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Till he saw the grey light of morning, though as yet it should scarce be day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his chaplain for Mass was ready, and to God and the knight they sing,<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For so did he give commandment. Then he bade them his harness bring,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he rode where a joust should wait him, and that self-same hour would ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">A horse that could charge the foeman, and turn swiftly to either side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And answer to bit and bridle if its rider would backward draw.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the watchers, both man and woman, his helm in the gateway saw, <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the anchor shone fair upon it; and no man ere this might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">So wondrous fair a hero, for like to a god was he!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And strong spears they bare for his using—How then was he decked, the knight?<br></span>
<span class="i0">With iron was his charger covered, as should serve for a shield in fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And above lay another covering, nor heavy methinks it weighed,     <span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a samite green; and his surcoat and blazoned coat were made<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Achmardi, green to look on, and in Araby fashioned fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no lie I tell, but the shield-thongs that the weight of the shield should bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were of silk and gold untarnished, and jewel-bedecked their pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the boss of the shield was covered with red gold, in the furnace tried.<span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He served but for love's rewarding; sharp conflict he held it light;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen she looked from her window, with many a lady bright.<br></span>
