<span class="i0">And see, there Heuteger held him, who the prize ne'er had failed to gain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he saw the knight draw nearer, in swift gallop across the plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thought, 'Now whence came this Frenchman? Who hither this knight hath sent?<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If a <i>Moor</i> I had thought this hero, my wit were to madness bent!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">No whit they delayed the onslaught, from gallop to swifter flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Each man spurred amain his charger; and as fitting a valiant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor one would evade the other, but would meet him in jousting fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From brave Heuteger's spear the splinters flew high thro' the summer air,<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But his foeman so well withstood him that he thrust him from off his steed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Adown on the grass; but seldom might he win for his joust such meed!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his foe in his course rode o'er him, and trode him unto the ground,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_22">[Pg 22]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he sprang up again, and valiant, fresh lust for the strife he found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Gamuret's lance had pierced him thro' the arm, and he bade him yield,<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he knew he had found his master, and he spake from the foughten field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now who shall have o'erthrown me?' and the victor he swiftly spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gamuret Angevin do men call me!' then he quoth, 'Thou my pledge canst take!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his pledge the knight took, and straightway he sent him within the wall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And much praise did he win from the women who looked from the castle hall.<span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And swiftly there came towards him, Gaschier of Normandy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A proud and wealthy hero and mighty in strife was he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gamuret made him ready, for a second joust he'ld ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strong and new was his spear-shaft, and the iron was both sharp and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the strangers they faced each other—But unequal their lot, I trow,<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For Gaschier and his gallant charger full swiftly were they laid low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight with his arms and harness he fell in the shock of strife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he thought it for good or for evil, by his pledge must he win his life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gamuret quoth, the hero, 'Thou hast pledged unto me thine hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the weapon it well hath wielded! Ride thou to the Scottish band,<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And bid them to cease from troubling; if they to thy will are fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou canst follow me to the city.' Then the knight hied him o'er the plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he prayed them, or gave commandment, they did at the last his will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Scottish host they rested, and from conflict they held them still.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Kailet spurred swift towards him, but Gamuret turned his rein,<span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His cousin he was, and near kinsman, why then bring him grief and pain?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Spaniard cried loudly on him; on his helm he an ostrich bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so far as I know to tell ye the knight he was decked so fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">With silken raiment goodly, and long were his robes and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the plain rang clear with the chiming of sweet bells as he o'er it hied.<span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The flower he of manly beauty, and his fairness it held the field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save for two who should come hereafter, and his fame unto theirs must yield;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_23">[Pg 23]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But Parzival and brave Beaucorps, King Lot's son, they are not here,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not yet were they born, but hereafter for their beauty men held them dear!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gaschier he grasped his bridle. 'Now checked will it be thy race,<span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So I tell thee upon mine honour, if the Angevin thou shalt face<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who there my pledge hath taken. Sir Knight, thou shalt list my prayer<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hearken unto my counsel; in Gamuret's hand I sware<br></span>
<span class="i0">From strife aside to turn thee: stay thy steed then for my sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For mighty is he in conflict!' Then aloud King Kailet spake,       <span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Is he Gamuret my cousin, and son unto King Gandein?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I care not with him to battle, no foe shall he be of mine!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Take thine hand from off my bridle'—'Nay, further thou shalt not fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till mine eyes have first beheld thee, with thine head of the helmet bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>mine</i> with blows is deafened!' Then his helmet the prince unbound.<span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet, tho' with him he fought not, Gamuret other foemen found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the day had grown to high morning—And the folk who the joust might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were glad at heart, and they gat them to their bulwarks right speedily,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he was as a net before them, and none might escape his hold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he chose him another charger, so the tale unto me was told,    <span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And it flew, and the earth it spurnèd, and its work could aright fulfil,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bold when the knight would battle, yet its speed could he check at will.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And what would he do the rider? His valour I praise alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he rode where the Moorish army to the west by the sea-coast lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thence a prince, Rassalig men called him, forgat not each coming morn<span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(He was Assagog's richest hero, to riches and honour born<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he came of a royal lineage) to take from the camp his way<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would fain joust before the city—But his strength it was quelled that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">By Anjou's dauntless hero; and a dusky maid made moan<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Since 'twas she who sent him hither) that her knight should be thus o'erthrown.<span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For a squire brought, without his bidding, to his master, brave Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A spear, with light reed-shaft fashioned, and its point 'gainst the Moor he set,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with it he smote the paynim from his steed down upon the sand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor longer he bade him lie there than as surety he pledged his hand.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_24">[Pg 24]</a></span>
<span class="i0">So the strife it had found its ending, and the hero had won him fame;<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gamuret saw eight banners toward the city that onward came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade the conquered hero the force with his word to stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And follow him to the city. And that word must he needs obey.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor Gaschier delayed his coming; and unto the Burg-grave told<br></span>
<span class="i0">How his guest sought for further conflict nor his wrath might the host withhold.<span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If he swallowed not iron as an ostrich, nor his wrath did on stones assuage<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas but that he might not find them! Then he gnashed his teeth for rage,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he growled as a mighty lion, and the hair of his head he tare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'So the years of my lifetime a harvest of folly bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The gods they had sent to my keeping a valiant and worthy friend,  <span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If with strife he shall be o'erladen, then mine honour hath found an end;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sword and shield they shall little profit—Yea, shame he would on me cast<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who should bring this to my remembrance!' Then swift from his place he passed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gat him into the portal, and a squire towards him drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bare a shield that was painted with a knight by a spear pierced thro',<span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In Eisenhart's land was it fashioned; and a helmet his hand must hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a sword that Rassalig carried in battle, that heathen bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now was he parted from it whose fame was in every place;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were he slain unbaptized I think me, God had shown to this hero grace!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And e'en as the Burg-grave saw it, ne'er of yore was his joy so great,<span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the coat-of-arms he knew it—So he rode thro' the city gate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And without, his guest had halted, young hero he, not yet old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As one of a joust desirous, and his bridle the Burg-grave bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lahfilirost was his name, he grasped it, and he led him within the wall;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot well no other foeman that day 'neath his spear must fall.<span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Lahfilirost the Burg-grave, 'Sir Knight, thou shalt tell to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thine hand Rassalig hath vanquished?' 'Then our land from all strife is free;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he of the Moors is chieftain, the men of true Eisenhart<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who have brought unto us such sorrow—But now shall our woe depart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a wrathful god who bade him thus seek us with all his host,  <span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But his weapons to naught are smitten, and to folly is turned his boast!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he led him in (ill it pleased him) and there met then the royal maid,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_25">[Pg 25]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And she loosened the bands of his vizor, and her hand on his bridle laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her care must the Burg-grave yield it: nor his squires to their task were slack,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they turned them about, and swiftly they rode on their master's track.<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So men saw the queen so gracious lead her guest thro' the city street<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who here should be hailed the victor—Then she lighted her on her feet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ah me! but thy squires are faithful! Fear ye lest your lord be lost?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without ye shall he be cared for; take his steed, here am I his host!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And above found he many a maiden: then her hands of dusky hue      <span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The queen set unto his harness, and disarmed the knight so true.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bed-covering was of sable, and the couch it was spread so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in secret a hidden honour they did for the knight prepare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no one was there to witness—The maidens they might not stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the door was fast closed behind them, and Frau Minne might have her way.<span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So the queen in the arms of her true love found guerdon of sweet delight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' unlike were the twain in their colour, Moorish princess and Christian knight!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the townsfolk brought many an offering to the gods who had seen their woe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">That which Rassalig needs must promise ere he from the field might go<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he did, in all truth and honour, yet heavy was he at heart,   <span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And afresh sprang the fount of his sorrow for his prince gallant Eisenhart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burg-grave he heard of his coming; then loud rang the trumpet call,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no man of Zassamank's princes but came to the palace hall.<br></span>
<span class="i0">They gave Gamuret thanks for the honour he had won in the field that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Four-and-twenty had fallen before him, and their chargers he bore away,<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And three chieftains had he made captive. And there rode in the princes' train<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many gallant knights, in the courtyard of the palace did they draw rein.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hero had slept and eaten, and clad him in raiment fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Chief host was he, for his body fit garments would they prepare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she who afore was a maiden but now was a wife would take       <span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her lord by the hand, forth she led him, and unto her princes spake:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_26">[Pg 26]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'My body and this my kingdom are vassals unto this knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If so be that his foemen fearing, resist not his hand of might!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gamuret spake, and his bidding was courteous, for hero meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Rassalig, go thou nearer, with a kiss thou my wife shalt greet;<span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Sir Gaschier, thou shalt do likewise.' Then the Scotch knight proud Heuteger<br></span>
<span class="i0">He bade on the lips to kiss her (and the wounds won in joust he bare).<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he bade them all be seated, and standing, he wisely spake:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I were fain to behold my kinsman, if he who did captive take<br></span>
<span class="i0">The knight shall have naught against it—As kinsman it seemeth me  <span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That I find here no other counsel save straightway to set him free!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen she smiled, and bade them go swiftly and seek the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then thro' the throng he pressed him, that count so fair and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet bare he the wounds of knighthood, and bravely and well had fought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the host of Gaschier the Norman the land of the Moors he sought.<span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He was courteous; his sire a Frenchman he was Kailet's sister's son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Killirjacac his name; in the service of fair women fair meed he won,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the fairest of men they deemed him. When Gamuret saw his face<br></span>
<span class="i0">(For like were they each to the other, as men of a kindred race)<br></span>
<span class="i0">He bade his queen to kiss him and embrace him as kinsman true,     <span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Now come thou and greet me!' and the knight to his arms he drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he kissed him, and each was joyful that the other he here might meet:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gamuret quoth unto him, 'Alas! cousin fair and sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What doth thy young strength in this conflict? Say, if woman hath sent thee here?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, never a woman sent me, with my cousin I came, Gaschier,      <span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He knoweth why he hath brought me—A thousand men have I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I do to him loyal service—To Rouen in Normandy<br></span>
<span class="i0">I came, where his force was gathered, and many a youthful knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">I brought from Champagne in mine army; 'neath his banner we fain would fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now evil hath turned against him what of cunning is hers and skill,<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wilt honour thyself if thou free him for my sake, and cure his ill!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thyself shalt fulfil thy counsel! Go thou, take with thee Gaschier,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_27">[Pg 27]</a></span>
<span class="i0">I would fain see my kinsman Kailet, do thou bring him unto me here!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">So they wrought out the host's desiring, and brought him at his behest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in loving wise and kindly did Gamuret greet his guest;         <span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ofttimes the queen embraced him, and kissed him with kisses sweet:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And nothing it wronged her honour in such wise the prince to greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was cousin unto her husband, by birth was himself a king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then smiling his host spake to him, 'God knows, 'twere an evil thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had I taken from thee Toledo, and thy goodly land of Spain         <span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For Gascony's king, who wrathful doth plague thee with strife amain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twere faithless of me, Sir Kailet, since mine aunt's son thou sure shalt be;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bravest of knights shall be with thee; say, who forced this strife on thee?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the proud young hero, 'My cousin Schiltung bade<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Since his daughter Friedebrand wedded) that I lend to the king mine aid.<span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the sake of his wife hath he won him, yea even from me alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">Six thousand chosen heroes, who valour and skill have shown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And other men did I bring him, but a part they shall hence have sailed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the Scottish folk came they hither, brave bands who in strife ne'er failed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there came to his aid from Greenland, strong heroes who bravely fought,<span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Two mighty kings, and a torrent of knighthood with them they brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a goodly vessel: and they pleased me, those men of might—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here for his sake came Morhold, who hath cunning and skill in fight.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'But now have they turned them homewards, and that which the queen shall say<br></span>
<span class="i0">Even that will I do with mine army, her servant am I alway!        <span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt thank me not for this service, from kinsman 'twas due, I ween.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now <i>thine</i> are these gallant heroes, if like mine they baptized had been<br></span>
<span class="i0">And were even as they in colour, then never a monarch crowned<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if they should fight against him, of conflict his fill had found!<br></span>
<span class="i0">But I marvel what here hath brought thee? Say, how didst thou reach this strand?'<span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yestreen I came, and this morning I am lord o'er this goodly land!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The queen by the hand she took me, and with love I myself would shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so did my wit give counsel—' 'Yea, so hast thou won the field,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_28">[Pg 28]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Those sweet weapons two hosts have vanquished!' 'Thou wouldst say, since I fled from <i>thee</i>,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So loudly on me thou calledst, say, what wouldst thou force from me?<span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Let us speak of the thing in friendship!' 'Thine anchor I failed to know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But seldom mine aunt's brave husband Gandein, did such token show!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'But I, I knew well thine ostrich with the snake's head upon thy breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Aloft stood thy bird so stately, nor hid it within a nest!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And I saw in thy mien and bearing that that pledge would have 'seemed thee ill<span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which two heroes afore had given, tho' first had they fought their fill.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'E'en such fate as theirs were my portion—But this thing I needs must say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' little I like a devil, were he victor as thou this day<br></span>
<span class="i0">For love of his gallant doings the women had deemed him sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, as sugar were fain to eat him!' 'Now thou praisest me more than meet!'<span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, of flattery know I little, thou shalt see that I hold thee dear<br></span>
<span class="i0">In other wise!' Then the hero bade Rassalig draw anear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And courteous he spake, King Kailet, 'My kinsman with valiant hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath made of thee here his captive?' 'Yea, Sire, so the thing doth stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I hold him for such a hero that Assagog's kingdom fair         <span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Should fail not to yield him homage, since the crown he may never wear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our prince Eisenhart! In her service was he slain who shall now be wife<br></span>
<span class="i0">To thy kinsman, as knight so faithful he gave for her love his life.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With my kiss have I sealed forgiveness, yet my lord and my friend I lost!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy cousin by knightly dealing will repay of his death the cost <span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I will fold my hands as his vassal: and wealth shall be his and fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All that Eisenhart from Tánkaneis as his heritage thought to claim.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Embalmed here the hero lieth, and I gaze on his wounds each day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since this spear thro' his true heart piercing, my lord and my king did slay!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he drew it forth from his bosom by a silken cord so fine,     <span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heroes saw the spear-blade 'neath his robe on his bare chest shine.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'It is now high morning, if my lord Sir Killirjacac<br></span>
<span class="i0">My token will bear to my princes, with him will the knights ride back.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a finger-ring he sent them: dark as hell were those heroes all<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they rode who were there of princes, thro' the town to the castle hall.<span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As his vassals he gave with their banners to Assagog's lords their land,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_29">[Pg 29]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And each one rejoiced in the fiefdom he won from his ruler's hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the better part was his portion, Gamuret's, as their lord and king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And these were the first—as they passed hence their homage they fain would bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">The princes of Zassamank's kingdom, and they came in their order due,<span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And each as their queen had bade them, they took from his hand anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their land, and the fruit it should bear them, as to each man was fit and right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And poverty fled from his presence. Now he who was slain in fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in life was a prince by lineage, Prothizilas, he had left<br></span>
<span class="i0">A Dukedom fair, and this country which was thus of its lord bereft <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave unto him who much honour had won by his strong right hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Burg-grave, in combat dauntless—With its banners he took the land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Assagog's noble princes took the Scotch Duke, proud Heuteger,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gaschier, the Norman hero, to their lord did they lead them there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake them free for their asking, and they thanked brave Gamuret.<span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Heuteger of Scotland with prayers did these knights beset,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now give to our lord the armour, as prize for his deeds so brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Eisenhart's life took from us, when to Friedebrand he gave<br></span>
<span class="i0">That which was of our land the glory—Forfeit of joy the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dead on his bier he lieth, since no love might his love requite—'<span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And earth knoweth naught so goodly, the helm it was strong and hard,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea even of diamond fashioned, in battle a goodly guard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Heuteger sware unto them, if the land of his lord he saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would pray of his hand the armour, and send it to them once more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And this did he swear them freely—Then leave would the princes pray<span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who stood in the royal presence, and they wend from the hall their way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' sorely the land was wasted, yet Gamuret scattered free<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such royal gifts and goodly as if laden with gold each tree.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And costly I ween the presents that vassal and friend must share<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the open hand of the hero; and the queen deemed it right and fair.<span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Full many a bitter conflict had been fought ere the bridal feast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But peace had the foeman sealèd, and the land was from strife released;<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Nor this song I myself have woven, but so was it told to me)<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_30">[Pg 30]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And Eisenhart did they bury with honours right royally.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To his grave did his kinsmen bear him, and the gold that his lands might bring<span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a whole year long, did they spend there, of their free will they did this thing.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gamuret bade his kinsfolk his riches and lands to hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">And use as they would; tho' they craved not such boon from the hero bold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At dawn from before the fortress the foe would their camp withdraw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And those who were there departed; many litters with them they bore.<span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the field was left unsheltered, save for one tent so great and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the king he bade his servants that tent to his vessel bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he said to his folk that to Assagog would he take it, and yet I wot<br></span>
<span class="i0">He did with that speech deceive them, for Assagog saw him not.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now that proud and gallant hero, his heart gave him little rest    <span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he found there no deeds of knighthood, and gladness forsook his breast;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet his dusky wife was dearer than e'en his own life might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ne'er knew he a truer lady whose heart was from falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She forgat not what 'seemed a woman, and with her as comrades good<br></span>
<span class="i0">Went purity untarnished, and the ways of true womanhood.           <span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He was born in Seville's fair city whom the knight would hereafter pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he grew of his sojourn weary, to sail with him far away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a mile had he led him, and he brought him unto this place,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a Christian was he, the steersman, nor like to a Moor in face.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wisely he spake, 'Thou shalt hide it from them who a dark skin bear,<span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Too swift is my barque for pursuing, from hence shall we quickly fare!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his gold it was borne to the vessel. Now of parting I needs must tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By night did he go, the hero, and his purpose he hid it well;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But when from his wife he sailèd, in her womb did she bear his child:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair blew the wind, and the breezes bare him hence o'er the waters wild.<span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the lady she found a letter, and 'twas writ by her husband's hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in French (for she well could read it) did the words of the writing stand:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_31">[Pg 31]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Here one love to another speaketh—As a thief have I stolen away<br></span>
<span class="i0">That mine eyes might not see thy sorrow—But this thing I needs must say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wert thou, e'en as I, a Christian I ever should weep for thee,     <span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For e'en now I must sorely mourn thee. If it chance that our child shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">In face like unto one other, then his is a dowry fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Anjou was <i>he</i> born, and Frau Minne for his lady he did declare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet was he in strife a hailstorm, ill neighbour unto his foe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That his grandsire hath been King Gandein, this I will that my son shall know.<span class="linenum">880</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Dead he lay thro' his deeds of knighthood; and his father the same death won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Addanz was his name, and unsplintered his shield hath been seen of none;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by birth he hath been a Breton, and two brothers' sons were they,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He and the brave Pendragon, and their sires' names I here will say;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Lassalies he hath been the elder, and Brickus was his brother's name,<span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Mazadan was their father whom a fay for her love did claim.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Terre-de-la-schoie did they call her, to Fay-Morgan she led the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he was her true heart's fetters; and my race from those twain did spring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair shall they be, and valiant, and as crownèd kings they reign—<br></span>
<span class="i0">If lady, thou'lt be baptizèd thou mayst win me to thee again!'     <span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet had she no thought of anger, but she spake, 'Ah! too soon 'tis o'er,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a sooth would I do his bidding, would it bring him to me once more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In whose charge hath my courteous hero left the fruit of his love so true?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! for the sweet communion that we twain for a short space knew!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall the strength of my bitter sorrow rule body and soul alway?   <span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Now his God to honour, his will would I fain obey,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly I'ld be baptizèd, and live as should please my love!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow with her heart struggled, and e'en as the turtle dove<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her joy sought the withered branches, for the same mind was hers, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the mate of the turtle dieth, she forsaketh the branches green.<span class="linenum">900</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the queen at the time appointed bare a son, who was dark and light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in him had God wrought a wonder, at one while was he black and white.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a thousand times she kissed him where white as his sire's his skin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she named the babe of her sorrows Feirefis Angevin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he was a woodland-waster, many spears did he shatter fair,     <span class="linenum">905</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And shields did he pierce—as a magpie the hue of his face and hair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now a year and more was ended since Gamuret won such fame<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_32">[Pg 32]</a></span>
<span class="i0">At Zassamank, and his right hand the victor's prize might claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet o'er the seas he drifted, for the winds vexed the hero bold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then a silken sail red gleaming he saw, and the barque did hold    <span class="linenum">910</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The men whom the King of Scotland, Friedebrand, sent upon their way<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the bidding of Queen Belakané: from her would they pardon pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">That ever he came against her, tho' in sooth he had lost the more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with them the diamond helmet, the corslet and sword they bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hosen e'en such as the harness, and a marvel it needs must be  <span class="linenum">915</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That the barque was thus borne towards him, as the venture hath told to me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they gave him the goodly armour, and an oath unto them he swore<br></span>
<span class="i0">That his mouth it should speak their message, an he came to the queen once more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they parted; and one hath told me that the sea bare him onward bound<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he came to a goodly haven, and in Seville his goal he found.  <span class="linenum">920</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with gold did he pay his steersman right well for his guidance true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they parted, those twain, and sorrow the heart of that steersman knew!<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_33">[Pg 33]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK II<br>

HERZELEIDE</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_34">[Pg 34]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>This Book tells how Gamuret sought for King Kailet, and found him
before Kanvoleis. How the Queen of the Waleis ordered a Tourney to be
holden, and of the heroes there assembled. How Gamuret did valiant
deeds, and was adjudged the victor; and how two queens laid claim to
his love. Of the wedding of Gamuret and Queen Herzeleide and their
love to each other. How Gamuret went to the aid of the Baruch, and
was treacherously slain before Alexandria. How the news was brought
to the land of the Waleis; of the sorrow of Herzeleide; and of the birth
of Parzival.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_35">[Pg 35]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK II</p>
<p class="ph2">HERZELEIDE
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_n.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_n.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now there in the Spanish country he thought him the king to greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His kinsman and cousin Kailet, and he followed with footsteps fleet<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Toledo, but thence had he ridden unto deeds of knighthood fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where many a spear should be splintered, and men thought not their shields to spare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought him to make him ready (so the venture doth tell I ween)<span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With many a blazoned spear-shaft, and many a sendal green;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For each spear it bare a pennon, with the anchor in ermine white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well was it wrought, the symbol, and costly in all men's sight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long and broad were the pennons, and e'en to the hand hung low<br></span>
<span class="i0">When men on the spear-blade bound them, a span-breadth the point below.<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a hundred spears were ready for that true and gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his cousin's folk they bare them, and with him went forth to fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And honour and loyal service they showed him as fit and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor I think had their lord been wrathful that his kinsman their love should share.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I know not how long he sought him, till shelter at length he found  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In the Waleis land: 'fore Kanvoleis were pitched on the open ground<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many tents so fair and knightly; (I speak not from fancy light<br></span>
<span class="i0">But sooth are the words I tell ye if the tale ye would hear aright)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade his folk to halt there, and he sent on before his face<br></span>
<span class="i0">The chief of his squires, and he bade him to seek them a resting-place.<span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He would fain do his master's bidding, and swift to the town he sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a pack-horse laden his comrades behind him led.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a house he saw there but its roof was a shield I trow,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_36">[Pg 36]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the walls were hung and circled with spears in a goodly row,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the queen of the Waleis country had ordered at Kanvoleis        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That a Tourney fair be holden, and they ordered it in such wise<br></span>
<span class="i0">That a coward had little liked it—for whoever would seek such strife<br></span>
<span class="i0">At his will doth it chance but seldom! She was maiden, not yet a wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And herself and two lands she offered to him who the prize should hold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many to earth had fallen in whose ear had this tale been told,  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who such fall must suffer he held that his chance was o'er.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a dauntless hero showed knighthood those walls before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a horse rushed onward as the knight spurred to onslaught fierce,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sword-blades rang clear on each other, and spears did the shield rims pierce.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A bridge from the plain was builded that crossed o'er the river's flow,<span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas closed by a tower-portal; nor the squire at his task was slow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he opened the gates, unwearied, when one would an entrance win.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And above it there stood the palace, and the queen sat the hall within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she gazed from the high hall window with many a maiden fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked on the squires beneath them to see what had brought them there.<span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twixt themselves had they taken counsel, and a tent did they rear on high<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the winning of love ungranted a king wrought it in days gone by,<br></span>
<span class="i0">('Twas in service of Queen Belakané). The squires laboured with might and main<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the burden of thirty pack-steeds they raised on the grassy plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A pavilion rich to look on, and the meadow it was so wide           <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That the silken ropes that held it might stretch forth on either side.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gamuret, their master, ate without in the open air—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then for his courtly entrance with skill would the knight prepare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor longer might be delaying—His squires take the spears straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they bind them fast together, and five in each band they lay,   <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sixth in their hand they carry, with its pennon and anchor white;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So proudly into the city came riding this gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the queen she heard the tidings that a noble guest was come<br></span>
<span class="i0">From a far-off land and distant, and in sooth was he known to none.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_37">[Pg 37]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'And courteous his folk in bearing; both heathen and French I trow, <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Angevin, some among them if their speech I aright may know;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their courage is high, and their raiment both rich and well shaped shall be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now was I with his people, and they seem me from falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they say, 'Who hath lust for riches, if he to our lord shall seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">He will free him from fear of scarceness!' The while I with them did speak,<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I asked them to tell of their master, and they thought not to hide the thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But spake of a true heart freely, 'Of Zassamank is he king.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Twas a page who brought the tidings—'Ah me! that pavilion fair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wouldst thou pledge thy crown and thy kingdom not half of its cost were there!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou needst not to praise so highly, my mouth ne'er shall say thee nay,<span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A rich man shall be its owner, no lack doth he know alway.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in this wise she spake, the lady, the fair and gracious queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Why cometh he not to the castle? For fain I his face had seen.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This she bade her page to ask him—Then the hero was fain to make<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brave entry into the city, and the sleepers must needs awake.       <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Many shields he saw fair shining—The blast of the trumpets clear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rang loud and long before him, and two drummers ye needs must hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">As they tossed and smote their tambours, and the walls echoed back the sound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the notes of the flutes 'twas mingled as the train through the city wound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a march that they played so gaily—Nor forget we how he must ride<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Their master and lord, he followed with the fiddlers his rein beside.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he threw his leg o'er his charger, that hero so bold and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And boots did he wear of leather, or else had his limbs been bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his mouth it was e'en as a ruby, and red, as a fire doth burn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And full, not too thin; fair his body wherever the eye might turn;  <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair was his hair and curling, and wherever one saw the skin<br></span>
<span class="i0">I ween 'twas as costly cover as ever a head might win.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of samite green was his mantle, and the sable shone dark thereon<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' white was his vest, and the gazers they came in a goodly throng.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many must ask the question, 'Who was he, the beardless knight   <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_38">[Pg 38]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Who rode with such pomp of riches?' Then the tale it was spread aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they spake it as truth who knew it—So they drew to the bridge anear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk of the town, and his people; and so bright was the radiance clear<br></span>
<span class="i0">That shone from the queen that it thrilled him thro' his strong limbs, that goodly knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he braced himself as a falcon that plumeth its wings for flight,<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lodging he deemed it goodly; so thought he that hero wise;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his hostess with joy beheld him, the lady of fair Waleis!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the king of Spain he heard it, how there stood on the open plain<br></span>
<span class="i0">The tent that at Rassalig's bidding Gamuret as his prize did gain<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Patelamunt, and the tidings a knight to his lord would bring—   <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he sped as a deer, joy's vassal I ween was the gallant king!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus spake the knight, 'Thy kinsman, and the son of thine aunt I saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with pomp and in state as aforetime, so to-day doth he hither draw;<br></span>
<span class="i0">There are floating a hundred pennons full fair by his knightly shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And around his high pavilion they stand on the grassy field,       <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And green as the grass the pennons, and the hero bold doth bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three anchors of snow-white ermine on every sendal fair.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Hath he come here arrayed for battle? Ah! then shall men see straightway<br></span>
<span class="i0">How he spurreth him swift to the onslaught, how he striveth in knightly fray!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long time hath the proud King Hardeiss his anger against me shown, <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Here in joust shall Gamuret fell him, and good fortune shall be mine own!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straightway he sent a message to Gaschier, the Norman knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where he lay with many a vassal; and Killirjacac the fair and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For here had they come at his bidding—The twain at King Kailet's side<br></span>
<span class="i0">Towards the fair pavilion with a goodly following hied.            <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Zassamank's king was joyful, for he held them dear at heart:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the time over-long had seemed them since they must from each other part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This they spake of a true heart truly—And the king he was fain to know<br></span>
<span class="i0">What knights should be here for the Tourney, who valour and skill should show.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then spake unto him his kinsmen, 'From distant lands they came,    <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_39">[Pg 39]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The knights whom love's power hath brought here, many heroes of dauntless fame.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Here Uther Pendragon fighteth, and with him his Breton host;<br></span>
<span class="i0">One grief as a thorn doth vex him, his wife hath the hero lost,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The queen who was Arthur's mother; a clerk who all magic knew<br></span>
<span class="i0">With him hath she fled, and Arthur doth after the twain pursue;    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis now the third year since he lost them, his son alike and wife—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here is his daughter's husband, a hero well skilled in strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Lot is his name, of Norway—swift seeketh he knighthood's prize,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But slow are his feet to falsehood, the knight so bold and wise.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here is his young son Gawain; as yet he too weak shall be      <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For any deed of knighthood—but now was the boy with me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, were he not too feeble a spear-shaft as yet to break<br></span>
<span class="i0">He were fain to do deeds of knighthood, in the Tourney his part would take!<br></span>
<span class="i0">His lust for strife waketh early! Here Patrigalt's king hath brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of spears a goodly forest; yet their valour shall be as naught     <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When weighed against the gallant doings of the men of Portugal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, <i>bold</i> we in truth may call them, and shields do they pierce right well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here are the men of Provence, with many a blazoned shield;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here the Waleis, to their onslaught the foemen perforce must yield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they ride at their will thro' the combat, for men of the land are they.<span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Many fight here for love's rewarding whose title I may not say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But all whom I here have named thee now lie, and the truth I tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At great cost here within the city, for so the queen deemed it well.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And without on the plain they hold them who deem their prize lightly won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Proud Arragon's haughty monarch, and the brave king of Askalon.    <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Eidegast, he is there from Logrois, and the King Brandelidelein<br></span>
<span class="i0">(The monarch is he of Punturtois), there too is bold Lähelein.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Morhold is there of Ireland, many pledges that knight hath ta'en;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a haughty German doth camp on that battle plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To this country the Duke of Brabant hath come thro' the King Hardeiss;<span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The king of Gascony gave him his sister the fair Aleiss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Yet his service ere that won payment) wrath against me those princes drew:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now I trust <i>thee</i> to think of our kinship—For love's sake do me service true!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the king of Zassamank, 'Cousin, no thanks would I have from thee<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_40">[Pg 40]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Whate'er I may do for thine honour, my will e'en as thine shall be.<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Doth thine ostrich yet stand un-nested? Thou shalt carry its serpent's head<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst thy foeman's demi-gryphon, <i>my</i> anchor shall swift be sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And find in his onslaught landing; himself shall a haven seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">Behind his steed on the gravel! If our wrath we be fain to wreak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ride one against the other, I fell him, or he felleth me—     <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On my knightly faith as a kinsman this word do I swear to thee!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Kailet he sought his lodging, and his heart it was gay and light.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then arose on the plain a war-cry, 'fore the face of two gallant knights,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They were Schyolarz of Poitou, and Gurnemanz of Graharz,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the plain did they meet together; ere the eventide might pass   <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The knights in their troops they rode forth, here by six and there by three,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they did gallant deeds of knighthood—nor otherwise might it be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now it was fully noontide, and the knight in his tent abode;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the king of Zassamank heard this, that o'er all the field they rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'O'er the length and the breadth they gallop, and in knightly order fight.'<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thither he rode, the hero, with many a banner bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he rode not in search of conflict, at his leisure he thought to see<br></span>
<span class="i0">What was done by one side and the other of fair deeds of chivalry.<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the plain did they spread his carpet, where the knights in strife would close,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shriek of the wounded horses o'er all the tumult rose.     <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The squires stood round in a circle mid the clash of the ringing steel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heroes for fair fame battled, and the swords sang for woe or weal.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There was sound as of splintered spear-shafts, but none need to question, Where?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his walls were of meeting foemen, by knightly hands builded fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And so near was I ween the jousting that the maids from the hall above<span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Might look on the toil of the heroes—But sorrow the queen did move<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the king of Zassamank did naught, nor mingled him in the fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Ah! why came he hither? I had deemed him a gallant knight!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Now the King of France, whose fair wife brought Gamuret sorrow sore<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_41">[Pg 41]</a></span>
<span class="i0">When he fought for her sake, lay lifeless, and the queen sought the wide world o'er<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To know if from heathen countries he had come to his land again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas love's power to the search that drove her, for love did her heart constrain.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And many brave deeds were done there of many a poor man bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who yet for the highest strove not, which the queen for their prize had told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herself and her two fair kingdoms,—they thought not such prize to gain,<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But they battled for other booty, tho' their hearts were for payment fain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now clad was Gamuret's body in the harness whereby his wife<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might bring to her mind forgiveness, and the ending of bitter strife.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Scotch King Friedebrand sent it, as a gift, to repay the woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">That with conflict he heaped upon her, nor shall earth of its fellow know.<span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he looked well upon the diamond—'twas a helmet, thereon they bound<br></span>
<span class="i0">An anchor, and jewels so precious were within its setting found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor small were the stones, but costly, and the weight it was none too light<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of that helmet, and yet he bare it, and decked was the guest for fight<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And what was his shield's adorning? of gold of Araby fair,         <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the boss it was rich and costly, and heavy the weight he bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the red gold shone so brightly that mirrored the face therein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And an anchor beneath of sable—I were fain to myself to win<br></span>
<span class="i0">That wherewith the knight was girded, full many a mark its worth.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wide was the coat emblazoned, and it reached e'en unto the earth,<span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween that few in battle such raiment shall think to wear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if I have skill to praise it, or its value aright declare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It shone e'en as when there burneth thro' the night-time a living flame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a tint was faded, and its shimmer as lightning came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A feeble eye had feared it! And with gold was it all inwrought,    <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That in Kaukasus' distant mountains from out of the rock was brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">By gryphon claws, for they guarded, and shall guard it unto this day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from Araby came the people who stole it by craft away,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Elsewhere shall be none so precious,—and they bare it to Araby<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where they weave Achmardi and Pfellel, and no vesture like <i>that</i> shall be!<span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His shield, round his neck he hung it—There stood a charger proud,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_42">[Pg 42]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Well-nigh to the hoof was it armed—and the squires cried the war-cry loud,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sprang on his steed as he found it; and many a spear of might<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did he break with strong hand in the Tourney, and where men did the closest fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">There he brake a way thro' the mêlée, and came forth on the further side,<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever behind the Ostrich the Anchor did close abide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gamuret smote from off his charger Poytewin of Prienlaskors<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many another hero, their pledge must they yield perforce.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But what knight bare the cross he rejoiced him in the hero's valiant deeds,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And much did he win by his valour, since he gave him the captured steeds.<span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now four banners, with self-same bearing, were led 'gainst that gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And bold riders they rode beneath them, and their lord was a man of might,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on each was the tail of a gryphon; and that hinder part I trow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was e'en as a hailstorm smiting, so rode they in goodly row.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gascony's king before them the fore part of that gryphon bare  <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On his shield; he was skilled in battle, and his body was armed full fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">As women alone might arm him; and he rode forth his knights before<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where he saw on a helm the Ostrich, but the Anchor towards him bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thrust him from off his charger, the brave king of Zassamank,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And made of him there his captive. Here close thronged the knightly ranks,<span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the furrows were trodden level, and their locks must the sword-blade know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a wood was wasted, and many a knight laid low—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they who thus fell, 'twas told me, they turned their chargers round<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hied to the back of the Tourney, where none but the cowards were found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And so near was I ween the combat that the women might see aright  <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who there won the prize of valour; Rivalein that love-lorn knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his spear hewed afresh a token, of Loheneis was he king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the crash of the splintered spear-shaft did aye with his onslaught ring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a knight did Morhold rob them, for he drew him from off his steed<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_43">[Pg 43]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And lifted him up before him (unseemly methinks such deed)         <span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Killirjacac they called him,—and ere this King Lac had ta'en<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such payment from him as in falling a knight from the earth may gain—<br></span>
<span class="i0">So his deeds had been fair and knightly; then this valiant man he thought<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would take him with never a sword-thrust, and the knight in his arms he caught.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the hand of the valiant Kailet it smote from the saddle-bow   <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Duke of Brabant, Prince Lambekein, and the hero was laid alow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And what think ye they did, his soldiers? Their swords into shields they turned,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with them did they guard their monarch—And ever for strife they yearned.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the King of Arragon smote him Uther Pendragon old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From his charger adown on the meadow fell the king of the Bretons bold,<span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the flowers stood fair around him—Ah! I courteous am I, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the Breton before Kanvoleis I lay on such couch alow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where never the foot of a peasant hath trodden unto this day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, perchance they may never tread there—'tis the truth and no lie I say—<br></span>
<span class="i0">No more might he keep his saddle as he sat on his steed of yore,   <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But his peril his friends forgat not, they fought fiercely the hero o'er.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And many a course was ridden; and the king of Punturtois<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fell prone in his horse's hoof-tracks on the field before Kanvoleis,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And low did he lie behind it—'Twas Gamuret dealt the blow—<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ride on, on thy course, thou hero, and tread thy foemen low!'     <span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Strife giveth whereon to trample! Then Kailet, his kinsman true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Made the Punturtois his captive, tho' he scarce pierced the mêlée thro'.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brandelidelein was prisoner, and his folk they had lost their king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his stead another monarch to their host did they captive bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hither and thither sped they, the heroes, in armour good,      <span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And by blows and by trampling kneaded, of alum I ween their food;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dark on their skin the swellings, and many a gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might speak, as he knew, of bruises he had won him in hard-fought fight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now as simple truth I say it, little rest was their portion here,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By love were they forced to conflict, many shields with their blazon clear,<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a goodly helmet whose covering the dust should be.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_44">[Pg 44]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the meadow with flowers was sprinkled, and green turf ye there might see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there fell on it many a hero, who of honour had won such meed—<br></span>
<span class="i0">More modest were my desiring! 'Twould content me to sit my steed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the king of Zassamank rode forth a space from the knightly fray<span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where a rested steed did wait him, and the diamond he loosed alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With no thought of pride in the doing, but the breezes blew fresh and cool,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the squires unbound his vizor, and his lips shone so red and full.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have named unto ye a lady—Her chaplain did hither ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with him three noble pages, and strong squires were there beside;<span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And pack-horses twain they led there, and the will of their queen they'ld do,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She was Lady of France, Anflisé—Her chaplain was wise and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway he knew the hero, and in French should his greeting be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Soit le bien venu, mon beau sire' to my lady as e'en to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As queen of France she reigneth whom the lance of thy love doth smite,<span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gave to his hand a letter, and therein read the gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">A greeting fair, and a token it held of a finger-ring—<br></span>
<span class="i0">As pledge of the truth of his mission the chaplain the same must bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">His lady of old received it from the hand of the Angevin—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bowed as he saw the letter. Would ye hear what was writ therein?<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Here biddeth thee love and greeting a heart that hath ne'er been free<br></span>
<span class="i0">From grief since it knew thy service—Thy love is both lock and key<br></span>
<span class="i0">To my heart, and my heart's rejoicing! For thy love am I like to die,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy love afar abideth, then all love from my heart shall fly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Come thou, and take from my true hand crown, sceptre, and kingdom fair,<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">It falleth to me as heirdom, and thy love well may claim a share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As payment for this thy service rich presents I send to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Four pack-horses' chests well laden—I would thou my knight shouldst be<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this the land of the Waleis, 'fore the city of Kanvoleis.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I care not if the queen shall see it, small harm may therefrom arise,<span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For fairer am I, and richer, and I think me shall better know<br></span>
<span class="i0">To take the love that is proffered, and love in return bestow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wilt thou live in true love as shall 'seem thee? Then here do I bid thee take<br></span>
<span class="i0">My crown as thy love's rewarding—This I pray for my true love's sake.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no more did he find in the letter—Then his squires once more they drew<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_45">[Pg 45]</a></span>
<span class="i0">O'er his head the under-helmet; from Gamuret sorrow flew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bound on the helm of diamond, 'twas harder than blade might pierce,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he thought again to prove him, and ride forth to conflict fierce.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the messengers did he bid them to lead to the tent for rest:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he cleared a space around him wherever the conflict pressed.   <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This was vanquished, and that one victor—Did a knight o'er-long delay<br></span>
<span class="i0">To win to him fame in battle, his chance might he find to-day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here twain would joust together; in troops would these others ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the customs of friendly combat for a space did they lay aside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sworn brotherhood nothing counted 'fore the strength of fierce anger's might,<span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the crooked was seldom straightened; nor spake they of knightly right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What they captured they kept, uncaring if another's hate they won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from many lands had they ridden who with brave hands brave deeds had done,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And their hurts but little grieved them. Here Gamuret heard her prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as Anflisé bade him, as her knight to the field would fare;<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a letter had brought the tidings—Ah! he giveth his courage rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is it love or the lust of battle that driveth him on amain?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great love and strong faith they quicken his strength into life anew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now see where his shield he beareth, King Lot, that hero true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His foemen to flight had forced him save for Gamuret's strong right hand,<span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His charger in gallant onslaught brake its way thro' the threatening band,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Arragon's king was smitten from his horse with a spear of reed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Schaffilor was his name, and the spear-point which thrust him from off his steed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare never a waving pennon, from paynim lands 'twas brought,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight made the king his captive, tho' his folk they had bravely fought.<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the inner force drave the outer far back on the grassy plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a good vesper-play, yea, a Tourney; many spears did they smite in twain—<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Lähelein 'gain wax wrathful, 'Shall our honour be reft away?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis the fault of him of the Anchor! Now one of us twain to-day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall lay in short space the other on a couch that he liketh ill,  <span class="linenum">335</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_46">[Pg 46]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For here are they well-nigh victors!' Then they cleared them a space at will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no child's play it was that combat—In such wise with their hands they wrought<br></span>
<span class="i0">That a woodland was well-nigh wasted; and alike from their squires they sought<br></span>
<span class="i0">'New spears! New spears! Bring them hither!' Yet Lähelein he must know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sorrow and shame, for his foeman thrust him down from his horse alow,<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he smote him the length of the spear-iron in a shaft of reed made fast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And one read of itself his surety, for the knight to the earth was cast.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Yet better I like to read them, sweet pears on the ground that lie<br></span>
<span class="i0">As thick as the knights lay round him! for his was the victory!)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the cry arose from many who had fallen in joust before,        <span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Fly! Fly! For the Anchor cometh!' Then a knight towards him bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(A prince of the Angevin country) and grief was his comrade true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he bare a shield inverted, and sorrow it taught anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the King, for the badge he knew it—Ah! why did he turn aside?<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ye will, I the truth will tell ye, 'twas given in royal pride   <span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By Galoes the son of Gandein, Gamuret's brother true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere Love this guerdon gave him that the hero in joust she slew.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he loosed from his head the helmet: nor thro' grass, nor thro' dust and sand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did he make him a way to the conflict, but he yielded to grief's command;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his thoughts within him battled, that he sought not ere this to hear<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From Kailet, his friend and kinsman, how it fared with his brother dear<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he came not here to the Tourney—Alas! tho' he knew it not,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He had fallen before Monthorie—Sore sorrow was there his lot,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For to anguish did love constrain him, the love of a noble queen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his loss had she grieved so sorely that death had her portion been.<span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And tho' sorely Gamuret sorrowed, yet had he in half a day<br></span>
<span class="i0">So many spear-shafts broken, were it Tourney indeed this fray<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then had he a woodland wasted. Did I think me to count each spear<br></span>
<span class="i0">One hundred in fight had he shattered, each blazoned with colours clear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the heralds, they won his pennons, in sooth were they theirs of right—<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then toward the fair pavilion he turned him, the gallant knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Waleis squire rode after; and his was the coat so fair,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_47">[Pg 47]</a></span>
<span class="i0">All pierced and hewn with sword-thrust, which he did to his lady bear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet with gold was it precious, and it shone with a fiery glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And right well might ye see its richness. Then joy did the queen's heart know,<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, 'A fair woman sent thee, with this knight, to this distant land!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, courteous, I must bethink me lest these heroes ashamed shall stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who have risked their fate in this venture—goodwill unto all I bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For all do I count my kinsmen, since Adam's flesh we share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet Gamuret's hand, I think me, the highest prize hath won.'       <span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But by wrath constrained they battled till the shadows of night drew on,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the inner host the outer by force to their tents had brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save for Askalon's king and Morhold thro' the camp they their way had fought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some were winners, and some were losers, and many sore shame had earned,<br></span>
<span class="i0">While others won praise and honour. Then the foe from each other turned,<span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Here no man might see—He who holdeth the stakes, if no light he show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who would cast the dice in the darkness? To such sport were the weary slow!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Men well might forget the darkness where Gamuret did abide,<br></span>
