<span class="i0">'Twas as day—That in sooth it was not, but light shone on every side<br></span>
<span class="i0">From many small tapers clustered. There, laid on the olive wood,   <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was many a costly cushion, and by each couch a carpet good.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen, she rode to the doorway with many a maid of rank,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would they see, those ladies, the brave king of Zassamank.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Many wearied knights thronged after—The cloth had they borne away<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere she came to the fair pavilion; then the host he uprose straightway,<span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the monarchs four his captives (and many a prince was there),<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she welcomed him with due honour, and she saw him, and deemed him fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then glad spake the queen of the Waleis, 'Thou art host where we twain do stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, even so I think me, am hostess o'er all this land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou deem it well I should kiss thee, such kiss seemeth good to me!'<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_48">[Pg 48]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Thy kiss shall be mine if these heroes, e'en as I, shall be kissed by thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if princes and kings must forego it, 'twere unfit I such boon should crave!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, e'en as thou wilt, so be it, tho' ne'er saw I these heroes brave!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she kissed, e'en as Gamuret prayed her, these princes of noble line,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he prayed her to sit, and beside her sat the King Brandelidelein!<span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then lightly they strewed, o'er the carpet, green rushes yet wet with dew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sat him down upon them whose presence brought joy anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the gracious queen of the Waleis; and love did her soul constrain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as Gamuret sat before her his hand did she clasp again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she drew him once more towards her, and she set him her seat beside.<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No wife was she, but a maiden, from whose hand did such grace betide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would ye know the name they called her? Herzeleide the queen was she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And her cousin was hight Rischoydè, King Kailet should her husband be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And <i>he</i> was Gamuret's cousin), and so radiant the queen, and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That e'en though they quenched the tapers, in her presence 'twould still be light!<span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Were it not that a mighty sorrow his joy which aloft would fly<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had beaten to earth, I think me he had wooed her right readily.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And courteous they spake to each other: then cup-bearers drew anigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from Assagog the vessels, and their cost might no man deny;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And noble pages bare them, many costly bowls and fair,             <span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of precious jewels wroughten, and wide, none too small, they were,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And none of them all were golden—'twas the tribute of that fair land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which Eisenhart oft had proffered, when love's need nerved his knightly hand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the drink unto each they proffered in many a coloured stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of emerald some, and of sardius, and of ruby some wrought alone.<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then there drew near to his pavilion two knights who their word must swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(To the outer host were they captive and from thence to the town would fare.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And one of them was King Kailet; and he looked upon Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw him sit heavy-hearted, and he spake, 'Dost thou sorrow yet<br></span>
<span class="i0">For all men they own thy valour; Herzeleide and kingdoms twain     <span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hast thou won, and all tongues have said it, to thy praises all men are fain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_49">[Pg 49]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Be they Britons or men of Ireland—Who speaketh with foreign tongue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If France be their land, or Brabant, with one voice they thy praise have sung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That none here both skill and wisdom in strife like to thine have shown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">True letter it is I read thee! No slumber thy strength hath known, <span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When these knights thou hast put in peril who surety ne'er sware of old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brandelidelein the monarch, and Lähelein, hero bold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Hardeiss and King Schaffilor; yea, and Rassalig the Moor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom thine hand before Patelamunt o'erthrew and he surety swore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such lesson thou there didst teach him—Yea, this doth thy fame desire<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That with every coming conflict it broader shall wax and higher.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'The queen sure will deem thou ravest, if in this wise thou praisest me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I think not that thou shalt sell me, since the buyer the flaw shall see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy mouth is o'er-full of praises! Say, how hast thou come again?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'The worthy folk of Punturtois, this knight from fair Champagne    <span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And myself have loosed, and Morhold who this nephew hath stolen of mine<br></span>
<span class="i0">Will set him free, if on thy part thou wilt free Brandelidelein;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Otherwise are we captive to them, both I and my sister's son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But such grace thou wilt surely show us—Here such vesper-play was run<br></span>
<span class="i0">That it cometh not to a Tourney this while before Kanvoleis,       <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth do I know how it standeth! Here sit they before mine eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The strength of the outer army—now speak, tell me when and how<br></span>
<span class="i0">They could hold the field against us? Much fame hast thou won, I trow!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the queen she spake to the hero from a true heart full tenderly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Whate'er be my claim upon thee, I pray thee to let it be.         <span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I were fain of thy service worthy—If here I my right shall claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thine honour thereby be tarnished, I will leave thee nor mar thy fame!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he sprang to his feet, the chaplain of Anflisé the wise and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Nay, my queen doth claim him, at her will to this land I fare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his love hath she sent me hither, for his love she afar doth pine,<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her love layeth claim upon him and <i>hers</i> shall he be, not <i>thine</i>.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er all women I ween doth she love him: here as messengers hath she sent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three princes, lads free from falsehood; and the one is hight Lazident<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of noble birth from Greenland, and in Kärlingen doth he dwell,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_50">[Pg 50]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And his own hath he made the language; and the second his name I'll tell,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Liodarz he, a count his father, and Schyolarz was he hight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And who was the third? Will ye hearken, his kinship I'll tell aright:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Belleflur she hath been his mother, Pansamur was his father's name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Liahturteltart they called him, of the race of the fays he came.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they ran all three before him, and they spake, 'Wouldst thy fortune prove?<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(The queen of France doth proffer the chance of a worthy love.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt play the game, and never a pledge shall be asked from thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor thy joy be to sorrow forfeit, as it waxeth still fair and free!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then e'en while they spake their errand Kailet he had ta'en his seat<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Neath a fold of the royal mantle, and she spake to him low and sweet,<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now say, hath worse harm befallen? Methinks I the wounds have seen?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">In that same hour his wounds and bruises she sought out, the gracious queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With her white hands so small and shapely, which their wisdom from God must win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore was he cut and wounded on nose and on cheek and chin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He had won for his wife the cousin of the queen who such honour fair<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Would show him, herself would she tend him, and her hands for his hurts should care.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then e'en as courtesy bade her she spake unto Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'The fair queen of France, it seemeth, her heart upon thee hath set;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now honour in me all women, and give what I here may claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Go not till men judge betwixt us, else thou leavest me here to shame.'<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This he sware unto her, the hero, and leave she from him would crave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she passed thence, and then King Kailet, that monarch so true and brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He lifted her to her saddle; and he turned him about once more<br></span>
<span class="i0">And came into the pavilion, where his kinsman and friends he saw.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then spake he unto King Hardeiss, 'Aleiss thy sister fair          <span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She proffered her love, I took it—Now wedded is she elsewhere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a better than I is her husband! No longer thus wrathful frown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Prince Lambekein, he hath won her—tho' in sooth she shall wear no crown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet honour enough is her portion—Brabant and Hennegau<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_51">[Pg 51]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Do her service, and many a brave knight doth unto her bidding bow. <span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy mind it shall turn to greet me let thy favour be mine once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And take thou again my service of a true heart as aye of yore.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the king of Gascony answered as befitted a hero brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, soft is thy speech, yet if greeting I give thee as thou dost crave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who hath offered to me such insult, men will deem <i>fear</i> such grace hath won,<span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For captive am I to thy cousin!' 'Yet ill shall he deal with none,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gamuret, he shall grant thy freedom, that boon my first prayer shall be:<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man shall thereto constrain thee, yet my service the day shall see<br></span>
<span class="i0">When thou as thy friend shalt claim me. For the shame, 'tis enow I wot,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For whate'er <i>thou</i> mayst do against me, thy sister, she slayeth me not!'<span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then all at his words laughed loudly. But their mirth it was soon o'erpast<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his true heart the host constrainèd, and desire held him once more fast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a sharp goad I ween is sorrow—Then the heroes they saw right well<br></span>
<span class="i0">How he wrestled anew with sorrow and his joy in the conflict fell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his cousin he waxed right wrathful, and he spake, 'Now thou doest ill.'<span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, nay, for I needs must sorrow, and naught may my yearning still<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the queen I have left behind me, afar on a heathen shore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pure wife and true is that lady, and my heart she hath wounded sore.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And her purity doth constrain me to mourn for her love so sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Vassals and lands she gave me; yet joy for a true knight meet      <span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Belakané of that hath robbed me! yet shame for a wavering mind<br></span>
<span class="i0">I think me is right and manly—With such fetters her love did bind<br></span>
<span class="i0">That she held me afar from Tourney, nor in search of strife I went;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I thought me that deeds of knighthood should free me from ill-content,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here have I somewhat striven—Now many a fool would say        <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That I, for her colour, fled her, to my eyes was she light as day!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her womanhood true I sorrow; o'er all others her worth stood high<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the boss from the shield outstandeth. And another grief have I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here make I my moan unto ye, my brother's arms I saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the shield on which they were blazoned, with point up-turned they bore.'<span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Ah! woe for the words that are spoken, and the tidings of grief they bring!)<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_52">[Pg 52]</a></span>
<span class="i0">His eyes they o'erflowed with water, that gallant Spanish king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! O queen for thy madness, thro' thy love is Galoes slain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom every faithful woman from her heart shall mourn amain<br></span>
<span class="i0">If she would that her dealing win her true honour in true man's thought.<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! queen of Auvergne I think me, tho' small grief it to thee hath brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet thro' thee have I lost my kinsman, tho' his ending was fit and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a knightly joust hath slain him who thy token in strife would bear!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And these princes here, his comrades, their heartfelt grief they show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As in funeral train their shield's-breadth do they turn to the earth below,<span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thus hath great sorrow taught them—In this guise do they knightly deeds,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Heavy-hearted that he, my cousin, serveth no more for true love's meed!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He hath won him another heart-grief as his brother's death is told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake aloud in his sorrow, 'Now mine anchor hath found its hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">And its haven in bitter rueing,' and the badge did he lay aside,   <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his grief taught him bitter anguish, and aloud the hero cried,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Galoes of Anjou! henceforward shall never a man deny<br></span>
<span class="i0">That on earth ne'er was born thine equal for manhood and courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fruit of a free hand knightly from thine heart did it bloom amain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! woe is me for thy goodness!' then to Kailet he spake again,    <span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'How goeth it with Schoettè, my mother, of joy bereft?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'So that God hath had pity on her! When Gandein this life had left,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dead was Galoes thy brother, and thou wert not by her side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she saw thee no more, then death brake her heart, and she too hath died!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the Gascon Hardeiss, 'Turn thy will to a manly mien,<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt mourn but in fitting measure if true manhood thine own hath been!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But too great was the load of his sorrow, and the tears as a flood must flow<br></span>
<span class="i0">From his eyes—Then all things he ordered that the knights a fair rest might know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he went where he saw his chamber, of samite the little tent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in grief and sore lamentation the hours of the night he spent. <span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When there dawned another morning the knights together came,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_53">[Pg 53]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The inner host and the outer, all who thought there to win them fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they young or old, were they cowardly or brave, they fought not that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the light grew to middle morning: yet so worn were they with the fray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the horses so spent with spurring, that the knights in battle tried <span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Were yet by weariness vanquished—Then the queen herself would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the valiant men from the open would she bring to the town again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the best of the knights within there she bade ride to the Leo-plain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway they did her bidding, and they rode in their knightly ranks,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they came ere the Mass was ended to the sad king of Zassamank. <span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the benediction spoken, Herzeleide the queen she came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as the folk upheld her, so she laid to the knight her claim:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'A wife have I Lady, and than life shall she be more dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, and e'en if I were without her thou another tale shouldst hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">That afar should drive me from thee, if men here shall list my right!' <span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But the queen she looked upon him, and she spake to the gallant knight:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thou shalt leave thy Moorish lady for my love; stronger far shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">The blessing that baptism giveth! From heathendom set thee free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wed me in Christian marriage, since my heart for thy love doth yearn.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or say shall the French queen's message to my shame and my sorrow turn? <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet words did they speak her people, and thou heardest them to the end!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, she is in truth my lady. When I back to Anjou must wend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then fair counsels and courteous customs with me from her land I brought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, even to-day doth she help me whom from childhood to man she taught.<br></span>
<span class="i0">She hath fled all that mars a woman—We were children then, she and I, <span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet gladly we saw each other in the days that are long gone by!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The noble queen Anflisé, in true womanhood hath she share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From her lands a goodly income she gave me, that lady fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(In those days was I still a poor man), yet I took it right willingly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a poor man thou still shalt count me, and Lady, shalt pity me, <span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He is dead, my gallant brother—Of thy courtesy press me not,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn thy love where thou findest gladness, for sorrow is aye my lot!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay, let me not longer sorrow; how wilt thou deny my claim?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thy question I'll gladly answer, here a <i>Tourney</i> thou didst proclaim,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_54">[Pg 54]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That Tourney hath not been holden, as many shall witness bear'     <span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'For the vesper-play hath marred it! The knights who had foughten there<br></span>
<span class="i0">So well have they tamed their ardour that the Tourney hath come to naught,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I did but defend thy city with others that bravely fought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shouldst force me not to withstand thee, here have others done more than I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mine the greeting that <i>all</i> may claim here, other right would I still deny!'<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then, so hath the venture told me, they chose them, both man and maid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A judge o'er the claim of the lady, and their cause they before him laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it drew near to middle morning, and thus did the verdict run,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'What knight hath bound on his helmet, and hath hither for conflict come,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hath fought, and the prize hath holden, then that knight he shall wed the queen.'<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And unto the judgment spoken the knights gave consent I ween.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the queen, 'Mine thou art, and I'll yield thee fair service thy love to gain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And will give thee of joy such portion that thy life shall be free of pain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And yet bare he grief and sorrow—Now the April sun was o'er,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And had left behind a token in the garment the meadow bore,        <span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With short green grass was it covered, so that coward hearts waxed bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And won afresh high courage; and the trees did their buds unfold<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the soft sweet air of the May-tide, and he came of the fairy race<br></span>
<span class="i0">That aye loveth, or sweet love seeketh, and his friend she would show him grace.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he looked on Queen Herzeleide, and he spake to her courteously,<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'If in joy we would live, O Lady, then my warder thou shalt not be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When loosed from the bonds of sorrow, for knighthood my heart is fain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou holdest me back from Tourney I may practise such wiles again<br></span>
<span class="i0">As of old when I fled from the lady whom I won with mine own right hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When from strife she would fain have kept me I fled from her folk and land!'<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she spake, 'Set what bonds thou willest, by thy word will I still abide.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Many spears would I break asunder, and each month would to Tourney ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt murmur not O Lady when such knightly joust I'ld run!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">This she sware, so the tale was told me, and the maid and her lands he won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The three pages of Queen Anflisé and her chaplain were nigh at hand,<span class="linenum">615</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_55">[Pg 55]</a></span>
<span class="i0">As the judgment was sealed and spoken they must hearken and understand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake to the knight in secret, 'To my lady this tale was told<br></span>
<span class="i0">How at Patelamunt thy valour did the guerdon of victory hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that there two kingdoms served thee—And she too hath lands I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she thinketh <i>herself</i> to give thee, and riches and gold enow!'<span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'As knighthood of old she taught me so must I hold fast alway<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the strength of the knightly order, and the rule of the shield obey.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' her my shield have I won me, else perchance I had worn it not,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here doth knightly verdict bind me, be sorrow or joy my lot.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Go ye homeward, and bear my service, her knight will I ever be,    <span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And for her is my deepest sorrow tho' all crowns were awaiting me!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he proffered to them of his riches, but his gifts did they cast aside.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet was she not shamed their lady, tho' homeward they needs must ride!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they craved not leave, but they rode thence, as in anger ye oft shall find,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the princes' sons, her pages, well-nigh did they weep them blind.<span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They who bare their shields inverted their friends spake to them this word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'The queen, fair Herzeleide, hath the Angevin for her lord.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Say, who from Anjou hath fought here? Our lord is, alas, elsewhere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He seeketh him fame 'gainst the heathen, and grief for his sake we bear!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'He who shall be here the victor, who hath smitten full many a knight,<span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He who smote and pierced so fiercely, he who bare on his helm of light<br></span>
<span class="i0">An anchor rare and costly, that knight is the knight we mean,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And King Kailet he spake his title, Gamuret Angevin—I ween<br></span>
<span class="i0">Good fortune doth here befall him!' Then swift to their steeds they sprung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their raiment was wet with the tear-drops that grief from their eye-lids wrung,<span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When they came where their lord was seated they gave him a welcome fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he in his turn would greet them, and sorrow and joy were there.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he kissed his knights so faithful, and spake, 'Ye no more shall make<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such measureless moan for my brother, his place I with ye will take.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn your shields again as befits them, and as men who would joyful fare;<span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My anchor hath struck its haven; my father's arms I'll bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the anchor it is a symbol that befitteth a wandering knight,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_56">[Pg 56]</a></span>
<span class="i0">He who willeth may take and wear it. I must rule my life aright<br></span>
<span class="i0">As now shall become my station: I am rich now, when shall I be<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lord of this folk? For my sorrow it worketh but ill to me.     <span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Queen Herzeleide, help me that thou and I may pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">The kings that are here and princes for my service awhile to stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till thou unto me hast yielded that which love from true love may crave!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus both of them made petition, and the heroes their promise gave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then each one went to his chamber, and the queen to her knight spake low,<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now yield thyself to my tending, and a hidden way I'll show!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his guests did they care as fitting tho' the host was no longer there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk they were all together, but the knight he alone must fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save for two of his pages only—Then the queen and her maidens bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">They led him where gladness waited, and his sorrow was put to flight,<span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And regret was o'erthrown and vanquished—And his heart it waxed high and brave<br></span>
<span class="i0">As is ever the lot of lovers! and her maidenhood she gave<br></span>
<span class="i0">The queen, fair Herzeleide: nor their lips did they think to spare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But close did they cling in kisses; grief was conquered by joy so fair!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then courteous deeds were begun there; for free were his captives set,<span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Kings Hardeiss and Kailet were made friends by Gamuret.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And such marriage feast was holden that he who had proudly thought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hereafter to hold such another much riches thereto had brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this did Gamuret purpose, his wealth he would little spare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Arabian gold did he scatter mid the poor knights; and jewels rare<span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Did he give to the kings and princes who were there with the host I ween;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And glad were the wandering players, for rich gifts had their portion been.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Let them ride whom he there had feasted, from the Angevin leave they prayed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the panther the badge of his father on his shield they in sable laid;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a small white silken garment, a shift that the queen did wear, <span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That had touched her naked body who now was his wife so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This should be his corslet's cover. And of foemen it saw eighteen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pierced thro' and hewn with sword-blade ere he parted from her his queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And aye as her love came homeward on her body that shift she drew:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_57">[Pg 57]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And many a shield had he shattered; and their love it waxed strong and true.<span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And honour enow was his portion ere his manly courage bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">The knight o'er the seas to conflict, for his journey I sorrow sore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there came unto him true tidings, how the Baruch, his lord of old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was beset by mighty foemen, by Babylon's princes bold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the one he was called Ipomidon, and Pompey his brother's name  <span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(For so hath the venture told me), a proud man of warlike fame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">('Twas not he whom Julius Cæsar had driven from Rome of yore).<br></span>
<span class="i0">His uncle was Nebuchadnezzar, who in books found the lying lore<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he himself should a god be, (o'er this would our folk make sport)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of noble race these brothers, nor of strength nor of gold spared aught.<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From Ninus they came who was ruler ere ever Bagdad might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nineveh did he found—Now an insult and a shame vexed them bitterly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Baruch as vassals claimed them—So the combat was won and lost,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bravely the heroes battled, and on each side they paid the cost.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus Gamuret sailed the water, and aid to the Baruch brought,      <span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly he bade him welcome; tho' I weep that that land he sought!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">How it chanced there, how went the conflict, gain or loss, how the thing might be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Naught of that knew Queen Herzeleide; and bright as the sun was she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her form it was fair to look on, and both riches had she and youth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And more than too much her gladness! I think me in very truth      <span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She had sped past the goal of all wishes—And on wisdom her heart was set,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she won from the whole world favour; her fair deeds with fair guerdon met,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all men praised Herzeleide, the queen, as both fair and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen of three kingdoms was she, of Waleis and fair Anjou,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of these twain was she aye the ruler; and beside them in far Norgals<span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Did she bear the crown and sceptre, in the city of Kingrivals.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so dear did she hold her husband, if never a maid might win<br></span>
<span class="i0">So gallant a man, what recked she? She counted it not for sin.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As for half a year he was absent she looked for his coming sure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For but in the thought of that meeting might the life of the queen endure.<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then brake the sword of her gladness thro' the midst of the hilt in twain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_58">[Pg 58]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Ah me! and alas! for her mourning, that goodness should bear such pain<br></span>
<span class="i0">And faith ever waken sorrow! Yea, so doth it run alway<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the life of men, and to-morrow must they mourn who rejoice to-day!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So it chanced that the queen one noontide in a restless slumber lay,<span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas as if with a start she wakened and by lightning was borne away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And towards the clouds it bare her, and they smote her with mighty force,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fiery bolts of Heaven, as they sped on their downward course,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sparks sprang from her floating tresses mid the fire of the circling spheres,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the thunder crashed loud around her, and the rain-drops were burning tears.<span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For a little space was she conscious, then a grip on her right hand fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, lo! it was changed, the vision, and wondrous things befell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For then did she nurse a dragon, that forth from her body sprung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And its dragon life to nourish awhile at her breast it hung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then it fled from her sight so swiftly she might look on it never more:<span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her heart it brake for the anguish, and the terror and grief she bore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And never methinks a woman in slumber such woe hath seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now had she been so joyful, alas! all was changed I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow should be her portion, and her ill it waxed long and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shadow of coming sorrow did still on her heart abide.      <span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she did what afore she could not, for the terror that on her lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She stretched her limbs in her slumber, and moaned in her grief alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she cried aloud on her people; and many a maid sat by<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they sprang to her side at her summons, and wakened her speedily.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Tampaneis he came riding, of her husband's squires the chief, <span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a page was with him, and joy's goal was o'erpassed in grief,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they cried, 'He was dead, their master!' And her senses forsook the queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she fell aback in her anguish—And the knights spake, 'How hath this been?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath our lord been slain in his harness, who ever was armed so well?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' sorely the squire must sorrow, to the heroes the tale he'ld tell:<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'No long life should he have, my master! His helm he put off awhile,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_59">[Pg 59]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The heat thereto constrained him—'twas accursed heathen guile<br></span>
<span class="i0">That stole him from us, our hero—A knight took a he-goats blood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from a long glass he poured it on the helmet of diamond good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And softer than sponge grew the diamond. May He Whom as Lamb they show<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the Cross in His hold, have mercy on the deeds that are wrought below!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Then when one host met the other: Ah! that was indeed a fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knights who were with the Baruch they fought all as men of might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there in the field by Bagdad full many a shield was pierced,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As they flew each one on the other, and they mingled in charges fierce,<span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And banner was mixed with banner, many fell who had bravely fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my lord's hand it did such wonders that his foemen became as nought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Ipomidon he came riding, and with death would reward the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he smote him down, and I think me many thousands they saw that sight.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'For my master, free from falsehood, rode against Alexandria's king,<span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But, alas! for the guile of the heathen, this joust but his death should bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the spear cut sheer thro' the helmet, and it pierced thro' my master's brain<br></span>
<span class="i0">(In his head did they find the splinters), yet the hero still held the rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dying he rode from the combat, o'er a wide plain his way he'ld take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his chaplain he knelt above him, and in few words his shrift he spake.<span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sent here the shift and the spear-blade that hath robbed us of our friend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He died free from sin—us his servants he did to the queen commend!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'At Bagdad was the hero buried, and the Baruch the cost would pay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With gold is it fair to look on, and rich is the tomb alway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a costly jewel doth gleam where he lies at rest,          <span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And embalmed was the fair young body (sad was many a faithful breast);<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the grave-stone it is a ruby, and thro' it he shineth clear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they granted us as with martyrs, the cross o'er his tomb to rear,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as Christ by His death hath freed us, and to comfort that soul so brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for shelter we raised the symbol—And the Baruch the cost he gave.<span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the cross was of emerald wroughten: heathen counsel we asked it not,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_60">[Pg 60]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For they know not the Cross, nor the blessing that Christ's death won for us I wot!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heathen they pray unto him as if he were a god in truth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor they do it the Cross to honour, nor hath Baptism taught them ruth<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Tho' it looseneth <i>us</i> from Hell's fetters when the uttermost day shall dawn),<span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But his knightly faith and honour, who leaveth us here forlorn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have wrought him a place in Heaven where he shineth with Heaven's light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And true penitence and confession—for falsehood e'er fled that knight.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And there in his diamond helmet an epitaph did they grave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fast to the cross they fixed it o'er the tomb of that hero brave,<span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus do they run the letters: '(<i>Through this helmet a joust hath slain)</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>This hero who bare all manhood, and</i> Gamuret <i>was his name,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>As king did he rule o'er three kingdoms, in each land the Crown he wore</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Whom mighty princes followed—Anjou's land this hero bore,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And he lost his life for the Baruch at the city of Bagdad fair.</i><span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And so high did it soar, his honour, that no knight may with him compare,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Howe'er ye may test their dealings. Nor is he of woman born,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>(I mean of the knightly order) to whose hand he his strength had sworn.</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>But help and true manly counsel to his friends did he steadfast give;</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And thro' women much grief he suffered, for he would in their favour live.</i> <span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Baptized was he as a Christian tho' Saracens mourn him yet,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>(This is truth and no lie)—All his lifetime since his years were on wisdom set</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>His strength strove for fame and honour, till he fell in his knightly pride,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Wish him bliss who here lieth buried! 'Twas by treason's hand he died!</i>'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So spake the squire, and the Waleis who heard it must weep full sore,<span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Cause hast they enow for sorrow! A living child she bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who of men was left unaided, Herzeleide the gracious queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With death the mother battled: her maidens were crazed I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since they thought not to help their lady, for within her womb she bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Him who should be flower of all knighthood, if death did not claim him there.<span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then there came a wise man ancient to weep with his lady's grief,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw how with death she struggled, and he brought to her swift relief;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he forced her teeth asunder, and betwixt her lips they pour<br></span>
<span class="i0">Water, and at their tending her senses they came once more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she spake, and aloud she mourned him, 'My heart's dearest, Ah! where is he?<span class="linenum">805</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_61">[Pg 61]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth my heart's deepest gladness was in Gamuret's chivalry,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet his valour of this hath robbed me—Now his <i>mother</i> am I and <i>wife</i>,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' far younger was I, for within me do I carry his flesh and life;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The love that we bore to each other hath been of such flower the root,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if God shall in truth be faithful, He withholdeth not here the fruit.<span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Already too sore my sorrow for my husband so proud and brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What ill death hath wrought upon me! Her love never woman gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his heart it rejoiced in her gladness, and sad for her grief was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus his true heart it gave him counsel who was aye from all falsehood free.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hearken yet more the story how the noble queen must mourn,     <span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Within her arms would she hold him, her child who was yet unborn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, 'Now God send me safely the child of my hero fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this is my heart's petition; God keep me from dark despair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twere Gamuret's second slaying if I thought myself to slay<br></span>
<span class="i0">While I bear of his love the token who was faithful to me alway!'  <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then careless of who might see her, the robe from her neck she tore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her fair white breasts she tended with the wisdom of mother-lore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her rosy lips she pressed them, 'Ah, thou food that shall feed my son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hath sent thee before his coming who life from my life hath won!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the queen it nothing vexed her that above her heart it lay     <span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The milk that her child should nourish, and softly she spake alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas true love that brought thee hither, if I yet unbaptized should be<br></span>
<span class="i0">From thee had I won my baptism, and the tears which shall flow so free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And openly and in secret will I mourn for my husband dear!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the shift with his life-blood crimsoned she bade them to bring anear,<span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Thus clad in the Baruch's army had Gamuret lost his life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he chose him a gallant ending in the turmoil and stress of strife),<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then for the spear she prayed them wherewith was her husband slain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Nineveh's Prince Ipomidon such guerdon he needs must gain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' tattered and hewn to pieces yet the queen fain the shift would wear,<span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As aforetime had been her custom when her lord did from Tourney fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But her maidens who stood around her they took it from out her hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they carried them to the Minster, the highest from out her land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the spear and the blood they buried as men bury a hero dead,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_62">[Pg 62]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow and bitter mourning thro' Gamuret's kingdom spread.     <span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when fourteen days were ended a babe lay the queen beside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a son, and so great and goodly that the mother had well-nigh died.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now 'tis cast the die of the venture, and here doth my tale begin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For now is he born who henceforward this song for his own shall win.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now have ye heard the story of his father, his love and grief, <span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of his gallant life, and the treason that ended its span so brief;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ye know whence he came, the hero of this tale, and how for long<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was hidden from deeds of knighthood, till his youth it waxed bold and strong.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the queen found sight and hearing she was fain on her child to look,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her maidens they bare him to her and the babe in her arms she took;<span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she saw his limbs soft rounded, and she knew she had born a son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her maidens with her were joyful that the earth had a man-child won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(As he bare of a man the body, so manly was he of heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a smith did he wield the sword-blade till fire from the helm would start)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no joy did she know, the mother, save ever her babe to kiss,   <span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with soft words she spake to him ever, '<i>Bon fils, Cher fils, Beau fils.</i>'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And e'en as herself she bare him, so herself she his nurse would be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At his mother's breast was he nourished who was ever from falsehood free.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she thought she had won her husband by her prayers to her arms again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She all folly forsook, and meekness and truth in her heart did reign.<span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And musing spake Herzeleide, 'The queen of Heaven high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gave her breast to the dear Lord Jesu Who a bitter death would die<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Man on the cross for man's sake, for thus did His love begin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who thinketh light of His anger his soul's peace shall hardly win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' he else were brave man and worthy—and this tale do I know for true!'<span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen of the land she bathed her in heart sorrow's bitter dew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her eyes on the babe rained tear-drops as soft in her arms it lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For hers was the way of women, where a true heart holdeth sway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She could laugh and weep together, her heart joyed for her baby's birth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the ford of her bitter sorrow had drowned in short space her mirth.<span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_63">[Pg 63]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK III<br>

GURNEMANZ</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_64">[Pg 64]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>In the Introduction the poet speaks of the honour in which he holds all
true women, though he be wroth with one who has wronged him. Yet,
though women shall count him their friend, he would fain that they should
honour him for his knightly deeds, rather than for this his song.</p>
<p>In Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> he tells of the sorrow and the faith of Queen Herzeleide; of
Parzival's childhood; of his meeting with the knights; of his faring forth
to seek knighthood from King Arthur; and of the death of Herzeleide.
How Parzival met with Jeschuté, and robbed her of her token, and of the
wrath of her husband Orilus. Of the sorrow of Siguné, and how Parzival
learnt his name and his lineage. How Parzival met with the Red Knight
and bare his challenge to the court of King Arthur, and how he craved a
boon of the king. Of the shaming of Kunnewaaré; and of the death
of the Red Knight. How Parzival came to Gurnemanz of Graharz and
was cured by him of his folly and taught all knightly wisdom, and how he
rode forth from the land of Graharz.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_65">[Pg 65]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK III</p>
<p class="ph2">GURNEMANZ
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_i.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_i.png_2">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is there ever a singer among you, who singeth a sweeter song<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the favour and love of women, I hold not he does me wrong!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full fain am I still to hearken to aught that may give them joy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But to one alone among women my homage I still deny.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, ever the fire of my anger doth kindle and flame anew,           <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sorrow her treason wrought me, it grieveth me still I trow!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I, whom men have named the singer, I, Wolfram of Eschenbach,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The words that against a woman I spake, I may ne'er take back.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, I hold fast my wrath for ever, and clasp it closer still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As I think how in soul and body alike hath she wrought me ill!      <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How can I do aught but hate her, till death setteth seal on life?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet it grieveth me sore that others should mingle in this our strife;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It grieveth me sore that maidens should say, as they name my name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Forsooth he hath shamed all women, let it be unto him for shame!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, then, an they reckon for evil the words that in grief I spake, <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I will speak them no more for ever, though my heart should in silence break!<br></span>
<span class="i0">But let them beware in their anger, these warlike maidens fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How they stir from his eyrie the eagle, rouse the lion from his lair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full well I know how to defend me, full well know I what beseems<br></span>
<span class="i0">The maid of a knight's devotion, the maid of the poet's dreams!     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Let a maiden be steadfast-hearted, pure and true in word and deed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her champion true she'll find me, comes there ever an hour of need.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I hold his renown waxeth slowly, and halteth upon the road,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who, for wrong at the hand of one woman, shall slander all womanhood:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if any will look upon me, and hearken to what I sing,           <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_66">[Pg 66]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Of a sooth I will not deceive them, though my tale over-strange may ring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Born was I unto the bearing of knightly shield and spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And though sweet be the song of the singer, I hold it not all too dear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I had rather my love should love me for my deeds of high renown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than because in the hall of the Wartburg they should crown me with music's crown!<span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the shield and the spear of knighthood will I seek for a knight's reward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor charm, with the harp of the singer, what I failèd to win with the sword!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor in praise of fair women only runs this tale that I have to tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many strange deeds it holdeth, and marvels that once befell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere the course of this wondrous venture be tracèd unto its end;     <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he who heareth shall reckon, if he fain would account me friend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That this is no book he readeth, for no maker of books am I!<br></span>
<span class="i0">But a singer of strange adventures, and of knightly prowess high:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stripped bare will I be of all honour, naked and reft of fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere I trust my renown unto letters, and give to a book my name!     <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It vexes me, soul and body, that so many should bear the name<br></span>
<span class="i0">And speak with the tongue of women, who reck not of woman's fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That those who have known no falsehood, and those who are swift to fall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Should carry one name in common, be counted as sisters all!<br></span>
<span class="i0">A truth that has faltered never, a faith that has aye withstood,    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Is the only glory of woman, the crown of her womanhood!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Many will say, 'What good thing can come out of poverty?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">She who for love endures it, she 'scapeth Hell thereby,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, in the kingdom of Heaven, receiveth a hundredfold<br></span>
<span class="i0">For all she has borne for love's sake, new joys for her sorrows old!<span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Not one have I known in my lifetime, I count it a bitter truth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Neither a man nor a maiden, who the joy and the pride of youth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all earth's riches and honour, will leave as a worthless thing<br></span>
<span class="i0">If weighed with the glory of Heaven, and the service of Heaven's King!<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Queen Herzeleide only, she left her fair estate,                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In her youth of all joy bereavèd, with sorrow afar to mate.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So holy was she and gentle, so faithful and pure of mind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That no tongue spake a word against her, and no eye a fault could find.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sunlight or shadow, what recked she? the day was to her as night,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_67">[Pg 67]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For her heart was the home of sorrow, and dead was the world's delight.<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sorrow and grief she wandered, till she came to Soltanè's strand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A woodland wild and lonely afar from her native land:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair flowers might bloom and blossom without, on the sunlit plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And be woven in rosy chaplets, but for her they would bloom in vain!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, mid the woodland shadows, she hid with Gamuret's son,    <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For she willed that her life's last treasure be revealed unto none:<br></span>
<span class="i0">So she called her folk around her, (who toiled in the upland field<br></span>
<span class="i0">With oxen and plough, that the furrows their daily bread might yield,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she charged them all, by the service which she as their queen might claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That they hide from the boy his birthright and the fame of his father's name.<span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'For the knightly deeds ye vaunt of, and the glory and pride of war,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have wrought me but heart's affliction, and trouble and anguish sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So, lest I yet more should suffer, I pray you, my servants dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That ye speak no word of knighthood, lest my son perchance should hear!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then full sore were her people grievèd, for they held it an evil thing,<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a training that ill beseemèd the son of a mighty king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his mother kept him hidden in the woodland valleys wild,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor thought in her love and sorrow how she wronged the kingly child:<br></span>
<span class="i0">No knightly weapon she gave him, save such as in childish play<br></span>
<span class="i0">He wrought himself from the bushes that grew on his lonely way,     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A bow and arrows he made him, and with these, in thoughtless glee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He shot at the birds as they carolled o'erhead in the leafy tree.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when the feathered songster of the woods at his feet lay dead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In wonder and dumb amazement he bowed down his golden head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in childish wrath and sorrow tore the locks of his sunny hair;  <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(For I wot well of all earth's children was never a child so fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">As this boy, who afar in the desert from the haunts of mankind did dwell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who bathed in the mountain streamlet, and roamed o'er the rock-strewn fell!)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought him well how the music, which his hand had for ever stilled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had thrilled his soul with its sweetness, and his heart was with sorrow filled,<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the ready tears of childhood flowed forth from their fountains free<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he ran to his mother weeping, and bowed him beside her knee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'What aileth thee child?' quoth the mother, 'but now wast thou gay and glad'—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_68">[Pg 68]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But, childlike, he gave no answer, scarce wist he what made him sad!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Queen Herzeleide watched him through the sunny summer days,     <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till beneath a tree she saw him stand silent, with upturned gaze,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a look of joyful rapture in the radiant childish eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he listed the bird, that, soaring, sang clear thro' the cloudless skies;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the mother's heart was troubled, and her wrath waxed to fever heat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She would brook in his love no rival—not even God's singers sweet!<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So she sent forth in haste her servants, with many a cunning snare<br></span>
<span class="i0">To capture the singers whose music made joyful the woodlands fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then, alas! for the birds, who struggled in the cruel snare in vain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet some few burst their bonds, and joyful, brake forth into song again!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the boy spake,'Now sweet my mother, why trouble the birds so sore?<span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Forsooth they can ne'er have harmed thee, ah, leave them in peace once more!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his mother kissed him gently, 'Perchance I have wrought a wrong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a truth, the dear God who made them, He gave unto them their song,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I would not that one of his creatures should sorrow because of me.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the boy looked up in wonder, 'God, Mother? Who may God be?'    <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'My son, He is light beyond all light, brighter than summer's day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And He bare a Man's Face, that we men might look on His Face alway!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou ever in need of succour? call on Him in thine hour of ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And be sure He will fail thee never, but will hear thee, and help thee still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet one there is dwelleth in darkness, and I wot men may fear him well,<span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For his home is the house of falsehood, and his kingdom the realm of Hell!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn thy mind away from him ever, nor waver betwixt the twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he who doubteth, his labour shall ever be wrought in vain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus his mother read him the riddle, the myst'ry of day and night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dread and the doom of darkness, and the glory and grace of light!<span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then javelin in hand he hastened thro' the forest pathways wild,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the deer sprang up from their thickets, and fled from the dauntless child;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But clear-eyed and eager-footed he hastened upon their track,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And full oft with a hornèd trophy, at even he hied him back.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Little cared he for rain or sunshine, summer's storm or winter's snow,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And daily in strength and beauty all men might behold him grow;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till at length no beast so mighty thro' the forest wild did roam,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_69">[Pg 69]</a></span>
<span class="i0">If it fell 'neath his shaft, unaided, on his shoulder he bore it home!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It chanced thro' a woodland thicket one morn as he took his way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And brake from o'erhanging bushes full many a leafy spray,         <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That a pathway steep and winding rose sharply his track anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the distant beat of horse-hoofs fell strange on his wondering ear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the boy grasped his javelin firmly and thought what the sound might be;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Perchance 'tis the devil cometh! Well, I care not if it be he!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks I can still withstand him, be he never so fierce and grim,<span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a truth my lady mother she is o'er-much afraid of <i>him</i>!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As he stood there for combat ready, behold, in the morning light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three knights rode into the clearing, in glittering armour bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From head to foot were they armèd, each one on his gallant steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad as he saw their glory thought each one a god indeed!   <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No longer he stood defiant, but knelt low upon his knee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And cried, 'God, Who helpest all men, I pray Thee have thought for me!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then wroth was the foremost rider as the lad barred his further way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake out, 'This stupid <i>Waleis</i> will hinder our work to-day!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Now here would I give to the Waleis the fame we Bavarians hold;   <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They are duller than e'en our people, yet manly in strife and bold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth were one born in both countries such marvel of strength and skill<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would he hide in himself that I think me their fame he might well fulfil!)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then there rode swift with hanging bridle, in costly harness dight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With plumed and jewelled helmet another gallant knight;            <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Swiftly he came as thirsting to challenge in mortal fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">The foe who sped far before him, who had done him a sore despite;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For two knights from out his kingdom a maiden had borne away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he held it a deed most shameful and one he must needs repay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the maiden's sorrow grieved him, and fain would he ease her pain:<span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(And the three knights who rode before him were part of his warlike train.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">He rode a Spanish war-horse, and his shield had fierce conflict seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Karnachkarnanz did they call him (he was Ulterleg's count I ween).<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he cried to his knights, 'Why loiter? who barreth our onward way?'<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_70">[Pg 70]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And straight on the lad did he ride there, who deemed him a god alway,<span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ne'er had he seen such glory; his harness shone fair with dew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on either foot the stirrups with golden bells rang true.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their length was e'en as fitting, and with bells did each strong arm ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he stirred himself, or his sword-blade in battle aloft would swing.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hero was swift in seeking the guerdon of knightly prize,   <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So he rode here, the prince, and had decked him in a fair and wondrous wise.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then spake this flower of all knighthood, 'Say, boy, did they pass thy way?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two knights who have shamed their knighthood, nay, <i>robbers</i> I ween are they,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they bear a maiden with them, and she rideth against her will!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the boy, tho' he spake with a man's tongue, as a god must account him still;<span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he thought how Queen Herzeleide had told him that God was Light<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dwelleth in Light for ever; and so to his dazzled sight<br></span>
<span class="i0">This knight, in his shining armour in the glow of the summer's day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was the God of his mother's lesson, and he knelt him again to pray.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But the prince he spake full gently, 'Fain am I to do God's will,  <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet for no God I hold me, but a sinful mortal still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, wert thou more clear of vision, thou wouldst see, an thou sawest aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No Lord of the host of Heaven, but only a humble knight!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Knight?' quoth the boy in answer, 'Nay! I wot not what that may be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is thy strength not of God, but of knighthood, then I would such were given to me!'<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Then wend thy way to King Arthur, an thou camest unto his court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A noble knight he would make thee, ashamed and afeared for naught,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For sure, now I look upon thee, thou com'st of a noble strain.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his knights they turned their bridles, and gazed at the boy again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full well might they look and wonder, at the work that God's Hand had wrought,<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For they say, who tell this story, that never could human thought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have dreamed of aught so goodly, since ever the world began,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For of all men beloved by women, was there never so fair a man!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Loud they laughed as the boy spake further, 'Good knight, what may these be?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_71">[Pg 71]</a></span>
<span class="i0">These rings that so close around thee, above and below I see.'     <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he handled, with curious finger, the armour the knight did bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His coat of mail close-linkèd as behovèd a knight to wear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake as he looked on the harness, 'My mother's maidens string<br></span>
<span class="i0">On their chains, and around their fingers, full many a shining ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But they cling not so close to each other as these rings that here I see,<span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I cannot force them asunder, what good are they then to thee?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince drew forth from its scabbard his shining blade so keen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now see, he who fights against me, must withstand my sword I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And lest he, on his part, should slay me, it is fit that with mail and shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I ward me against his spear-thrusts, and the blows that his arm may wield.'<span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Swiftly the lad made answer, 'Little good would it do the deer<br></span>
<span class="i0">An their coats were e'en such as thine is, they would fall still beneath my spear.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Full wroth were the knights and scornful that their lord thus long had talked<br></span>
<span class="i0">With this lad with the face of an angel, and the speech as of one distraught;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the prince he spake full gently, 'God keep thee in His good grace,<span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I would that my shield's bright mirror might show me as fair a face!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, an the Giver of all gifts but gave thee wit enow<br></span>
<span class="i0">To match with a mien so goodly, full rich wert thou then I trow!<br></span>
<span class="i0">May He keep all sorrow from thee, and thy life be a summer's day—'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with that he turned his bridle, and wended once more his way.  <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then adown the woodland pathway they rode, till they came full soon<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the carles of Queen Herzeleide toiled hard thro' the sultry noon:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fields must they plough and harrow, if a harvest they hoped to reap,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So they goaded the patient oxen to their toil on the hillside steep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince he gave them 'Good-morrow,' and asked if there passed that way<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden in need and sorrow? and they dared not to say him nay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But they answered him e'en as he prayed them, and they spake 'Yea, at early morn<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two knights and a maiden passed here, and the maiden, she wept forlorn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knights as they rode beside her, spurred ever her flying steed.'<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_72">[Pg 72]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then the prince knew his foe, Meljakanz, and his wrath waxed hot indeed,<span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On his tracks he followed swiftly, and they who this venture tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say he won back in fight the maiden ere the shadows of evening fell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But sore were the queen's folk troubled that the heroes had chanced that way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake, 'God forbid that our queen's son fall in with these knights to-day!<br></span>
<span class="i0">An he chances to light upon them in the pride of their warlike gear,<span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">It will anger full sore our mistress if by hap she the tale should hear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ill-luck will it bring upon us that, ere ever the dawn of day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With us while his mother slumbered, to the woods he stole away!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Little recked the boy of their trouble as he chased the flying deer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shouted in youthful gladness, as they fell before his spear    <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
