<span class="i0">Then homeward he sped to his mother, but ere he his tale might tell<br></span>
<span class="i0">She was smitten with deadly terror, and low at his feet she fell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then soon as Queen Herzeleide found hearing and speech once more<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her boy was she fain to question tho' her heart it misgave her sore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Who spake to thee, son, of knighthood? What knowest thou of such-like rede?'<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'I met in the woods, sweet mother, four men I deemed gods indeed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So light were they all and shining, God Himself ne'er could brighter be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of knighthood they spake and King Arthur, who might well make a knight of me!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then her sorrow of old-time wakened, and the queen in her heart she sought<br></span>
<span class="i0">For some cunning wile of woman, that her boy from his will be brought.<span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the simple lad and gallant would crave from her hand a steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' heavy her heart, she bethought her in naught to gainsay his need,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yet not as he asks will I give him, no mother's gifts be mine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever the worst and the meanest that my skill may aye divine.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she thought her, Queen Herzeleide, 'Many folk thro' the world shall fare<span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who love mocking—On his fair body my son shall a Fool's dress wear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then sure when the mockers see him, and to scoff at his garb are fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An he at their hands be smitten, then he cometh to me again!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! for a woman's cunning, and the cruelty of mother's love,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_73">[Pg 73]</a></span>
<span class="i0">She chose from her stores a sackcloth, the coarsest that might be wove,<span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a garment of this she made him that should reach e'en unto his knee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his sunny hair such covering as on fools men are wont to see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And instead of hose she bound him on his limbs so strong and fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Leggings of undressed calf-skin—And all wept who beheld him there.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his mother with forethought bade him to tarry till morning light,<span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nor from hence would I have thee journey till my rede thou hast heard aright—<br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>'Keep thou ever from paths untrodden and ford not the darkling stream,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Where the waters flow clear and limpid, there safe is the ford I ween.</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And be ever fair and courteous, greet all men who pass thy way.</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>If a wise man old and grey-headed would teach thee, as well he may,</i><span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>All courteous ways and fitting, as his word so shall be thy deed,</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Nor wax wroth if by whiles he chide thee, but give to my words good heed.</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And one thing, my son, would I tell thee, canst thou win from a maid her ring</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>And her greeting fair, thou shalt take them, and sorrow hath lost her sting!</i><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>If a kiss from her lips she will give thee, and thine arms shall the maid enfold,</i><span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Be she pure and true thou art blessèd, and thy strength shall wax high and bold!'</i><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And hearken my son, a proud knight, Lähelein, do men call his name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From thy princes two lands hath wrested, else from them couldst thou tribute claim.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Waleis they are and Norgals—and one of thy princes brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turkentals, hath he slain, and thy people he hath smitten and doth enslave.'<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'For such wrong will I vengeance, mother, if vengeance be here God's will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be he never so strong with my javelin I think me to wound him still.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then e'en at the daylight's dawning the boy would no longer stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the thought of King Arthur's glory yet heavy upon him lay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Queen Herzeleide kissed him, and she sped swift his steed behind,<span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sorrow of sorrows smote her when her boy she no more might find.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Hence he rode and what heart rejoiceth?) Then the queen from all falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fell low on the earth, and grief tare her till death must her portion be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I wot that her death so faithful it hath saved her from pains of Hell,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_74">[Pg 74]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And to be of such son the mother, it repayeth all anguish well!    <span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus she, the root of all goodness whence humility's flower might blow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herself on a pilgrimage wended that a goodly goal should know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Woe worth us! that none of their children should live still, to hand us down<br></span>
<span class="i0">In these days when we look on falsehood their honour and fair renown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefore shall faithful women wish well to this lad so bold,  <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who rideth fair ventures seeking, whose journey ye now behold!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the gallant lad rode onward on his way toward Briziljan's wood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came to a rippling streamlet, and a cock well might wade that flood!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And flowers in the grass were blooming, yet so darkling ran the wave<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the lad he thought not to ford it; but as wit the counsel gave,<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So he followed its course thro' the daylight, and he passed as he could the night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he saw once more the morning, and he came to a fair ford bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the further side was a meadow, and a tent decked the grass so green,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tall was the tent wide-spreading, and riches thereon were seen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas of samite of threefold colours, on the seams lay fair ribbons wide,<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a leathern covering hung there, 'gainst the rain-cloud to guard its pride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">('Twas Duke Orilus of Lalande, whose wife he beneath it found—<br></span>
<span class="i0">She lay there in peaceful slumber with riches happed fair around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A Duchess she was, well worthy the love of a gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the venture it tells that Jeschuté was the name of that lady bright)<span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Softly the princess slumbered,—yet weapons of love she bore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">A mouth so red and glowing, that a knight's heart had wounded sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as she slept they parted asunder, her lips so bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the fire of love had kindled, (fit venture for gallant knight)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And even as ivory snow-white, and little, and close the row        <span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the teeth that gleamed white betwixt them—methinks that a man were slow<br></span>
<span class="i0">To use himself to such kisses from a mouth that all men might praise—<br></span>
<span class="i0">I wot that so fair a guerdon but seldom hath crowned my days!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A covering of richest sable over foot and knee was thrown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(For the heat she aside hath cast it, whom her lord had thus left alone)<span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her form it was fairly fashioned, and wrought by a skilful hand,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_75">[Pg 75]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Since 'twas God Himself in His wisdom who so fair a work had planned.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long was her arm and rounded: on her snow-white hand a ring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gleamed golden, and when he saw it the lad to her side did spring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For had not his mother told him such jewels were the guerdon fair  <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That a knight well might crave? and he thought him he fain would such token bear!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the lady awoke in terror as his clasp on her white arm fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gazed in startled wonder and wrath as beseemed her well;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Who is it, who thus would shame me? Nay, sir, thou art all too free!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Go, choose thee some fairer maiden, my favours are not for thee!'  <span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In vain might she weep and bewail her; he asked not her yea, or nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But took from her lips unwilling the kiss she would fain gainsay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the ring of gold from her finger with ungentle hand he'ld take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the clasp that her shift had fastened from the garment he roughly brake:<br></span>
<span class="i0">In vain were her tears and struggles, she was but a woman still,   <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his strength was to hers as an army, perforce must she do his will.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lad spake aloud, he hungered, from his hand was the lady free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Of a truth 'twere better thou shouldst not make meal of me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou wert but a little wiser thou wouldst choose thee some other meat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There stand bread and wine, and two game-birds, of them mayst thou freely eat,<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks when my maiden brought them, 'twas scarcely of thee she thought!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he asked not where sat the hostess, but he ate e'en as hunger taught,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he drank his fill; and the lady she deemed all too long his stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she thought him bereft of his senses, and she wished he were well away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for fear and shame the sweat-drops stood thickly upon her brow—<span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, 'Thou my ring shalt give me, and the clasp thou didst take but now,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And get thee away, if he cometh, my husband, then shalt thou bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The weight of his wrath, and I think me thou wouldst then wish thyself elsewhere!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the noble youth, 'What care I how fierce thy lord's wrath may be?<br></span>
<span class="i0">If my presence doth shame thine honour, then from hence will I swiftly flee.'<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he stepped to the bedside boldly, and kissed her as there she lay,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_76">[Pg 76]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' little it pleased the Duchess, and without leave he rode away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake a word of parting as he vaulted upon his steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'God have thee in His safe keeping, so my mother she gave me rede.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the lad he was glad of his booty, and thus did he ride a while—<span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks there was little lacking that from hence he had gone a mile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere he came of whom I would tell you: on the dew he the tracks might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of one who had sought his lady—The tent-ropes displaced should be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the lad thro' the grass had ridden; then the gallant Duke and proud<br></span>
<span class="i0">Found his lady within in sorrow, and Orilus spake aloud,           <span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! for the service done thee—for smitten and put to shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is the crown of my knightly honour, since another thy love can claim!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then little, alas! might it profit that with streaming eyes she swore<br></span>
<span class="i0">No lover had she save her husband,—he would hearken her tale no more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she spake in her fear and anguish, 'Twas a <i>fool</i>, he who came to me,<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet tho' a fool, of all men I wot he may fairest be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">My ring and my clasp gold-gleaming, he took them against my will!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, I doubt not so well he pleased thee, thou didst grant him more favours still,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now, God forbid! for his fool's garb and his javelin were e'en too near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It shameth us both, my husband, such words from thy lips to hear!  <span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Are <i>queens</i> wont to love thus lowly, that thou speakest such words of me?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wrongest our royal breeding, when thou deemest such things may be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Duke spake, 'This shame, O lady! alone hast thou won from me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou dost call thyself <i>Queen</i> no longer; tho' thy title shall <i>Duchess</i> be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Little good hath that bargain brought me—So bold shall my manhood be,<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That thy brother, King Lac's son Erec, for that cause beareth hate to thee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He is wise, and right well he knoweth that my fame so high shall stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">That nothing shall stain mine honour, save at Prurein when his right hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">In knightly joust once felled me, but that have I paid right well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a joust at Karnant I smote him, and behind his steed he fell,   <span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his pledge did he yield unto me,—thro' his shield I thy token bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thought not, my wife Jeschuté, with <i>another</i> thy love to share!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou mayst also well assure thee that the son of King Gandein,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_77">[Pg 77]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Proud Galoes, once lay lifeless before this arm of mine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou thyself wast witness when the Knight Plihopleheri         <span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode swift in a joust against me, nor his strife it hath passed me by,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My spear from the saddle thrust him that his charger he sat no more;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, great was the fame that I won me by my prowess in days of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many knights have I borne from their chargers,—yet it profiteth not I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor outweigheth the bitter shaming that thro' thee hath my portion been!'<span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And with reason good do they hate me, those knights of the Table Round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since eight of their bravest champions have I borne unto the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many fair maidens saw it, when at Kanedig fierce we fought<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the hawk; there was I the victor, and my hand fame to thee hath brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that didst thou see with King Arthur—At his court doth she dwell to-day,<span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My sister, sweet Kunnewaaré, and grave is her mien alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her lips may not move to laughter till the day that her eyes shall light<br></span>
<span class="i0">On him who of all shall be reckoned the fairest and bravest knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would he come unto me, that hero! Ah! then should a strife be seen<br></span>
<span class="i0">As to-day in the early morning already my lot hath been.           <span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I have fought, and a prince hath suffered, for joust he toward me sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But my spear-point so sorely smote him that he lay there before me, dead!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Well I know that in righteous anger for a lesser sin than thine<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many had slain the sinner, but I would not such deed were mine!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the service of knightly honour that to thee I had offered fair,<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforth shalt thou know but lacking; nor thy need do I think to spare—<br></span>
<span class="i0">No more with thy white arms circled in love and in peace I'll lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Those golden days of love's glory have faded and passed us by,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But pale be thy mouth so rosy, and tear-dimmed thy shining eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For joy shall be put far from thee, and thy heart's songs be turned to sighs!'<span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sadly she looked upon him, that princess so fair and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'May it be for the honour of knighthood what seemeth thee best to do,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wise art thou indeed and loyal, and I in thy power may be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I know well that heavy sorrow and pain thou canst bring on me:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the ordeal, I prithee, put me, and do this for all women's sake,<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_78">[Pg 78]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thereafter, an I be guilty, for my sin do thou vengeance take!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If another's hand shall slay me, (for <i>thee</i> were such deed un-meet)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then gladly I'll die—Dost thou scorn me? then welcome is death, and sweet!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he broke out in bitter anger, 'If thy pride be still so great,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It is meet I should meekness teach thee, tho' the lesson be all too late—<span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No more shall we be companions, together no more we'll eat;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be our marriage couch forgotten and the hours of communion sweet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This garment in which I found thee thy only robe shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And instead of jewelled bridle hempen twist will I give to thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy steed be the guest of hunger, and thy saddle once decked so fair<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall be robbed of its goodly trappings!' and with hasty hand he tare<br></span>
<span class="i0">The samite adown, and he brake it, the saddle she rode erewhile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Nor her gentle ways and seemly might his angry wrath beguile)<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a hempen cord he bound it—Too soon had she won his hate!<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he did this he spake, 'Now Lady, 'tis best we no longer wait,   <span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Could I reach him who shared thy favours, then fulfilled were my heart's desire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The venture I'ld face, though as dragon he were breathing forth flames and fire!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then with weeping instead of laughter she passed from out the tent<br></span>
<span class="i0">That lady so rich in sorrow, and sadly her way she went;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet more than she mourned her shaming she wept her lord's grief, I ween,<span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His sorrow so sorely moved her, e'en death would have lighter been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now of true heart shall ye bemoan her who thus did sore anguish know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' hatred I won from all women, still I'ld mourn for Jeschuté's woe!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So rode they upon the traces of the lad who before them fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, dauntless, he little thought him how a foeman behind him sped,<span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But whoever his eyes might light on, as his pathway they drew anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave to him kindly greeting, 'Thus bade me my mother dear!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus rode he, our lad so foolish, adown a mountain side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When a woman's voice before him from amid the rocks loud cried;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a cry of heartfelt sorrow, for her joy was in ruins laid—   <span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then swift rode the lad towards her,—Now hear what she did, this maid:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She tore, the maid Siguné, her plaits of long brown hair<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_79">[Pg 79]</a></span>
<span class="i0">From out her head thro' sorrow; and the lad he beheld her there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw Schionatulander, the prince, on her knee lie dead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maiden she wailed above him, and her joy had for ever fled.<span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">('If sad be their mien or joyful, my mother she bade me still<br></span>
<span class="i0">Greet all men, whoe'er might meet me) God keep thee from greater ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth a sorry treasure have I found on thy knee to-day!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who hath wounded this knight?' (For an answer the lad he would press alway)<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Did one with a javelin slay him? For Lady, he sure is dead;       <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wilt thou tell me naught? Who hath slain him? If he none too far hath fled<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks I might overtake him, for gladly with him I'ld fight!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lad he laid hold on his quiver wherein lay the javelins bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And still in his hand tight claspèd, the tokens twain he bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which he in his thoughtless folly erewhile from Jeschuté tore.     <span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had he known the courtly customs with his father's life in-bound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His shield were better smitten when the duchess alone he found<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who thro' him must suffer sorrow—for more than a whole year long,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her husband withheld his favour, tho' in sooth did he do her wrong.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now list to this maid Siguné who her grief would bemoan as meet,   <span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She spake to the lad, 'Thou art courteous, all hail! to thy youth so sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy face so fair; yea blessèd thy lot shall hereafter be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">No javelin pierced this hero, but slain in a joust was he—<br></span>
<span class="i0">From truth wast thou born who truly for another's woe can grieve!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his name she was fain to hearken, ere the lad her side might leave,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, God with skill had wrought him—But his answer was naught but this,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'At home all who know me call me '<i>Bon fils, Cher fils, Beau fils!</i>'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ere ever the word was spoken, the maiden she knew his name—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now hearken aright his title, that hereafter ye own his fame<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who is hero of this my venture, who now standeth the maid beside— <span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her red lips they spake unfaltering, 'Thou art <i>Parzival</i>,' she cried,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy name it shall mean '<i>to pierce thro</i>',' for thy mother's faithful heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">With furrow of grief was riven when she from her lord must part:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I speak not that those shouldst vaunt thee; thy mother my aunt shall be,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_80">[Pg 80]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And in truth, with no guile of falsehood, thy race will I tell to thee!'<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'An Angevin was thy father, thy mother of fair Waleis,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I know for a truth thy birthplace was the city of Kanvoleis;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou art the King of Norgals, and there in the citadel<br></span>
<span class="i0">As king shalt thou bear the sceptre and crown as beseems thee well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy sake was he slain, this hero, who thy kingdom for thee would guard,<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His truth it hath faltered never, tho' in death did he find reward.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two brothers have wrought thee evil, two kingdoms from thee have reft,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Orilus this thy kinsman in a joust hath lifeless left.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And me too hath he left in sorrow—He served me nor thought it shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This prince of thy land, where my childhood did thy mother's tending claim.<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now fair and sweet my cousin wouldst thou hear how he met his end?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas the fair wove leash of a brachet that brought sorrow unto my friend—<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hath served us twain, in our service hath he won him but death alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, I have won but sorrow, and henceforth for his death make moan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For scant of wit was I surely, that I gave not my love afore—     <span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So God hath my gladness shattered, and the dead I love evermore!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'I must mourn, O cousin, thy grief, and my bitter wrong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a truth till I may avenge them the time seemeth over-long!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then straight would he ride to battle, but the way did she falsely show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she feared were he slain then henceforward yet sorer should wax her woe.<span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But a road he found that led him straightway to the Breton's land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And smooth and wide was that highway—An there met him on either hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Afoot or ahorse a merchant or knight, he would greet them still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so was his mother's counsel; and she spake with no thought of ill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But great weariness o'ertook him, as darkened the eventide,        <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a house that was none too stately the youth in his folly spied.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a churl he who sat within it, discourteous by birth and low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(A fisherman he, little kindness might one at his hand e'er know)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lad drew rein for he hungered, and craved of him drink and meat.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the host quoth, 'Nay, not a half-loaf shalt thou have at mine hand to eat<span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In thirty years; he who waiteth, in the gifts of mine hand to share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er-long shall delay his journey—For none but myself I care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thereafter perchance for my children—Thou comest not here to-day,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_81">[Pg 81]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Hadst thou money or pledge 'twere other, then thine host would I be straightway!'<span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Jeschuté's clasp all golden the lad he would bid him take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soon as the peasant saw it, with smiling mouth he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Wilt thou stay here, sweet lad? then due honour be thy portion from all within—'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Wilt thou feed me to-night and to-morrow wilt help me the way to win<br></span>
<span class="i0">To King Arthur (for well I love him) then thyself mayst keep the gold!'<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, that will I do,' quoth the peasant, 'for ne'er might mine eyes behold<br></span>
<span class="i0">A face and form so comely—I will thee, as a marvel, bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the court, and the good Round Table, and the face of the noble king!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So the lad thro' the night abode there, and ere ever the dawn of day<br></span>
<span class="i0">He roused himself full eager to get on his onward way,             <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fisher, he made him ready, and before the lad he ran,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the boy he rode behind him, and swift were both steed and man.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">(Herr Hartmann von Aue, and thy lady, the queenly Guinevere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy gallant lord, King Arthur, a guest do I bring ye here;<br></span>
<span class="i0">No tool is he for your mocking, nay, never a harp or lute,         <span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ye shall choose ye some other plaything, such as courtesy well doth suit;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Else will I thy lady Enid, and her mother Karnafite<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pass under the mill, and their honour with bitter scorn I'll smite—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' I tune my song to mocking, and thy lips with mockery seal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet here will I guard my hero lest thy scorn he perchance should feel!)<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the lad with his guide so humble to the city walls drew near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Nantes might be well discernèd in the morning light so clear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'God keep thee, boy,' said the fisher, 'thou seest where thou must ride.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the lad yet scant in knowledge, 'Yet nearer must thou be guide!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, nay, so proud as these court-folk, such folly be far from me,<span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An' a peasant came nigh unto them, his welcome would sorry be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So alone the lad rode onward o'er a plain that was none too wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the flowers stood fair around him and blossomed on every side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No Kurwenal was his teacher and of courtesy knew he naught—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_82">[Pg 82]</a></span>
<span class="i0">They know it not, the untravelled, till the world hath wisdom taught—<span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of hempen twist his bridle, and feeble and faint his steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And oft it fell, as stumbling it went o'er the flowery mead.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And nowhere upon his saddle fair leather and new was seen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of samite fair and ermine full great his lack had been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">No mantle clasp he needed, nor knightly garb he wore,              <span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of blazoned coat or surcoat; his javelin alone he bore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He whose deeds were praised of all men, his father so brave and wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was robed in far other fashion on the carpet 'fore Kanvoleis!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He who ne'er felt the sweat of terror, to him did a knight draw near;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he greeted him, 'May God keep thee! thus bade me my mother dear.'<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'God reward thee, lad, and thy mother,' swift answer the knight would bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Uther Pendragon reared him, he was cousin unto the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And unto the land of Bretagne did the self-same knight lay claim)<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was Ither of Gaheviess, 'The Red Knight' they called his name.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All dazzling red was his armour, the eye from its glow gleamed red;<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Red was his horse swift-footed, and the plumes that should deck its head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of samite red its covering; redder than flame his shield;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair-fashioned and red his surcoat; and the spear that his hand would wield<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was red, yea, the shaft and the iron; and red at the knight's desire<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was his sword, yet the blade's fair keenness was not dimmed by the raging fire.<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the King of Cumberland, stately, in his mailèd hand did hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">A goblet, with skill engraven, and wrought of the good red gold—<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the Table Round had he reft it—All red was his shining hair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet white was his skin, and kindly his speech to the lad and fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now hail to thy fair young body, that in sooth a true woman bare, <span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, blessèd is she thy mother! Ne'er saw I a face so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the light of thine eyes, I think me, is kindled by love alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Love shall in thee be victor, as by thee Love is overthrown!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in thee is the joy of woman, whose bliss finds in thee its goal,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_83">[Pg 83]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And for thee shall the load of sorrow weigh heavy upon the soul—  <span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now do me this grace I pray thee, an thou wend thee unto the town<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bear greeting from me to King Arthur, and his heroes of high renown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And say that no fleeting vision am I who now speak with thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But here I abide, and await him who thinketh to joust with me!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And never a man will wonder: to the Table Round I came            <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, in the heroes' presence to my kingdom would I lay claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with hasty hand I raised it, this cup, and the wine out-poured<br></span>
<span class="i0">The robes of the queen besprinkled, as she sat there beside her lord.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This I did as the custom olden of one who would claim his right<br></span>
<span class="i0">For better I thought the wine-cup, than the straw-wisp all alight, <span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For its smoke perchance had soiled me, thus I chose it not' spake the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nor for robbery rode I hither, my crown doth forbid such thing—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say thou to the queen that the wine-drops, they fell on her 'gainst my will<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where those heroes sit, nor remember, nor their knighthood as meet fulfil.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether kings they shall be or princes o'er-long doth he thirst their king!<span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This cup, why delay to fetch it? Their fame it hath taken wing!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the lad spake, 'I'll bear thy message, yea, e'en as thou biddest me.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then unto Nantes fair city he gat him right speedily,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a youth they followed to the court of the palace fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas filled with a motley gathering, and they thronged him and pressed him there.<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Iwanet sprang from out them, and this youth from falsehood free<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave him a kindly greeting, and he proffered him company.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad he quoth, 'God keep thee, (so my mother she bade me speak<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet from home I wended) King Arthur I fain would seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">But here see I full many an Arthur! Who of all these shall make me knight?'<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Iwanet laughed loud 'I will show thee, not yet hast thou seen the right!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the Table Round he led him where sat the heroes all<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as best he could for the tumult cried the lad thro' the lofty hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'God keep ye all ye heroes! I greet ye both queen and king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thus did my mother bid me fair greeting to ye to bring.        <span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all who have won by their valour at the Table Round a seat<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_84">[Pg 84]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Ye gallant knights and heroes, ye too did she bid me greet!<br></span>
<span class="i0">But in one thing my skill doth fail me, who is host here I may not know;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To him do I bear a message from a knight who all red doth glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He waiteth without the portal (methinks he is fain to fight)       <span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That he spilt o'er the queen the wine-cup that sorely doth grieve the knight—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! if I his gear so goodly from the king's hand as gift might take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In sooth were I rich in gladness—so knightly and fair its make!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus spake the youth gay and careless, and the courtiers they thronged around<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hither and thither pressed him till scarce might he stand his ground:<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And well did they look upon him, for each for himself might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">That never in man or maiden might the fruit of love fairer be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in truth it was no ill working that in Parzival God had wrought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In whom never a sight of terror had wakened of fear a thought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus they brought him before King Arthur, he whom God for a wonder chose,<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And no man might bear him hatred—Then the queen from her seat arose<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she gazed for a space upon him ere she passed from out the hall<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the wine from the golden goblet perforce on her robes must fall.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Arthur he looked upon him—To the simple youth he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now lad to thy kindly greeting a kindly answer take,              <span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For this would I do thee service, yea with body alike and land;<br></span>
<span class="i0">This I speak of a true heart truly, so my will doth toward thee stand!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Would to God that were true! Now I think me it well-nigh a year shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I fain would be knight, lacking knighthood all else seemeth ill to me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now make thou no more delaying, be knighthood my lot straightway.' <span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the king, 'I were fain to do so if worth fail me not alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So noble art thou to look on; and goodly gifts and rare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would I give thee; to do thee service I'll naught of my treasure spare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, loath had I been to refuse thee, wait but for to-morrow's light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I myself will dower thee with all that befits a knight.'       <span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The lad like a bird new cagèd, he shook himself to and fro,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'For naught do I ask thee! But that knight who as fire doth glow<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou givest me not his armour no gift will I take from thee,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_85">[Pg 85]</a></span>
<span class="i0">My <i>mother</i> will not withhold it—For a queen shall she surely be.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Arthur he quoth, 'That armour so gallant a knight doth wear   <span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That to give thee a gift so goodly methinks I may hardly dare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And guiltless I live in sorrow since his homage I must forego,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ither he is of Gaheviess; thro' my joy hath he wrought me woe.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now my King sure it were ungracious to say to his pleading nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt give him what he desireth, nor think it too great,' quoth Kay,<span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Let him forth to the plain; bid him bring thee the cup if it be thy will!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here hast thou the whip, there the top is, let the child have of sport his fill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The women, forsooth, will praise him, and it seemeth good to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">He should learn to take blows an he gives them, many such will his portion be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the life of the twain what care I? Each of us needs must have his day,<span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy dogs for the spoil shall hunger, thou must e'en give thy dogs their way.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I were loath to refuse his pleading, yet I feared lest he here be slain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to knighthood I fain had helped him.' Thus Arthur he spake again.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus the lad won the gift he craved for, which many perforce must rue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And young and old they followed, as forth from the hall he flew.   <span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By the hand would Iwanet lead him, 'fore a bower that was none too high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And backward and forward turning the lad gazed with eager eye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bower was so low that within it the lad he both heard and saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefrom did he win a sorrow that vexed him with torment sore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The queen from her bower window to look on the sight was fain,     <span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her knights and maidens round her they gazed and they gazed again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maiden Kunnewaaré she sat there, the fair and proud,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never, that man might wot of, had she laughed or low or loud.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For never she vowed, an she died first, would she laugh ere her eyes might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">That knight, who of knights the bravest or was, or henceforth should be.<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As the lad rode beneath the window she brake into laughter sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her back was sore from the guerdon—reward for a maid unmeet!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Kay the Seneschal seized her, the maiden of fair Lalande,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_86">[Pg 86]</a></span>
<span class="i0">By her waving hair, and the tresses he wound fast around his hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without a band he bound her—Tho' never an oath she sware          <span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His staff he laid unknightly on her maiden shoulders fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ere ever the sound of the smiting on the ear had died away<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' white skin and royal raiment had he wounded the maid that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thus did he speak in his folly, 'Now hast thou thine own fair fame<br></span>
<span class="i0">Cast aside, and I wot thou hast done it to thine own mending shame!<span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now see, e'en in flight have I caught it, and I bring it to thee once more<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise thou mayst well remember, and be e'en in the memory sore:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I wot well unto King Arthur, to his court and his palace hall<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many gallant men have ridden, yet hast thou despised them all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ne'er hast thou smiled upon them—And now doth thy laughter ring<span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For one knowing naught of knighthood! Unseemly I deem this thing!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now whate'er might be done in anger I wot well no king's decree<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had bid him thus smite the maiden; and her friends mourned her bitterly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Might she bear knightly shield and armour it had helped not this sore disgrace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Discourteous the blows were smitten.) She came of a royal race,    <span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had her gallant brothers seen it, Lähelein and Orilus<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far fewer blows had fallen; she ne'er had been smitten thus.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Sir Antanor the Silent, who thro' silence a fool was thought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(His speech and the maiden's laughter on a self-same thread were wrought)<br></span>
<span class="i0">For never a word would he utter till she laughed whom Kay thus did smite,<span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As clear rang the maiden's laughter, aloud spake the silent knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now here before God I tell thee, Kunnewaaré of fair Lalande<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast wronged for that lad, and thy guerdon awaiteth thee at his hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor so weak shall he be, nor so foolish, but he turneth thy bliss to bale!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'And thy speech thou hast found but to threaten for joy shall it naught avail.'<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His food would he make full bitter.—Kay smote him upon the ear<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his fist till naught but a singing and a whispering might he hear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival saw the sorrow of the maiden and Antanor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart was hot for their shaming, and grief for their sake he bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he grasped his javelin tightly, but the throng pressed so close around<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_87">[Pg 87]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That perforce the dart must he lower, lest some other aim it found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus alone from the court of King Arthur rode the son of Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came to the plain where the Red Knight his foeman awaited yet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bare unto him the tidings how in Nantes was there never a knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose heart yet yearned for jousting, or who lusted with him to fight.<span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'But a gift King Arthur gave me—I spake as thou saidst before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That without thy will had it chanced thee the wine o'er the queen to pour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy discourtesy sorely vexed thee—They think not to fight with thee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now give me the steed thou ridest, and thine harness give thou to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They were given me in the palace, therein shall I be a knight,     <span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wouldst withhold them, I will not greet thee—Yield thou what is mine of right!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the King of Cumberland answered, 'If Arthur hath given to thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mine armour, my <i>life</i> he gave thee, if that life thou canst take from me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So well doth he love his kinsmen! Hath he known thee before to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That so swiftly the service done him with such guerdon he would repay?'<span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'I may win what I will I trow me, of a sooth had he given me more;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now leave thou thy claim on his kingdom—'Tis time I a knight's shield bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>squire</i> will I be no longer!' He laid on the rein his hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou art Lähelein, so I think me, who hath taken from me my land!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the knight he turned his spear-shaft, and he struck with so true a blow<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That the lad and his sorry charger on the meadow he laid them low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hero was swift in his anger, and he smote with a will so good<br></span>
<span class="i0">That there where the spear-shaft struck him there sprang forth bright drops of blood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival sprang up swiftly and stood wrathful upon his feet<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he grasped his javelin firmly—Where the helm and the visor meet<span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And betwixt the twain is an opening, there the javelin swiftly sped<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' eye and neck it struck him, and the knight on the plain lay dead.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fierce foe had he been to falsehood; women's sighs, true hearts wounded sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were the fruit of his death, and with tear-drops must many an eye run o'er.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they whom his love made joyful their gladness asunder brake,   <span class="linenum">720</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_88">[Pg 88]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And their joy to the goal of sorrow o'er a rough road its way must take.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival in his folly turned the dead knight o'er and o'er,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would he loose his armour, yet was lacking the needful lore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He fingered both helm and corslet with his bare white hands alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the fastening he failed to loosen, nor with force might they be undone<span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' oft and again he tried them, who in wisdom was all untaught.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the horses they neighed so loudly that the sound on the breeze was brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Iwanet's ear, and he heard them, by the city moat he stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(To Queen Guinevere was he kinsman, and he did to her service good)<br></span>
<span class="i0">He heard the cry of the horses, but naught of the riders saw,      <span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As his true heart would give him counsel, Parzival did he seek once more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Ither lay dead; and his slayer by his folly was vexed amain—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then swiftly he sprang to aid him, and Parzival thanks must gain<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the honour he here had won him o'er the hero of Cumberland:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'God reward thee, but give me counsel for skill here doth fail mine hand,<span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How best may I loose this armour which myself I were fain to wear?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Such lore I right well may teach thee,' quoth Iwanet the proud and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So the armour was reft from the dead man, 'fore Nantes on the grassy plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they did it upon the living, o'er whose dealings did folly reign.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Iwanet, 'These leather leggings fit not with the mailèd gear,<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As a <i>knight</i> shalt thou now be clothèd,' and the lad deemed it ill to hear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'What my mother aforetime hath given me<br></span>
<span class="i0">That cometh not from my body, or for good or for ill it be!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And much did Iwanet marvel, for clever was he i' troth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he followed perforce his bidding, nor waxed at his folly wroth.<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he drew above the leggings the hosen of shining mail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the spurs with red gold in-wroughten should unto the harness fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of silk and gold the laces, nor leather might there be found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere he gave unto him the corslet he bound him with greaves around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' o'er-long Parzival deemed it yet the time was swiftly sped,<span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere in knightly armour shining he clad him from foot to head.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lad would have ta'en his quiver, but Iwanet he spake out free,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_89">[Pg 89]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, no javelin will I give thee, unknightly such arms shall be!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he girt the sharp sword around him, and he showed how to draw the blade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade him ne'er fly in battle, nor in conflict to be dismayed.<span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then nearer he led unto him the charger the dead knight rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas tall and strong, yet the saddle the youth with one spring bestrode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He recked not the weight of his armour, and of stirrups had little need—<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en to-day do men speak of his swiftness, and the fame of his mighty deeds.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor o'er-much did Iwanet think it to teach him with fitting skill  <span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To hold his shield and to guard him, while he wrought to his foeman ill;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a spear in his hand he gave him—But Parzival turned aside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, nay, what good may that do me?' 'If a joust one with thee would ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt on thy foeman break it, perchance drive it thro' his shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou doest that oft, 'fore the maidens will they praise thee for well-fought field.'<span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And this hath the venture told me,—Not in Maestricht, or e'en Cologne<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might a painter so fair a picture as this lad and his steed have shown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then straightway he spake to Iwanet, 'My friend and companion dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The boon that I asked have I won me, of that art thou witness here.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My service bear thou to the city, to Arthur the noble king,        <span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And mourn unto him my shaming—This cup thou again shalt bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tell him a knight hath wronged me, since he smote that maiden fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who looked, and who laughed upon me, and grief for her grief I bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor hath it but lightly touched me, it hath pierced to my inmost heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">This maid's woe all undeservèd—Now do thou in her shame have part <span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the friendship that thou hast shown me! God keep thee in peace alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And watch o'er us twain, for I think me no longer I here may stay!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Ither the prince of Gaheviess on the plain had he lifeless left,<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en in death was he fair to look on who was thus of fair life bereft.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If in joust by a spear-thrust pierced he thro' knighthood his death must gain<span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who had mourned for the grief and the marvel? By a javelin he here was slain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Iwanet he strewed above him a covering of blossoms bright,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_90">[Pg 90]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he smote the shaft of the javelin in the ground by the fallen knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that lad so true and faithful, he pierced with the crimson blade<br></span>
<span class="i0">A bough of wood, and in this wise a cross o'er the dead man made.  <span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he gat him again to the city, and the heavy tidings told;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from many a trembling woman, and from many a hero bold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rose the wail of love and of sorrow; and the dead would they fetch in state,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Host they bare before her, as the queen passed the city gate.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then o'er Cumberland's prince and hero, who by Parzival's hand was slain,<span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Queen Guinevere spake in sorrow while her tear-drops they flowed amain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! alas! for broken in twain is King Arthur's might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he whom the good Round Table accounted its bravest knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here slain before Nantes he lieth! His heritage did he claim<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where men gave him death for his guerdon—For naught marred his knightly fame;<span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Here long hath he dwelt among us in such wise that never an ear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The tale of a deed unknightly, or wrong he had done, might hear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He held him afar from falsehood, to guile was he aye a foe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lock and the seal of knighthood all too soon must we bury low.<br></span>
<span class="i0">His heart wise in courteous wisdom, and steadfast as seal and sign,<span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Taught him ever the fairest counsel that a man's heart might aye divine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereby with true love and courage a man woman's love may woo<br></span>
<span class="i0">And show manhood's truth—Fruit-bearing it seedeth itself anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">The plant of all woman's sorrow! From thy wounds grief shall ever grow—<br></span>
<span class="i0">So red was thy hair that the blossoms that bloom here thy corse below<span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Scarce redder may be with thy life-blood—All laughter hast thou forbid<br></span>
<span class="i0">To fair women, and joy and gladness by thy death are for ever hid.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus Ither, beloved of all men, as a king in the grave was laid,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his life must he pay for his armour who taught sighing to many a maid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since Parzival in his folly for the harness his death had sought,  <span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hereafter, when he won wisdom, he scarcely such deed had wrought!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">NOW this might ye mark in the charger, great labour it held as naught,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it hot, were it cold, no journey the sweat on its coat had brought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">It sped over stone or tree-trunk, and scarce was there need to draw<br></span>
<span class="i0">The girth by one hole the tighter if the knight for two days it bore.<span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So fully armed, in his folly yet further he rode that day<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_91">[Pg 91]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Than a wise man unarmed in two days if his steed he betimes would stay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever it onward galloped, and but seldom would walk or trot,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How to check its speed by the bridle as yet Parzival knew not.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he saw the roof of a castle rise fair in the evening glow,    <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad he thought in his folly that the towers from the earth must grow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the one roof bare so many—And he thought Arthur sowed such seed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who could work such marvels were a holy man indeed!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he said, 'While at home I tarried ne'er looked I on woodland field<br></span>
<span class="i0">That a crop so rich and so stately in growth might ever yield;     <span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I think me my mother's people their labour but little know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For never too dry, I think me, is the soil where their seed they sow!'—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now Gurnemanz of Graharz of this mighty Burg was lord:<br></span>
<span class="i0">At his portal a spreading linden stood fair on the summer sward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor too long nor too wide was the meadow, and the horse and the road they led<span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To where Parzival found him seated who of castle and land was head.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now weariness sore constrained him, nor his shield might he rightly hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">But it backward and forward wavered as beseemed not a rider bold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Prince Gurnemanz sat all lonely, and the boughs of the linden tree<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gave shade as was meet to its master, the captain of courtesy—    <span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his life it fled from falsehood—Then e'en as should be his right<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave to the guest fair welcome, and with him stood nor squire nor knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival made him answer—In his folly he spake straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'My mother bade me seek counsel from an old man with locks of grey;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy rede will I do thee service, for so did my mother speak!'  <span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'If here thou art come for counsel, and aid at my lips would seek,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy favour thou still shalt leave me whatever my counsel be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou will that thy prayer I hearken, and give rede as seem best to me!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince cast a yearling falcon from his hand and aloft it flew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it winged its way to the castle, and its golden bells rang true,<span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a messenger; and the pages came swiftly in garments fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade them to lead the guest in, and lodging as meet prepare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad he spake in his folly, 'My mother she told me true,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_92">[Pg 92]</a></span>
<span class="i0">An thou follow an old man's counsel his rede shalt thou never rue!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the pages they led him straightway where stood many a gallant knight,<span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there in the castle courtyard from his steed did they bid him light.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the youth, and he showed his folly, 'Tis a King who hath bidden me<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be a knight, and whate'er befall me on this charger my seat shall be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My mother she bade me greet ye!' And mother they thanked and son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Both horse and man were wearied) then, the words of greeting done,<span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many a time they urged him, but it cost them many a thought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere the lad within the castle, and from off his steed they brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they led him to a chamber, and they prayed the stranger guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Let us loose thine harness off thee, that thy wearied limbs find rest.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But scarce had they loosed his armour when lo! there came to view  <span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A garment e'en such as Fools wear, and leggings of calf-skin new;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then startled and shamed they turned them, and they whispered each to all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with bated breath the tidings ran swift through the castle hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host for shame was speechless—But a knight spake in courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Let that be as it may, one so noble mine eyes they might never see,<span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Good Fortune hath looked upon him by his mien so high and fair—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! he whom Love's light hath chosen, who bade him such garb to wear?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it grieveth me sore to find thus on the World's Joy such poor attire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! well for the mother who bare him, she hath won her full heart's desire!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his helmet is decked so costly; ere his harness from him we took<span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">It became him well, and knightly and noble I ween his look,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a bruise and blood-stain the lad on his limbs doth bear.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the host, ''Tis perchance a woman who bade him such garb to wear!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, Sire, for so strange his bearing he would know not a maid to pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">To take from him knightly homage,—Tho' his face is so fair alway  <span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">It had fitted him well for Love's service.' Then the host spake, ''Tis best we see<br></span>
<span class="i0">This lad, in whose strange attiring a marvel for sure shall be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then to Parzival they betook them, and they found that a wound he bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">From a spear that was never shattered, and the host for his hurts would care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so kindly I ween his tending that a father, whose heartfelt love<span class="linenum">880</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To his children, found no denial, his faith might no better prove.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he washed his wounds and bound them, the prince, with his own right hand,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_93">[Pg 93]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Ere forth to the hall he led him where the evening meal should stand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And food the guest sore needed, and hungry was he alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the house of the fisherman fasting had he ridden at break of day,<span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his wound and the heavy harness which he before Nantes had won<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wrought him weariness sore and hunger ere ever the ride was done.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For from Arthur the King of the Bretons the whole day he needs must ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor his fast at the Court had broken, and now it was eventide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the host bade him eat at his table, and Parzival did his will,<span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the food it swiftly vanished, as if one would a manger fill!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gurnemanz was well pleasèd, and ever the lad did pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">To eat as he would, and his hunger and weariness put away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When 'twas time, and the meal was ended, 'Now weary art thou, I ween,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the host to his guest, 'If this morning betimes thou a-foot hast been?'<span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'God knoweth my mother slumbered, so early she ne'er doth wake.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the host he laughed, and he led him where rest he right well might take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade him disrobe, tho' unwilling, he needs must—An ermine fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">They cast o'er his naked body,—fairer fruit never woman bare!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By weariness taught to slumber, but seldom throughout the night    <span class="linenum">900</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On his other side did he turn him, he might well wait the morning light.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the prince he bade his servants ere ever 'twas middle day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A bath, as was meet, make ready by the couch where the young knight lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And roses they threw within it—And tho' he no call might hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The guest awoke from his slumbers, and he stepped in the waters clear.<span class="linenum">905</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I know not who sent them hither, but maidens richly dressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lovely and sweet to look on, all courteous sought the guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They washed his wounds and bound them with their hands so soft and white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Nor should this o'er strange have seemed him who was reft of wisdom's might)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And both ease he felt and gladness, nor his folly they made him rue—<span class="linenum">910</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus these fair and gentle maidens they tended the lad anew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake 'twixt themselves, and he hearkened, yet never a word would say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet too early he might not deem it, for they shone as a second day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their beauty it vied with the morning, yet his fairness outshone the twain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_94">[Pg 94]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For naught to the youth was lacking that favour and praise might gain.<span class="linenum">915</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then a linen cloth they proffered, but the lad he took it ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An he robed himself before them, their presence should shame him still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Perforce must the maidens leave him, nor longer might linger there<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' in sooth they would fain have questioned lest deeper the wounds he bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(For such was the way of woman, and such is true woman's will,     <span class="linenum">920</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' scatheless themselves yet the sorrow of a friend it doth work them ill.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he strode to the bed, and he found there fresh raiment so fine and white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a girdle he bound it round him, 'twas of silk and of gold so bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hosen of scarlet woollen they drew on the fearless knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In sooth they well became him who was comely in all men's sight.   <span class="linenum">925</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And of ruddy brown well fashioned, (nor lining they thought to spare)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were robe alike and mantle, and within was the ermine fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And without were they decked with sable, both black and grey in hue;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the gallant youth the mantle around his shoulders threw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a belt so rich and costly he girt him found the waist,        <span class="linenum">930</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fastening of the mantle with a golden clasp was graced.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And his mouth was red and glowing—Then his host he drew anigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a proud knight followed, to greet him courteously,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as 'twas done the heroes they spake with a great amaze<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ne'er saw they a man so goodly!'—And all would the mother praise <span class="linenum">935</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who such son to the world had given—And in truth and in courtesy<br></span>
<span class="i0">They spake, 'Whatsoe'er he asketh for his service fulfilled shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And favour and love await him if his worth win its meed alway,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of those who hereafter saw him none were there who said them nay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By his hand the host then took him, and forth from his chamber led,<span class="linenum">940</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince fain would hear the story how the night hours with him had sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Were it otherwise, I think me that living I scarce might wake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas well that my mother bade me thus shelter with thee to take<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet from her I had ridden—May God requite ye both,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For mercy Sir Knight, and kindness, hast thou shown to me nothing loth.'<span class="linenum">945</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So went our hero witless where to God and the host they'd sing,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_95">[Pg 95]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince by the Mass would teach him that which health to the soul shall bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would rede him well of the Offering—How to sign himself with the Cross,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus work on the Devil vengeance, who seeketh for aye our loss!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then again to the hall of the castle and the morning meal they came,<span class="linenum">950</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host set his guest beside him, and he ate without fear or shame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake the prince so courteous, 'An it seemeth not ill to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fain am I to know thy dwelling, and from whence thou art come to me?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then frankly he told the story how his mother's side he fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the ring and the clasp so golden, and the winning the harness red.<span class="linenum">955</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince he knew the Red Knight, and his fate it pleased him ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the name of his guest he asked not but 'The Red Knight' he called him still.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then e'en as the meal was over, were they tamed the ways so wild,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the host to his guest he quoth thus 'Thou speakest as doth a child,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why hold not thy peace of thy mother, and otherwise turn thy speech?<span class="linenum">960</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou follow henceforth my counsel far wiser the ways I'll teach!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And thus I begin, do thou hearken—From true shame shalt thou never flee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A shameless man, bethink thee, what place in the world hath he?<br></span>
