<span class="i0">As a bird that moulteth ever so his honour doth fall away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hereafter he hath his portion in the fires of Hell for aye.'   <span class="linenum">965</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'So noble methinks thy bearing, a folk's Lord thou well mayst be;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If high be thy birth, and yet higher the lot that awaiteth thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then see that thy heart hath pity for the poor and needy man<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fight thou against his sorrow with free gifts as best thou can,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a true knight must aye be humble—A brave man who need doth know<span class="linenum">970</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full often with shame he battles, and sore is that strife I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For him shall thy help be ready—(Who lighteneth his brother's need<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Heaven he winneth favour as rewarding for righteous deed.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth his case is harder than theirs who as beggars stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Neath the window, and succour seeking, for bread shall stretch forth the hand.'<span class="linenum">975</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou shalt learn in a fitting measure both rich and poor to be,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_96">[Pg 96]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Who spendeth as lord at all times no lordly soul hath he—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet who heapeth o'er-much his treasure he winneth methinks but shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But give thou unto each their honour, so best shalt thou guard thy fame.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'I saw well as thou earnest hither that thou hadst of my counsel need—<span class="linenum">980</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yield not unto ways discourteous but give to thy bearing heed,<br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Nor be thou so swift to question</i>—Yet I would not that thou withhold<br></span>
<span class="i0">An answer good and fitting to the speech one with thee would hold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou canst hear and see, I wot well full five shalt thy senses be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou use them aright, then wisdom it draweth anear to thee.'    <span class="linenum">985</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'In thy wrath remember mercy, and slay not a conquered foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He who to thine arms shall yield him take his pledge and let him go;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unless he such ill have wrought thee as sorrow of heart doth give,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An my counsel thou fain wouldst follow, then in sooth shalt thou let him live.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Full oft shalt thou bear thy harness—When thy knightly task is sped<span class="linenum">990</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy hands and face thou shalt cleanse them from the rust and the iron red,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For such is in truth thy duty, so thy face shall be fair and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And when maiden's eyes behold thee they shall deem thee a goodly sight.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Be manly and of good courage, so shalt thou deserve thy fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hold women in love and honour, it shall be to thine own good name; <span class="linenum">995</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And be ever steadfast-minded as befitteth good man and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An with lies thou wouldst fain deceive them much harm can thy dealings do.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If true love be repaid with falsehood then swift shalt the judgment be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a speedy end to all honour and renown shall it bring to thee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As beneath the stealthy footsteps of the thief the dry stick breaks,<span class="linenum">1000</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the slumbering watcher, startled, to his danger swiftly wakes<br></span>
<span class="i0">So false ways and dealings crooked in their wake bring but strife and woe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Prove this by true love, for true women have skill 'gainst the hidden foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their wiles can outweigh his cunning—An thou winnest from women hate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then for ever art thou dishonoured, and shame on thy life shall wait.'<span class="linenum">1005</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'So take thou to heart my counsel—And more would I tell to thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Husband and wife united as one shall they ever be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the sun that this morning shineth, and this morn that we call to-day,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_97">[Pg 97]</a></span>
<span class="i0">So the twain may be sundered never but <i>one</i> shall be held alway.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As twin blossoms from one root springing e'en so shall they bloom and grow;<span class="linenum">1010</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With wisdom receive my counsel that its truth thou hereafter know.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he thanked his host for his teaching, nor spake of his mother more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But as true man and son so loving in his heart her memory bore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince spake as did him honour, 'Yet more will I teach to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt learn knightly skill and bearing—In such wise didst thou come to me,<span class="linenum">1015</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many a wall have I looked on that the shields might better deck<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than that shield erewhile became thee, as it hung there around thy neck.<br></span>
<span class="i0">None too late shall be the morning, we'll hence to the open field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fitting skill I'll teach thee that thine arms thou mayst rightly wield.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So bring to my guest his charger, and mine shalt thou hither lead,<span class="linenum">1020</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And each knight shall make him ready, and mount, e'en as I, his steed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And pages shall thither follow, and each one shall bear a spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shaft shall be strong and untested, and blazoned with colours clear.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So the prince and his guest together they rode to the grassy plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a feat so skilful was shown by that knightly train.      <span class="linenum">1025</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad he learned how to check him his charger in seeming flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">With touch of spur, and turn him once more 'gainst the foeman's might;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His spear to sink as needed, and before him hold his shield<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he rode a joust; 'Thus shalt thou thine arms in future wield!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus of lack of skill he cured him better than by the bough       <span class="linenum">1030</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That smiteth unruly children and breaketh their skin I trow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade swift knights come hither, and a joust with the stranger ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And himself to the ring he led him, and against the foe would guide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lad in his first joust carried his spear through the foeman's shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' strong was the knight yet he smote him from his steed on the open field.<span class="linenum">1035</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And they marvelled much who beheld it—Then another to joust rode near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival took unto him a fresh and unbroken spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his youth had strength and courage—The beardless lad and fair<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_98">[Pg 98]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Was spurred by his inborn manhood, and to Gamuret's skill was heir—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he urged his charger onward full swiftly against the foe,    <span class="linenum">1040</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his spear rang true on the four nails, and struck nor too high nor low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the host's knight might keep his saddle, but prone on the sward he fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the spear-shaft full many a splinter the force of the blow might tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus five of the knights were smitten ere the host to the Burg would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the victory was his, and hereafter fierce strife might he well abide.<span class="linenum">1045</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they who his deeds had witnessed, the wise men, they needs must say<br></span>
<span class="i0">That great was the skill and valour he had shown in the joust that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Our lord may be free of sorrow, and his youth it may bloom anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he give him to wife his daughter, our lady so fair and true.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If we see him wax in wisdom then the sorrow shall be o'erpast—   <span class="linenum">1050</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The death of his sons a shadow o'erlong o'er his life hath cast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now to his door hath ridden one who maketh amends for all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladness no more shall fly him, but it seeketh his palace hall!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then homeward they turned at even when the board for the feast was spread,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince bade his daughter hither (for so I the tale have read)<span class="linenum">1055</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As he saw the maid draw near him the host to Liassé spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'To this knight shalt thou do all honour, and a kiss from his lips shalt take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With Good Fortune for guide he fareth! And of <i>thee</i> would I pray this thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If token perchance she beareth, thou wilt leave to the maid her ring—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet none hath she, nor clasp—Who should give her what that forest princess wore?<span class="linenum">1060</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>she</i> won from the hand of her husband what thine hand from her raiment tore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From <i>Liassé</i> canst thou take little'—Then the lad he must blush for shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On her lips did kiss the maiden, and her mouth it was red as flame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Liassé was fair to look on, and gentle of heart and pure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a hero might well have loved her with a love that should aye endure.<span class="linenum">1065</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Full long and low was the table, nor many might sit thereat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At its head was the prince so kindly, and his guest by his side he set<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betwixt him and his daughter, and the maiden with snow-white hand<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_99">[Pg 99]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Must carve, as he willed, for the Red Knight, so her father would give command,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And courteous, she did his bidding, and none did the twain prevent<span class="linenum">1070</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As shy glances rosy-blushing, they each to the other sent!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The feast over, the maiden left them, but she bade not the guest 'Farewell,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">For twice seven days in honour Parzival with his host did dwell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But within his heart lay a sorrow, 'twas no other I ween than this,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would he enough had striven to be worthy of wedded bliss,      <span class="linenum">1075</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought him a goal so worthy must lead to a guerdon high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both in this life and e'en in the other—And these words they shall be no lie.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One morning for leave he prayed him, from Graharz he fain would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his host, sore loth to lose him, awhile rode his steed beside.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fresh sprang of grief the fountain as the prince spake, 'I lose once more<span class="linenum">1080</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A son, Death of <i>three</i> hath robbed me, thy loss now shall make them <i>four</i>.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And threefold it was, my sorrow—Who my heart would in pieces smite<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fourfold and from hence would bear them, in the pain should I find delight.<br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>One</i> for thee, since thou ridest from me, and <i>three</i> for my three sons slain—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bravely they fell in battle, such guerdon doth knighthood gain!'  <span class="linenum">1085</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And its end is of sorrow woven—One death all my joy doth lame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The death of my son so gallant, Schenteflur did they call his name;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When Kondwiramur her kingdom and herself would withhold with strife<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Klamidé the king, and Kingron, in her aid did he lose his life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart with the thrust of sorrow, as a hedge is it piercèd thro'.<span class="linenum">1090</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now all too soon dost thou leave me since no comfort from thee I drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! would Death were here my portion since Liassé, that maiden bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the land I had deemed so goodly find no favour in this thy sight!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'My other son, Count Laskoit, by Idêr son of Noit was slain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Anent a hawk—Little gladness from his death I methinks might gain—<span class="linenum">1095</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Gurzgrei did they call my third son, to whom Mahaut gave her heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his wife did he win the maiden from her brother proud Ekunât.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst Brandigan on a venture for Schoie-de-la-kurt he'ld ride,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_100">[Pg 100]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the Prince Mabonagrein smote him, and there by his hand he died.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Mahaut she lost her beauty, and his mother, my wife, lay dead,<span class="linenum">2000</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thro' sorrow and bitter yearning the days of her life were sped.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the guest saw his host's deep sorrow as he told unto him his woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Little wisdom have I, yet if ever the day I know<br></span>
<span class="i0">When I win knightly fame and honour, so that maiden I well may woo,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt give unto me Liassé, thy daughter so fair and true.    <span class="linenum">2005</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast told me of o'er-much sorrow; if thy grief I may lift from thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the load of so sore a burden I gladly will set thee free!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then leave from the prince so kindly the young knight that morn would pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from all his gallant vassals; and he rode from their land away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince, in the game of sorrow, tho' heavy before his throw,<span class="linenum">2010</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had lost yet more, for from threefold to fourfold his grief must grow.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_101">[Pg 101]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK IV<br>

KONDWIRAMUR</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_102">[Pg 102]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p><span class="smcap">Book IV.</span> tells how Parzival came to Pelrapär, and found it besieged by
sea and land, and the folk wasted by famine. How Queen Kondwiramur
besought his aid; how he overthrew Kingron, and sent him to the court
of King Arthur. How Parzival wedded the Queen; and of the wrath
of King Klamidé when he heard the tidings. How the Burgers defended
Pelrapär against their foemen; how Klamidé challenged Parzival to single
combat, and was overthrown; and how he came to the court of King
Arthur at Dianasdron. Of the love of Parzival and Kondwiramur; and
how the hero parted from his wife, and went in search of knightly venture.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_103">[Pg 103]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK IV</p>
<p class="ph2">KONDWIRAMUR
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_t.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_t.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus Parzival parted from them, and courteous he now might bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">His knightly garb, and he knew them, the customs of knighthood fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But alas! he full sore was troubled with many a bitter pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the world was too close, and too narrow the width of the spreading plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the greensward he thought was faded, and his harness had paled to white;<span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So the heart the eye constraineth and dimmeth awhile the sight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For since he had waxed less simple somewhat of his father's lore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The desire of the man for the maiden, in his wakening heart he bore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought but of fair Liassé, that maiden so true and sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How never her love she proffered, yet with honour the guest would greet.<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And wherever his horse might turn it he took in his grief no heed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if slowly it paced or swiftly he thought not to guide its speed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor many a field well-fencèd nor wayside cross he found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor chariot-wheel nor horse-hoof had furrowed with tracks the ground;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Untrodden the woodland pathway, nor wide was I ween the way,        <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he knew not the hills and the valleys—Full oft shall ye hear men say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Who rideth astray, in his wandering the lost axe may often find.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">They lay here unnumbered round him, if for <i>axe</i> ye have <i>trees</i> in mind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet tho' far was the road he journeyed yet he went in no wise astray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus from the land of Graharz he rode through the livelong day, <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he came to the kingdom of Brobarz thro' mountains wild and high—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_104">[Pg 104]</a></span>
<span class="i0">When the shadows of evening lengthened, and red flushed the western sky,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he came to a mountain torrent, and the voice of the raging flood<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rang clear as its waves rushed foaming round the crags that amid them stood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So he rode adown by the waters till he came to the city fair        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which a king had bequeathed to his daughter; 'twas the city of Pelrapär,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot that tho' fair the maiden who bare of that land the crown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great grief and small gladness had they who dwelt in that noble town!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Like an arrow that swiftly speedeth from the bow by a strong arm bent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The waters onward rushing on their downward pathway went;           <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a bridge hung high above them with woven work so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the stream it flowed swift to the ocean—Well-guarded was Pelrapär,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As children in swings delight them, and swing themselves to and fro,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So swung the bridge, yet ropeless, youthful gladness it scarce might know!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And on either side were standing, with helmets for battle bound,    <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of knights e'en more than thirty, and they bade him to turn him round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with lifted swords, tho' feeble, the strife would they gladly wait,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They thought 'twas the King Klamidé whom they oft had seen of late,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So royally rode the hero to the bridge o'er the field so wide—<br></span>
<span class="i0">As thus to the youth they shouted, and with one voice his arms defied,<span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' he spurred his steed full sharply it shrank from the bridge in fright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ne'er knew he a thought of terror—To the ground sprang the gallant knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he led his horse by the bridle where the bridge hung high in air,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too faint were a coward's courage so bitter a strife to dare!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well must he watch his footsteps for he feared lest his steed should fall—<span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From the other side of the water the knights had ceased their call,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with shield and sword-blade gleaming within the town they passed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they feared lest an army followed, and they closed their portals fast.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So Parzival crossed the river, and he rode o'er a grassy plain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where many in search of knighthood must death for their guerdon gain;<span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came to the palace portal, and stately the Burg and high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there hung there a ring of iron, and he gripped it right manfully.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But none to his call made answer, save only a maiden bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who looked forth from out her window, and was 'ware of the gallant knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the maiden so fair and courteous, 'An thou comest, Sir Knight, as foe,<span class="linenum">55</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_105">[Pg 105]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Little need have we of thine hatred, for heavy enough our woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A wrathful host doth threaten already by sea and land!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Nay, gentle lady, at thy portals a man doth stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who will, if he can, do thee service! For thy service my hand is fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never reward save thy greeting as payment I think to gain.'     <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the maiden she went in her wisdom to the queen and an entrance prayed<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the knight, and in sooth his coming it brought to their sorrow aid.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So Parzival came to the city; down the roadway on either hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk who would fain defend them in close groups he saw them stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Soldiers on foot, and slingers, and they who the dart could throw,  <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He saw as he came towards them, in many a goodly row.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a squire so valiant, the bravest from out the land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long, sharp, and strong were the lances they bare in each strong right hand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There too, so the story telleth, was many a merchant grave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the javelin and axe were their weapons, so their lady commandment gave.<span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And their skins, they were loose for hunger—Then the Marshal of the queen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Made his way thro' their ranks to the castle, and heavy his task I ween.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well was that castle guarded, with towers o'er the chambers high;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And barbican, keep, and oriel in such numbers they met his eye<br></span>
<span class="i0">That buildings so strong and so many in his lifetime he never saw,  <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And on horse or afoot from all sides the knights to his welcome draw.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a sorry host, for as ashes some were grey, some were pale as clay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(My lord the Count of Wertheim sure had starved on such scanty pay!)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thro' want full sore they hungered, nor cheese, nor bread, nor meat<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had they, and their teeth were idle since naught might they find to eat.<span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And their palate knew naught of the flavour of the wine-cup, or red or white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their doublet hung loosely on them, and wasted each limb of might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their skin like wrinkled leather on each rib hung gaunt and grim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For hunger their flesh had wasted and driven from every limb.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' want must they sorely suffer, little grease in their fuel ran—<span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(A hero to this had forced them, the proud King of Brandigan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus they paid for Klamidé's wooing)—The mead might they seldom spill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For small was their store, I think me, the vessel or cup to fill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Trühending oft shall ye hearken the hiss of the frying cake,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_106">[Pg 106]</a></span>
<span class="i0">In such music, methinks, but seldom the folk might their pleasure take!<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">(And if for such want I'ld mock them, then in truth must I share their shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there where I oft dismount me, where men do me '<i>Master</i>' name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At home in mine house, with trouble e'en the mice shall their portion steal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor oft for their food be joyful! Nor need they the bread conceal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unhidden, I scarce may find it—Yea, oft doth it happen so,         <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, Wolfram of Eschenbach, ofttimes such pleasure and ease may know.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But enough of my lamentation, once more ye the tale shall hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">How the city was full of sorrow, and for gladness they paid full dear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">How these heroes, so rich in courage, must in need and in scarceness live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so did the manhood bid them, to their need shall ye pity give—<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For their life stood in pledge, might He free it in Whose Hand all power shall be!—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet more of their grief would I tell ye that ye mourn for them bitterly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With shame their guest did they welcome, for they deemed him so rich and great<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he craved not thro' need their shelter; he knew naught of their poor estate.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">On the grass did they spread a carpet, where a linden was walled around,<span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And trained to a welcome shadow—'Neath its boughs they his arms unbound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the vassals they took his harness; but other than theirs his face<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he in the streamlet washed it, and cleansed it from red rust trace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, the sunlight's rays were shamèd 'neath the glow of his beauty bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a worthy guest they thought him as they gazed on the gallant knight.<span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then a mantle rich they brought him e'en like to the robe he bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And new was the smell of the sable wherewith it was garnished fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they spake, 'Wilt thou look upon her, the queen, our lady true?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight made answer straightway, that thing would he gladly do.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the palace they came, and the stairway steep and high to the portal led,<span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the light of a fair face met him when his footsteps so far were sped.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of his eyes should she be the sweetness—There shone from that lady bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">A radiant glow and dazzling, ere she welcomed the stranger knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now Kiot of Katelangen and Manfilot, Dukes the twain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_107">[Pg 107]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Led hither their brother's daughter who as queen o'er this land did reign:<span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(For the love of God their harness, shield, and sword, had they put away<br></span>
<span class="i0">These princes true and stalwart, fair of face tho' their hair was grey.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Midway adown the staircase all courteous the maid they led,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she kissed the gallant hero, and the lips of the twain were red;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she gave him her hand, and she led him, Sir Parzival, to the hall,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they sat them adown together in the midst of the courtiers all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And feeble and faint the maidens, and the knights who stood there around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And vassal alike and hostess, small joy in their life they found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet Kondwiramur, her beauty did high o'er all others stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it Enid, or fair Jeschuté or Kunnewaaré of far Lalande,       <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whoe'er men had deemed the fairest when they women's beauty weighed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their fame to the earth was smitten by the glance of this royal maid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, even the twain Isoldé, tho' men praise them evermore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They must yield the crown of beauty to the lady Kondwiramur.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And her name in our tongue betokens her shapely form and fair)    <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And well had they done, the mothers, who had borne such a goodly pair<br></span>
<span class="i0">As these twain who sat here together, naught did they who stood around<br></span>
<span class="i0">But gaze on the one and the other—Many friends had our hero found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the thoughts of the knight will I tell ye, <i>'There</i> Liassé, Liassé <i>here</i>,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">God will free me from care since I see here Liassé that maiden dear<span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The child of a gallant father!'—Yet her fairness was naught I wot,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst her beauty who sat beside him, in whom God no wish forgot.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(The maiden was queen of the country) Yea, e'en as by morning dew<br></span>
<span class="i0">Refreshed, the rose from its calyx forth buddeth in beauty new,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And is white and red together—And grief to her guest it wrought,  <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To whose courtesy naught was lacking since Gurnemanz' side he sought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his words had from folly freed him; and had bidden him questions spare<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save only where they were needful—So he sat by that lady fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a word his lips spake, tho' he sat close the maid beside—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet to those who know more of woman such silence doth oft betide.  <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the queen to herself said softly, 'This man disdaineth me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He deemeth my fairness faded. Nay, perchance it yet may be<br></span>
<span class="i0">That in this thing he doeth wisely, his hostess in sooth am I,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_108">[Pg 108]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he is my guest, the first speech should be mine assuredly!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gently he looks upon me tho' never a word we speak,                <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And courteous hath been his bearing, 'twere well I the silence break;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too long have I yet delayed me since here side by side we sit.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her guest did she turn, the maiden, and she spake as it seemed her fit:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight, it were well as hostess that the first words came from me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since I wot well my kiss as hostess a greeting hath won from thee, <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou offeredst me thy service, so my maiden hath borne me word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our guests scarce are wont to do so, tho' the tidings I fain had heard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now tell me, my guest, I prithee, since the tale I am fain to know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From whence art thou come to my kingdom, and whither thou yet wouldst go?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, at early morning I rode from my host away,                  <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A brave knight is he and faithful, yet he sorroweth sore to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Prince Gurnemanz do men call him, in Graharz he holds command,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From thence I to-day have ridden, thence came I unto this land!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the noble maiden answered, 'Sir Knight, had another told<br></span>
<span class="i0">This tale, methinks that scarcely for truth I the words might hold,<span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou in one day hadst ridden a journey that scarce in twain<br></span>
<span class="i0">My swiftest squire could compass, tho' his charger he spurred amain!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy host was my mother's brother; his daughter's youthful glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It hath paled before the sorrow which she, e'en as I, must know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many sad days and mournful, with sad eyes we've wept our fill  <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I, and the maid Liassé—Wouldst thou show to thy host goodwill?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then thou shalt with us, man and woman, this night-tide our sorrow share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt serve him thereby; and I'll tell thee the want we perforce must bear.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake her uncle Kiot, 'Lady, I send to thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">Twelve loaves of bread, and of shoulders and hams do I give thee three,<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And eight cheeses too are with them, and two casks of wine I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my brother, he too shall aid thee, of such aid hast thou need enow!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Manfilot spake, 'Yea, Lady, I send thee the self-same fare.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maiden she sat in gladness, and of thanks she no word would spare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then leave they craved from their lady, and forth would the old men ride<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_109">[Pg 109]</a></span>
<span class="i0">To their hunting-house that was nigh there—But the cell where they would abide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was in Alpine wilds so lonely, there unarmed did they dwell afar,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a foeman vexed them with tumult or strife of war.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the messenger sped full swiftly, and the fainting folk were fed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No Burger within the city but was lacking for other bread,         <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many were dead of hunger ere food for their need was found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen she bade them share it to the feeble folk around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the cheese, the flesh, and the red wine, as Parzival counsel gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Scarce a morsel was left, yet they shared it, the queen and her guest so brave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And swiftly the store had vanished, tho' to many who yet might live,<span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor were slain by cruel hunger this succour fresh life might give.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they bade them a couch make ready for the guest, and 'twas soft his bed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Had the Burgers been hawks for the hunting methinks they were not o'er-fed<br></span>
<span class="i0">As their scanty board bare witness) yea, the folk there, one and all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare the marks of bitter hunger, save the gallant Parzival.        <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then leave he prayed of his hostess, he would lay him down to rest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Do ye think that for tapers straw-wisps must light so brave a guest?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, better were they I think me; he betook him, the hero fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To a bed so rich and stately a king well might slumber there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor of poverty bare it token, and a carpet before it lay.          <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he prayed the knights to go hence, nor longer there delay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And noble lads un-shod him, and straightway he fell asleep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the cry of heart-sorrow woke him, and tears that bright eyes should weep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This chanced e'en as I will tell ye; no woman's law she brake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For pure was she aye, the maiden of whom this venture spake.       <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Long stress of war constrained her, and the death of her champion true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So heavy her heart with sorrow that sleep from her eyelids flew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So she went, this royal lady, (but never such love to claim<br></span>
<span class="i0">As urgeth a gentle maiden to crave of a <i>wife</i> the name)<br></span>
<span class="i0">But she sought help and friendly counsel, tho' clad in a warlike gear,<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A silken shift, (strife she wakeneth who doth thus to a man draw near.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maiden she wrapped around her a mantle of samite long,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_110">[Pg 110]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And she went as her steps were guided by sorrow and bitter wrong.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her maidens and waiting women who lay there around her bed<br></span>
<span class="i0">She left them slumbering softly, and with noiseless footsteps sped <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To a chamber, there, e'en as she bade them, Parzival all lonely lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And around his couch the tapers burnt bright as the light of day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To his bed she turned her footsteps, and she knelt low his couch before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But no thought of love unlawful the heart of either bore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of joy bereft was the maiden, his help she was fain to claim,      <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If awhile they lay there together it brought unto neither shame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So bitter the maiden's sorrow that there fell full many a tear<br></span>
<span class="i0">On Parzival, and her weeping thro' his slumbers the knight might hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And waking, he looked upon her, and sorrow and joy he felt,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he rose up, the youthful hero, as the maiden before him knelt, <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake to the queen, 'Say, Lady, wilt thou now make a mock of me?<br></span>
<span class="i0">To God only, and never to mortal methinks shouldst thou bow the knee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But rise thou and sit beside me, or grant me I pray this grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lay thyself down where I was lying, I will seek me some other place!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But she spake, '<i>Thyself</i> wilt thou honour, and show honour alike to me,<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And by never a touch wilt shame me, I will e'en lay me down by thee.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the knight he spake by his knighthood he would e'en do as he should say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So down on the bed beside him in peace the maiden lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tho' well sped were the hours of the night-time no cock did they hear to crow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Empty and bare the perches, for the famine had left them so.       <span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the maiden, grieving sorely, prayed him courteous her plaint to hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">''Twill rob thee of sleep an I tell thee, and work to thee ill I fear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My foeman the King Klamidé, and Kingron his seneschal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My castles and lands have wasted, yea, all but this citadel.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My father, King Tampentäre, by his death me, poor orphan, left     <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In peril and need so deadly, of all hope am I well-nigh reft.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kinsmen and princes many, and vassals, both rich and poor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, a mighty army served me, but they serve me now no more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">One half, nay, far more I think me, in defence of my land are slain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_111">[Pg 111]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! whence shall I, poor maiden, or gladness or succour gain?    <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In such sore strait do I find me, I am ready myself to kill<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere my maidenhood and this body I yield to Klamidé's will.<br></span>
<span class="i0">His wife he is fain to make me, yet his was the hand that slew<br></span>
<span class="i0">My Knight Schenteflur, the hero, whose heart was both brave and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the flower was he of all manhood, falsehood he ne'er might know,<span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who was brother unto Liassé, and she too shall share my woe.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But e'en as she named Liassé then sorrow awoke anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his heart who would fain do service, and his spirit, so high and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sank, as sinketh a hill to the valley, at the thought of that maiden dear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he spake to the queen, 'Say, Lady, how best may I serve thee here?'<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight an thou couldst but rid me of Kingron the seneschal;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In knightly joust of my warriors full many before him fell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the morning again he cometh, and he thinketh that free from harm<br></span>
<span class="i0">His lord soon shall lie, my husband, in the clasp of my circling arm.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My Burg hast thou seen, and thou knowest how lofty its towers and high,<span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet down to the moat below them will I fling myself joyfully,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere of maidenhood King Klamidé shall rob me against my will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If no better may be, then by dying, his boasting I yet may still!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Lady, French or Breton, of what country soe'er he be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Kingron my hand shall shield thee, with what power may be given to me.'<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The night was spent, with the dawning the queen she arose again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lowly she bent before him, nor from thanks would her lips restrain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she passed from the chamber softly, and no man might be aware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' wise were he else, of her errand, save only the knight so fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor Parzival longer slumbered, for the sun was swift to rise,      <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And it pierced thro' the clouds of morning, and smote on his wakened eyes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he heard the sweet bells chiming, as the folk church and minster sought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Klamidé their joy had banished, and their land in sore peril brought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then up rose the young knight also; the chaplain was in his place<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sang to God and his lady; and the guest saw the maiden's face,<span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gazed till the Mass was ended, and the benediction o'er.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_112">[Pg 112]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade them to bring his harness, and soon was he armed once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A good knight and strong they deemed him, in gallant armour fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then on came Klamidé's army with banners borne high in air.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kingron, he came full swiftly, he sped far before the force,   <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, so hath the story told me, of Iserterre's land his horse.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there waited before the portal the son of King Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prayers and the hopes of the townsfolk on the youthful knight were set.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor with sword he ere this had striven—From afar did he aim his stroke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so swift his joust, in the meeting the gear of both chargers broke,<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And their girths were burst asunder, and each steed to its knees was brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heroes who yet bestrode them of their swords must they needs take thought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In their scabbards did they find them—And already did Kingron bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wounds in arm and breast, and I wot me that loss was his portion there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this joust brought him loss of the glory that methinks had been his alway<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he met with this knight, and their meeting, of his pride was the dying day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And valiant did men account him, six knights had he prostrate laid<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who rode in one field against him, yet here was he well repaid<br></span>
<span class="i0">By Parzival's right hand valiant, and Kingron the seneschal<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thought strange was indeed his peril, for <i>stones</i> surely on him fell<span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Cast forth from a mighty engine—Other arms wrought his overthrow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a sword clave clean thro' his helmet, and Parzival laid him low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he knelt with one knee upon him, and he bade him forthwith to give<br></span>
<span class="i0">What he ne'er to a foe had given, his pledge, an he fain would live.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he thought not to be his captor who had vanquished him here in field,<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But he bade him ride hence to Graharz and his pledge to its lord to yield.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay, Sir Knight, thou hadst better slay me, 'twas I who slew his son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas my hand of life that robbed him, Schenteflur—Thou from God hast won<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great honour, yea, men shall praise thee for the strength that thou here hast shown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a sooth art thou here the victor, and Good Fortune shall be thine own.'<span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Yet another is the choice I will give to thee,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_113">[Pg 113]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Yield thou to the queen whom thy master in his wrath wronged so grievously!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay! Then were I lost of a surety, for I wot with their sword-blades keen<br></span>
<span class="i0">My body they'ld hew in pieces, small as dust in the sun is seen!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such sorrow of heart, I think me, and grief thro' my hand they win,<span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many a gallant hero who dwelleth those walls within.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Then hence from this plain shalt thou journey to the kingdom of Brittany,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bear to a gentle maiden thy pledge and thy fealty.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she for my sake hath suffered a sorrow she ne'er had borne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had not Kay been of knightly customs, and of courtesy fair forsworn.<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Say to her how with me it fareth, that I come not in joy again<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till my spear, thro' his shield sharp-piercing, hath wiped out her honour's stain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To King Arthur and to his lady, and the knights of the Table Round<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bear my greeting, and say in their presence shall I never again be found<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the day I from shame have freed me; from the shame which <i>I</i> too must share<span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the maiden who smiled upon me, and great grief for that greeting bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say to <i>her</i> I am aye her servant, to serve her with service fain!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">So Kingron must swear unto him ere they parted, those heroes twain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus he came afoot to the city, for thither had fled his steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Burgers' help in battle, from their anguish the folk he freed. <span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But the outer host was troubled that Kingron, their chosen knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this wise had been dishonoured, and broken his dauntless might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they led Parzival in triumph to their queen so fair and young,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maiden was fain to greet him, and her white arms around him clung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in close embrace she held him as she spake, 'The wide earth doth hold<span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No man I will have for my husband save him whom these arms enfold!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as here they disarmed the hero her part would the maiden bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">With ready hand and skilful, nor her service she thought to spare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But tho' heavy had been his labour, yet scanty, I ween, the board.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burgers they came before him, and they sware him with one accord<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They would have him for lord and master; and the queen in her turn she spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she said that this knight so valiant for her love and her lord she'ld take<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who had won him a fame so mighty o'er Kingron the seneschal—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_114">[Pg 114]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But now from the castle bulwarks two sails might be seen by all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A strong wind to the haven brought them, and their lading must needs make glad<span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk, they bare naught but victuals,—God's guidance they surely had!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they rushed adown from the ramparts, and swift to the ships they fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The hungry crowd, for the booty, as leaves by the wind are sped.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With flesh they were not o'erweighted, so wasted and thin were they,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor they strutted with well-filled belly, but bending they went their way.<span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The queen's marshal he sware the shipmen, by the doom of the hempen cord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Safe conduct for life and lading, none should touch that which lay aboard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade them to lead these merchants straightway into the town,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival for their lading the double he paid them down,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly the merchants took it, for princely they deemed such pay;<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burgers these welcome viands to their fires did they bear straightway.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now fain would I there take service, no man of them all drank beer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wine and food had they there in plenty—Then he did as you now shall hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Parzival, the gallant hero, for first in portions small,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his own right hand he shared out the viands among them all,   <span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, even unto the nobles; so long had they lacked for bread,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He feared it had wrought them evil if perchance they were over-fed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But to each one he gave his portion, and his counsel they deemed it right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And more should they win ere nightfall from the hand of this gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To their marriage couch they bade them, 'twas the will both of king and queen—<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet throughout the night so courteous he bare him, in truth I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He little had pleased those ladies who now, in these latter days,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In passion's heat forget all that should win for a woman praise;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' modest they seem to strangers, yet their heart gives their mien the lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their tenderness worketh sorrow to their friend, tho' in secrecy.<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But the steadfast knight and faithful guards himself at every hour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well knoweth to spare a woman an she chanceth within his power.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he thinketh, and thinketh truly, 'For many a lonely year<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her favours I served this lady; now, behold, the day is here<br></span>
<span class="i0">When her will is to reward me, and here we twain do lie—          <span class="linenum">375</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_115">[Pg 115]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Had I touched with bare hand her vesture I were blest to eternity!<br></span>
<span class="i0">An I vantage take of her slumbers to myself untrue I seem,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks we were both dishonoured did I waken her from her dream,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a woman's sleep is holy, and all men shall own its sway.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus the Waleis, who ne'er had feared him, lay still till the dawn of day.<span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus he whom men called the Red Knight, a maiden he left the queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet surely she deemed in the morning his wife she o'er night had been,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for love of her lord her tresses she bound with the morning light<br></span>
<span class="i0">As matrons are wont to bind them. And he won him, the gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Castles and lands around them from the hand of his maiden bride,   <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But her <i>heart</i> was ere this his guerdon, and in peace did the twain abide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus glad in their love they held them two days till the third night fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And often he thought might he take her to himself it would please him well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought of his mother's counsel, and how Gurnemanz spake of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That man and wife should as <i>one</i> be, and the doubt vexed his soul no more,<span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his wife did he take unto him—Love's custom ever old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ever new to lovers, to these twain brought joy untold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Twas well, not evil, with them—Now hear how the king, their foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he rode in his might to battle, must tidings of evil know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a squire who fain had told them, all crimson his spurs with blood;<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Before Pelrapär on the meadow have they foughten those heroes good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a bitter strife and knightly; thy seneschal fell that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kingron, who led thine army, to King Arthur must take his way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he in departing bade them lies the army upon the plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pelrapär shalt thou find well guarded 'gainst thyself and thine armies twain,<span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There within is a gallant hero, and naught doth he crave but strife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the camp of thy hired soldiers is many a rumour rife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They say from the good Round Table cometh Ither of Cumberland<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the help of the queen, and knightly and valiant methinks his hand!<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas his arms that rode forth for jousting, and no man his deeds shall blame,<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise hath he borne his armour as winneth him meed of fame.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the king to the squire, 'My lady, the queen, she desireth me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she and her land so goodly I trow shall my portion be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kingron the seneschal told me, and surely the truth he spake,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_116">[Pg 116]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That famine doth plague the city, and peace they ere long must make,<span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen she her love shall proffer'—His wrath must the squire abide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the king and his host passed onward, and a knight did toward them ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spared not his horse but spurred it, and told them the self-same tale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the king deemed the loss o'er-heavy, and courage and joy must fail.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then a prince spake from out the army, 'Tho' Kingron hath valour shown,<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet never he fought for <i>our</i> manhood, he fought for himself alone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now let him to death be stricken—Why then should they be cast down,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two hosts, this one, and the army that lieth before the town?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade his lord take courage, 'Once more will we try our fate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let them look to their arms, the conflict shall be for their strength too great,<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">We will make an end of their gladness! Bid thy vassals and kinsmen hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With banners twain before them to the town shall they draw anear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Down the hill will we ride upon them, but afoot must we storm the gate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so shall we work them evil, and victory shall on us wait.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Galogandres, the Duke of Gippones, it was who this counsel gave,   <span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow he brought on the Burgers—but slain was this hero brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And slain, too, the brave Count Narant, a prince from Uckerland's shore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many another hero whom dead from the field they bore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear ye another story, how the Burgers would guard their wall.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Strong stakes of wood sharp-pointed they made fast in tree-trunks tall;<span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Sore pain thus was wrought the besiegers) and the trunks were made fast that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">To a rope that by wheel was guided, so they guarded their walls alway.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all this had they done and tested ere Klamidé would storm the gate<br></span>
<span class="i0">To avenge the fall of Kingron—There had come to their land of late<br></span>
<span class="i0">Greek fire, for the ships had brought it that of food brought a goodly store,<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And it burnt of the foe the weapons, and the engines of deadly war;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And battering-ram or tortoise in vain 'gainst the walls were wheeled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No weapon had they for onslaught but was forced to the flame to yield!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Kingron the seneschal journeyed till he came on to Breton ground,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his hunting-house in Briziljan King Arthur at last he found,    <span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Karminöl did they call it—As 'fore Pelrapär he fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So at Parzival's word his surety to the maid of Lalande he brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And glad was fair Kunnewaaré that, faithful, he mourned her shame<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_117">[Pg 117]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Whom men there knew as the Red Knight, and this knight at his bidding came.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And soon were the wondrous tidings amid the courtiers spread,      <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he stood there before King Arthur, a gallant knight ill-sped.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spake unto him and his vassals in such wise as he needs must speak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kay was with terror smitten, and crimson it grew, his cheek,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Is it thou, O Kingron? Ah! many a Breton knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou seneschal of Klamidé, thy hand hath o'erthrown in fight!      <span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy captor ne'er look upon me with favour, thine office high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall turn to thy good; we are rulers of the caldron, both thou and I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of thy wisdom and skill do thou aid me, to win me the favour fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of this maiden Kunnewaaré, and sweet cates for her board prepare!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor they asked from him other ransom—Now leave we that tale and hear<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What had passed since we left the story—So the host to the town drew near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Pelrapär came the King Klamidé, and a bitter strife arose.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The inner host strove with the outer, and in sooth were they gallant foes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fresh strength had they won and courage, and bravely they held the field;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival, lord of the country, in the vanguard he bare his shield.<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he swung aloft his weapon, thro' the helm clave the blade so keen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knights he o'erthrew before him found a bitter death I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there, where the corslet opened, the Burgers they pierced them thro',<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise would they take their vengeance—this wrought grief to the hero true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival, he forbade them, and they ceased at their lord's command,<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But of living knights full twenty were captive unto their hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Parzival well had marked it how the king and his bravest knights<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sought not fame before the portals, but far out in the plain would fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then forth by a path untrodden the hero a circuit made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And swiftly he charged where the monarch his banner aloft displayed.<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, see! there a mighty slaughter the guard of the king befell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shields they were hewn in pieces, the Burgers they fought so well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival's shield had vanished 'fore the blows and the sword-blades keen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' little his skill rejoiced them, yet all who the strife had seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They spoke but to praise his valour—Galogandres the standard bare,<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_118">[Pg 118]</a></span>
<span class="i0">(Well he knew how to wake their courage!) but dead lay the hero there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Klamidé himself stood in peril, and great stress on his army lay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade them withdraw, for the valour of the Burgers had won the day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Parzival, gallant hero, bade them treat their captives well<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the dawn of the third day's morning, and fear on his foemen fell.<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the young host, proud and joyful, bade the knights on their oath go free—<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Good friends, when the word I send ye, then wend your way back to me!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their swords and their goodly harness as prisoners they needs must yield;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unarmed did they fare from the city to the host on the outer field.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'For sooth,' spake their comrades mocking, 'from <i>wine</i> must ye needs be red,<span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Poor souls, since within the city ye have hungered for lack of bread!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay! nay! ye may spare your pity,' so spake they, the heroes good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'If ye lie here a whole year longer, within is such store of food,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That by them might ye well be nourished! And the queen hath the fairest knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her husband, that e'er won knighthood, or carried a shield in fight,<span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He may well be of lofty lineage, for he lacketh no knightly skill!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the king needs must hear the tidings, and in sooth did they please him ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And heralds he sent to the city, and he bade them this challenge bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">To him whom the queen had wedded, 'If this knight the strife shall dare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen doth hold him worthy herself, and her lands so wide, <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To defend in single combat, then in peace may our hosts abide!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Parzival he was joyful at the message the heralds bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart was fain for the combat; and out spake the hero fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now I pledge me upon mine honour that no man within this wall<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall lift his hand for my peril, <i>alone</i> will I stand or fall!'<span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So betwixt the moat and the meadow a truce did they swear that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And those smiths of battle armed them as meet for the coming fray.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">On a gallant war-horse armèd sat the King of Brandigan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas hight Guverjorz—This charger with many a gallant man,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_119">[Pg 119]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And many a goodly present, from Gringorz his nephew, king          <span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Ipotente did Count Narant from the north o'er the deep seas bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therewith were a thousand footmen, well armed save no shield had they;<br></span>
<span class="i0">(If the tale speaketh true to the third year the king had made good their pay.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gringorz sent him knights five hundred, each one with his helm on head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And skilled were they all in battle; with Klamidé they hither sped.<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus had the mighty army, alike both by sea and land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Encircled the town of Pelrapär, and great need must its folk withstand!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth rode Parzival from the city to the field that should aye declare<br></span>
<span class="i0">If 'twas God's will his wife to leave him, the child of King Tampentäre.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Proudly he rode, yet he spurred not his steed to its swiftest flight,<span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas armed for need, and its covering was a samite of red so bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the iron lay beneath it—And the hero himself shone fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his harness red, red his corslet, and the shield that he proudly bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Klamidé began the conflict—A short spear of wood unwrought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With that would he fell his foeman, and the joust from afar he sought;<span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Guverjorz sprang forth swiftly, and the joust it was ridden well<br></span>
<span class="i0">By those heroes young and beardless, nor one from his saddle fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a horse or a rider had foughten a better fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the steam rose in clouds from the chargers on which sat each gallant knight,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And so fierce was the fight that the horses, out-wearied with conflict sore,<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Stumbled and fell together, in sooth could they do no more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And joyful they smote, the heroes, till fire from the helm must spring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Small time had they there for leisure, but zeal to their task must bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shields were hewn in pieces, and the splinters were tossed on high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As shuttlecocks gaily smitten to the winds of heaven fly.          <span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet Gamuret's son was unwearied, and never a limb did ache,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' Klamidé deemed that the foemen from the city the truce would break.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bade his fellow-foeman to look to his honour well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stay the hand of the slingers, for the blows heavy on him fell<br></span>
<span class="i0">As of stones shot forth from an engine—But Parzival made reply,   <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, safe art thou from the slingers, my word is thy surety,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_120">[Pg 120]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast peace from mine hand, and I swear thee that never a sling shall break<br></span>
<span class="i0">Head, or breast, or thigh, thou art safe here, were it but for mine honour's sake!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All too soon was Klamidé wearied and spent with the deadly fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who was victor, and who was vanquished, ere long might be seen aright,<span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked on the King Klamidé, on the grass was he laid alow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival's right hand gripped him till forth streamed the crimson flow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of blood from the ears and nostrils, and the green turf was dyed with red;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his foeman unbound the helmet and visor, and bared his head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The vanquished would face the death-blow, and the victor spake, 'Here I free<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My wife for aye from thy wooing! Learn thou what Death may be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay! nay! thou gallant hero, thirty-fold doth thy glory grow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the valour thine hand hath shown here, since in strife thou hast laid me low.<br></span>
<span class="i0">What higher fame dost thou look for? Kondwiramur sure shall say<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Good Fortune hath smiled upon thee, whilst <i>I</i> am Misfortune's prey;<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy land hast thou now delivered—As when one a leaking boat<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doth free from the load of water, that it light o'er the waves may float,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So lightened am I of honour! Manly honour and joy I trow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Are waxen thin and faded, what profit to slay me <i>now</i>?<br></span>
<span class="i0">From children and children's children mine heritage shall be shame,<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To do more here methinks were needless—For joy thou hast won and fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a living death is my portion, since for ever from her I part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who fast in love's magic fetters hath held me both mind and heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Little good it forsooth hath brought me, ah! most wretched henceforth am I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this land and its lovely lady for aye in thy power shall lie!' <span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he who was here the victor on Gurnemanz' counsel thought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How mercy should well beseem him who with manhood had valiant fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought him the rede to follow; and thus to the king he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I free thee not, to the father of Liassé submission make!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, Sir Knight, I have wrought him evil, 'twas thro' me that his son was slain,<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An ill-fate wouldst thou bring upon me! The hand of thy queen to gain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_121">[Pg 121]</a></span>
<span class="i0">With Schenteflur I battled, and in sooth had I died that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save that Kingron came to my succour, and his hand did the hero slay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Gurnemanz of Graharz had sent him to Brobarz' land<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the head of a gallant army; 'twas a fair and knightly band,     <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nine hundred knights who fought well, and rode upon mail-clad steeds,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fifteen hundred footmen all armed for valiant deeds,<br></span>
