<span class="i0">For naught but shields should fail them—Too great their might I thought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the seed of such goodly harvest once more their country sought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet now hath my loss been greater! Of my heroes but few are left,  <span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What more would thine hand take from me, who of gladness am now bereft?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'An easier way I'll show thee, to Brittany shalt thou ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kingron has gone before thee, there King Arthur he doth abide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To <i>him</i> shalt thou bear my greeting, and bid him to mourn alway<br></span>
<span class="i0">The shame I bare as my portion when I rode from his court away.    <span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden who smiled upon me for my sake was smitten sore—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of all that in life e'er grieved me naught ever hath grieved me more!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that maid shalt thou tell of my sorrow; and thy pledge to her hand shalt yield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And do even as she shall bid thee—Or die here on this foughten field!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'So, if here I must choose betwixt them, not long shall my choice delay,'<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the King of Brandigan swiftly, 'From hence will I ride straightway!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his oath did he swear ere he parted whom pride had in peril brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival, the hero, for his wearied charger sought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his foot touched nor horse nor stirrup as he light to the saddle sprung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his steed the hewn shields' splinters around him in circles flung.<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the Burgers I ween were joyful—but their foemen were sad and sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For flesh and bone were wearied, and sorrow of heart they bore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they brought King Klamidé wounded to those who might give him aid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the dead on the bier they bare them, and to rest in the grave they laid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From many a guest unwelcome the land at last was freed,            <span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the gallant King Klamidé to Löver he rode with speed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now it fell at this time King Arthur and the knights of the Table Round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many another hero, at Dianasdron were found.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_122">[Pg 122]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth no lie I tell ye when I say that this plain so good<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare of tent-poles a greater number than the trees in Spessart's wood.<span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For 'twas ever the wont of King Arthur the high feast of Pentecost<br></span>
<span class="i0">To keep with his knights and vassals, and of maidens a goodly host.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There were many a noble banner, and many a warlike shield<br></span>
<span class="i0">With coat of arms emblazoned, and fair tents stood adown the field;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twould be thought of the world a marvel, who should make all the travelling gear<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For such wondrous host of ladies as those that were gathered here!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I think me that never a maiden but had counted it to her shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">If no knight mid the knights around her she might as her lover claim!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Came I myself to such gathering, an such youthful knights were there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I were loth if my wife beside me thro' such tumult were fain to fare—<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Nay, when folk thus come together far liefer were I away)<br></span>
<span class="i0">May be one might speak unto her, and some such words would say—<br></span>
<span class="i0">'With love of her was he smitten, and ne'er might he healing know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save that she herself should heal him. Yea, an but her will were so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her knight would he be for ever, to serve her his whole life long' <span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I were swift, with my wife beside me, to flee from such foolish throng!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet enough of myself have I spoken—Now hear how King Arthur's tent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might be known apart from the others; before it on gladness bent<br></span>
<span class="i0">He feasted, the king, with his vassals whose hearts never falsehood knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with many a stately maiden, whose thoughts aye to jousting flew,<span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As if with darts they sported, and their friend 'gainst the foe would aim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if ill befell their hero with sweet words to his aid they came.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the youthful King Klamidé in the ring would he bridle draw;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His steel-clad limbs and charger the wife of King Arthur saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His helmet and good shield cloven her maidens they saw right well—<span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So he came to the court, (who had sent him small need have I here to tell.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">So sprang he adown from his charger, and they thronged him on either hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere he came where she sat whom he sought for, Kunnewaaré of fair Lalande.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Art thou she, O Lady, to whom I owe service fair?<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Yet need doth in part constrain me) from the Red Knight I greeting bear,<span class="linenum">630</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_123">[Pg 123]</a></span>
<span class="i0">He willeth to take upon him the shame that thy lot hath been;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He prays that King Arthur mourn it—Thou wast smitten for him I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here, Lady, my pledge I bring thee, so my victor hath bidden me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Else my body to death were forfeit—I will do here as pleaseth thee!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the maiden Kunnewaaré by his hand led the gallant knight      <span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where Queen Guinevere was seated, she ate with her maidens bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kay uprose from the table as the tidings he needs must hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They brought gladness to Kunnewaaré, but to Kay had they wrought but fear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'What he speaketh, Lady, who thus unto thee hath sped<br></span>
<span class="i0">He speaketh perforce, yet I think me he greatly hath been misled!  <span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I thought but to teach thee better, yet for this cause thou hatest me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now bid thou this knight disarm him, for his standing o'er-long shall be.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she bade him put off his helmet and visor, the maiden true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as the bands were loosened Klamidé the king they knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kingron he looked upon him, and he saw his lord again,         <span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he wrung his hands in his anguish till as dry twigs they cracked amain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the seneschal of Klamidé, from the table he sprung straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asked of his lord the tidings; and joyless was he that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he spake, 'I am born to sorrow; I have lost such a gallant host,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man that was born of woman, I think me shall more have lost.    <span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the load of such bitter sorrow lieth heavy upon my breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And joy is to me a stranger, and gladness a fleeting guest!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And grey am I grown for the anguish she hath wrought me, Kondwiramur,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, the sorrow of Pontius Pilate, and false Judas who evermore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Must grieve for his faithless dealings, who did Christ unto death betray,<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What of punishment God layeth on them that woe would I bear alway—<br></span>
<span class="i0">If so be that the Lady of Brobarz were my wife of goodwill and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And mine arms held her fast, I had recked not what hereafter should chance to me.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, alas! for her love is withholden from the ruler of Iserterre,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my land and my folk henceforward for her sake shall sorrow bear.<span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Mine uncle's son, Mabonagrein, for her love long hath suffered pain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by knightly hand constrainèd in thy court I, O king, draw rein!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well dost thou know in my kingdom much harm have I done to thee,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_124">[Pg 124]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Forget that, true knight and faithful, from thy hate do thou set me free<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since here I abide, a captive—And this maiden my life shall shield,<span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since I stand in her sight, her servant, and my pledge to her hand would yield!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then of knightly heart King Arthur forgave him as he would pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with faithful words, and kindly, showed favour to him that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Far and wide did they tell the tidings how the King of Brandigan<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode hither, and man and maiden in thronging crowds they ran.      <span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the king he would crave a comrade, and he spake out with joyless mien,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Commend me unto Sir Gawain, if thou deemest me worth, O Queen!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Well I know that he would desire it, and if he thy word obey,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he honoureth thee, and the Red Knight shall win praise at his hand to-day.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then King Arthur he bade his nephew deal well with the captive king,<span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Tho' I wot well, without his bidding, Sir Gawain had done this thing.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the conquered knight, in whose dealings no falsehood had part or share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the vassals and gallant heroes won a welcome both fit and fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Kingron he spake in sorrow, 'Alas! that I needs must see<br></span>
<span class="i0">The day when in Breton dwellings my king shall a captive be!       <span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For richer wert thou than Arthur, and of vassals a greater host<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath served thee, nor strength was lacking, and of youth canst thou make thy boast.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall men count it to <i>Arthur's</i> honour that Kay in his wrath did smite<br></span>
<span class="i0">A princess whose heart hath shown her the wisdom to choose aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And smile upon one whom henceforward all men may with truth proclaim<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Elect to the highest honour and crown of true knightly fame?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The tree of their fame these Bretons may deem to have waxen high;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dead lay Cumberland's king, but I wot well be by no deed of theirs must die!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the fame shall be theirs that, my master, thou didst yield to that self-same knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or that I myself have been vanquished in fair and open fight;      <span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sparks sprang bright from our helmets, and our swords clave the whistling air<br></span>
<span class="i0">As for life and death we battled, and men looked on our combat fair.'<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_125">[Pg 125]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then all at the good Round Table, both rich and poor alike,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With one voice spake that Kay did evil when a maiden he thought to strike.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now will we leave their story, and fare back unto Pelrapär     <span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where Parzival reigned as monarch; the waste lands were builded fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And joy was their lot and singing, (and red gold and jewels bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Tampentäre left in the city where awhile he had reigned in might)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then rich gifts he gave till men loved him for his knightly hand and free;<br></span>
<span class="i0">New shields and costly banners the pride of his land should be,    <span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a joust and Tourney did he and his heroes ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en on the distant borders in gallant deeds he vied,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hero young and dauntless, and no foeman might e'er deny<br></span>
<span class="i0">That on battle-field or in Tourney his hand won the victory.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now of the queen would I tell ye—What lot might ye hold so fair<span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As hers, that gentle lady? In earth's joys had she fullest share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her love it might bud and blossom, nor weakness nor wavering show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the worth of her lord and husband her heart scarce might fail to know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each found their life in the other, and each was the other's love.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If, as saith the tale, they were parted, what grief must each true heart move!<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I mourn for that gentle lady, her body, her folk, her land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(So he won of her love the guerdon) had he freed with his strong right hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus courteous he spake one morning (and the knights stood their lord beside),<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, an it so please thee, give me leave that I hence may ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">And see how my mother fareth, if weal be her lot, or woe,          <span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught of all that befalls her methinks I for long may know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a short space would I go thither; and if ventures my skill approve<br></span>
<span class="i0">Therewith would I do thee service, and be worthy my lady's love.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus he spake, and the story telleth she thought not to say him 'Nay,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she deemed it well; from his vassals all lonely he took his way.<span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_126">[Pg 126]</a><br><a id="Page_127">[Pg 127]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK V<br>

ANFORTAS</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_128">[Pg 128]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>Book V. tells of the wonderful adventure of the Grail Castle; how
Parzival met with the Fisher King, and became his guest; and of the great
feast in the hall of Monsalväsch. How Parzival saw the bleeding spear,
and all the marvels of the Grail, and how be asked no question. How he
in the morning found the palace deserted, and was mocked by the squire
as he rode away. Of Parzival meeting with Siguné, and how she
reproached him for his silence. Of Orilus and Jeschuté; of the fight
between the heroes; and of Parzival's oath. How Orilus and his wife were
made friends again, and of their welcome at the court of King Arthur.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_129">[Pg 129]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK V</p>
<p class="ph2">ANFORTAS
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_n.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_n.png_1">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he who would hear what befell him who thus for ventures sought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall hearken many a marvel ere the tale to an end be wrought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let the son of Gamuret ride forth, and all ye good folk and true<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wish him well, for bitter sorrow this hero hereafter knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' honour and joy should crown him—And sorely his heart did grieve<span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That the wife he loved so dearly he now for a space must leave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the mouth never read of woman, and never hath tale been told<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a fairer wife and truer, and his heart did she captive hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his spirit so high was troubled by thoughts of his wife and queen—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had courage not been his birthright he had lost it ere this, I ween!<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O'er rock and marshy moorland, with loosened reins the steed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dashed free, the rider thought not to guide or check its speed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a truth the venture telleth, so far did he ride that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en a bird had been outwearied, and its flight were fain to stay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An the tale hath not betrayed me, no further the knight did fare    <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When Ither he slew, or from Graharz rode swift unto Pelrapär.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear ye what chanced unto him; he came at the close of day<br></span>
<span class="i0">To a water fair, and upon it many boats at anchor lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fishers were lords of the water; to the shore did they lie so near<br></span>
<span class="i0">That e'en as they saw him riding his question they well might hear. <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And one he saw in a vessel all clad in such royal pride<br></span>
<span class="i0">Scarce richer had been his vesture were he lord of the world so wide;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_130">[Pg 130]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Of peacock's plumes his head-gear—Then the knight to the Fisher spake<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he prayed him for knighthood's bidding, and he prayed him for God's dear sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To help him unto a shelter where he might thro' the night hours rest.<span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Fisher sad he answered in this wise the stranger guest;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Nay, Sir Knight, I know not for full thirty miles around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By land alike or water, where dwelling may yet be found<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save one house, I would bid thee seek it, for it lieth in sooth anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the livelong day wert thou riding none other thou findest here.<span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ride there to the high cliff's ending, then turn thee to thy right hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Until to the moat thou comest, and thy charger perforce must stand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then bid thou the castle warder to let the drawbridge fall<br></span>
<span class="i0">And open to thee the portals, then ride thou unto the hall.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he did as the Fisher bade him, and leave would he courteous pray,<span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But he quoth, 'I myself will thine host be, an thou fail not to find the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be thy thanks then as is our tendance—As thou ridest around the hill<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have a care lest the wood mislead thee, such mischance would but please me ill.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival turned his bridle, and gaily he took his way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor missed he the path till before him the moat of the castle lay;  <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the drawbridge was raised, and the fortress it lacked not for strength I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a turner with skill had wrought them stood the turrets in goodly row.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But with wings, or on winds of heaven uplifted, might ye have won<br></span>
<span class="i0">To that Burg, an a foeman stormed it little harm he methinks had done.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so strong were the towers and the palace that its folk they had held the hall<span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And mocked at the foe, if all armies thirty years long beset the wall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then a squire looked forth from the castle, of the knight was he well aware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asked whence he came? and wherefore he thought to their Burg to fare?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival spake, ''Tis the Fisher who hath bidden me ride to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With all courtesy have I thanked him for the shelter he proffered free,<span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis his will that the bridge be lowered, and I ride here the Burg within.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight thou shalt here be welcome, and thy way to the Burg shalt win<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_131">[Pg 131]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Since the Fisher so spake—And honour would we shew unto thee his guest!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the squire he let fall the drawbridge, for so was their lord's behest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So the hero came to the fortress, to a courtyard so broad and wide, <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By knightly sports untrodden—Nor oft would they Tourneys ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(By short green turf was it covered) and but seldom with banners bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">As on Abenberg's field did they ride there, as fitting for gallant knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas long since they might disport them in such pastimes of warlike skill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For sorrow lay heavy on them, and mirth it beseemed them ill.       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But little the guest should rue that, for knights both old and young,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They welcomed him with all honour, and swift to his bridle sprung.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And pages of noble breeding laid their hands on his bridle rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And others would hold his stirrup as the knight to dismount was fain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knights they prayed him enter, and they led him where he might rest,<span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with ready hands and skilful of his armour they freed the guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked on the beardless hero, and they saw his face so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake, of a truth Good Fortune and blessing should be his share.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he bade them to bring him water, and the rust-stains he washed away<br></span>
<span class="i0">From face and hands, and they saw him as the light of a second day, <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So he sat in all eyes lovely—Then a mantle rich they brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of silk of Araby fashioned, and flaw therein was there naught;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he laid it around his shoulder, that hero so fair and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the clasp did he leave unfastened, and with one voice they praised the knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Repanse de Schoie, our lady and queen, did this mantle bear,'      <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the chamberlain, 'She hath lent it while fit robes they for thee prepare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I feared not this boon to ask her since it seemeth sure to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">That a gallant man and faithful, Sir Knight, thou shalt prove to be!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'God reward thee who lookest on me with such true and trusting heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks, an thou seest rightly, Good Fortune shall be my part,     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I wot well such gifts come only from the power of God on high.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then gladly they pledged the hero, and in honour and loyalty<br></span>
<span class="i0">They who sorrowed with him were joyful; far more had they there, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than at Pelrapär, when his right hand their shelter from grief had been!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then sadly he thought, as his harness the squires on one side would bear,<span class="linenum">85</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_132">[Pg 132]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That in knightly joust and Tourney he here might find little share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then one to the host would call him, and fast came his words and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And boldly he spake to the stranger, yea, e'en as in wrath might be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his life had he nigh paid forfeit to Parzival's youthful pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he laid his hand to his sword-hilt—When he found it not by his side<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he clenched his fist so tightly that the clasp rung the blood-drops red<br></span>
<span class="i0">From beneath his nails, and crimson to the sleeve of his robe they spread.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay, nay,' quoth the knights, 'be not wrathful, for fain would he make us smile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hath licence to jest, and with jesting our sadness would he beguile.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Show thy courtesy here towards him, nor be wroth for a foolish word,<span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That the Fisher hath come to the castle, naught else shalt thou here have heard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now do thou to our lord betake thee, here art thou an honoured guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the load of thy heavy anger be banished from off thy breast.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the palace hall they gat them, where a hundred crowns hung low<br></span>
<span class="i0">With many a taper laden; round the walls shone the tapers' glow.   <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And beneath stood a hundred couches, with a hundred cushions fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each of these goodly couches four knights should between them share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And betwixt each twain of the couches an open space was found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And before each there lay a carpet of cunning work fashioned round.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thereto had he wealth in plenty, King Frimutel's son and heir:     <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And one thing had they not forgotten, nor their gold did they think to spare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For within the hall were builded three hearths of marble rare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With skill and wisdom fashioned, and each hearth stood four-square,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the wood was Lignum aloe, and so great a fire, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ne'er hath burnt on the hearth at Wildberg—Such things have aye costly been.<span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the host had bid them lay him on a costly folding bed<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Fore the central hearth; and gladness from before his face had fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his life was but a dying—Parzival the hero fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the hall found kindly welcome from him who had sent him there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his host bade him stand no longer, but be seated his couch anear,<span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, here by my side, didst thou seat thee yet further from me, I fear<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_133">[Pg 133]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Twere treating thee as a stranger'—In this wise to his gallant guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the host thus rich in sorrow, whose heart was by grief opprest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the host he craved thro' his sickness great fires, and warm robes would wear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both wide and long, and with sable were they lined and garnished fair.<span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the poorest skin was costly, and black was its hue and grey;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a cap of the self-same fashioned he wore on his head that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas within and without of sable, with bands of Arabian gold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wrought around, and a flashing ruby in the centre might all behold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now many brave knights they sat there, and grief passed their face before,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For a squire sprang swift thro' the doorway, and a lance in his hand he bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And thus did he wake their weeping) from the point did the blood run fast<br></span>
<span class="i0">Adown to the hand of the holder till 'twas lost in his sleeve at last.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then thro' the lofty palace was weeping and wailing sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk of thirty kingdoms could scarce have bemoaned them more.  <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus to each of the four walls with the lance in his hand he drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he reached once again the doorway, and passed him the portal thro'.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stilled was the lamentation, and the grief that this folk must know<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the squire bare the lance before them, and thus bade them to think on woe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">(An here ye be not outwearied I gladly would tell the tale,        <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How the feast in this Burg was ordered, for in courtesy naught did fail.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At the end of the hall a doorway of steel did they open fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two noble children entered—Now hearken what guise they bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An a knight for love would serve them, with love they his task might pay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two fair and gracious maidens as e'er man might woo were they.     <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And each wore on her hair loose flowing, a chaplet of blossoms bound<br></span>
<span class="i0">With silken band, beneath it their tresses sought the ground.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hand of each maiden carried a candlestick all of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And every golden socket did a burning taper hold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor would I forget the raiment these gentle maidens ware,          <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For one was Tenabroc's countess, ruddy-brown was her robe so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the self-same garb wore the maiden who beside the countess paced,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with girdles rich and costly were they girt round each slender waist.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And behind them there came a Duchess and her fellow; of ivory white<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_134">[Pg 134]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Two stools they bare, and glowing their lips e'en as fire is bright.<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they bowed, the four, and bending, the stools 'fore the host they laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor was aught to their service lacking, but fitly their part they played.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they stood all four together, and their faces were fair to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the vesture of each fair maiden was like to the other three.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now see how they followed swiftly, fair maidens twice told four,   <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And this was I ween their office, four tapers tall they bore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the others deemed too heavy the weight of a precious stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by day the sun shone thro' it, and as Jacinth its name is known.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas long and broad, and for lightness had they fashioned it fair and meet<br></span>
<span class="i0">To serve at will for a table where a wealthy host might eat.       <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And straight to the host they stepped them, and they bowed their fair heads low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And four laid the costly table on the ivory white as snow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The stools they had placed aforetime—and courteous they turned aside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there by their four companions stood the eight in their maiden pride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And green were the robes of these maidens, green as grass in the month of May,<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Samite in Assagog woven, and long and wide were they.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the waist were they girt with a girdle, narrow, and long, and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each of these gentle maidens ware a wreath on her shining hair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Iwan, the Count of Nonel, and Jernis, the lord of Reil,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the Grail were their daughters summoned from many a distant mile.<span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they came, these two princesses, in raiment wondrous fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two keen-edged knives, a marvel, on cloths did those maidens bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of silver white and shining were they wrought with such cunning skill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so sharp, that methinks their edges e'en steel might they cut at will.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And maidens four went before them, for this should their office be <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To bear lights before the silver; four children from falsehood free.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Six maidens in all they entered and took thro' the hall their way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now hearken, and I will tell ye the service they did that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They bowed, and the twain who carried the silver they laid it low<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the Jacinth, and courteous turning to the first twelve in order go.<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_135">[Pg 135]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And now, have I counted rightly, here shall eighteen maidens stand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And lo! see six more come hither in vesture from distant lands,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Half their robes were of silk, gold inwoven, half of silk of Nineveh bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For both they and the six before them, parti-coloured their robes of light.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And last of those maids a maiden, o'er the others was she the queen,<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So fair her face that they thought them 'twas the morning's dawn, I ween!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they saw her clad in raiment of Pfellel of Araby,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she bare aloft on a cushion of verdant Achmardi<br></span>
<span class="i0">Root and blossom of Paradise garden, that thing which men call 'The Grail,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">The crown of all earthly wishes, fair fulness that ne'er shall fail!<span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Repanse de Schoie did they call her, in whose hands the Grail might lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the Grail Itself elected was she to this office high.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they who would here do service, those maids must be pure of heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And true in life, nor falsehood shall have in their dealings part.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And lights both rare and costly before the Grail they bore         <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Six glasses tall, transparent—and wondrous balsam's store<br></span>
<span class="i0">Burnt within with a strange sweet perfume; with measured steps they came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen bowed low with the maidens who bare the balsam's flame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then this maiden free from falsehood, the Grail on the Jacinth laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival looked upon her, and thought of the royal maid        <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Elect to such high office, whose mantle he needs must wear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the seven courteous turned them to the eighteen maidens fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the noblest they placed in the centre, and twelve on either side<br></span>
<span class="i0">They stood, but the crownèd maiden no beauty with hers had vied!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And as many knights as were seated around that palace hall,        <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So to each four was there a server, with golden beaker tall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a page so fair to look on who bare a napkin white—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Riches enow, I trow me, had ye seen in the hall that night!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they bare there a hundred tables, at each table four knights would eat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And swiftly they spread them over with coverings fair and meet.    <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The host himself took water, and heavy at heart was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival, too, he washed him, for so should the custom be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A silken towel, bright coloured, a count's son would proffer fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Swift to the guest he gat him, and knelt low before him there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wherever there stood a table there four squires were ready dight<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_136">[Pg 136]</a></span>
<span class="i0">To serve the four who sat there, and their service they knew aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For twain would carve, low kneeling, and twain to the knights would bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of food and drink as needful, and thus for their wants would care.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hearken ye greater riches—on wheelèd cars were rolled<br></span>
<span class="i0">To every knight in order, fair vessels of wroughten gold,          <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And four knights set them on the tables, and with each ye a steward might see<br></span>
<span class="i0">To aid them, and claim the vessels when the feast at an end should be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hearken another marvel—to a hundred squires they spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they bade them in fair white napkins the bread from the Grail to take.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway they went, and to each knight at each table the bread they bare;<span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As I heard so I tell unto ye, and the truth ye, each one, shall swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas the Grail Itself that fed them, and before the Grail did stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">What of food or drink desiring, each one might stretch forth his hand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Would I here betray another then in sooth ye shall lie with me)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Food warm or cold, or dishes that known or unknown shall be,       <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Food wild or tame—Such riches ye never on earth shall find,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So many have said, yet I think me that folly doth rule their mind—<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the Grail was the crown of blessing, the fulness of earth's delight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Its joys I right well may liken to the glories of Heaven's height!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they brought in small golden vessels that which every man should need<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of sauces, or salt, or pepper—would one sparely or fully feed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet each found enough—and courteous they bare to each noble guest;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And red wine and sweet drinks luscious, each one as he liked him best<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might speak the word, and proffer the cup, and behold! 'twas filled<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the power of the Grail—Thus the hunger of that gallant host was stilled,<span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail Itself sustained them, and Parzival wondering saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">The riches and mighty marvels, yet to question his host forbore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he thought, 'Gurnemanz he bade me, in truth, without thought of guile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To withhold my lips from question—If here I abide awhile<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks it will then befall me as aforetime in Graharz land,      <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They will tell me, without my question, how here with this folk it stands.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then e'en as he sat thus musing came a squire who a sword did bear,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_137">[Pg 137]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And its sheath was a thousand marks' worth, and its hilt was a ruby rare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the blade, it might well work wonders—Then the host gave it to the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'I full oft have borne it in many a deadly fight     <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere God's Hand thus sorely smote me; now with this shalt thou be repaid<br></span>
<span class="i0">If aught hath in care been lacking—Henceforth shalt thou bear this blade<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whatever chance befall thee, and when thou its power hast tried<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wilt know thou art fully armèd, whatever strife betide.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ah! woe to the guest that asked not, I am sorrowful for his sake,  <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When his hand clasped the sword 'twas a token that his silence he well might break.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the host too my heart is heavy, thus tortured by nameless woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a question therefrom had freed him, yet to question his guest was slow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But now the feast was ended, who the vessels hither bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Again to their task they turn them, and they bear them forth once more.<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The cars again they circle; each maid to her task was fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">From last to first; the noblest she turned to the Grail again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To host and guest all-courteous the queen and her maidens bend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What they brought they once more would bear forth thro' the door at the high hall's end.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Parzival he gazed after, and lo! thro' the open door           <span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Within an outer chamber, on a folding couch he saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fairest of old men ancient whom ever his eyes had seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Grey was he as mists of morning—Nor o'er rash is the tale, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who he was shalt thou know hereafter, when a fitting time shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The host, his Burg, and his kingdom, yea, all will I name to ye,   <span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all shall be clear and in order, no halting my tale shall know;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks that I then shall show ye the bowstring without the bow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Tis a symbol good, the bowstring, for swift as ye deem the bow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the shaft that the bowstring speedeth findeth swifter its aim, I trow!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And not without thought I said it, for the string, it seemeth me,  <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Is like to the simple story wherewith men well-pleased shall be;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_138">[Pg 138]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For it goeth straight to its ending, while he who aside shall stray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' his goal at last he reacheth findeth all too long his way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When unbent the bow thou sawest, then straight was, I ween, the string,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the straight line thou erst must draw it, ere the shaft to its goal may wing.<span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But he who his story aimeth at the ear of a fool shall find<br></span>
<span class="i0">His shaft go astray, for no dwelling it findeth within his mind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too wide is the road, I think me, and that which he chance to hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet he may know the meaning flies out at the other ear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far rather at home I 'ld bide me than in such ears my story tell,  <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A beast, or a stock, I think me, as a hearer would serve as well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But further I fain would tell ye of this people so full of woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">To whom he had come, our hero, glad song might they seldom know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or sound of dance or of Tourney; so heavy were they at heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">That never a thought of gladness might find in their life a part,  <span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And oft shall the folk be fewer yet of joy shall have fuller share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But here every nook was crowded, nor space in the court to spare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The host to his guest spake kindly, 'Methinks they thy couch have spread,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou weary? then list my counsel, and get thee, my guest, to bed.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Now here might I raise my war-cry at the parting betwixt the twain,<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For I wot well that bitter sorrow each must from the venture gain.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the side of his host he stepped him, Parzival the fair of face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Fisher a fair night wished him—Then the knights stepped each from his place,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a part drew near towards him, and they led the stranger guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">Straightway to a sleeping chamber, and goodly should be his rest.  <span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas richly decked for his honour, and the couch it was spread so fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">That my poverty sorely grieves me since the earth doth such riches bear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And that bed knew, I ween, no lacking, and a rich silk above it lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bright-coloured its hue, and glowing as tho' fire-light did on it play;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival prayed the heroes to get them again to rest,         <span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he saw there but one couch only, and they passed hence at his behest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But he lacked not for other service—His fair face and tapers light<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gave challenge unto each other—What day e'er might shine so bright?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And before his couch was another, thereon would he take his seat<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_139">[Pg 139]</a></span>
<span class="i0">While pages drew them nearer, and proffered him service meet.      <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they bared his white feet comely, and they laid his robes aside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of noble birth were these children, and fair in their youthful pride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then there passed thro' the open doorway four maidens fair and bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They would know if they well had served him, and if soft lay the stranger knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so the venture telleth, a squire a taper bare                  <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Before each gentle maiden—Parzival, that hero fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sprang swift to his couch; then the maidens with gentle voice they spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight, we fain would pray thee for our sake awhile to wake'—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet as children sport with each other had he hidden him from their sight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet they might hear his greeting, yet their eyes had found swift delight,<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And their heart's desire was quickened at the sight of his red lips' glow<br></span>
<span class="i0">That for youth were as yet unhidden, for no hair did upon them grow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear what they bare, these maidens, three in their hands so white<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brought syrups sweet, and red wine, and the fourth, that maiden bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bare fruit that e'erwhile had ripened in the garden of Paradise    <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On a cloth fair and white, and she knelt low before him that maiden wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade her sit, but she answered, 'Nay, Sir Knight, so is it best<br></span>
<span class="i0">For else were I sure unworthy to serve such a gallant guest.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he drank and would eat a little, and he spake to them soft and sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he laid him adown, and the maidens craved leave of him as was meet.<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then down on the costly carpet the squires set the tapers bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">When they saw that he slept, and swiftly they gat from the gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Parzival lay not lonely, for until the dawn of day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Heart-sorrow would lie beside him, nor passed with the dawn away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And every coming anguish its heralds before would speed,           <span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en so that the fair youth's vision out-weighed e'en his mother's need<br></span>
<span class="i0">When she dreamed ere the death of her husband. As a carpet unrolled his dream,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The centre of fair jousts woven, while the edge was with swords agleam.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in slumber his foemen pressed him, and would swiftly upon him ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So fearful his dream that, wakened, thirty times had he rather died.<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus fear and unrest awoke him, and the sweat streamed from every limb;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_140">[Pg 140]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The daylight shone fair thro' the windows, yet no voice had called on him.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'Where are now the pages, who stood before me of late?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who shall hand unto me my garments?' Then awhile would he patient wait<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till slumber again o'ercame him; none spake, none aloud would cry, <span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Vanished the folk—When he wakened the noon-tide sun was high.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he sprang up, and lo! before him on the carpet his harness lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two swords, his host's gift, and the other from Prince Ither he bare away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spake to himself, 'Now wherefore was this done? I these arms will take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In sleep I such anguish suffered, methinks that I surely wake      <span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To-day to some task of knighthood—If mine host doth some foeman fear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his will will I do right gladly, and faithful her prayer will hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who of true heart this mantle lent me—If my service she think to take<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I were for such service joyful; yet not for her sweet love's sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my wife hath a face as lovely as ever this castle's queen,     <span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay more, an the truth be spoken she is fairer far I ween!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he did e'en as seemed him fitting, and he armed himself for fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">From foot to head, and beside him he girded those swords of might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then forth went the gallant hero, and his steed to the palace stair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was bound, shield and spear stood by it, and he joyed as he found them there.<span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then ere Parzival, the hero, his charger would mount again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He sought thro' many a chamber, and he called on the folk amain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But none might he see or hearken, and it vexed the knight full sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wrathful he grew—Yet seeking, the hero he came once more<br></span>
<span class="i0">To where he at eve dismounted when first he the castle found,      <span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the earth and grass were trampled, and the dew brushed from off the ground.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then, shouting, he turned, the young knight, once more to his charger good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with bitter words he mounted—Wide open the gateway stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the track led across the threshold; nor longer he thought to stay<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he turned his rein, and swiftly to the drawbridge he made his way,<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_141">[Pg 141]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But a hidden hand drew the rope taut, and the forepart it rose on high<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well-nigh had his charger fallen, then he turned him right speedily<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would he ask the meaning, but the squire cried aloud in scorn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Goose that thou art, ride onward, to the sun's hate hast thou been born!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy mouth hadst thou thought to open, of these wonders hadst asked thine host,<span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Great fame had been thine—But I tell thee now hast thou this fair chance lost!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the guest cried aloud for his meaning, but answer he ne'er might win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the squire made as if he slumbered, and the portal he barred within.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too early for peace his parting, and the hour it hath brought him woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he payeth in joy the tribute, nor longer may gladness know;    <span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And doubled the throw of sorrow since here he had found the Grail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his eyes, not his hand, had he cast it, and dice to the throw should fail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If by grief he be now awakened such was never his wont of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught had he known but gladness, nor sorrow of heart he bore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">On the track that he saw before him would Parzival ride apace,     <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought, 'They who go before me to-day will a foeman face<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fight for their master's honour; an they knew it, their ring of might<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks would be little weakened if I in their ranks should fight!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would waver not, but would aid them whate'er be their need to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus my bread would I earn, and this fair sword, the gift of my host, repay,<span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Undeserved as yet do I bear it—Sure they hold me for coward knight!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he turned him, the free from falsehood, where the hoof-tracks still met his sight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And sorely I rue his parting—Now the venture doth grow apace,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">They had parted who rode before him, and their track he might scarcely trace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What aforetime was broad waxed narrow till he lost it nor found it more<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And tidings he heard, the hero, that wrought to him sorrow sore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For the young knight, rich in courage, heard a woman's voice make moan.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(On the grass lay the dew of morning.) On a linden there sat alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden, whose truth wrought her sorrow, for between her arms so white<br></span>
<span class="i0">Embalmed did she lifeless hold him who living had been her knight. <span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Were there one who saw her sorrow and mourned not for her bitter woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then false of heart must I hold him, one who true love might never know!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he turned his steed towards her, tho' as yet unknown was she,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_142">[Pg 142]</a></span>
<span class="i0">(Tho' the child of his mother's sister)—As the wind that fleeteth free<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is all earthly faith to her true love—Then Parzival greeting spake,<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, methinks that sorrow I must bear for thy sorrow's sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou needst in aught my service, would it free thee from further ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then look thou on me as thy servant, thy grief were I fain to still!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sadly her thanks she bade him, and asked him, 'Whence camest thou here?<br></span>
<span class="i0">He were ill-advised who his journey should take thro' this woodland drear.<span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To them who know not its pathways great evil might here betide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, oft have I seen and hearkened how men in this wood have died,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For death was in strife their portion—Turn hence then, thou gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou lovest life—Yet tell me in what shelter didst pass the night?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'But a mile from here stands a castle, there I thro' the night abode,<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And naught have I seen like its riches, from thence in short space I rode.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the maiden she looked upon him, and she spake, 'Now, methinks, 'twere ill<br></span>
<span class="i0">With falsehood to thus betray them who trust thee with right goodwill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From thy shield art thou here a stranger, and canst naught but woods have found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An here thou hast ta'en thy journey from planted and builded ground,<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thirty miles round have they never, for a dwelling, hewn wood or stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save but for one Burg, in this region that Burg it doth stand alone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis rich in all earthly riches, yet he who that castle fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would seek, he may never find it, tho' many that quest shall dare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unawares must they chance upon it, for I wot in no other wise      <span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall that Burg and all that it holdeth be looked on by mortal eyes.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight, <i>thou</i> hast never seen it; Monsalväsch I ween its name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Terre de Salväsch the kingdom where its lord the crown may claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Titurel once bequeathed it to his son King Frimutel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So they called him, the dauntless hero; much fame to his portion fell,<span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a joust was he slain at Love's bidding, and four children fair he left,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And three, they have store of riches, yet are they of joy bereft.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And poor is the fourth, for penance hath he chosen this lot I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Trevrezent is his name—Anfortas, his brother, hath grief enow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He can neither stand, nor be seated, nor walk, but must aye recline,<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">At Monsalväsch he hath his dwelling, the head of that noble line.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she spake, 'If indeed thou camest to that folk who so sore doth mourn<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_143">[Pg 143]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then perchance is their king releasèd from the burden he long hath borne?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Out spake the Waleis, 'I saw truly great marvels, and many a maid<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of beauty rare'—she knew him by his voice ere the words were said.<span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Now indeed I know thee, for in sooth art thou Parzival!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Didst thou see the mournful monarch? Didst thou see the wondrous Grail?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! tell me the joyful tidings, may his woe at last be stilled?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Well is thee that the blessèd journey thou hast ta'en, now shall earth be filled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As far as the winds of heaven may blow, with thy fair renown;      <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Naught on earth but shall do thee service, fulfilment each wish shall crown!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival spake in wonder, 'Say, Lady, whence knowest thou me?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she answered, 'I am that maiden who erewhile made her plaint to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am she who thy name first told thee, near of kin to that gracious queen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy mother, of all earth's blossoms the fairest flower, I ween,    <span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' a flower that the dew ne'er nourished! May God reward thee well<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who didst truly mourn my hero who in knightly combat fell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">See, here in my arms I hold him, now think thou upon the woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">God hath laid for his sake upon me who too short a life must know;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rich was he in all manly virtues, his death it has wrought me pain,<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And day by day as it dawneth reneweth my plaint again!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Alas! is it thou, Siguné? Say, where are thy lips so red<br></span>
<span class="i0">That gave me to wit so truly who I was? From thy youthful head<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have thy locks so brown and waving been shorn since I saw thee last;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then wert thou still fair to look on, tho' sorrow might hold thee fast,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now pale art thou waxed and feeble, such friendship, methinks with woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had vexed me too much, hear my counsel, and bury this dead knight low!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Great tears bedewed her garments, for ne'er to that maiden fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had any given such counsel as Lunete to her lady bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(This rede did she give to her lady, 'Let him live who thy lord hath slain,<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt in his love hereafter amends for thy sorrow gain.')<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not such was the will of Siguné, as maidens of wavering mind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(On their names I had best keep silence) here the tale of true love ye'll find.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she spake, 'If joy e'er befall me that shall be when I know relief<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_144">[Pg 144]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Is his, who so long hath suffered, when is lightened his load of grief.<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If thro' <i>thee</i> he hath found this succour then in truth shall all praise be thine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinketh e'en now at thy girdle do I see his sword to shine—<br></span>
<span class="i0">If its magic spell thou knowest then to strife mayest thou fearless fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For its edge is keen—Its maker a noble name doth bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Trebuchet's hand hath wrought it; by Karnant there flows a spring, <span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And '<i>Lac</i>' from the name of that streamlet methinks is he named, the king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sword will withstand the first blow, at the next it will break in twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou to these waters bring it from their flow 'twill be whole again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet where at its source the streamlet flows forth from its rocky bed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shalt thou seek those healing waters ere the sun stand high overhead.<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0"><i>Lac</i> is the name of that fountain—If unsplintered shall be the blade<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then press thou its halves together, from the waters shall it be made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not whole alone, but stronger the blade and the edge shall grow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor their brightness and fair adorning be dimmed by the water's flow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet a spell thou first must master, ere thou draw that sword of might,<span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast left it behind, I fear me! Hast thou learnt its words aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in truth all earthly blessings shall blossom and bear for thee—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Believe me, dear my cousin, what of marvels thou there couldst see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To thine hand shall they all do service; the crown of blessings fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Uplifted o'er all earth's noblest henceforward thine head shall bear.<span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thine is desire's fulfilment, and none with thy wealth and might<br></span>
<span class="i0">May measure himself, if the question hath won at thy lips its right!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Nay, I asked no question!' 'Alas I' cried the mournful maid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'That ever mine eyes have seen thee, who to question wast sore afraid!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such marvels they there have shown thee, yet no word might they win from thee,<span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When thou sawest the Grail, and those maidens who serve It, from falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair Garschiloie, and yet fairer Repanse de Schoie the queen.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast seen the knives of silver, thou the bleeding spear hast seen—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! wherefore hast thou sought me? Dishonoured, accurst art thou<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who bearest wolf's fang empoisoned! And deep in thine heart I trow <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Is it rooted, the plant of falsehood, and afresh doth it ever spring!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shouldst have had pity on him, Anfortas, their host and king,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_145">[Pg 145]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And have asked of his bitter sorrow, on whom God hath a wonder sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now thou livest, and yet I tell thee to bliss art thou henceforth dead!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'Nay, gentle cousin, show kindness to me I pray,    <span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If in aught I have sinned, repentance my sin sure shall put away!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Little good may repentance do thee,' quoth the maiden, 'for well I know<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thy knightly fame and honour at Monsalväsch were laid alow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a further answer or word shalt thou win from me.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival turned his bridle and left her right mournfully.     <span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">That his lips were so slow to question when he sat by the mournful king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the heart of the gallant hero must sorrow and rueing bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus thro' his heavy trouble, and the heat of the summer's day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great sweat-drops stood on his forehead as he rode on his lonely way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the sake of the air he loosened his helmet and visor band,     <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his face shone fair thro' the iron-rust as he carried them in his hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he saw a fresh track, and before him short space did two horses fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A war-horse was one, well harnessed, but unshod was, I ween, the mare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it bare on its back a woman—Behind her he took his way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he looked on her steed, to hunger o'er-long had it been a prey;<span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' its skin might its ribs be counted, a halter of hemp its rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Its colour was white as an ermine, to the hoofs hung the untrimmed mane;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The eyeballs were sunk in the sockets, the hollows were deep and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween that this lady's palfrey by famine had oft been tried.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas lean and dry as touchwood, 'twas a marvel it yet could go,   <span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For little should she who rode it of the care of a charger know.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Narrow and poor the trappings that lay on that charger's back,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The saddle and bells were shattered, and much did the harness lack;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lady was sad, not joyful, and her girth was a hempen cord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, I ween, was her birth too noble in such guise to ride abroad. <span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By twigs and thorny branches tattered her shift and torn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the rags had she knit together where'er it had been out-worn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But beneath her skin gleamed spotless, white as the swan's white wing;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And naught but rags was her clothing—where they might some shelter bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">There her skin was fair to look on, but elsewhere 'twas by sunburn dyed.<span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet her lips were red, tho' sorrow and want she must long abide,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_146">[Pg 146]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And so glowing and bright their colour a fire had ye kindled there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And where-e'er one would ride beside her on that side had ye found her bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet of base degree to hold her were to do her a wrong, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' little had she upon her, yet guiltless she aye had been—     <span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Of your courtesy shall ye heed me, she forgot not her womanhood)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of her poverty have I told ye, yet wherefore? If ye deem good<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then this will I say, that ragged and bare I this dame would take<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er many a well-clad maiden, were it fitting my choice to make.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As Parzival bade her greeting, she saw him, and red she grew,      <span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of all men was he the fairest, small marvel his face she knew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she quoth, 'Once before have I seen thee, great grief have I won thro' thee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">God grant to thee greater honour than thou hast deserved from me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far other hath been my raiment when thou sawest me last, I wot,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hadst thou ne'er in that hour come near me then honour were still my lot!'<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'Now bethink thee, Lady, who thus should thy hatred claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For never my hand, I think me, hath brought to a woman shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(So had I <i>myself</i> dishonoured) since ever I bare a shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or thought upon deeds of knighthood, or hath striven in battle-field;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet else am I sad for thy sorrow!' Then forth brake the tear-drops bright,<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ran fast adown her bosom, and over her breasts so white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So fair, and so softly moulded, that never might turner's skill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' swiftly he wrought and rounded, his task in such wise fulfil.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so lovely was she in her sorrow his heart was to pity fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with hands and arms a cover from his glance did she strive to gain.<span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival spake, 'Now, Lady, of true service from mocking free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In God's Name take thou here my surcoat, a covering 'twill be for thee.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, Sir Knight, I may never take it, e'en tho' bliss I thereby should gain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ride swift on thy way, I pray thee, an thou wouldst not we both were slain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' my death it would little grieve me, if I fear me, 'tis for thy sake!'<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Say, Lady, who thus would wrong us? Who thinketh our life to take?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas God's hand that gave it to us—Nay, were they an armèd host<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who here for our life were thirsting, I would face them nor fear the cost!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she spake, ''Tis a dauntless hero, so gallant in strife is he<br></span>
<span class="i0">That heavy would be their labour if <i>six</i> should his foemen be;<span class="linenum">570</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_147">[Pg 147]</a></span>
<span class="i0">(I would thou wert not beside me) I aforetime his wife had been,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet so poor am I now and wretched, for his slave were I all too mean,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus his wrath doth he wreak upon me.' To that lady he spake again,<br></span>
