<span class="i0">'Say, who rideth here with thy husband? For if I to fly were fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As here thou dost give me counsel, thyself sure wouldst deem it ill,<span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere of flight I have learnt the lesson I would die with a right good will!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the Duchess sadly, 'Alone with my lord I fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But yet that may little serve thee, nor shall victory be here thy share.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in rags was all her vesture, and naught but the hem untorn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the crown of woman's honour in her poverty had she worn,       <span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her ways were ways of goodness, and falsehood afar had fled—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he bound afresh his visor and the helmet upon his head<br></span>
<span class="i0">As one who to battle rideth—Then his charger aloft would rear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It was 'ware of the steed beside it, and its neigh rang out loud and clear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who a space before them on the woodland way would ride,     <span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He hearkened the sound, and would see him who rode there by his lady's side.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he turned his bridle wrathful by the side of the narrow way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with lance in rest for jousting Duke Orilus rode that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And manly, I ween, his bearing, from Gaheviess came his spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And weapon alike and harness of one colour were blazoned clear.    <span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His helmet, Trebuchet wrought it; the shield in distant Spain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was welded fair for the hero, King Kailet in that land doth reign,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strong were the rim and the centre—In Alexandria's city fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was the costly pfellel woven that for surcoat and coat he ware.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The covering of his charger at Tenabroc was it made                <span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of rings of steel close welded—And thus he his pride displayed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For over the iron cover lay a pfellel so fair to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all men who saw bare witness that costly its worth must be—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gorget, and greaves, and headgear, tho' rich, yet their weight was light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a plate of iron it guarded this gallant knight;           <span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In Beàlzenan was it fashioned, chief city of fair Anjou.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(But she who rode bare behind him far other her garb to view,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth might she find none better) from Soissons his breastplate came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he won his gallant charger from the far-off lake Brimbane,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_148">[Pg 148]</a></span>
<span class="i0">In the mountains of Monsalväsch—Lähelein, his brother bold,       <span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a joust o'erthrew the rider, and the steed as his prize would hold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Parzival too was ready—his charger in onward flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst Orilus of Lalande bare swiftly the gallant knight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw on his shield a dragon, yea, e'en as it were alive,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And another upon the helmet fast bounden did upward strive.        <span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many small golden dragons on surcoat and robe he bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Enriched with many a jewel, and with red eyes of ruby fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From afar would they make their onslaught, these dauntless heroes twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No need to renounce their friendship, nor thro' kinship from strife refrain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Aloft flew the spears in splinters—Methinks I might vaunt me well <span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If I such a joust had witnessed as here in this wood befell!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus they rode at swiftest gallop not one joust alone, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Jeschuté at heart bare witness fairer jousting she ne'er had seen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So she stood, and her hands she wrung them, this lady of joy bereft,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor harm did she wish to either, that one should be lifeless left. <span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In sweat were they bathed, the chargers, and the knights they strove for fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sparks sprang bright from the sword-blades, and forth from the helm flashed flame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the blows fell fierce and mighty, and far flashed the light of strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">None were better than they in battle, and they met here for death or life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' willing and swift the chargers that the heroes would here bestride,<span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They forgot not their spurs, and their sword-blades bright-glancing they deftly plied.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival won him honour, for here hath he rightly shown<br></span>
<span class="i0">How before a hundred dragons one man well might hold his own.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And ill did it fare with one dragon, and sore were its wounds that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas the crest that aloft in glory on Orilus' helmet lay,         <span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And so clear that the light shone thro' them were the costly jewels bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">That fell when the helm was smitten by Parzival's sword of might;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas on horse, not afoot, that they fought thus—The love of her angry lord<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was won back again for Jeschuté by the play of the glittering sword.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they dashed again on each other so close that they smote away,<span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With their knees, the rings of iron—So valiant in strife were they!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will tell ye why one was wrathful; that his lady of royal race<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_149">[Pg 149]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Ere this had been shamed; her guardian, from him might she look for grace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he deemed that with wandering fancy her heart from her lord had strayed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that she, in the love of another, her honour had lowly laid.   <span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he would for such wrong have vengeance, and his judgment on her was done<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise, save were <i>death</i> her portion no woman such woe had won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet she in naught had wronged him—If his favour he would withhold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What man e'er might think to hinder? For ever from days of old<br></span>
<span class="i0">The man hath power o'er the woman, the husband shall rule the wife.<span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet Parzival the hero, he thought him to win with strife<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Jeschuté her husband's favour—Methinks one should pray such grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">In courteous wise, but flattery it here found but little place.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And both they were right, I think me—He who ruleth the ways of life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or straight they may be or crooked, 'twas His so to rule their strife<span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That never to one nor the other the joust death for guerdon brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Harm enow had they done to each other the while they so fiercely fought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hotter it waxed, the conflict, each hero would fain defend<br></span>
<span class="i0">His knightly fame 'gainst the other; Duke Orilus of Lalande,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He fought with the skill and cunning his hand had learnt of yore,  <span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For I ween none like him had battled—he had courage and strength in war,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefore had he been victor on many a foughten field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' other were here the ending—His foe would he force to yield;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he threw his arms around him, the hero so proud and bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Parzival, little daunted, on his foeman made good his hold,    <span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he drew him from off his saddle; as a sheaf from the field ye reap<br></span>
<span class="i0">So beneath his arm he swung him, and light from his horse did leap.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er a fallen tree he held him, for here was he overthrown<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who never of need or peril such fortune before had known.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now do penance for this thine anger that hath wrought to thy lady woe,<span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An thy favour be yet withholden, then death shalt thou surely know!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, nay, not so swift,' quoth his foeman, Duke Orilus of Lalande,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tho' o'erthrown, I am not so vanquished that I may not thy will withstand!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival, strong and valiant, his foeman he gripped amain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And forth thro' the visor gushing streamed the blood in a crimson rain,<span class="linenum">670</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_150">[Pg 150]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince, I ween, was vanquished, he could win from him what he would,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To die was he all unwilling, and he spake to the hero good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! thou bold knight dauntless, who evil on me hath sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say how have I earned this peril, to lie here before thee, dead?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival quoth, 'Right gladly, Sir Knight, will I let thee live,<span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If favour and love to thy lady thou swearest again to give!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'That I will not! Her sin against me I trow all too great shall be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rich in honour she was; she hath injured herself, and she plungeth me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her lord, in yet deeper sorrow. In all else thy will I'll heed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou thinkest my life to leave me—'Twas God gave it me indeed, <span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now thine hand is become His servant, to give it to me anew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I to thy valour owe it'—In this wise spake the hero true:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'For my life will I give fair ransom, for kingdoms twain, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My brother with might hath won him, of riches he hath enow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt ask as it best may please thee: if from death thou wilt set me free,<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He loveth me, and will loose me whatever the cost may be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my Dukedom again as thy vassal will I take from thy valiant hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy fame it shall gain new lustre, since I might not thy power withstand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now release me, thou hero dauntless, from forgiveness of her, my wife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whatever shall be for thine honour, by that will I buy my life,    <span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But with her, my dishonoured Duchess, at peace will I never be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, not for all pain or sorrow that shall otherwise fall to me!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Folk or kingdoms, or riches or jewels rare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All these they shall nothing profit—Thy pledge thou to me shalt swear<br></span>
<span class="i0">In naught to delay thy journey, but to haste thee to Brittany      <span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where dwelleth a gentle maiden—One hath smitten her sore for me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I will on that man have vengeance, an his safety she shall not pray—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy pledge and my loyal service bear thou to that maid straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or here, without fail, I slay thee—To King Arthur and to his queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To both shalt thou bear my greeting; well paid hath my service been,<span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If they for that blow ill-smitten the maiden do well entreat.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But first will I see that thou givest to this lady thine homage meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that without guile—Dost withstand me, and thinkest my will to dare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On a bier, and no more on a charger, from hence shalt thou lifeless fare!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now mark thou my words, for their doing a pledge shalt thou straightway give,<span class="linenum">705</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_151">[Pg 151]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And thy surety swear unto me, if longer thou fain wouldst live!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">To King Parzival spake his foeman, Duke Orilus, 'Helpeth naught<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst this thy will, I will do it, for fain I my life had bought!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the fear for the life of her husband Jeschuté, that lady fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mourned sore for his woe, yet the foemen to part might she little dare.<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival bade him rise up, and speak to his lady bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">The words of peace and of pardon; and thus quoth the vanquished knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, since this my shaming in strife hath been for thy sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So be it, the kiss of forgiveness from my lips shalt thou herewith take.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' thee have I lost much honour—What boots it? I pardon sware!'<span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then swift from her steed on the meadow sprang the lady with white limbs bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the blood that ran from his nostrils had dyed his mouth with red,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet she kissed him e'en as he bade her, so was Parzival's bidding sped.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the three rode on together till a hermit's cell they saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the rocky wall, and our hero his bridle was fain to draw;       <span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he saw there a shrine so holy, and a spear with fair colours blent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stood beside the shrine; 'twas the dwelling of the hermit Trevrezent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There Parzival dealt with honour—On the relic an oath he sware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Himself laid the oath upon him, and he spake and they hearkened fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'If I have worth or valour, as 'seemeth a gallant knight—         <span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If I have it or not let those witness who have looked on my shield in fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, let them approve my knighthood, for knighthood's power may claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the shield-bearer oft shall tell us, high guerdon of praise and fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the name of knight is honoured—My body to shame for aye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Will I give, and my fame and honour henceforth shall be put away;  <span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(With these words I my bliss would pledge here in the Hand that shall highest be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that Hand is God's Hand, I think me)—All loss, bitter mockery,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this life and the next be my portion from His power, if this lady fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'er did thee wrong when it chanced her that the clasp from her robe <i>I</i> tare—<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Of a token of gold I robbed her)—A <i>fool</i> and no man was I, <span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Not yet had I waxed to wisdom—And sore did she weep thereby,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_152">[Pg 152]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And anguish and grief she suffered; yea, guiltless was she that day—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And forfeit my bliss and mine honour if the words be not truth I say!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now see, dost thou hold her guiltless thou shalt give her her ring again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the clasp I in such wise parted that my folly must bear the blame!'<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Duke took the ring, and the blood-stains he wiped from his lips away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he kissed her, his heart's best treasure—And a covering she won straightway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The ring he placed on her finger, with his surcoat her shame would hide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' hewn by the hand of hero, of rich silk was it fashioned wide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But seldom in coat emblazoned mine eyes have a woman seen,         <span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And this one was marred in combat. No war-cry was hers, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That should summon the knights to Tourney, and never a spear she brake<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whatever her garb—In Tourney far better the part they'ld take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lambekein, methinks, and the good squire, if together they thought to fight—<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now was the lady pardoned, and her sorrow had taken flight.    <span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Orilus, 'Now, thou hero, the oath thou didst freely swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great joy and small grief hath brought me; tho' shaming I needs must bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet gladness therefrom I win me—In all honour I will repay<br></span>
<span class="i0">This lady true for her sorrow when I put her in shame away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And since all alone I left her she was guiltless did aught betide; <span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet so did she speak of thy beauty, methought there was more beside.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now may God reward thee, thou hast shown her from falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I have done her a wrong—Thro' the young wood have I ridden in search of thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">Afar from Briziljan's forest.' Then Parzival took the spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wild Taurian, Dodine's brother, erewhile had he left it here.      <span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now say where the heroes rested, or how they would pass the night—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Helmet and shield had suffered, they were shattered and hewn in fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Parzival to the lady, and her husband, a farewell bade;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Duke to his hearth would bid him, 'twas in vain howsoe'er he prayed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So here, as the venture telleth, they parted, those heroes twain,  <span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Prince Orilus he sought him his pavilion and folk again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And glad were his faithful people with one mind when at last they saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their lord and his gracious lady dwell in peace and in love once more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor longer was there delaying, the Duke he aside would lay<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_153">[Pg 153]</a></span>
<span class="i0">His arms, and the rust and blood-stains from his face did he wash away;<span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By her hand he led the Duchess where atonement he fain would make,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Weeping she lay beside him for joy, not for sorrow's sake.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For such is the way of women, know ye not the saying well?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tearful eyes make sweet lips,' of such lore methinks I yet more might tell!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Love knoweth joy as sorrow, and he who the twain would weigh   <span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a balance shall find them equal an he testeth the scales alway!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At peace were they now, full surely, forthwith to the bath they went,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Twelve fair maidens they waited on her, with them had she shared her tent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They had tended her since, all guiltless, the wrath of her love she bare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">(At night might she lie well covered, tho' by day she ill-clad must fare)<span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And joyful they bathed their lady—But now are ye fain to hear<br></span>
<span class="i0">How Orilus won him tidings that King Arthur would now draw near.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For thus spake a knight to his master, 'On a grassy plain I saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">In fair and knightly order a thousand tents, yea, more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Arthur the noble monarch, the King of the Breton's land        <span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With a wondrous fair host of maidens his court holdeth nigh at hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks scarce a mile are they distant, nor shout of knights shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On either side Plimizöl's waters their camp lies adown the vale.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Duke in haste and gladness forth from his bath he stept—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would ye know how she fared, Jeschuté? No longer the lady wept,    <span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But she went, the fair and gentle, from her bath to her couch straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And far fairer, I ween, her garments than she ware for many a day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And closely they clung together, the prince and the princess wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Love came to the aid of gladness, and joy here hath won the prize.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the maidens they clad their lady, but the knights their lord's armour brought,<span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And much had ye praised the vesture of Jeschuté, 'twas fairly wrought<br></span>
<span class="i0">And birds caught in snares they brought them, on their couch did they sit the twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And joyful they ate; many kisses from her lord did Jeschuté gain!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they brought to the lovely lady a palfrey, so strong and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas bridled, and richly saddled, and a lady right well might bear,<span class="linenum">800</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_154">[Pg 154]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And they lifted her to the saddle, with her brave lord she hence would ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his charger was armed, as for battle the knight would his steed bestride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sword he that morn had wielded hung the saddle-bow before.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then from foot to head well armèd he came forth to his steed once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, where his lady waited, to the saddle he sprung, the knight,<span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He would ride forth without delaying, with Jeschuté his lady bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his folk should fare back to Lalande, save one knight who should show the way<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the camp and the court of King Arthur, so he counselled his folk that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soon came they anear King Arthur, and his tents they right well espied,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the space of a mile they stretched them adown by the water's side.<span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The knight who had led him hither he bade to his folk repair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No comrade he'ld have save Jeschuté, his lady so true and fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Arthur, the brave and humble, he sat where at eve he'ld eat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On a plain with his vassals round him, in order due and meet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Duke Orilus rode to their circle, and none might his blazon know,  <span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So hewn were both shield and helmet—'twas Parzival dealt such blow!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From his horse sprang the gallant hero, Jeschuté she held his rein;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Swift sprang the squires to aid them, and thronged close around the twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake, 'We will care for the horses,'—Orilus, on the grass he laid<br></span>
<span class="i0">His shield so marred and splintered, and he asked of the gracious maid<span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For whose sake he had ridden thither, and they showed him the lady's seat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kunnewaaré she was of Lalande, and her mien for a maid was meet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then, armed, he drew near unto them—King and queen bade him welcome fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thanked them, and to his sister his pledge was he fain to swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the maiden, right well she knew him by the golden dragon's shine,<span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, 'Thou art sure my brother, Orilus, or Lähelein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And pledge will I take from neither, for both of ye aye were fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To render to me such service as I from your hands would gain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I were dead to all truth and honour if I dealt with thee as a foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My courtesy sure were shamèd by my own hand, and laid alow.'       <span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince knelt before the maiden and he spake, 'Thou the truth hath said,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am Orilus thy brother; the Red Knight this oath hath laid<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_155">[Pg 155]</a></span>
<span class="i0">On me that my pledge I yield thee, for so must I buy my life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wilt thou take it, then have I done that which I sware after bitter strife.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his pledge, who had borne the dragon, in her white hand the maid must take,<span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she set him free, and he rose up, and thus to his sister spake:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now to sorrow shall faith constrain me, alas! who hath smitten thee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The blows perforce must wound me—He who lusted thereto might see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If this were the hour for vengeance, that grief I with thee must share;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bravest of men mourneth with me that ever a woman bare,    <span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He calleth himself the Red Knight—O king! he doth bid me greet<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both thee and the queen thy lady, he doth offer ye service meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he fain would serve this my sister—His service ye will repay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ye kindly entreat this maiden that her shaming be put away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, too, had fared far better at the hand of this dauntless knight,<span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had he known the maid for my sister, and her blows on my heart must light.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Kay, he hath earned fresh hatred from all who would there abide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both knights and gentle ladies, by Plimizöl's flowing tide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Iofreit the son of Idöl, from Gawain, and the vanquished king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Klamidé, of whose sore peril I of yore unto ye would sing.         <span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And from many another hero whose names I right well had told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But o'er-long would it be my story—So they thronged round the hero bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, courteous, he took their service—his wife would they nearer bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She sat as yet on her palfrey, and they welcomed her, queen and king.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the women they kissed each other, and thus spake the king so true,<span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thy father, King Lac of Karnant, for a gallant man I knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his sake I mourned thy sorrow when first men the tale did bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks that thy lord should have spared thee for the sake of thy face so fair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the prize was thine at Kanedig thro' the light of thy beauty's ray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hawk didst thou win for thy fairness, on thine hand did it ride away.<span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If Orilus wrong hath done me, yet I wished unto thee no ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never I liked his judgment; and so doth it please me still<br></span>
<span class="i0">To see thee restored to favour, and clad in these garments fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As fitting thy state, O Lady! since woe thou o'er-long didst bear.'<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_156">[Pg 156]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Now may God reward thee, O Sire! for these words so true,<span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That thy fame may wax the higher, and may blossom and bloom anew!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Jeschuté and her husband, the twain, she took by the hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And forth from the circle led them, the maiden of fair Lalande.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And near to the royal pavilion, where a stream from the meadow sprung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stood her tent on the plain, and above it a wingèd dragon hung;    <span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Half an apple it held in its clutches, and four ropes did it draw on high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en as if the tent it lifted, and aloft to the clouds would fly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Orilus thereby knew it, for the self-same arms he bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And beneath it would they disarm him—Then his sister so true and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She gave him due care and honour, and the vassals, each one they spake,<span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How the Red Knight's valour dauntless would Fame for its comrade take.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As thus aloud men praised him, in Kingron's ear spake Kay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade him do Orilus service—(Well he might, whom he thus did pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For oft had he done such service for Klamidé in Brandigan.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for this Kay would give his office to the hand of another man, <span class="linenum">880</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His ill-star had bid him smite her, the prince's sister fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So hard with his staff, 'twas fitting from their service he should forbear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor pardon she found for his trespass, this maiden of royal race;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But viands he sent, and Kingron, he set them before their face.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Kunnewaaré, the wise and gentle, with her slender hands and white, <span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Would cut the food for her brother, at his side sat his lady bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Jeschuté of Karnant bare her with courteous and comely mien,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Arthur the King forgat not, for fain he the twain had seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came where they sat together, and ate with right friendly will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Be good service lacking, then for sure it shall please me ill,<span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ne'er hath a host received ye, I trow, with a will so good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a heart so free from falsehood!' And he spake in kindly mood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'My Lady Kunnewaaré, see thou well to this gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the blessing of God be on ye, and keep ye till morning light!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Arthur to rest betook him, and a couch for the twain they spread,<span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And till daylight in peace they slumbered, and sorrow afar had fled.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_157">[Pg 157]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK VI<br>

ARTHUR</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_158">[Pg 158]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p><span class="smcap">Book VI.</span> tells how King Arthur sought for the Red Knight; and how
he took an oath of his heroes to refrain from fighting. Of the blood-stained
snow, and the love-trance of Parzival; and how, unknowing, he
overthrew Segramor, and took vengeance on Kay. How Gawain led
Parzival to the court of King Arthur; and how he was made a knight of
the Round Table. Of the coming of Kondrie, and Kingrimursel, and the
shaming of Parzival and Gawain. Of Parzival's wrath and despair, and
how he rode forth to seek the Grail. How the knights went forth to the
venture of Château Merveil; and how Gawain rode to Askalon; and of the
scattering of this goodly company.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_159">[Pg 159]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK VI</p>
<p class="ph2">ARTHUR
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_n.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_n.png_2">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now perchance it were well I should tell ye, how, as this his folk did pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Karidöl and his kingdom, King Arthur had ridden away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now the venture telleth, on his own and on stranger ground<br></span>
<span class="i0">For eight days long had they ridden, nor yet had the Red Knight found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in truth 'twas for him they were seeking, to honour his hand were fain,<span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From sorrow had he released them, who had erst Prince Ither slain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Klamidé the king, and Kingron, in a welcome hour had sent<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the court of the Breton Monarch: for on this was King Arthur bent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would make him one of his circle, a knight of the Table Round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No labour too great he counted, so the hero at last he found!       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus o'er mountain and vale they sought him—All who knightly shield might bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Arthur now called around him, and in this wise he bade them swear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">What deeds so e'er of knighthood they should see, by this their oath,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They should on no conflict venture, but faithful still keep their troth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As they sware unto him, their monarch, and fight but as he thereto  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Should give them leave—He spake thus, 'Now, 'tis well! Since we needs must go<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' many a stranger country, where many a stranger spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a gallant hero are waiting us, I fear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ye, like hounds untrainèd whose leash shall have slipped the hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of him who was late their master, shall roam free o'er all the land,<span class="linenum">20</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_160">[Pg 160]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Much evil might there befall ye, and such chance should but please me ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by this your oath, I think me, such rashness I best may still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be ye sure and need ariseth, your king ne'er will say you Nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till then, as I here command ye, ride peaceful upon your way.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now the oath, ye shall well have heard it—Now hear ye how Parzival,<span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Waleis, rode near unto them: thro' the night did the snow-flakes fall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Light they fell, yet lay thickly on him, yet if well I the tale may know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the singer aright hath sung it, it was never the time of snow;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For whate'er men have sung or spoken of King Arthur, at Whitsuntide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or when May-blossoms deck the meadow, these marvels did aye betide. <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For sweetly the springtide bloometh, and many a garb, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall it bear this song of my singing, tho' snow-clad it now be seen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The falconers from Karidöl, as the shadows of evening fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode, hawking, by Plimizöl's waters, when an evil chance befell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the best of their hawks flew from them, nor stooped to the lure again,<span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But all night in the dusky shadows of the woodland it did remain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With Parzival it sheltered; to the twain was the woodland way<br></span>
<span class="i0">A road unknown, sharp the frost stung, in the far east uprose the day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, lo! all around the hero, the snow-flakes lay thick and white:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the forest paths untrodden, in ever waxing light,             <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode our hero by hedge or thicket, by rock and by fallen tree,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till clear grew the shadowy woodland, and its depths he well might see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a mighty tree of the forest had fallen where he would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(The falcon yet followed after) 'mid its clustering boughs he spied<br></span>
<span class="i0">A flock of wild-geese from the Northland, their hissing he first had heard,<span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Swift swooped the falcon upon them and struck to the earth a bird:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And scarce might it fly the clutches of its foe, and fresh shelter take<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Neath the shade of the fallen branches; in its flight from the wounds there brake<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three blood-drops, all glowing crimson, and fell on the spotless snow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Parzival's eyes beheld them, swift sorrow his heart must know!   <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear ye his love so loyal—As he looked on these blood-drops bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That stained with a stain of crimson the snow-flakes that lay so white,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_161">[Pg 161]</a></span>
<span class="i0">He thought, 'Say what hand hath painted these colours that here I see?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kondwiramur, I think well, these tints sure shall liken thee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And white snow and blood-drops crimson, do ever thy likeness share, <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For this favour I praise God's working, and the world he hath wrought so fair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in this wise I read the vision,—in this snow that so spotless lies,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst the blood-drops, that ruddy-gleaming, glow crimson beneath mine eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I find ever thy face so gracious, my lady, Kondwiramur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Red as blood-drops and white as the snowdrift, it rejoiceth me evermore!'<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then her sweet face arose before him, in that night she first sought his side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When on each cheek a tear-drop glistened, and a third to her chin did glide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so true was his love and steadfast, little recked he of aught around,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But wrapped round in love and longing, saw naught but the blood-stained ground.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Frau Minne with force constrained him, as here on his wife he thought,<span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And by magic of colours mystic, a spell on his senses wrought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So held he him still, as sleeping—Would ye know who found him there?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The squire of fair Kunnewaaré would forth unto Lalande fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as on his way he journeyed, by the woodland green he saw<br></span>
<span class="i0">A helmet all battle-dinted, and a shield which yet traces bore      <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of many a bitter conflict that was foughten for lady fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a knight there abode in armour, and his lance he aloft did bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">As one who here patient waited the joust that he fain would ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The squire swiftly turned his bridle and back to the camp he hied.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet in sooth had he seen the stranger, and his lady's champion known,<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He had ne'er been so swift to decry him, nor had wished he were overthrown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor e'en as he were an outlaw, set the heroes upon his track:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The squire he of queen unfaithful, small wonder he knighthood lacked!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And in this wise he called upon them, 'Fie! Fie! on ye, coward knights!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hold ye not Gawain for a marvel? Have ye not in a hundred fights    <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Won honour and fame as heroes, who fight for a hero king?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Know now that ye stand dishonoured, and broken your goodly ring!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! then there arose a clamour, and none but was fain to know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the deed of knightly prowess, that should shame their honour so.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When they heard how but one knight dared them, that but one knight a foe did wait,<span class="linenum">85</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_162">[Pg 162]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then sorely they mourned the promise that they sware to their king of late.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Knight Segramor sprang swiftly from amid the angry throng,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He ran, for in sooth he walked not, and ever his heart did long<br></span>
<span class="i0">To be in the midst of conflict, where conflict might chance to be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An they failèd with cords to bind him, in the thick of the fight was he!<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And nowhere the Rhine's swift waters may flow so strong and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the stream should run swift between them, an men fought on the further side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He stayed not to test the waters, if the current be hot or cold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But straightway the stream he breasted, as fitted a swimmer bold!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Swift-foot to the tent of the monarch, the eager youth he sped,     <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the day was but yet in its dawning, and the king he lay yet abed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then straight thro' the lists he hied him, and he gat him thro' the door,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the covering all of sable, with hasty hand he tore<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the twain who lay warm beneath it, and slumbered a slumber deep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet his haste moved them but to laughter, tho' he waked them from out their sleep!<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And loudly he cried on his cousin—'Queen, Lady, Guinevere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the world knoweth well our kinship, thou must do me this service here,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speak thou for me to thine husband, and pray thou of him this grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since a knightly venture nears us, my lot <i>first</i> the foe to face!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Arthur spake, 'Now bethink thee of the oath thou didst swear to me,<span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In all things my will to follow, nor rashly to venture thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For if thou a joust now ridest, hereafter shall many a knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Crave leave at mine hand to ride forth, and seek for fame in fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twere ill thus our force to weaken, for know thou that near at hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Anfortas of Monsalväsch with a mighty host doth stand.             <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This wood of his he guardeth, and since we but little know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where he and his force shall hold them, such chance well might work us woe!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Guinevere wrought so wisely Segramor was well-nigh fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To die of joy, from King Arthur, his lady this grace did gain.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_163">[Pg 163]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And on fame and honour only was the gallant youth intent,          <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor for gold had he sold the venture on which his heart was bent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now the hero young and beardless, well armed his steed bestrode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And over the fresh young greensward his charger at full speed rode;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bushes were bent beneath him, and the golden bells rang clear<br></span>
<span class="i0">On trapping alike and armour; and I deem well an need were here    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To seek for the magic pheasant mid thicket and thorny brake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He who fain this knight had followed, the bells for his guide might take!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus rashly rode the hero, to him whom Frau Minne's spell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fast fettered in magic fetters, and no blow at the first there fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the peace by his word was broken—There held fast by threefold might,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the power of red blood-drops threefold stood ever the stranger knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">(Yea, well I myself have known this, how Frau Minne with power may hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And holding, the senses scatter, and with passion of grief untold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall fill the heart to o'erflowing—'Twas a woman who wrought this ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And vanquished, she doth condemn me, and refuseth me comfort still.<span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus draweth she guilt upon her, for the sin shall be hers, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And afar must I fly from the presence, that of old time my joy hath been.)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus Segramor quoth unto him, 'Now it seemeth but ill to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thus near our army lieth, and our presence rejoiceth thee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou holdest his fame too lightly, whom with pride we may hail our king,<span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'tis meet thou for this do penance,—or the death-chime for me shall ring!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus armed, all too near thou ridest; yet first would I courteous pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou yield thee at this my bidding, or my wrong will I here repay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my blow shall be swift, and thy falling shall scatter these snow-flakes white!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I call on thee here to yield thee, ere I put thee to shame, Sir Knight!'<span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Parzival still kept silence—for Frau Minne, so fair and young,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a sorer conflict held him—Then his steed Segramor swung<br></span>
<span class="i0">Aside, as for jousting ready, round wheeled him the war-horse good<br></span>
<span class="i0">On whose back the gallant hero yet sate in mystic mood,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_164">[Pg 164]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And ever he gazed on the blood-drops; as his charger turned him round<span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Awhile from his eyes they vanished, and fame in their stead he found!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For swift as the blood-drops crimson thus passed from his dazzled sight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hearkened the voice of the foeman, and braced him anew for fight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then as Segramor rode against him, Parzival sought afresh the spear<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he found by the woodland chapel, with blazon of colours clear;<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For tough was the shaft, and he gripped it, and he held the point full low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his foeman dashed fair against him, his shield rang with the ringing blow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he spurred him anew to the onslaught, and the joust he so well repaid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the knight in his golden armour was low in the snowdrift laid!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet still was the spear unsplintered, tho' it bare him from off his horse;<span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival still kept silence, and he wheeled him upon his course,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his eyes sought once more the blood-drops, and e'en as they met his sight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Frau Minne with fetters bound him, and held him in cords of might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake never word, nor question, but gazed ever upon the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, dreaming, he lost the knowledge which he for a space had found!<span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But affrighted, the gallant charger had fled back into its stall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And its rider arose, little comfort might he find, though he soft might fall!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Outstretched had he lain in the snowdrift, in such wise e'en as men shall go<br></span>
<span class="i0">To rest, yet but ill he sleepeth, who sleepeth on couch of snow!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And such bed had sorrow brought me! for he to whom ill betides     <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath but mocking for his bedfellow, but the lucky doth God's hand guide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So near was King Arthur's army, that right well might Parzival<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be seen of all men, and the wonders, and the conflict that then befell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The victor by Love was vanquished, by Love that in days of old<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did the king of all kings the wisest, King Solomon, captive hold!  <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Short space, then, ere back to the army once more Knight Segramor came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An with praise or with blame they should greet him, he counted it still the same.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sharp words he flung among them, with mocking tongue and bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' vanquished, yet not dishonoured, must they ever the hero hold!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Have ye never heard this, that strife bringeth loss as gain?<span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a joust, I wot me, but the victor doth one remain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_165">[Pg 165]</a></span>
<span class="i0">While one aye shall be the vanquished: The best ship in storm may sink,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot that ye ne'er have heard me to speak, for I ne'er did think,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An he knew of my shield the blazon, he had faced me not as a foe!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Much evil, in sooth, hath he wrought me, and yet doth he wait below<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All those who would ride against him, for he seemeth for conflict fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An a knight should in joust o'erthrow him, such chance might he count for gain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straightway unto King Arthur Sir Kay did the tidings bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How his knight, Segramor, had fallen, and his victor, without their ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A young knight, for jousting ready, yet waited with ill intent—   <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, I think an this stranger warrior of so many unpunished went,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A burden both sore and shameful on our honour such lack would lay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, my king, an thou hold me worthy, do thou grant me this grace, I pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would ride hence to ask his meaning, who thus in the presence fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of our Queen Guinevere and her maidens his lance-point aloft doth bear;<span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But if thou shouldst this boon refuse me, then know, not another hour<br></span>
<span class="i0">I abide here as this thy servant; for I hold that the knightly power<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fair fame of thy Round Table are stainèd if we delay<br></span>
<span class="i0">To arm ourselves 'gainst the stranger who dareth our strength to-day!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, I prithee, give leave to fight him—For tho' blind and deaf were we,<span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet 'tis time that we should defend us'—'As thou willest, so let it be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then swift did the seneschal arm him, and I ween in fierce anger's fire<br></span>
<span class="i0">A woodland he fain had wasted 'gainst the foe, who with strong desire<br></span>
<span class="i0">And love was thus sorely burdened; for Frau Minne a magic spell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had wrought with the snow-flakes spotless, and the blood-drops that crimson fell.<span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his knighthood he sorely shamèd, who thought here to work him harm,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he faileth true Love to honour, who denieth of Love the charm.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Frau Minne, say, why dost thou make glad the souls that mourn<br></span>
<span class="i0">With bliss that too swiftly fleeting, but leaveth them more forlorn?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And how canst thou, Frau Minne, true worth and knightly fame,      <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And manly strength and courage, thus vanquish and put to shame?<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the least is to thee as the greatest, and the earth shall no hero boast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who thinketh to scorn thine empire, but he learneth unto his cost<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_166">[Pg 166]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That thou canst, an thou wilt, o'erthrow him; yea, all men thy power obey,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy sceptre we own as mighty, and wide as the world its sway.  <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet this one thing it doth thee honour, tho' thou rulest all else but ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Joy maketh her dwelling with thee, and for this would I praise thee still!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Frau Minne, alas! of old time full false were thy ways, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor hast thou thy dealings mended, nor to-day hast thou truer been,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast many a maiden shamèd, who love forbidden sought;         <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' thy dealings, upon the vassal, his lord hath sorrow brought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the friend shall false and faithless to the friend of his bosom prove,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the servant betray his master; such deeds do but shame thee, Love!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I would that it were far from thee, the body to yield to lust,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise that the soul ashamèd is stricken with sorrow's thrust,<span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And that with force compelling, the young thou makest old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though their years but few be counted, this must we for treason hold!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Such speech, I ween, beseems not the man who in serving thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath comfort found! If succour thine hand ever brought to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I had been less slow to praise thee, but sorrow and loss alone     <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hast thou counted to me as guerdon, and such glamour thine art hath thrown<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er mine eyes, that, methinks, henceforward I trust thee never more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though small profit it brought unto thee, the bitter grief I bore!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet too high above me art thou, that whate'er my wrong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I should e'en as a fool upbraid thee with bitter words and strong: <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy spear too sharply pierces, and scarce may we bear the weight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou layest at will upon us—Methinks he who sang of late,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Neath a tree, of thy mystic dealings, and thy wondrous ways of old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had better done had he told us how we thy grace might hold!<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Heinrich of Veldeck was he, and he taught us, I ween, right well  <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the winning of Love, of its guarding, alas! he failed to tell.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">For oft one thro' folly loses the prize that he late did win;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, to me hath such fate befallen, yet Frau Minne, <i>thine</i> was the sin!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since all wisdom shall be thy portion, since against thee nor spear, nor shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor charger, nor guarded fortress their vaunted power can wield,   <span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I know not what shall withstand thee, nor on earth, nor on the sea!<br></span>
<span class="i0">He who feareth to face thy conflict, say whither shall he flee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas thy mystic power, Frau Minne, that dealt thus with Parzival,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_167">[Pg 167]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And reft him awhile of knowledge, and wrought with him as a fool.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fair was the queen and gracious who reigned in far Pelrapär,   <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she thought on her lord and husband, and she made thee her message bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for this cause Kardeiss her brother, hast thou for thy payment slair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And since thou such tribute askest, 'tis well that I ne'er have ta'en<br></span>
<span class="i0">From thine hand aught of good, since in such wise thou dost for thy debtors care—<br></span>
<span class="i0">This I spake for the sake of all men—List ye now how Sir Kay did fare:<span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he rode forth in knightly armour to the strife that he sore did crave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gamuret's son, right willing, to his wish fulfilment gave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wherever fair maids compelling, their voices uplift in prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the grace they shall ask be granted, let them pray here for his welfare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since it was thro' a woman's beauty, that the spell of a woman wrought<span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Love's magic, of senses robbed him—Then his charger to halt Kay brought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake to the gallant Waleis, 'Sir Knight, since thou thus our king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hast shamed, thou shalt hear my counsel, for wisdom perchance 'twill bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt hang thee a hempen halter around thy neck straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so may I lightly lead thee, and take thou with me thy way.     <span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor think thou, thou canst escape me, but with me unto my lord<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shalt thou go, as befits a captive, else worse may be thy reward!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By love constrained, the Waleis nor word nor answer spoke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kay gripped his spear-shaft tightly and he smote with a mighty stroke<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the hero's head, till the helmet rang loudly beneath his hand;  <span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Now will I awake thee! Dost think here to take thy stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And standing sleep unsheeted? Nay, other shalt thou fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Low on the snow I'll lay thee! The ass that is wont to bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sack from the mill would rue it, did one smite him in such wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As here I think now to smite thee, and thy sloth and thy sleep chastise!'<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Frau Minne, now bethink thee, for sore this shameth thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For an one should wrong a peasant, in this wise his speech will be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'My lord will sure repay thee!' Vengeance from thee he'ld seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks, this gallant Waleis, an thou wouldst let him speak!<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_168">[Pg 168]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Now let him from out thy circle, and loose him from thy ban,       <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This stranger guest shalt prove him, a true and valiant man!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Swift rode Sir Kay unto him, and he turned his bridle round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no more his longing glances their joy and their sorrow found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The white snow and blood-drops crimson, that mystic likeness bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the queen of his love and his longing, the Lady of Pelrapär;    <span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He knew all that passed around him—His charger Sir Kay addrest<br></span>
<span class="i0">To jousting, he spurred him onward, and his spear he laid in rest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the joust, that which Kay had aimed at he smote, for his spear did pierce<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Waleis' shield, yet swift payment was his, for in onslaught fierce<br></span>
<span class="i0">The seneschal of King Arthur fell prone on the fallen tree,        <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the geese erewhile had hid them, and hurt full sore was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dead lay his gallant charger—''Twixt a stone and the saddle-bow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Right arm, and left leg had he broken—so mighty his overthrow<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all that had decked his charger, girths, saddle, bells of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the force of the fall were shattered, thus the stranger his payment told,<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with one blow, for twain repaid him—the one that erst for his sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden had borne and the other, which he from Kay's hand must take.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus he who knew naught of falsehood was guided of truth to know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her message in blood-drops threefold, on the white of the drifted snow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas tear-drops, not blood, that he saw there, and well might his senses fail,<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the thoughts of his heart wax heavy, as he mused on the wondrous Grail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorely the semblance grieved him that spake of his wife and queen.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet tho' o'er the twain he sorrowed, the greater woe, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was the woe that Frau Minne wrought him, for there liveth not heart so strong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But longing and love united break its power, ere the time be long. <span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Count we here those twain as ventures? Nay, 'twere better methinks to hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That they were naught but pain and sorrow, that vanquished the hero bold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now ye unto whom I tell this, I rede ye to mourn Kay's woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For full oft as his manhood bade him, he many a strife did know.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_169">[Pg 169]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And in many a land they speak thus, that Kay, Arthur's seneschal,  <span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was a firebrand, hell-born, yet I wot well far other the tale I'ld tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From reproach would I gladly free him, tho' few but should say me nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet a gallant man and a worthy, I swear was this knight, Sir Kay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my mouth to this truth beareth witness, and more would I tell to thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto Arthur's Court came strangers in many a company,              <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And their manners and ways were diverse, nor all there might honour claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Kay an he saw false dealing, he counted such ways as shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his face he turned from the sinner, yet he who dealt courteously,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And true man with true men would hold him, Kay served him right heartily.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And one who fall well discernèd the manner of men was Kay,         <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus he did to his lord good service, for his harsh words drave far away<br></span>
<span class="i0">The men who would falsely vaunt them good knights and true to be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ill was he to them as a hailstorm, sharp as sting of an angry bee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Small wonder that these deny him his honour and knightly fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True servant and wise they found him, and for this cause upon his name<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Their hatred doth still heap slander—Prince Herman, Thuringia's lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou with vassals that crowd around thee, and strangers who seek thy board,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Good service might Kay have done thee, since so free art thou aye of hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That true men and men dishonoured, side by side in thine hall they stand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefore Knight Walter singeth, 'Now greeting to all I bring, <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Men evil and good!' And I trow well, where a singer such song may sing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There the false are too highly honoured—Nay, far other Sir Kay had taught,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Yea, and Heinrich of Rispach also)—Now hearken ye in what sort<br></span>
<span class="i0">On Plimizöl's plain men bare them; from the field Sir Kay was borne<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the tent of his king, and around him, o'er his ill-fate his friends did mourn;<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And maiden and knight they stood there; to the tent where his comrade lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">Came Gawain, and he quoth in sadness, 'Alas! for the woeful day<br></span>
<span class="i0">That so ill a joust was ridden that hath robbed me of a friend!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake Kay in his anger, 'Now make of thy moan an end,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If comfort thou here wouldst bring me, do not as the women do,     <span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since thou art my monarch's nephew! I would do to thee service true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As of free heart I ever did it, in the day that God gave me power,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor long for my aid hadst thou prayed me! There cometh, perchance, an hour<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_170">[Pg 170]</a></span>
<span class="i0">When I, as of old, may serve thee: now cease thou thy moan I pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For tho' mine be the pain, yet my monarch shall ne'er find another Kay,<span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot that for mine avenger art thou all too nobly born;<br></span>
<span class="i0">An yet hadst <i>thou</i> lost a finger I had counted myself forsworn<br></span>
<span class="i0">An I risked not mine head to pay it! Let that be as it may,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Believe me or not, as shall please thee, yet sooth are the words I say!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'No joust shalt thou ride at my urging, for roughly he greets his foe,<span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who holdeth without his station, and rideth nor swift nor slow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I think me, of maidens' tresses, tho' frail be such cord and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Enough from such strife to bind thee, the chain of a single hair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the man who shall show such meekness, he well doth his <i>mother</i> love,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since his <i>sire</i> would fain in the conflict his knightly mettle prove.<span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But follow thou aye thy mother, Sir Gawain, list well her rede.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn thou pale at the glancing sword-blade, and shrink from the manly deed!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thus on the gallant hero the bitter words he spake<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fell sharply, he looked not for them, nor on Kay might he vengeance take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full seldom a knight may do so, since shame on his lips setteth seal,<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But they who thus speak discourteous, such shame shall they never feel.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gawain he quoth in answer, 'Where men knightly sword might bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And have foughten, and I fought with them, then no man beheld me there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And saw that my cheek waxed paler at sight of wound or blow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I was ever thy friend—'twas needless that thou shouldst reproach me so!'<span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he strode from the tent, and he bade them bring hither his charger good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor spur on his heel he buckled, unarmed he his steed bestrode.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So came he unto the Waleis (whose sense was of love held fast),<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his shield to all eyes bare witness of three spears thro' its circle passed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For three jousts of late had he ridden, and he rode them with heroes twain,<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Orilus too was he smitten—Then gently uprode Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spurred not his steed to gallop, nor conflict nor strife he sought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he rode but in love and in kindness, to seek him who here had fought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair spake Gawain the stranger, to greeting deaf was he,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_171">[Pg 171]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Frau Minne yet held him captive, how other might it be?            <span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">True son of Herzeleide, to this lot was he born,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To lose himself for love's sake; such passion as had torn<br></span>
<span class="i0">The hearts of these his parents, afresh in his heart awoke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And but little his ear might hearken what the mouth of Gawain spoke.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth King Lot's son unto the Waleis,' Sir Knight, here thou doest ill<span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In that thou withholdest greeting—tho' patient I wait thy will<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far otherwise can I bear me! Know thou that to friend and king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, to all whom I count my fellows, thy deed doth dishonour bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And our shame ever waxeth greater; yet prayed I for thee this grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The king of free heart forgives thee, if now thou shalt seek his face.<span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So hearken, I pray, my counsel, and do thou as I shall say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ride thou with me to King Arthur, nor too long shalt thou find the way.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor threatening nor prayer might move him, this fair son of Gamuret:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the pride of King Arthur's knighthood his memory backward set,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought of Frau Minne's dealings, and the time when the knife's sharp blade<span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He drave thro' his hand unwitting, thro' the love of a gracious maid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that time when from death's cold clutches, a queen's hand had set him free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When of Lähelein was he vanquished, and captive in joust was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a queen in the day of his danger must pledge her fair life for his,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her name shall of men be praisèd, Queen Ingus of Bachtarliess. <span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thought Gawain, 'It may be Frau Minne dealeth so with this goodly man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As she dealt with me of old time, so claspeth him in the ban<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of her magic spells fair-woven, that his spirit within the snare<br></span>
<span class="i0">She holdeth fast entangled'—Then his eyes on the snow-flakes fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">He cast, and he knew the token, and swift from the spell-bound sight<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With cloth of fair silk and sendal, he covered the blood-drops bright.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The blood-stained snow was hidden, nor longer its spell was seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his sight and his sense unclouded she gave him, his wife and queen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet his heart did she hold in her keeping, and its dwelling was Pelrapär,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he cried aloud in his sorrow thro' the silent summer air;      <span class="linenum">400</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_172">[Pg 172]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! who of thee hath robbed me, who erewhile wast my queen and wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy love, thy crown, and thy kingdom my right hand hath won in strife.<br></span>
