<span class="i0">Say, say, am I he who saved thee from Klamidé the warrior king?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, sorrow and bitter sighing, and grief that the heart doth wring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Are the guerdons I won in thy service, and now from mine eyes be-dazed<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou reft, and thy place I know not, tho' but now on thy face I gazed.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Now, where shall my spear be, since I wot well I brought it here?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Gawain, 'A joust hast thou ridden, and splintered shall be thy spear.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'With whom should I joust?' quoth the Waleis, 'thou bearest nor sword nor shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And little had been mine honour, an thou to my hand didst yield!   <span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet bear I awhile thy mocking, nor will I thy friendship pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' many a joust have I ridden, yet my saddle I kept alway.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou be not for jousting minded, and I find not in thee a foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the world lieth wide before me, and hence on my way I go;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For labour and strife am I seeking and fain would I win me praise, <span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Be anguish or joy my portion; nor unfruitful shall be my days.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Gawain, 'What I spake aforetime I spake of true heart and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor my thoughts were the thoughts of evil, for well would I deal with thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the boon that I crave will I win me, my monarch with many a knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lieth here at hand with his army, and with many a lady bright,     <span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An it please thee, Sir Knight, to betake thee to our goodly company,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From all strife shall this right hand guard thee, and gladly I'll ride with thee.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I thank thee, Sir Knight, fair thou speakest, yet say ere with thee I ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who the monarch may be whom thou servest? and who rideth here at my side?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'A man do I hail as master, thro' whose fame much fame I won,      <span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor here shall my mouth keep silence on the things he for me hath done.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For dear hath he ever held me, and as true knight did me entreat:<br></span>
<span class="i0">(His sister King Lot hath wedded, and the twain I as parents greet.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the good gifts God gave unto me, to his service I yield them all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my hand and my heart he ruleth, whom men do King Arthur call.  <span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor mine own name need here be hidden, nor a secret shall long remain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_173">[Pg 173]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For the folk and the lands that know me, they call on me as Gawain:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain would I do thee service, alike with my hand and name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou turnest here at my bidding, nor bringest upon me shame!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Is it thou, O Gawain? too little I yet have done   <span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou shouldst as a friend entreat me; yet hast thou this honour won<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all men thou gently treatest—and thy friendship I here will take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet not for mine own deserving, but repayment I fain would make.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now say where thine army lieth, since so many tents I see<br></span>
<span class="i0">That stand fair by the brink of the river? If King Arthur in truth shall be<span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So near, then must I bemoan me, that in honour I may not dare<br></span>
<span class="i0">To enter his royal presence, or look on his queen so fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since 'tis meet that I first avenge me of a foul and discourteous blow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For which, since the day I left them, I sorrow and shame must know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a maiden as she beheld me, laughed sweetly, the seneschal      <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For my sake smote the maid so sorely, 'twas a wood that upon her fell.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Rough vengeance thou here hast taken! (Gawain to the Waleis spake)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since thou in a joust hast felled him, and right arm and left leg he brake.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ride here, see his charger lifeless, that lieth the stone below;<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the snowdrift behold the splinters of the spear that hath dealt the blow!<span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis the spear thou but now wast seeking!' Then the truth knew Sir Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway he spake unto Gawain, 'Now, if this be the seneschal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the man who so sorely shamed me, if thou swear me that this was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou mayst ride where thou wilt, and gladly will I ride in thy company!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, never a lie do I tell thee,' quoth Gawain, 'thou hast overthrown<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Segramor, who ere now in battle was ever as victor known,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He fell ere yet Kay had met thee: great deeds hast thou done to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since o'er two of our bravest heroes the prize thou hast borne away.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So rode they, the one with the other, the Waleis and Knight Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the folk, both afoot and on horseback, with honour would greet the twain,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Gawain and his guest the Red Knight, this did they of courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the twain to his fair pavilion they gat them right speedily.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lady, fair Kunnewaaré, whose tent by Gawain's did stand,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_174">[Pg 174]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Rejoiced, and she joyful greeted the hero, whose strong right hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had failed not to wreak stern vengeance for the ill that Kay wrought that day;<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then her brother and fair Jeschuté she led by the hand straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival looked upon them as the three to his tent drew near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his face, thro' the rust of his armour, it shone ever fair and clear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As roses dew-dipped had flown there: his harness aside he laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he stood before Kunnewaaré, and thus spake the gentle maid:    <span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'To God shalt thou first be welcome, as welcome thou art to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since thy manhood thou well hast proven, and the faith that I had in thee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere the day that my heart beheld thee, nor laughter nor smiles I knew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kay, who in that hour smote me, with stern hand my gladness slew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now hast thou well avenged me! With a kiss I thy deed would pay,<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If I of thy kiss were worthy!' 'Nay, so had I thought to-day<br></span>
<span class="i0">To crave of thy lips my payment,' quoth Parzival, 'if thou still<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wilt give me such gracious greeting, right gladly I'll do thy will!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she kissed him, and down they sate them, and the princess a maiden sent<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bade her to bring rich raiment; so sped she unto the tent;     <span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the garments they lay there ready, of rich silk of Nineveh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her prisoner, King Klamidé, had she fashioned them cunningly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the maiden who bare the garments, full sorely must she bewail<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the mantle was yet unfinished, since the silken cord did fail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lady, Kunnewaaré, from her side drew a silken band        <span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From the folds of her robe, in the mantle she wove it with skilful hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then courteous her leave he prayed him, the rust would he wash away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair shone his face, and youthful, and his lips they were red that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And robed was the gallant hero, and so bright and so fair was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all men who there beheld him, they sware he for sure must be  <span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The flower and the crown of manhood, a knight without shame or fear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked upon him, and they praised him and his colour waxed bright and clear,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_175">[Pg 175]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And right well did his garb become him; an emerald green and rare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The gift of fair Kunnewaaré, as clasp at his neck he bare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a girdle beside she gave him, all wrought in a cunning row     <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With mystic beasts, bejewelled, that burnt with a fiery glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And its clasp was a red-fire ruby—How think ye the beardless youth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was seen when thus richly girded? Fair was he in very sooth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so the story runneth—the folk bare him right goodwill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men and women who looked upon him, they counted him worthy still.  <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forthwith, as the Mass was ended, came Arthur the noble king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knights of his Table with him, a goodly following.<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man there whose lips spake falsehood. Yea, all heard the word that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'With Gawain the Red Knight dwelleth!' the king thither took his way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the knight who so sore was beaten came swiftly, Sir Antanor,  <span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For, fain to behold the Waleis, his feet sped the king before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asked, 'Art thou he who avenged me, and the lady of fair Lalande?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now vanished shall be Kay's honour, for it falleth unto thine hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And an end hast thou made of his threatening, and the days of his strife are o'er,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his arm it is weak, and his vengeance I fear for it never more!'<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And so fair was the knight and radiant, that all men beheld his face<br></span>
<span class="i0">As an angel from heaven, that wingless, abideth on earth a space.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well did King Arthur greet him, and his knights were no whit behind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all they who looked upon him, naught but love in their hearts might find,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their lips to their heart made answer, and all spake to his praises, 'Yea,'<span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And no man gainsaid the other, so lovely his mien that day!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Arthur spake fair unto him, 'Thou hast wrought me both joy and pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ne'er from the hand of a hero such honour I thought to gain<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the honour that thou hast brought me! yet no service I did to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An I did, then thy fame had repaid it, tho' no other thy deeds should be<span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Than the deed thou hast done in the winning for Jeschuté her husband's grace!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor Kay's guilt had been unavengèd, if ere this I had seen thy face<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_176">[Pg 176]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Myself had, unasked, chastised him.' Then Arthur in this wise spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Since so far they had come, and their journey had they taken but for his sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They all with one voice did pray him, to swear to them brotherhood,<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And be one of the gallant Table, a comrade both true and good.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their prayer it seemed good unto him, and joyful at heart was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sware them the oath that they asked for, and their knight would he gladly be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hear ye, and speak the verdict, if on this day the Table Round<br></span>
<span class="i0">Its right, and its due observance had here, as aforetime found;    <span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since for many a day King Arthur in this wise had ruled his court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No knight should break bread before him, if there came of fair venture naught.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But enough should have chanced this morning, and to Table they well might go,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though from Nantes might they never bear it, yet they here would its semblance show.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wide enow was the flowery meadow, nor hindered them tree or tent,  <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As they did here their monarch's bidding—for this was his heart's intent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair honour to give the Red Knight, and his valour, as meet, reward—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then a silk in Acraton woven, they laid on the grassy sward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas brought from far lands of paynim, and 'twas shapen both wide and round;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For ever this courteous custom mid these gallant knights was found,<span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No high seat had they of honour, but all men were equal there;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus had King Arthur willed it, both the knights and their ladies fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the Table Round were welcome, yea, an they might honour claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Knight, lady, or gentle maiden, at his court all should fare the same!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there, with her maiden following, came fair Guinevere the queen,<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a noble princess amid her train was seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And none but was fair to look on, and the ring it was spread so wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">That within, without strife or crowding, each maid sat her knight beside.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Arthur, who ne'er knew falsehood, led the Waleis by the hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Kunnewaaré she walked beside him, the lady of fair Lalande,    <span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From sorrow the knight had freed her—Then, with kind and friendly eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Looked Arthur upon the hero, and he spake to him in this wise:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'My queen will I bid to kiss thee, who art fair both of form and face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For ne'er, in this court, of lady I ween wouldst thou crave this grace,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_177">[Pg 177]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Since from Pelrapär thou hast ridden, and wert thou on kissing bent<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From lips of all lips the fairest, hast thou there thy full heart's content!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet this one grace will I pray thee, if ever there dawn the day<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I find 'neath thy roof abiding, this kiss I may then repay!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'In sooth, will I do thy bidding,' quoth the Waleis, 'both there and here!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then unto the gallant hero stepped the Lady Guinevere,             <span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair on the lips she kissed him, and she quoth, 'Here I pardon thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">The ill thou aforetime didst me, and the sorrow thou gavest me.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou didst leave me sorely grieving, when from hence thou didst ride away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">By thy hand and thy dart my kinsman Prince Ither was slain that day!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all tear-bedewed were the eyelids of the Lady Guinevere,       <span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For Prince Ither's death wrought sorrow unto many a woman dear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now must King Klamidé seat him, on the bank by Plimizöl,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And beside him sate Iofreit, who was son unto King Idöl;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twixt Klamidé and Gawain must the Waleis have his place—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they know who tell the venture, none sate here of royal grace, <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">None who woman's breast had suckled, whose fame stood so high and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For courage and youthful beauty did the Waleis, as jewels, wear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they owned, who there looked upon him, that many a maiden bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saw herself in a darker mirror than the lips of this fair young knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on cheek and on chin his colour might well as fetters be       <span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For those who should need such fetters, whose fancy flitteth free.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here might there be naught of changing—(of women my rede I trow<br></span>
<span class="i0">For some they are ever wavering, and ever new friendships know!)<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his look ever constant held them, till I wot well that thro' their eyes<br></span>
<span class="i0">His entry he gained triumphant, and made of their hearts his prize!<span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus maiden and man beheld him, and his honour all men did praise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he found here the goal of sighing, and the end of his joyous days.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For hither came one I must tell of, and faithful was she in truth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' discourteous her ways, and for sorrow, I ween, had she little ruth!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the folk for her message sorrowed—Now hear how the maid must ride,<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her mule it was tall as a war-horse, and branded on either side;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And its nostrils were slit as is custom in the far land of Hungary,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet her harness and bridle were costly, with rich work broidered cunningly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Soft and slow paced her mule, yet the maiden was not as a maid, I trow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">What sought she? She came as 'twas fated, and sorrow must Arthur know.<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And of wisdom forsooth this maiden might boast her a wondrous store,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_178">[Pg 178]</a></span>
<span class="i0">No tongue but she spake, French, Latin, and Paynim: in all such lore<br></span>
<span class="i0">As men read in the highest heavens, Dialectics, Geometry,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In all was she courteous trainèd, and her name it was called Kondrie.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'The sorceress' did men name her, nor her speech halted on its way,<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Too ready her tongue, since rejoicing she smote into grief that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This maiden, so rich in wisdom, bare little of maiden grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No lover e'er praised her beauty, no tongue spake her fair of face.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A tempest she, joy destroying, yet of bridal cloth from Ghent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did she wear a mantle, bluer than azure the soft tints blent.      <span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As a cap was it fairly fashioned, such as maidens in France shall wear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And beneath it, around her body, a silken robe she bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a hat of the English peacock, with silk of orient lined,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And new was the hat, and the fastening, and it hung low the maid behind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And like to a bridge her message, that sorrow o'er joy had crossed,<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And shame enough did she bring them, till laughter in tears was lost.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In a thick plait above her headgear had she flung her tresses back,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And adown on the mule were they hanging, so long, and so coarse, and black,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor softer to touch than the bristles, which swine on their backs shall show.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her nose as a dog's was shapen, and from out her mouth did grow<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Two tusks as had 'seemed a wild boar, a hand's-breadth long were they;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And above her eyes the eyebrows as thick as plaits they lay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I speak but the truth, as I needs must, tho' my words lack in courtesy<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since I speak of a maid, yet, for such cause, none other reproacheth me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And ears as a bear had Kondrie, and never the eye might trace      <span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A shy glance of love, or of longing, I ween in that wondrous face.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a scourge did she bear, and the handle was a ruby, of silk the cord;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hands of this winsome maiden like a lion's were sharply clawed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the skin as an ape's was dusky, and the nails they were not too light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween, for her maiden favours, but seldom would heroes fight! <span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So rode she unto the circle, and her coming did sorrow bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair joy did she put in peril—Then turned she unto the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And Kunnewaaré sat beside him, his table-mate was she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair Guinevere, his consort, a queen bare her company.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus in royal state King Arthur as monarch sat that day—          <span class="linenum">625</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_179">[Pg 179]</a></span>
<span class="i0">To the Breton king rode Kondrie, and in French did she speak alway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' I in another language than hers shall the venture tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I rede ye to wit that the telling it pleaseth me none too well!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thou son of high Pendragon, thyself, and thy Breton host,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By thy deed hast thou shamed—From all lands the noblest that they might boast<span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Once sat here a gallant circle, but poisoned is now their fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy Table Round dishonoured by traitor, and brought to shame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Arthur, o'er all thy fellows, thy praises of old stood high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But it sinketh now, thy glory, and thy fame, that did swiftly fly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforward goeth halting; thine honour doth seek the ground      <span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since it showeth stain of falsehood—The fame of thy Table Round<br></span>
<span class="i0">It suffered for the friendship ye with Parzival did swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' I wot well the outward token of a spotless knight he bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">"The Red Knight" ye here do call him, the name of one who lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dead before Nantes, yet I tell thee unlike in their life are they! <span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For no mouth hath read of a hero whose fame knew nor fault nor flaw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his!' From the king she turned her, and did rein by the Waleis draw,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Now sore shalt thou rue it, since I, for thy sake deny<br></span>
<span class="i0">My greeting unto King Arthur, and the knights of his company.<br></span>
<span class="i0">May thy fair face be dishonoured, and thy manhood I look on here.  <span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of forgiveness and joy were I merchant, in sooth shouldst thou buy them dear!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I deem thou art but a monster, and myself shall far fairer be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speak, Sir Parzival, as I bid thee, and this riddle read thou to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When thou sawest the fisher sit there, joyless, of comfort reft,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why didst thou not loose his sighing? Why was he in bondage left?' <span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'For he showed thee of his sorrow—Oh! thou false and faithless guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For hadst thou had pity on him, his anguish had gotten rest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would that thy mouth might perish, yea, the tongue thy mouth within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For e'en as the heart the tongue is, in thine <i>heart</i> is the root of sin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Hell shalt thou be predestined, by the Ruler of Heaven high,    <span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And this be on earth thy portion, that true men thy face shall fly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ban hast thou won for blessing, and for bliss shalt thou find but bale,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_180">[Pg 180]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For too late dost thou strive for honour, and thy striving shall naught avail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so feeble shall wax thy manhood, and thy fame it shall be so weak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That never shall soul's physician the promise of healing speak.    <span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An one to the oath should drive me, on thine head were I fain to swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That never a darker treason was wrought by a man so fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hook in fair feathers hidden, bright serpent with poisoned fang,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who ne'er of the sword was worthy, which thine host at thy side did hang!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The goal of thy sins, this thy silence, of Hell's horde art thou now the sport,<span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And dishonour upon thy body, Sir Parzival, hast thou wrought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saw'st thou not how they bare before thee the Grail, and the bleeding spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sharp silver? Thy joy's destruction, and thy shelter from grief were here!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Yea, hadst thou but asked at Monsalväsch; afar, in a heathen land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rich o'er all earthly riches, doth the town of Tabronit stand;     <span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the riches thy speech had won thee had been greater far, I ween—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with gallant strife of knighthood the hand of that country's queen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Feirefis Angevin hath won him: no fear doth his manhood stain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">One father, I ween, hath borne ye, yet unlike shall ye be, ye twain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy brother is strange to look on, for both white and black his face,<span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And at Zassamank he reigneth o'er the folk of his mother's race.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And my thoughts to thy sire are turning; his country was fair Anjou,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he left thee far other heirdom (for his heart never falsehood knew,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than the heritage thou hast won thee, and the crown of an evil fame!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And could I but think thy mother had wrought here a deed of shame  <span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I had said that <i>his</i> child thou wert not! Yet her faith it but wrought her woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of her naught but good be spoken! And thy father, as all men know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his manhood was true and steadfast, and in many a distant land<br></span>
<span class="i0">He won for him meed of honour, and his praise o'er all men did stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For great heart and little falsehood as a roof did defend his breast,<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A dam 'gainst the flood of evil, and a home for his love to rest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in manly strength and courage was his honour for aye held fast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But <i>thy</i> truth it is turned to falsehood, and thine honour to earth is cast!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! for the day I heard it, alas! for the mournful tale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the child of fair Herzeleide in knighthood and faith should fail.'<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She herself was the prey of sorrow, and her hands did she wring amain,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_181">[Pg 181]</a></span>
<span class="i0">While the teardrops they chased each other down her cheeks like a shower of rain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her eyes they gave faithful witness to the grief that her bosom filled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For of true heart she spake, the maiden, nor e'en then was the sorrow stilled.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then unto the king she turned her, and she spake 'Is there here a knight<span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who yearneth for love's rewarding, and for honour and fame would fight?<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I know of four queens, and maidens four hundred, and all are fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Château Merveil is their dwelling; and like to the empty air<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall be all knightly ventures to the venture that Burg within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he who shall face its peril, from true love shall his guerdon win.<span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' far be that Burg and distant, and weary and rough the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Its walls must I seek if haply I reach them ere close of day.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sad was the maid, not joyful, nor courteous she bade farewell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But weeping she gazed around her, and she cried as the teardrops fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ah! woe unto thee, Monsalväsch, thou dwelling and goal of grief,  <span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since no man hath pity on thee, or bringeth thy woe relief!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus had the sorceress Kondrie, that maiden fierce and proud,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wrought evil upon the Waleis, and his fame to the earth had bowed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Naught they helped him, his bold heart's counsel, his manhood and knightly fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And high o'er all other virtues, the virtue of knightly shame.     <span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(For falsehood he ne'er had hearkened,) and true shame doth rewarding bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it crowneth the soul with honour as the circlet doth crown a king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who true shame doth cherish his work shall for ever stand—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she lifted her voice o'er the maidens, the maiden of fair Lalande,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she wept for the words of Kondrie, and the sorrow of Parzival, <span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the fairest of men did she deem him; and swiftly the teardrops fell<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the eyes of many a woman, for the sake of that hero bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they sorrowed at heart, and their weeping must many a knight behold!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now sorrow had Kondrie brought them; and e'en as her way she went<br></span>
<span class="i0">Another must ride towards them on a warlike errand bent;           <span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A knight of a haughty bearing, and his harness was fair to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From his foot to the goodly helmet, and royal its cost must be,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_182">[Pg 182]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And richly plumed was the helmet; and, e'en as the man, the steed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was clad in such glittering armour as serveth for knightly need.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he found them, both man and maiden, heavy and sad at heart,    <span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As he rode nigh unto the circle; hear ye how he bare his part—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' his mien it was high and haughty, yet his heart it was full of woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the twain shall ye learn the reason; thro' his manhood he pride must know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet grief to his heart taught mourning—Thus rode he unto the ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it well he should come within it? Then squires to his aid did spring,<span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the gallant knight they greeted, yet were he and his shield unknown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor he doffed from his head the helmet, and sorrow was his alone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his hand bare a sword unsheathèd, and he asked for those heroes twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Where are they whom I fain would speak with, King Arthur and Knight Gawain?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straight thro' the ring he passed him, and a costly coat he bare,<span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas wrought of silk all shining, in Orient woven fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And before the host he halted as he sate there within the ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake aloud, 'God's favour be on thee, thou gracious king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And upon these knights and ladies—To all whom mine eyes here see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I offer, in greeting, service, yet be <i>one</i> from my greeting free;<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ne'er will I do him service, nay, rather I choose his hate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ill-will he beareth to me, mine ill-will with his may mate!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And 'twere well that I name him to ye. Alas! alas! woe is me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">My heart he so sore hath wounded, mine anguish o'er-great shall be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here doth he sit, Sir Gawain, whom all men were wont to praise,<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">High standeth his fame, yet dishonour it ruleth, methinks, his ways;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since avarice to this betrayed him, in greeting my lord he slew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The kiss once by Judas given, it taught him such guile anew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many thousand hearts hath he wounded—'Twas murder base, abhorred,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he, upon whom he wrought it, erewhile was my dearest lord.     <span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An Sir Gawain would here deny it, true answer our strife shall yield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forty days from to-day shall he meet me, and face me on battlefield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before Askalon's king and ruler, in the city of Schamfanzon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus I bid him in honour face me, and for conflict his armour don.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And this grace shall he not refuse me, but thither his shield shall bear;<span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet further shall he bethink him, by the helmet he weareth fair,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_183">[Pg 183]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the life that a knight beseemeth, who two treasures in pledge doth hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True shame, and a faith unwavering, and their fame shall be new, as old.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But from shame may Gawain ne'er free him, if a knight of the Table Round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose heroes stand here before me, he thinketh he may be found.    <span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For its honour and fame are vanished, if false knight sit its board beside—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks ye have heard mine errand, and ye know I came not to chide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For here would I not blame, but battle, and death shall my guerdon be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An it be not a life of honour, that Good Fortune shall hold for me!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sad was the king and silent, yet answer at last he gave,      <span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Know, Sir Knight, that Gawain is my nephew, and myself would the conflict brave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere his bones should lie dishonoured—If Good Fortune by Gawain stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">In strife shalt thou well acknowledge, 'neath the might of his strong right hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">That his body in faith he keepeth, and falsehood afar doth hold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If another hath done thee evil methinks art thou over-bold,        <span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His shame dost thou speak too loudly, who never hath done thee ill—<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he winneth, perchance, thine homage, and thou ownest him guiltless still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet hast thou in short space spoken such words of a blameless knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">As have shamèd for aye thine honour, if this folk read the thing aright!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then upsprang the proud Knight Beaucorps, brother to Gawain he,    <span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake in his wrath, 'Wouldst thou fight him? Then myself his pledge will be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thou speakest false of Gawain; and know that thy words of shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have kindled anew within me fierce wrath's devouring flame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou speakest not Gawain guiltless of all dishonour, I<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stand here to fight his battle, and to be his surety.              <span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Think not by thy words of scorning to lower his lofty fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unstainèd is Gawain's honour, and thy words are but words of shame!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he turned him to his brother, and he spake of true heart and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Bethink thee now, my brother, of all thou hast done for me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast helped me unto the winning of fame, for thy toil's reward<span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Bid me here to be hostage for thee, and bid me thine honour guard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If Good Fortune be here my portion, and I win here my meed of fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then <i>thine</i> be the crown of honour, and thy foeman hath naught but shame.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">By his knighthood and love as a brother he besought him right earnestly;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_184">[Pg 184]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Gawain, 'Now in sooth, my brother, too wise shall I surely be<span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To hearken to thee, and to grant thee what thou askest of right good-will;<br></span>
<span class="i0">What meaneth this strife, I wot not, and of fighting have had my fill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of good-will would I ne'er deny thee what boon thou from me shouldst crave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet shame must I bear for ever if this conflict I fail to brave!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Beaucorps he prayed him straitly—then out spake the stranger knight,<span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'A man whom I ne'er have heard of now lusteth with me to fight!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I spake not of <i>him</i>, and no evil, methinks, hath he done to me.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Strong, gallant, and fair to look on, and faithful and rich is he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And well might he be my hostage, yet against <i>him</i> no wrath I bear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">My lord and my kinsman was he for whose death I this strife declare,<span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And brothers twain were our fathers, as comrades and kinsmen true;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And were he a crownèd monarch against whom my sword I drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By my birth might I give him battle, and vengeance of right demand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a royal race, and a princely, was I born in a distant land.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Askalon is my country, I am Landgrave of Schamfanzon,          <span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Kingrimursel do they call me; if Gawain's fame be not outrun<br></span>
<span class="i0">No otherwise may he free him, but conflict with me must dare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet safe-conduct throughout my kingdom, from all save my hand, I swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In peace may he ride, and safety, to the field where I vengeance claim;<br></span>
<span class="i0">God keep in His grace those I leave here, save one, and ye know <i>his</i> name!'<span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So passed he, the gallant hero, from the plain of Plimizöl,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as his name was namèd, all men knew Kingrimursel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the fame of this knight so valiant was known thro' the far lands wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it seemèd them well that to Gawain might ill thro' this strife betide<br></span>
<span class="i0">When they thought of the strength and the manhood of this knight who rode swift away.<span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many must sorely vex them that no honour he won that day;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet full often a message cometh, I myself shall such venture know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of such wise, that the guest who bears it, of his host must ungreeted go!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From Kondrie they heard the tidings of Parzival's name and kin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How a queen, she had been his mother, and his sire was an Angevin. <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake—''Twas at fair Kanvoleis, and the story we know full well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He served her with deeds of knighthood, and many a joust befell,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_185">[Pg 185]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And there by his dauntless manhood he won him that lady bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the noble Queen Anflisé, she taught him, that gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such courtesy as befitted a hero of lineage high;                  <span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And no Breton but shall rejoice him, that his son now draweth nigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For of him, e'en as of his father, may this tale of a truth be told<br></span>
<span class="i0">That honour is his yoke-fellow, as she was of his sire of old.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus joy alike and sorrow came to Arthur's host that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And mingled, the life of the heroes, since the twain they must have their way.<span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Upstood they all as one man, and all with one voice they wept,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bravest knights among them within the circle stept,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they looked on Gawain and the Waleis where each by the other stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they wove them fair words of comfort to pleasure the heroes good.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Klamidé the king bethought him that the loss which should be his share<span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was greater than that of another, and too sharp was his pain to bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to Parzival he quoth thus, 'If the Grail thee for lord must own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet still would I mourn my sorrow, and of true heart my woe make known.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the kingdom of Tribalibot, and Kaucasus' golden strand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whatsoe'er shall be writ of riches in Christian or paynim land,    <span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, even the Grail and its glory, they had failèd the hurt to cure<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which at Pelrapär was my portion, or the grief that I here endure!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah me! Of all men most wretched am I since thy valiant hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of joy and of blessing robbed me!—See the princess of fair Lalande,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Know thou that this noble lady she keepeth such faith with thee,   <span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That no service else she craveth, and none other knight will she;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet well might she crown his service who served her for love alone!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that I am so long her captive, methinks may she well bemoan.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If my joy thou to life wouldst quicken, then give me thine aid, I pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And teach her herself to honour in such wise that her love repay   <span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a measure the ill thou didst me, and that which thro' thee I lost,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the goal of my joy fled from me and my pathway by thee was crossed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But for thee, I, methinks, had reached it, and if thou art foeman true<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wilt help me with this fair maiden, and my gladness shall wax anew!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Right gladly will I,' quoth the Waleis, 'if so be she will grant my prayer,<span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would I bring thee comfort, since <i>mine</i> is that maiden fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">For whose sake thou sore didst sorrow, my wife and my queen is she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kondwiramur, the fairest of all women on earth that be!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the heathen Queen of Ianfus, King Arthur, and Guinevere,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_186">[Pg 186]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Kunnewaaré of Lalande, and Jeschuté of Karnant, who these words must hear,<span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Came near with sweet words of comfort—what would ye they should do more?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kunnewaaré they gave to Klamidé, who yearned for her love so sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gave her, as her rewarding, himself, his body fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a queenly crown and golden henceforth on her head she bare!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the heathen unto the Waleis, 'Kondrie a man hath named,      <span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom thou as in truth thy brother, rejoicing, might well have claimed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For far and wide he ruleth in the power of a double crown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And alike by land and water men in fear to his hand bow down.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Assagog is one kingdom, Zassamank shall the other be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two mighty lands and powerful from fear and from weakness free.    <span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And naught shall be like his riches save those the Baruch doth own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or those of far Tribalibot, he is worshipped as God alone!<br></span>
<span class="i0">A marvel his skin to look on, and like unto none his face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For 'tis black, and 'tis white, as his parents, who sprang of a diverse race.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' one of his lands I journeyed as hither I took my way,        <span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And full fain had he been my wanderings in a far-off land to stay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet but little his will prevailèd, tho' I am his near of kin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The cousin unto his mother, and <i>he</i> is a mighty king!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet hear thou more of his prowess; his saddle no man may keep<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who rideth a joust against him, and fame doth he richly reap.      <span class="linenum">880</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And no gentler knight or truer e'er lay on a mother's breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And falsehood it fleeth from him, and truth in his heart doth rest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, true and fair in his dealings is Feirefis Angevin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And women he serveth duly, tho' he pain thro' his service win!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Tho' all men to me were strangers, yet hither I came to know      <span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What ventures of gallant knighthood a Christian land might show;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of all Heaven's gifts the highest, I ween, shall thy portion be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Christendom winneth honour thro' the praise it doth give to thee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thine is a noble bearing, and fair is thy form and face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in thee beauty mates with manhood, and strength doth thy youth embrace!'<span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Both rich and wise was the heathen, and of wisdom she token gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the French tongue her speech was holden.) Then out spake the hero brave,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_187">[Pg 187]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'God reward thee, Lady, who thinkest to comfort me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet sorrow it fast doth bind me, and the cause would I tell to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the shame that has here befallen think not I shall lightly bear,<span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And here many sin against me, who give to my plaint no ear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The while I must list their mocking!—No joy shall my portion be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or long or short be my wanderings, till the Grail once again I see!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my soul's unrest constrains me, and it driveth me on my way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor so long as my life endureth shall my feet from their wanderings stay!'<span class="linenum">900</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'If a courteous and knightly bearing but bringeth rewarding still<br></span>
<span class="i0">In shame, and in this world's mocking, then methinks I was counselled ill!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For 'twas Gurnemanz who bade me of questions rash beware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from words and ways unfitting a courteous knight forbear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here standeth full many a hero, I pray ye give counsel true,       <span class="linenum">905</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By your courtesy and knighthood, that your grace I may win anew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here hath judgment been passed upon me with bitter words and strong—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who withholdeth from me his favour, I deem not he doth me wrong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If perchance, in the days hereafter, fame and honour my lot shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then according to those my dealings, I pray ye to deal with me;    <span class="linenum">910</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But now must I haste far from ye—An oath have ye sworn me here<br></span>
<span class="i0">While I stood in the strength of mine honour; of that oath do I hold ye clear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the day I have won me payment for my fresh joy waxed wan and pale;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart shall be home of sorrow, nor tears to mine eyes shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the day that at far Monsalväsch my labour I left undone,       <span class="linenum">915</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And myself from all joy I severed, and woe for my guerdon won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah God! they were fair, those maidens! and ne'er was there wonder tale<br></span>
<span class="i0">That men told, but as naught its marvels to those of the wondrous Grail!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet torment so sore, and sighing, are the lot of Its king, alas!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Small good hath my coming done thee, thou hapless Anfortas!'       <span class="linenum">920</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor longer the knight might linger, but part they must alway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So turned he unto King Arthur, and leave he fain would pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of him, his knights, and ladies, with their favour would he depart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And none, I ween, but sorrowed that he rode hence sad at heart.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hand in hand King Arthur sware him, if henceforth his land should bear<span class="linenum">925</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such woe as Klamidé brought him, then the shame he with him would share,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_188">[Pg 188]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake that full sore it grieved him that crowns and kingdoms twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the riches that were their portion, Lähelein from the knight had ta'en.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And service both true and faithful many sware unto him that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet from the court of King Arthur, sorrow-driven, he passed away.<span class="linenum">930</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the fair maid Kunnewaaré, she took the hero bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hence by the hand she led him, and in this wise the tale is told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Gawain he turned and kissed him, and he spake out in manly wise<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the hero strong and gallant: 'Now thou ridest in warlike guise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy feet shall be swift to battle—God guide thee upon thy way,<span class="linenum">935</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And give me such strength to serve thee as my heart shall be fain alway.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Parzival cried, 'Woe is me! Who is He, this mighty God?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had He power, then methinks our portion had ne'er been this shame abhorred!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Small power shall be His! I served Him from the day I first knew His grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforth I renounce His service; doth He hate me, His hate I'll face!<span class="linenum">940</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, friend, in thine hour of peril, as thy shield may a <i>wife's</i> love stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dost thou know her for pure and holy, then the thought of her guide thine hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her love from all evil guard thee,—as I wish, may it be to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For little I wot of the future, if thy face I again may see!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And their parting it brought them sorrow, for comrades in ill were they.<span class="linenum">945</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the maiden Kunnewaaré, to her tent must he take his way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she bade them bring his harness; with her hands so soft and white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She bound the armour on him who had served her as faithful knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, ''Tis my right to do this, since it is thro' thy deed alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Brandigan's gallant monarch now claimeth me as his own.       <span class="linenum">950</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For otherwise thy valour but bringeth me grief and pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou not against sorrow armèd, then thy loss shall outweigh my gain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For battle decked was his charger, and his sorrow must wake to life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair was the knight to look on; and the harness he bare for strife<br></span>
<span class="i0">Knew never a flaw, but was costly, and as sunshine 'twas white and fair,<span class="linenum">955</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And radiant with gold and jewels the corslet and coat he ware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the helmet alone was lacking—ere he bound it upon his head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the self-same hour he kissed her, Kunnewaaré, the gracious maid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this of the twain was told me, that the parting was sore to see<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_189">[Pg 189]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Twixt those two who loved each other in all honour and loyalty.   <span class="linenum">960</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So hence let him ride, our hero, and what ventures a man may tell<br></span>
<span class="i0">He shall measure them not with the ventures that to Gamuret's son befell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet hear ye awhile of his doings, where he journeyed and whence would ride—<br></span>
<span class="i0">He who loveth not deeds of knighthood, if counsel he take of pride<br></span>
<span class="i0">For awhile will forget his doings—On thee, Kondwiramur,           <span class="linenum">965</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On thy fair face and lovely body, thy lover thought evermore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">What ventures he dared in thy service as knightly the Grail he sought!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor tarried he in the seeking but onward his way he fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The child of fair Herzeleide, and knew not that he was heir<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the glories that he rode seeking, to the Grail and Its palace fair!<span class="linenum">970</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then forth went full many a vassal on a toilsome and weary way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To gaze on the wondrous castle where in magic fetters lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">Four hundred gracious maidens, and four queens, right fair to see.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Château Merveil was the castle; and no hate shall they earn from me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I grudge them naught they may win there! No woman rewardeth me,    <span class="linenum">975</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For she to whom I do service, from payment hath set me free!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the Greek, Sir Klias, 'Yea, there was I overthrown!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And thus in the ears of all men did he frankly the truth make known)<br></span>
<span class="i0">'For the Turkowit he thrust me from my charger unto my shame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And four queens who there lie captive the knight unto me did name; <span class="linenum">980</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And old are the twain, and the others as yet they shall children be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the first maid is called Itonjè, and the second shall be Kondrie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the third she is named Arnivè, and Sangivè the fourth is hight!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then fain to behold the wonders of that castle was many a knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet their journey brought little profit, for sorrow o'ertook them there.<span class="linenum">985</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I mourn not o'ermuch for their sorrow; for he who would labour bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strife, for the sake of a woman, for guerdon shall gladness know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' grief shall be mixed with his gladness, and his joy shall be crossed with woe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I know not the which shall be stronger, or if sorrow shall joy outweigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But so runneth the world for ever, where Frau Minne she holdeth sway!<span class="linenum">990</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now Gawain he must make him ready, and he girded his armour on,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_190">[Pg 190]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For the strife that afar should wait him, in the kingdom of Askalon.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sad was many a Breton, and ladies and maidens fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a true heart did they bemoan them that Gawain must to conflict fare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And orphaned and reft of glory henceforth was the Table Round.     <span class="linenum">995</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Sir Gawain he well bethought him, since victor he would be found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade the merchants bring him good shields both hard and light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And little he recked their colour so they served his need in fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">On laden mules they brought them, and methinks that they sold them dear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And three did he take as his portion—and the hero he chose him here<span class="linenum">1000</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Seven chargers well fit for battle, and he chose him as friends so good<br></span>
<span class="i0">Twelve spears of sharp steel of Angram, and the hilts were of hollow wood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">They were reeds grown in heathen marshlands, Oraste Gentesein their name.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain he prayed leave, and rode forth, dauntless, to seek him fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with royal hand, for his journey, King Arthur he gave the knight<span class="linenum">1005</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Red gold, and rich store of silver, and jewels gleaming bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And heavy the weight of his treasure—Then the hero rode swift away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween 'twas towards sore peril that his pathway must lead that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she sailed to her distant kingdom, the young Queen Ekuba,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I speak of the heathen princess; and they scattered to lands afar <span class="linenum">1010</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk who awhile abode there, on the fair plain of Plimizöl;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And King Arthur and all his courtiers they gat them to Karidöl.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet first they prayed leave, Klamidé and Kunnewaaré of fair Lalande,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Duke Orilus and his lady, Jeschuté of Karnant.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet till the third day with Klamidé in the plain did the twain abide,<span class="linenum">1015</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the marriage-feast was holden ere yet from the place they ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet small was the pomp; in his kingdom, I ween, should it greater be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And free was his hand and knightly, and he dealt right courteously,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a knight at his bidding henceforth must his man remain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a wandering minstrel did he gather within his train,     <span class="linenum">1020</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he led them into his kingdom, and in honour, rich gifts, and land<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gave unto them, nor churlish would any refuse his hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Duke Orilus and Jeschuté, to Brandigan the twain would fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the love that unto Klamidé and Kunnewaaré they bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they thought them that fitting honour to their sister they scarce had done<span class="linenum">1025</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till as queen they had seen her crownèd, and set on the royal throne.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now I know well if wise the woman, and true of heart she be,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_191">[Pg 191]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Who seeth this story written, of a sooth will she own to me<br></span>
<span class="i0">That better I speak of women than I spake of <i>one</i> erewhile;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For true was fair Belakané, and free from all thought of guile,   <span class="linenum">1030</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For dead was her love, yet lifeless he still o'er her heart did reign.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a dream filled fair Herzeleide with torment of fear and pain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Queen Guinevere bewailed her full sorely for Ither's death,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(And little I grudge her mourning, for no truer knight e'er drew breath).<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot when King Lac's fair daughter rode forth such a shameful ride<span class="linenum">1035</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then sorely I mourned the sorrow that, guiltless, she must abide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sore smitten was Kunnewaaré, and torn was her golden hair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now the twain they are well avengèd, and glory for shame they bear!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he who doth tell this story, he weaveth his ventures fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he knoweth right well to rhyme them, in lines that break and pair.<span class="linenum">1040</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain were I more to tell ye, an she give to my words good heed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who treadeth with feet far smaller than the feet that shall spur my steed!<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_192">[Pg 192]</a><br><a id="Page_193">[Pg 193]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK VII<br>

OBILOT</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_194">[Pg 194]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>The poet will now for a while recount the adventures of Gawain;
whom many have held to be as valiant a knight as Parzival.</p>
<p>Book <span class="smcap">VII.</span> tells how Gawain fell in with the army of King Meljanz of
Lys, who would fain avenge himself on Duke Lippaut, whose daughter had
scorned his love. How Gawain came to the beleaguered city of Beaurosch;
how Obie scorned him; and how Obilot besought him to be her knight.
How the heroes fought before the walls of Beaurosch, and of the valiant
deeds of Gawain and the Red Knight. How Gawain took Meljanz of
Lys captive; how Obilot made peace betwixt Obie and Meljanz, and how
Gawain rode forth from Beaurosch.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_195">[Pg 195]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK VII</p>
<p class="ph2">OBILOT
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_a.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_a.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Awhile shall this venture follow the knight, who to fly was fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">From shame, nor with guile had dealings, that hero bold, Gawain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a one hath held him for as brave, yea, for braver knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than Parzival, who the hero of this wonder-tale is hight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he who his friend would ever with his words to the heavens upraise<span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Is slow to speak well of another, or to yield him his meed of praise;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But him shall the people follow whose praises with truth are wrought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Else whatever he speak, or hath spoken, shall ne'er under roof be brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who shall shelter the word of wisdom if wise men their aid withhold?<br></span>
<span class="i0">But a song that is woven of falsehood is best left in the outer cold,<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Homeless, upon the snowdrift, that the mouth may wax chill and sore<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hath spread for truth the story—such rewarding hath God in store<br></span>
<span class="i0">As all true folk must wish him whose guerdon in toil is told—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who is swift to such deeds, I wot me, but blame for reward shall hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if good men and true shall praise him, then folly doth rule their mind;<span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He will flee such who true shame knoweth, and in knighthood his rule would find.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And true of heart was Sir Gawain, for courage as sentinel<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had guarded his fame, nor shadow of cowardice across it fell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But his heart in the field of battle was strong as a mighty tower,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Steadfast in sharpest conflict, yet foremost in danger's hour.      <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And friend and foe bare witness to the fame of his battle-cry;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fain was Kingrimursel to rob him of his glory thus waxen high—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now far from the court of King Arthur for many a weary day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I know not their tale to tell ye, did the valiant Gawain stray;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So rode he, the gallant hero, from out of a woodland shade,         <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_196">[Pg 196]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And his folk they were close behind him as he wended adown the glade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there on a hill before him he was 'ware of a goodly sight<br></span>
<span class="i0">That would teach him fear, yet fresh courage it brought to the gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For the hero he saw full clearly how a host on their way would fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">With pomp of warlike pageant, and banners borne high in air.        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought, 'I too far have journeyed this host in the wood to wait'—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade them prepare the charger that was Orilus' gift of late,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And red were its ears, and Gringuljet, I think me, they called its name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without a prayer he won it—The steed from Monsalväsch came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lähelein, in a joust he took it, when lifeless its rider fell       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By the Lake of Brimbane—Hereafter Trevrezent would the story tell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thought Gawain, 'He who cowardly flieth ere the foe on his track shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Flieth all too soon for his honour—this host would I nearer see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whatever may then befall me; they have seen me ere this I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, for aught that may chance unto me, wit shall counsel me well enow.'<span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then down he sprang from his charger as one who his goal hath found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Countless I ween the army that in troops was toward him bound,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw many robes fair fashioned, and shields with their blazon bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he knew them not, nor the banners that danced on the breezes light.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Strange shall I be to this army,' quoth Gawain, 'strange are they to me,<span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If they count this to me for evil then a joust shall they surely see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a spear will I break with these heroes ere yet on my way I ride!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gringuljet too was ready when his master would strife abide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In many an hour of peril he the hero to joust had borne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Gawain had well bethought him when the steed he would ride that morn.<span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There Gawain saw many a helmet, costly and decked full fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And new spears white, unsplintered, in sheaves to their goal they bare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the pages hands were given those blazoned with colours clear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the badge might ye read on the pennons that floated from every spear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the son of King Lot, Sir Gawain, he saw there a crowded throng, <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There were mules with harness laden; heavy wagons with horses strong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they hasted them, fain for shelter; and behind them a wondrous store<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of goods, borne by travelling merchants as was ever the way of yore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And women were there in plenty, and of knightly girdle bright<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_197">[Pg 197]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The twelfth might some wear, the payment and pledge of love holden light.<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Not <i>queens</i> were they hight, I think me, <i>Vivandierès</i> was their name—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And young and old behind them a rabble onward came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they ran till their limbs were weary; and a rope had fit guerdon been<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many who swelled this army, and dishonoured true folk I ween!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So they rode, and they ran, that army, and Gawain stood beside the way,<span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So it chanced they who saw the hero deemed him part of their host that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never this side of the water, or in lands that beyond it lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So gallant a host had journeyed, great their strength and their courage high.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And close on their track there followed, spurring his steed amain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A squire of noble bearing, with a led horse beside his rein;        <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a fair new shield he carried, and ever his spurs he plied,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor thought to spare his charger, but swift to the strife would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his raiment was fairly fashioned—Then Gawain his pathway crossed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, greeting, he asked him tidings, who was lord of this goodly host?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the squire, 'Sir Knight thou mockest, were I lacking in courtesy,<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And have chastisement earned, then I pray thee that my penance shall other be<br></span>
<span class="i0">That shall wound not so sore mine honour—For God's sake lay thine hate aside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks thou right well shalt know them, these knights that before us ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why askest thou me? Of a surety to each other shall ye be known<br></span>
<span class="i0">As well, nay, a thousand times better, than I unto thee had shown!' <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then many an oath he sware him, he knew not the race or name<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the folk who went there before him, 'My journey hath won but shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since in truth must I make confession that never before to-day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mine eyes have beheld these heroes, tho' mine aid men right oft would pray!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the squire he quoth unto Gawain, 'Sir Knight, <i>mine</i> the wrong hath been,<span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy question I should have answered, here my wisdom hath failed I ween!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now pass judgment on me, I pray thee, of thy friendly heart and true,<br></span>
