<span class="i0">Hereafter I'll gladly tell thee, first must I my folly rue.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Then, lad, by thy words of repentance, sure token of courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The name of this gallant army I prithee to tell to me!'             <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_198">[Pg 198]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight, he who rides before us, and no man his way doth bar,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is King Poidikonjonz; and beside him Duke Astor he rides to war,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Lanveronz is he ruler—and there rideth beside the twain<br></span>
<span class="i0">One whose roughness and ways discourteous Love's payment have sought in vain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He beareth the brand unknightly, Meljakanz that prince is hight,    <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He wooeth nor wife nor maiden, but their love will he take with might,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, methinks, men for that should slay him—Poidikonjonz' son is he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here will he fight with his army, and he fighteth right valiantly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dauntless his heart; but such manhood it profiteth naught, I trow—<br></span>
<span class="i0">An ye threaten, perchance, her sucklings, she fighteth, the mother sow!<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a voice shall praise him whose strength lacketh knighthood fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And methinks to the truth of my speaking many men will their witness bear.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now hearken to greater marvels, and mark thou the words I say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">One with a mighty army doth follow upon our way<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom folly doth drive to battle—The young King Meljanz of Lys,    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Scorned love wrought in him fierce anger, and pride vexed him needlessly,'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And courteous he spake to Sir Gawain. 'What I saw, I Sir Knight will say:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sire of the young King Meljanz, as he on his death-bed lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He bade them draw near unto him, the princes from out his land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his gallant life lay forfeit, a pledge in stern Death's cold hand,<span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to Death he needs must yield him—In grief o'er his coming end<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the faith of the princes round him his son would the king commend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he chose out one from among them, the chief of his vassals true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his faith was proved and steadfast, and from false ways afar he flew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gave the lad to his keeping, and he quoth, 'Now, with hand and heart,<span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">True service henceforward show him, bid him aye act a kingly part<br></span>
<span class="i0">To vassal alike and stranger; bid him list to the poor man's prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And freely give of his substance.' Thus he left him unto his care.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And Prince Lippaut did as his monarch, dying, of him did pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor failed in aught, but true service he did to his lord alway.    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he took the lad to his castle, and the prince had two children fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He loved them well, and I think me, e'en to-day they his love shall share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">One maiden in naught was lacking, save in age, that a knight might crave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her love for his love's rewarding; Obie was the name they gave<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_199">[Pg 199]</a></span>
<span class="i0">To this maid; Obilot, her sister; and the elder maid, I ween,      <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath wrought ill, for she, and none other, the cause of this strife hath been.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'It so fell that one day the young king for his service reward would pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas an ill thought, she quoth, and she asked him why his wits he had cast away?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake unto him, 'I think me, e'en if thou so old shouldst be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That 'neath shield thou the hours hadst counted that in worthy strife might flee;<span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With helmet on head hadst mingled in knightly venture bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the tale of thy days, if reckoned, full five years more had told;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If there thou hadst won thee honour, and hither hadst come again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bowed thyself to my bidding, if a <i>yea</i> I to speak were fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To that which thou now desirest, all too soon should I grant thy prayer—<span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou art dear, I will ne'er deny it, as Galoes to Annora fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For death did she seek, and I think me that her seeking was not in vain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When she lost him, her well belovèd, and her knight in a joust was slain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now sore doth it grieve me, Lady, that love worketh so in thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thine anger with words of scorning thus venteth itself on me. <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For true service,' quoth he, 'winneth favour, an love thus be well approved;<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er-weening thy pride thus to taunt me that madness my speech had moved!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Small wisdom in this thou showest, 'twere better thou hadst bethought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How thy father is but my vassal, and save of my grace hath naught!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'For that which he holds can he serve thee,' she spake, 'higher is my aim,<span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For fief will I hold of no man, none shall me as vassal claim!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so high do I prize my freedom that no crown it shall be too high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That an earthly head e'er weareth!' Then he spake out wrathfully,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Methinks thou hast been well tutored, that thy pride shall have waxed so great,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thy father such counsel gave thee, then penance on wrong shall wait—<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis meet that for this I arm me, some wounded shall be, some slain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An they call it or war, or Tourney, many spears shall they break in twain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thus in anger he left the maiden, and all did his wrath bemoan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, full sore it grieved the lady—Her father must well atone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' he sware as his lord reproached him, guiltless of wrong was he,<span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Or straight were his ways or crooked, his peers should his judges be,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_200">[Pg 200]</a></span>
<span class="i0">All the princes in court assembled)—that he to this strait was brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' no sin of his own—And eager the prince from his lord besought<br></span>
<span class="i0">His favour and love as of old time, but in vain he for peace might pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For anger it ruled the monarch, and his gladness was reft away.'   <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Tho' hasty the prince they counselled a prisoner to make his lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His host had he been, and such treason of a true knight were aye abhorred.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Farewell, the king ne'er bade him, but he rode forth in wrath and pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his pages, the sons of princes, aloud in their sorrow cried.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long time with the king they dwelt there, and goodwill they to Lippaut bare,<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For in truth did he aye entreat them, nor failed them in knighthood fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis my master alone who is wrathful, tho' he, too, Lippaut's care might claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A Frenchman, the lord of Beauvais, Lisavander they call his name.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the one alike and the other, ere a knight's shield they thought to bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Must renounce the prince's service, and war against Lippaut swear; <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And some shall be prince's children, and some not so highly born,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom the king to the ranks of knighthood hath lifted, I ween, this morn.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And one who in strife is skilful and bold doth the vanguard lead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Poidikonjonz of Gros, and with him hath he many an armed steed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Meljanz is son to his brother; and haughty of heart the twain, <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The young as the old, I think me discourtesy here doth reign!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thus these two kings, moved by anger, will forth unto Beaurosch ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where with toil he would win the favour that the maid to his love denied.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there with thrust and onslaught shall be broken many a spear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet so well is Beaurosch guarded that, tho' twenty hosts were here,<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Each one than our army greater, it ne'er to our force would yield!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The rear-guard knoweth naught of my journey, from the others I stole this shield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest perchance my lord should find here a joust, and with onslaught fierce<br></span>
<span class="i0">And clash of the meeting chargers the spear thro' his shield might pierce.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the squire he looked behind him, and his lord on his track did ride,<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Three steeds and twelve spears unsplintered sped onward his rein beside.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween that his haste betrayed him, he would fain in the foremost flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">The first joust for his own have challenged, so read I the tale aright.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_201">[Pg 201]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the squire he spake unto Gawain, 'Thy leave I, Sir Knight, would pray,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he turned him again to his master—What should Gawain do alway <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Save see how this venture ended? Yet awhile he doubted sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought, 'If I look on conflict, and fight not as aye of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then methinks shall my fame be tarnished; and yet if I here delay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en tho' it may be for battle, then in sooth is it reft away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My meed of worldly honour—To fight not, methinks, were best,      <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">First must I fulfil my challenge.' But afresh doubt vexed his breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he deemed that his warlike errand but little might brook delay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet how could he take his journey thro' this army that barred his way?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Now God give me counsel, and strengthen my manhood's might,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on to the town of Beaurosch rode Gawain as gallant knight.     <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So before him lay Burg and city; fairer dwelling no man might know;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Already it shone before him with its turrets in goodly row,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The crown of all other castles—Before it the army lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the plain 'neath the walls of the city; thro' the lines must he take his way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And right well he marked, Sir Gawain, many tents in a goodly ring, <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And strange banners waved beside them, which strange folk to the fight would bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And doubt in his heart found dwelling, by eagerness cleft in twain—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then straight thro' the host encamped there rode the gallant knight Gawain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One tent-rope it touched the other, tho' the camp it was long and wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw how they lay, and he noted the task which each one there plied.<span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth they, '<i>Soit bien venu</i>' then '<i>Gramercy</i>' the knight for an answer gave—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And troops from Semblidag lay there, hired soldiers both strong and brave;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And closely they camped beside them, the archers from Kahetei—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strangers are oft unfriendly; As King Lot's son he passed them by<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man of them all bade him tarry, so he rode o'er the grassy plain,<span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And toward the beleaguered city Sir Gawain he turned his rein.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he thought,'Must I e'en as a smuggler, in hiding-place bestow<br></span>
<span class="i0">My goods, then the town is safer, methinks, than the plain below,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor on gain shall my thoughts be turnèd, for this be my care alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An Fate will so far befriend me, to guard that which is mine own!' <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To the city gate he rode thus, and he found that which worked him woe,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_202">[Pg 202]</a></span>
<span class="i0">None too costly the Burgers deemed it, but their portals against the foe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had they walled up; well armed the watch-towers, and he saw on each rampart high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Archers, with cross-bow bended that their bolts 'gainst the foe might fly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For defence and defiance ready on the battlements they stood.      <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Up the hillside toward the castle he turned him, that hero good.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tho' little he knew the pathway to the Burg came the gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway his eyes beheld them, full many a lady bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the prince's wife had come there, from the hall abroad to gaze,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And daughters twain stood by her, bright as the sunlight's rays.   <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they spake in such wise as Gawain right well their words might hear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now, who is this,' quoth the mother, 'who doth to our aid draw near?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where goes he with pack-horse laden?' Spake the elder daughter fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, mother, 'tis but a merchant!' 'Yet he many a shield doth bear.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Such shall oft be the wont of merchants!' Then the younger sister spake,<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou sayest the thing that is not, and shame to thyself shouldst take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For surely he is no merchant! My knight shall he be straightway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If his service here craveth guerdon, such debt I were fain to pay!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now the squires they saw how a linden and olive-trees stood fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Beneath the walls, and they thought them how a welcome shade were there.<span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What would ye more? Then King Lot's son he straight to the ground did spring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the shade was best, and his servants, they swift to their lord would bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">A cushion fair and a mattress, and the proud knight he sat thereon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From on high gazed a crowd of ladies—Then, as he his rest had won,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They lift adown from the pack-steeds the chests, and the harness bright,<span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And beneath the trees they laid them who rode here with the gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Spake the elder duchess, 'Daughter, what merchant think thou would fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such royal guise? Thou wrongest his rank who now sitteth there!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the younger sister, 'Discourteous she aye shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With pride and scorn did she treat him, our king, Meljanz of Lys,  <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_203">[Pg 203]</a></span>
<span class="i0">When her love he besought—unseemly such words and ways I trow!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then spake Obie, for anger moved her, 'I see naught in that man below!<br></span>
<span class="i0">There sitteth, methinks, a merchant, and he driveth a goodly trade;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would that they well were guarded, the chests that his steeds do lade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And like to a brooding dragon, O foolish sister mine,              <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er his treasure-chest he watcheth, this gallant <i>knight</i> of thine!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And each word that they spake, the maidens, fell clear on Gawain's ear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Leave we their speech, of the city and its peril ye now must hear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A water that ships had sailed on 'neath a bridge of stone flowed past,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the land here was clear of foemen, nor its flood held their armies fast.<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A marshal came swiftly riding 'fore the bridge on the plain so wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a goodly camp had he marked out ere his lord to the field should ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came e'en as they were ready, and with him came many more—<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will tell ye their names who, for truth's sake, and the love they to Lippaut bore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here rode to his aid—His brother, men called him Duke Marangliess,<span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And two swift knights came with him from the land of Brevigariez;<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Schirniel, the gallant monarch who ware crown in Lirivoin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with him there rode his brother, the monarch of Avendroin.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now when the Burgers saw well that help drew anigh their wall<br></span>
<span class="i0">They deemed that an evil counsel which aforetime seemed good to all—<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake their lord, Duke Lippaut, 'Alas! for the woeful hour<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Beaurosch must seal its portals against the foeman's power!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet if I against my master in open field had fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then mine honour, methinks, were smitten, and my courtesy brought to naught.<br></span>
<span class="i0">His grace would beseem me better, and gladden me more, I ween,     <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Than the hatred which now he showeth, of such hate have I guiltless been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A joust that his hand had smitten but little would grace <i>my</i> shield.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or if <i>his</i> of the sword bare token that I 'gainst my king would wield.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinketh, tho' wise the woman, she were shamed an she praised such deed—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, say that my king were captive in my tower, I my lord had freed,<span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And myself had become his prisoner—what had pleased him best to do<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of evil, I'ld gladly bear it, as befitted a vassal true,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_204">[Pg 204]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And I thank my God of a true heart that I here, a free man, stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' spurred by love and anger my king doth invade my land!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he quoth again to the Burgers, 'Now may wisdom with ye be found<span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To counsel me in the perils that compass my path around.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then many a wise man answered, 'Thou hast wrought in no wise amiss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might innocence win its guerdon, then thou never hadst come to this.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then all with one voice they counselled that the gates be opened wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that he should bid their bravest forthwith unto jousting ride. <span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they quoth, 'So to fight were better than thus our ramparts high<br></span>
<span class="i0">To defend 'gainst our king, and the armies twofold that around us lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the most part they are but children who ride with their king to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twere easy to take a hostage, so wrath oft is turned away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the king he shall be so minded, that if here knightly deeds be done,<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He shall free us perchance from our peril, and the ending of wrath be won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far better in field to seek them than forth from our walls be brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">As their captives—Nay, e'en to their tent-ropes, methinks, we with ease had fought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it not for the King Poidikonjonz, 'neath his banner the bravest fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there is our greatest peril, the captive Breton knights,       <span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Duke Astor it is who leads them, and foremost in strife are they;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the king's son is there, Meljakanz; higher his fame to-day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had Gurnemanz been his teacher! Yet never he feareth fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But help have we found against them,'—Now their rede have ye heard aright.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the prince he did as they counselled, the portals he open brake,<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burgers who ne'er lacked courage their way to the field would take.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here one jousted, and there another; and the armies they made their way<br></span>
<span class="i0">With high courage towards the city, right good was their vesper-play.<br></span>
<span class="i0">On both sides the troops were countless; manifold was their battle-cry,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Scotch and Welsh might ye hearken, for in sooth here I tell no lie.<span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And stern were their deeds of knighthood as fitting so stern a fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bravely those heroes battled, till weary each gallant knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And they were little more than children who with the king's army came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they took them as pledge in a corn-field, who thought there to win them fame,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_205">[Pg 205]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he who had ne'er won token of love from a lady fair,           <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Might never more costly raiment on his youthful body bear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Meljanz the venture telleth that in harness bright he rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On high flamed his youthful courage—A charger the king bestrode<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Meljakanz won when in jousting his foe from his steed he swung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas Kay, and so high he smote him that aloft from a bough he hung;<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There Meljakanz won the charger that Meljanz would ride that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And foremost of all the heroes he strove in the knightly fray.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Obie beheld his jousting, and watched him with eager eye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As she stood there among her maidens, and gazed from the palace high.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So quoth she unto her sister, 'See, sister mine, thy knight        <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And <i>mine</i>, unlike do they bear them, for thine hath no will to fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thinketh for sure this city and castle we needs must lose.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An here we would seek defenders, other champion we needs must choose!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the younger must bear her mocking—then she spake, 'Yet I trust my knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hath time yet to show his courage, and thy mockery put to flight.<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For here shall he do me service, and his gladness shall be my care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou holdest him for a merchant, with me shall he trade full fair!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As with words they strove, the maidens, he hearkened, the Knight Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he made as tho' he heard not as he sat on the grassy plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if knightly soul should hearken, nor feel in the hearing shame,<span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twould but be that death had freed him from burden of praise or blame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now still lay the mighty army that Poidikonjonz had led,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save one gallant youth with his vassals, who swift to the combat sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lanveronz was his dukedom—Here came Poidikonjonz the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the old man wise one and other again to the camp would bring,  <span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the vesper-play was ended—In sooth had they fought right well,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for love of many a maiden full many a deed befell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the King Poidikonjonz to Lanveronz' gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">''Twere fitting to wait for thy leader, an thou lusted for fame to fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dost think thou hast borne thee bravely? See the brave Knight Lahduman,<span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And here is my son Meljakanz,—Came these two in the van,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I myself, then, I think me, that a fair fight thou sure shouldst see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wert thou learnèd enow in combat to know what a fight should be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I come not again from this city till of strife we have had our fill,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_206">[Pg 206]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Or man and woman yield them as prisoners to my will!'              <span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Duke Astor, 'The king, thy nephew, O sire fought before the gate<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his army of Lys—Should thine army here slumber o'er-long and late<br></span>
<span class="i0">The while these others battled? Say when didst thou teach such lore?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Must I slumber while others battle then I'll slumber as ne'er of yore!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet believe me, had I not been there then the Burgers had won them fame,<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a fair prize their hand had taken—I have guarded thee here from shame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In God's Name be no longer wrathful! Such valour thy folk have shown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They won more than they lost,—I think me fair Obie the same will own!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet Poidikonjonz was wrathful with his nephew, Meljanz the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' of many a joust the token the young knight from the field must bring,<span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And youthful fame ne'er mourneth such pledge of strife, I ween—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now hear ye again of the maiden who the cause of this strife had been.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hate enow did she bear to Gawain who was guiltless of ill intent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shame would she bring upon him—A servant the maiden sent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Below, to Gawain as he sat there, 'Now ask thou, without delay,    <span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If his steeds be for sale—In his coffers, perchance, he doth bear alway<br></span>
<span class="i0">Goodly raiment that we may purchase; say thou if it so shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then we ladies above in the castle will buy of him readily.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So the serving man went, and his greeting was wrath, for Sir Gawain's eye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Taught fear to his heart, and in terror the lad from his face would fly,<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asked not, nor gave the message his lady had bid him bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor Gawain held his peace, 'Thou rascal, from hence shalt thou swiftly fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a blow will I give thee if again thou dost dare draw near!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the lad hied him back to his lady; what she did shall ye straightway hear:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For she bade one speak to the Burg-grave, Scherules they called his name,<span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Saying, 'This shall he do at my bidding for the sake of his manly fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Neath the olive-trees by the Burg-moat stand seven steeds, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In them shall he find his guerdon, and riches beside enow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A merchant will here deal falsely—I pray he prevent such deed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I trust in his hand; none shall blame him, if the goods he doth hold for meed.'<span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_207">[Pg 207]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The squire went below as she bade him, and his lady's plaint he bare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'From knavery must we guard us,' quoth Scherules, 'I forth will fare.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">So he rode where Gawain was seated whose courage might never fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he found there all weakness lacking, high heart that for naught would quail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a face so fair to look on—Scherules he saw him well,          <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his arms and hands so skilful that a knightly tale might tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Thou art here a stranger, Sir Knight, sure good wit we need<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since here thou hast found no lodging; as sin shalt thou count such deed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will now myself be marshal, folk and goods, all I call mine own<br></span>
<span class="i0">That freely shall do thee service; nor host to his guest hath shown<span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such favour as I would show thee.' 'Thy favour,' quoth Knight Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'As yet shall be undeservèd, yet to follow thee am I fain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Scherules, of honour worthy, he spake of a true heart free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Since the office hath fallen to me, thy guardian 'gainst loss I'll be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If the outer host would rob thee, thou shalt call to thine aid mine hand,'<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then, smiling, he spake to the servants whom he saw round their master stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now load ye again your harness that never a piece shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For hence must we ride, and shelter shall ye find in the lower vale.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With the Burg-grave he rode, Sir Gawain, nor Obie her wrong would own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But she sent a minstrel maiden whom her father right well had known,<span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she bade her bear the tidings, a false coiner had passed that way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'And goodly and rich is his lading; by his knighthood my father pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since many a hireling serves him for steed, and garb, and gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he here let them take their payment, 'twere enow, were they sevenfold.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the prince did she tell, the minstrel, all that his daughter said—<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now to win so rich a booty that his hirelings may be well paid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The need right well he knoweth who hath ridden forth to war,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lippaut, the prince so faithful, by his soldiers was pressed full sore—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought, 'I must win this treasure or by love or by force to-day.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And swiftly he rode; but Scherules, he met him upon his way,       <span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now whither dost ride so swiftly?' 'A knave would I here pursue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A false coiner is he, I think me, if the tale I have heard be true!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now guiltless in sooth was Gawain, 'twas but thro' his steeds and gold<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_208">[Pg 208]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That suspicion on him had lighted—Then loud laughed the Burg-grave bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Nay, sire, they misled thee, they lied who thus told the tale<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Were it wife, or man, or maiden—Nor knighthood my guest shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far otherwise shalt thou judge him, no die he methinks shall hold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ne'er bare he the purse of the changer, if the tale shall aright be told.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Look thou on his mien, and hearken his word, in my house is he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An knighthood aright thou readest then thou knighthood in him shalt see,<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ne'er was he bold in falsehood—Whoever hath done him wrong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An my child it were, or my father; whose wrath waxeth fierce and strong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An my kinsman it be, or my brother, then the rudder of strife shall turn<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst myself, for I will defend him from the wrong that he ne'er did earn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If I with thy will may do so. The knight's garb would I gladly change<span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the hermit's robe of sackcloth, and afar thro' the wide world range<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a land where none may know me, than here thou shouldst reap thee shame!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks it would better fit thee to welcome such guests as came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who have heard the tale of thy sorrow, than to rob them of goods and gold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twould better beseem my master as treason such deed to hold!'     <span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The prince spake, 'I fain would see him.' 'Methinks 'twill not harm my guest.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">So he rode where he looked on Gawain, and two eyes and a heart confessed<br></span>
<span class="i0">(The eyes and the heart of Lippaut) that the stranger was fair to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And knighthood and manly virtue the mate to his mien should be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whosoe'er, by true love constrainèd, hath felt of true love the pain,<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then his heart, as right well ye know it, doth forfeit to Love remain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so doth she change and rule it that no mouth can the wonder speak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be it heart of man or of maiden on which she her will would wreak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the wise doth she bend to folly. Now the twain they were lovers true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Meljanz and maiden Obie—His anger ye needs must rue,         <span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since in wrath he had ridden from her; of sorrow such load she bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">That her spirit was moved to anger unfitting a maiden fair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, guiltless, must Gawain suffer, and others must feel her pain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She had womanly ways forsaken when she gave to her wrath the rein.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whene'er she beheld the hero as a thorn was he to her sight,       <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_209">[Pg 209]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For her heart was fain that Meljanz be held for the bravest knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she thought, 'Doth he bring me sorrow, then sorrow I'll gladly bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er all the world do I love him, my hero, so young and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart for his love aye yearneth.' Oft anger from love doth grow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor blame ye o'er-much the maiden if her love she by wrath would show.<span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now list how he spake, her father, as he looked on the Knight Gawain<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bade him a kindly welcome—In this wise he spake again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight, it may be that thy coming the dawn of our bliss hath been;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' many a land have I journeyed, but no face have I ever seen<br></span>
<span class="i0">So fair to mine eyes as thy face. In this our day of grief         <span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy coming shall bring us comfort, thro' thee may we find relief.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he prayed him take part in the conflict—'If harness shall lack to thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">All thou needest will I prepare thee, so here thou wilt fight for me.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the gallant Gawain, 'That would I of right goodwill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am strong, and well armed for battle, yet from strife must I hold me still,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor fight till the hour appointed; or else would I gladly fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">As thou farest, the fate of battle with thee were I fain to share.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now must I needs forego it, for 'tis fitting I first should fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the foeman to whom I pledged me on mine honour as faithful knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the favour I claim from all true knights my fame must I there defend<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or die on the field—To this conflict, Sir Knight, I my way would wend!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then a grief were his words to Lippaut, and he quoth, 'By thy knightly fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy courtesy, do thou hear me, for free shall I be from blame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two daughters have I, and I love them, and dear to my heart are they,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the joy God in them hath given would I live to my dying day.    <span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, well is me for my children, tho' sorrow thro' them I win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the one of my two fair daughters methinks hath her share therein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And unlike, tho' alike, we share it—for thro' Love doth my lord and king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Work sorrow to her, and thro' Hatred his forces 'gainst me would bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus do I read the riddle, my lord worketh ill to me,          <span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since a <i>son</i> I lack, but I wot well that my <i>daughters</i> shall dearer be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">What, then, if for them I suffer? Then my woe do I count for weal—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who hath never an heir save his daughter, tho' the sword ne'er her grip may feel,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_210">[Pg 210]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Yet other defence may she bring him, she may win him a son and heir;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And such is my hope!'—Quoth Gawain, 'God grant thee this favour fair!'<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Lippaut he sorely pressed him, 'In God's name give thy pleading o'er,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the son of King Lot, 'I pray thee, of thy courtesy ask no more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor let me betray mine honour—Yet this will I do, Sir Knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will think the thing o'er, and my answer shalt thou have ere it draw to night.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he thanked him, the prince, and he rode forth; in the courtyard he found alway<span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His child with the Burg-grave's daughter; with rings did the maidens play.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now, daughter mine, whence camest thou?' thus to Obilot he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Father, I came from the castle, to the strange knight my way I'ld take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would pray him as knight to serve me, methinks he will hear my prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And do for my sake such service as winneth rewarding fair!'        <span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, I fear me, my little daughter, for he saith me nor yea, nor nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But plead thou as I have pleaded.' To the guest did she run straightway.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So came she to Gawain's chamber, he greeted her courteously,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At her fairy feet he sat him, and thanked her that, maidenly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She spake for him to her sister; and he quoth, 'Now if ever a knight<span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had fought for so small a maiden, I were ready for thee to fight!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the little maiden tender spake out so frank and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knight, as God is witness, the first man thou aye shalt be<br></span>
<span class="i0">With whom I have held free converse; if in this my maiden shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my courtesy I wrong not, then joy as reward I claim!           <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ever my mistress taught me how speech is the crown of thought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I pray thee, Sir Knight, to help us—Thro' sorrow thine aid I sought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou wilt, all our need I'll tell thee, nor do thou be wroth with me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I do as befits a maiden, and my prayer to <i>myself</i> shall be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For altho' our name be diverse, yet methinks that <i>thou</i> art <i>I</i>,<span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Take thou my name, and maiden and knight art thou verily.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This grace from us both do I pray here, and if I from hence must go<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ashamed, and my prayer unanswered, then, Sir Knight, I would have thee know<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thy knightly fame must answer to thy knightly courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since my maidenhood sought for shelter in vain in thy chivalry.    <span class="linenum">510</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_211">[Pg 211]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But if thou indeed wilt hearken, and do me this thing I ask,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a true heart true love I'll give thee as rewarding for knightly task.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And art thou true man and courteous, then surely thou'lt do my will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For see, wilt thou serve a maiden, I am worthy thy service still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis true that my father kinsman and cousin for help hath prayed,  <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But for that shalt thou not refuse us, for my love shalt thou give thine aid!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Thy lips, sweet maiden, would bid me my word forswear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wouldst have me my pledge to forfeit? On my knightly honour fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">I pledged my word—An I fail me, 'twere better methinks to die.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, e'en an I did thee service for thy love, still long years must fly<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet thou shalt be a woman, and my service might well approve.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he thought how Parzival trusted less in God than in woman's love,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the words he spake bare the message of the maid unto Gawain's heart;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he vowed to the little lady to bear arms on her father's part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, laughing, he spake, 'My sword-blade thy little hand must guide,<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If my foeman a fair joust seeketh, then thou must against him ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for me shalt thou strive in conflict, for tho' men think they see <i>me</i> fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet <i>thou</i> in my stead shalt have battled,—so keep I my pledge aright.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she spake, 'That will I, right gladly, thy shelter and shield I'll be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thine heart, and thine heart's best comfort, since from grief thou hast set me free.<span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy friend will I be and comrade, and whatever chance betide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A roof 'gainst misfortune's stormcloud, safe dwelling wherein to hide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">True peace this my love shall give thee, Good Fortune to thee I'll bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That-thy strength may by naught be vanquished, I'll guard thee 'gainst host and king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Host am I alike and hostess—To combat I'll ride with thee,        <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou keepest my words in remembrance strength and bliss shall thy portion be.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the gallant Gawain, 'Yea, maiden, the twain I'll share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since my life I vow to thy service, thy love and thy comfort fair.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hand of the little maiden the while in his strong clasp lay—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then she quoth, 'To fulfil mine office I must hence to the Burg away,<span class="linenum">540</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_212">[Pg 212]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Wouldst thou fare forth without my aiding, and without my token fight?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, for that all too dear I hold thee—My part will I play aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my token I will prepare thee, and if thou my pledge shalt bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I wot well that o'er all others thy glory shall blossom fair.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they went forth, the little maidens, and Gawain, the stranger guest,<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They thanked with sweet words and kindly, and thus he his speech addrest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'When older ye twain shall be waxen, were they spears, every woodland bough,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the forest bare naught but spear-shafts, then too poor were the crop, I trow!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If your childhood shall thus be powerful, what then of your maidenhood?<br></span>
<span class="i0">For your favour brave knights shall shatter both strong shield and spear-shaft good!'<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then forth sped the little maidens, and their hearts they were glad and gay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, the Burg-grave's daughter, 'Lady, I prithee say<br></span>
<span class="i0">What wilt give to thy knight for a token, since naught but our dolls have we?<br></span>
<span class="i0">An mine were but somewhat fairer I would give it right willingly<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor be wroth with thee for the taking, we should strive not o'er that I ween!'<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Lippaut the prince o'ertook them half-way on the hillside green,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he saw Obilot and Clauditté, as up towards the Burg they sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade them stand still, and await him, and his daughter towards him fled.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Father, I never needed thy help as I do to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now give me I pray thy counsel, for the knight he hath said me yea.'<span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Whate'er be thy will, little daughter, an I may, I will give it thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For happy the day whose dawning brought thee, a fair gift to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Good Fortune smiled sweetly on me.' 'I will tell thee, my father dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the thing that so sore doth vex me thou must it in secret hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So hearken, and do as I pray thee!' Then he bade them to lift the maid<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On his charger, 'But what of my playmate?' Many knights round their leader stayed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they strove which of them should take her, for each one well pleased would be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then one as his prize he claimed her, for Clauditté was fair to see.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then riding, he spake, her father, 'Now Obilot tell to me<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_213">[Pg 213]</a></span>
<span class="i0">How dost thou need my counsel? What is it that vexeth thee?'       <span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'I have promised my knight a token, and my wits were I ween astray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If nothing I find to give him then worthless my life to-day;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he vowed unto me his service then in sooth must I blush for shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If I give him naught—Never hero truer love from a maid might claim!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he quoth, 'Trust to me, little daughter, and thy token I will prepare,<span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If service from him thou winnest thou shalt give him his payment fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thy mother she too be willing—God grant he may bring us aid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That gallant knight and worthy; what trust I on him have laid!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' never a word to the hero had I spoken before to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet last night in a dream I saw him, as asleep on my couch I lay.' <span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Lippaut he sought the Duchess, and with him he led the maid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Now lady, help us, for we twain sorely need thine aid;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart would shout for gladness that God gave me this maiden fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And parted me from the sorrow that I all guiltless bare.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake the Duchess, 'Tell me, what wilt thou of my grace?' <span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Lady, since thou wilt hearken, this maid craves a better dress,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she deems she of right may ask it, since a knight will her token bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asketh her love, and he offers to do for her service fair.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake the maiden's mother, 'Ah, good and gallant knight!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the stranger I ween thou speakest, as May-tide his glance of light.'<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then samite of Ethnisé the wise mistress she bade them bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">And rich stuffs as yet unsevered, and silk of Tabronit fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">From far Tribalibot's kingdom—Red the gold on Kaucasus' strand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair is I ween the raiment which the heathen, with cunning hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wrought from silk, with the gold inwoven—And Lippaut, the prince, he bade<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That therefrom for his little daughter fitting garments should straight be made.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor the best would he grudge to the maiden, and they shaped her a garment fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of silk that with gold was heavy; but one white arm they left yet bare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a sleeve that the arm had covered from the vesture they cut away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This should Gawain win for his token and badge in the coming fray. <span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So this was the gift that she gave him, a rich silk of Orient bright,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_214">[Pg 214]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That was brought from the land of the paynim, and had covered her arm so white.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But they sewed it not to the garment, nor wrought it at all with thread,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Clauditté to Gawain bare it, when home from the Burg she sped.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And free from all care was the hero; and three were his shields so bright,<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And on one straightway he bound it, and glad was the gallant knight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fairest thanks he gave her, and oft would he praise the road<br></span>
<span class="i0">On which the maid had trodden when she sought him in his abode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so gently bade him welcome, and with sweet words and maiden wile<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had made him rich in gladness, and made joy on his path to smile.  <span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now the daylight had waned, and the night fell,—many valiant knights and good,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A mighty force, lay on each side,—the besiegers were e'en a flood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they less, for the folk of the city their army enow should be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now by the light of the moonbeams they would fain to their outworks see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor terror nor cowardice moved them, they were ready ere break of day,<span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Twelve breast-works wide, and a deep moat before every earth-work lay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus they shielded them well from onslaught, and to every earth-work wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were barbicans three, that the army might forth to the conflict ride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And at four of the gates the Marshal, Kardefablet of Jamore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his army bravely battled, as men well at the dawning saw.     <span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the rich Duke fought full knightly; he was brother to Lippaut's wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stronger in heart than others who yet bear them well in strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for men of war are reckoned—In conflict he grief would bear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">With nightfall his host drew nearer, from far land would he hither fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For but seldom from stress of battle or conflict he turned aside,  <span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And four of their gates he guarded right well in his warlike pride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The force from beyond the river passed o'er it ere morning light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And entered the walls of Beaurosch, as Lippaut should deem it right.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But they of Jamore had ridden o'er the bridge before the gate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And every door was guarded, and warlike their foes they wait,      <span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere ever the day had dawnèd—Scherules one door would ward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which he and the brave Knight Gawain would let not from out their guard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there had ye heard lamentation from the lips of many a knight,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_215">[Pg 215]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And the best they were who mourned thus, they had failed here to see the fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the vesper-play was ended ere yet they a joust might share.    <span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet needless their lamentation, for countless they proffered there<br></span>
<span class="i0">To all who had lust for battle, and to joust in the field would ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the streets saw ye many a hoof-track, and there drew in on every side<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full many a tossing banner by the light of the moonbeam's ray.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a costly helmet would they wear in the joust that day,    <span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And spears with bright colours blazoned—A Regensburg silk, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had been held of little value 'fore Beaurosch on the meadow green.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For many a coat emblazoned had ye looked upon that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose goal had methinks been higher in the cost that its lord would pay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the night, as of old her custom, had yielded her place to day, <span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor by song of the lark might they know it, for they hearkened far other lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose voice was the voice of warfare with the crash of the splintered spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a cloud that is cleft and riven when the thunderbolt falleth near.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the King of Lys' young army sought the host of Lirivoin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, with his warriors, battled the monarch of Avendroin;    <span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a joust rang loudly, e'en as when one is wont to throw<br></span>
<span class="i0">Chestnuts within the furnace that burst in the fiery glow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah, me! how they strove together that morn on the grassy plain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How the knights spurred their steeds to jousting, and the Burgers they fought amain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Gawain, and his host the Burg-grave, since it health to their souls might bring,<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yield them a meed of blessing, bade a priest a Mass to sing;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sang unto God and the heroes—And the prize of their fame waxed fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this was their pious bidding—Then they would to their post repair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But their rampart ere this was guarded by many a gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The followers they of Scherules, and well would those heroes fight.<span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And what should I tell ye further? Poidikonjonz was proud I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he came with such host, if in Schwarzwald each bough had a spearshaft been<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_216">[Pg 216]</a></span>
<span class="i0">I had looked on no greater forest than here on this field ye saw.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And six banners they bare, and early to battle would nearer draw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With ringing blasts of trumpet e'en as thunder that wakeneth fear, <span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And drums strove amain with the trumpets, and smote on the listening ear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If a grass blade were left untrampled by the conflict I knew it not—<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en now shall the Erfurt vineyards show such tokens of strife, I wot!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then hither he came, Duke Astor, and he fought with the men of Jamore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for sharp joust the spears they whetted, and many a knight they bore<span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">From his saddle down on the meadow, and for combat they aye were fain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And clear rang the stranger war-cries—And masterless o'er the plain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sped many a gallant charger, and afoot went the fallen knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I ween he had learnt the lesson how one oft is o'erthrown in fight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he saw, the gallant Gawain, how out on the plain afar         <span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The host of both friend and foeman were mingled in deadly war;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spurred him swift towards them; nor 'twas light in his steps to tread,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' little they spared their chargers, those knights who behind him sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Scherules and his vassals—Gawain gave them pain, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah, me! for the spears he shivered and the knights that he laid alow.<span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Had God given him not such valour, this knight of the Table Round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in sooth had one made petition for the fame that he there had found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas all as one, both armies, 'gainst the twain did he set his hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That of Gros as of Lys—Many chargers did he win from each knightly band,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straightway the hero brought them where his host's banner waved on high,<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he asked who was there who should need them? And many swift reply;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he gave them e'en as they answered, and rich were they all, I trow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' this brother-in-arms whose friendship they here for a space should know.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then there came a knight fast spurring, nor spears did he think to spare<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Lord of Beauvais and Gawain they rode 'gainst each other there,<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the young knight, Lisavander, midst the flowers of the field he lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From his saddle behind his charger did Gawain thrust the prince that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the sake of his squire shall this grieve me, who yestreen so courteous spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And told to Gawain the tidings, and whence all this woe did wake.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_217">[Pg 217]</a></span>
<span class="i0">He dismounted, and bent o'er his master, and Gawain he knew his face,<span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gave him the steed he had won there, and the squire thanked his hand of grace.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now see ye how Kardefablet himself on the ground doth stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">From a joust that was ridden against him, and aimed by young Meljanz' hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the ground his warriors lift him, and loud rings the battle-cry<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Jamore!' and the clashing sword-blades to the challenge make swift reply.<span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And closer the fight draws round him, onslaught on onslaught pressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the blows ring loud and deafening that fall on each knightly crest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain called his men around him, and swift to his aid he sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he covered the knight with the banner of his host that flew high o'erhead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many brave knights had been felled there—Tho' witness I never knew,<span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet in sooth ye may well believe me for the venture it telleth true!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Count of Montane rode 'gainst Gawain, and a goodly joust they ran,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And behind his horse, on the meadow, lay the brave Knight Lahduman,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hero, proud and gallant, his pledge unto Gawain gave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And nearest of all to the ramparts fought Duke Astor with heroes brave,<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a joust was ridden, and many a spear was crossed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nantes! Nantes!' came the war-cry pealing, the cry of King Arthur's host,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Firm they stood, and no whit they yielded, the captive Breton knights,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hirelings from Erec's kingdom and men spake of their deeds of might—<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Duke of Lanveronz led them—So well did they fight that day    <span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That Poidikonjonz well might free them, since his captives they were alway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the mountain Cluse from King Arthur, in the days that were long gone by,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his prisoners did he win them, when they stormed him right valiantly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here, as was aye their custom, where'er they might chance to fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They shouted 'Nantes' as their war-cry, 'twas the way of these men of might;<span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many had waxed grey-bearded, and on every Breton breast<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or high on their helmet gleaming stood a Gampilon for their crest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as Ilinot's arms they bare it, who was Arthur's gallant son—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gawain he sighed as he saw it (small fame he 'gainst these had won).<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart awoke to sorrow for the blazon right well he knew,   <span class="linenum">725</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_218">[Pg 218]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And it filled him again with anguish for the death of his kinsman true.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his eyes ran o'er with tear-drops, and he passed them upon the field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor with them would he fight—Thus to friendship a hero full oft shall yield!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he rode on to Meljanz' army, whom the Burgers with might withstood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their rightful meed of honour they won from the warriors good; <span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' perforce 'gainst o'ermastering numbers they had failed to hold the field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And backward within their trenches awhile to the foe must yield.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he who the Burgers challenged his harness glowed red as flame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'The Nameless Knight' they called him for none knew from whence he came;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I tell it to ye as I heard it, to Meljanz he rode, this knight,<span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But three days back, and the Burgers must mourn it in coming fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he swore his aid to their foeman—Twelve squires unto him he gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To serve him as meet in the jousting, and to follow to onslaught brave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the spears their hand might proffer those spears he right swiftly brake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And clear rang his joust o'er the tumult, when he did as his captives take<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">King Schirniel and his brother; nor he would from his pledge release<br></span>
<span class="i0">The knight whom he here had vanquished, the Duke of Marangliess.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bravely they fought mid the foremost, and he vanquished them as they stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet their folk still held them valiant tho' reft of their leaders good.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there fought the young King Meljanz, and all were they friend or foe,<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They owned greater deeds of valour a young knight might seldom show;<br></span>
<span class="i0">By his hand were the strong shields cloven—Ah! the spears that he brake in twain<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the forces together mingling dashed swift o'er the battle-plain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his young heart for conflict lusted, and none gave him of strife his fill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it vexed him sore, till Gawain would joust with him at his will.<span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gawain took a spear of Angram, that he won him at Plimizöl,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And twelve were those spears—The war-cry of Meljanz was 'Barbigöl!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of his kingdom of Lys 'twas chief city—Gawain aimed his joust so true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Oraste Gentesein taught sorrow to the king since it pierced him thro'<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_219">[Pg 219]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That strong shaft of reed; his shield piercing, it brake in his arm of might—<span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a fair joust again was ridden, and Gawain smote the King in flight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hinder bow of the saddle it brake, and those heroes twain<br></span>
<span class="i0">They stood on their feet, and valiant, they battled with swords amain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twere more than enough such labour for two churls on the threshing-floor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each one bare the sheaf of the other, and each smote the other sore.<span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And a spear must Meljanz carry that had smitten him thro' the arm,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' conflict fierce the hero in blood and sweat waxed warm.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain by force he drave him within a portal wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade him his pledge to swear him, nor the young king his will defied;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were he not so sorely wounded then so swiftly he ne'er were known, <span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To yield himself to a foeman, but his prowess had longer shown.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Lippaut the prince, the land's host, his valour might not restrain<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the monarch of Gros he battled; and alike must they suffer pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both man and steed from the bow-shots, for their skill they were fain to show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They of Semblidag, and Kahetines, for they fled as they bent the bow.<span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burgers must well bethink them the foe from their lines to hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But foot-soldiers had they, and sheltered by their ramparts they battled bold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who of life was forfeit for the wrath of a maid must pay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For her folly and scorn on her people brought sorrow enow that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But what part therein had Lippaut? I think me his lord of old,     <span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">King Schaut, ne'er had thus beset him! Now faint waxed those heroes bold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Meljakanz still fought bravely—Do ye think it was whole, his shield?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not a hand's-breadth wide was the fragment—Then he bare him across the field<br></span>
<span class="i0">Duke Kardefablet, and I think me the Tourney it came to stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the meadow fair and flowery, for fast locked was either band.   <span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain he rode swiftly to them, and he pressed Meljakanz so sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en Launcelot, gallant hero, ne'er wrought him such grief afore<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the sword bridge he crossed to battle—Her captivity pleased him ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Queen Guinevere, and he thought him by the sword-blade to free her still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Lot's son he rode full gallop—Meljakanz, what could he do    <span class="linenum">785</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_220">[Pg 220]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But spur his steed towards him? And many that joust must view.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who lay there behind his charger? He whom the gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Norroway had smitten to earth with his spear of might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a knight and lady they looked on this joust so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake in praise of Gawain, and his fame would aloud declare.<span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maidens right well might see it as they looked from the hall on high.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Underfoot was Meljakanz trampled; many steeds did o'er him fly,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tare with their hoofs his surcoat, who fodder might taste no more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they covered the prostrate hero with rain of sweat and gore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a day of doom for the chargers, but the vultures at will might feast;<span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Duke Astor he came to the rescue, and from them of Jamore released<br></span>
<span class="i0">Meljakanz, or else was he captive, and he raised him from off the ground—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Tourney was o'er, and the combat methinks had its ending found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now who had as knight best ridden, or best for a maiden fought?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, I know not, an I would name them small leisure such task had brought.<span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For Maid Obilot's sake with the townsfolk a knight valiant deeds had dared;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without, a Red Knight fought bravely, and the fame 'twixt those two was shared.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the guest of the outer army had learnt he no thanks might win<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the king he had served, since Meljanz was captive the town within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He rode where his squires were waiting, and thus to his prisoners spake,<span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir Knights, ye your word have pledged me; ill-chance doth me here o'ertake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For King Meljanz of Lys is captive—Now if ye such grace can find<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his captors, that for <i>your</i> freedom <i>his</i> fetters they will unbind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such service I'ld gladly do him!' To the King of Avendroin<br></span>
<span class="i0">He spake, and to Duke Marangliess, and King Schirniel of Lirivoin. <span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And this oath must they swear unto him, ere they rode the walls within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To loose Meljanz, or if they failed here, to help him the Grail to win.<br></span>
