<span class="i0">But never a word could they tell him of where It was hid, the Grail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save 'twas guarded by King Anfortas, but further, their lore must fail.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When thus they spake, quoth the Red Knight, 'Then if it shall still betide<br></span>
<span class="i0">That my wish find not here fulfilment, ye to Pelrapär shall ride,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_221">[Pg 221]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And unto the fair queen yielding say, "He who in days of yore<br></span>
<span class="i0">Faced Kingron for her and Klamidé, for the Grail now sorroweth sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he yearneth for her, his lady, and after the twain in thought<br></span>
<span class="i0">And deed is he ever striving." To her be this message brought      <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ye heroes bear it truly, and as on your way ye ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">God have ye in His safe keeping, for the world and its ways are wide.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they prayed his leave, and they rode hence—And the knight to his squires he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Here is booty none may gainsay us, of these steeds ye at will may take;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But leave me one for my riding, since sore wounded mine own shall be.'<span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the Squires, 'Sir Knight, we must thank thee for the grace thou hast shown us free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For our lifetime hast thou enriched us.' Then he chose in his charger's stead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the close-cropped ears, Ingliart, the same that from Gawain fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When Meljanz he made his captive, and the twain they must fall in field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Red Knight's hand had caught it, when hewn was many a shield.<span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Farewell the hero bade them—Full fifteen steeds they tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the squires he left, unwounded, in sooth might they thank him well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they prayed him to linger with them, and abide with them yet a space,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But far hence lay the goal he was seeking, and the road he was fain to trace.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So he turned him about, the hero, to where ease should be bought full dear<span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught but strife was he seeking—In the days that ye read of here<br></span>
<span class="i0">No knight e'en as he had battled—Then the outer host would ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">To where they might find a lodging, and in peace for a space abide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And within, Lippaut spake, and asked them how matters had gone that day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Meljanz was taken captive, that tale did he know alway.       <span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all was as he would have it, and comfort the hour would bear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gawain loosed the sleeve full gently from his shield, lest perchance it tear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he deemed it o'er good for tearing, and Clauditté she held it fast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twas slashed in the sides and the centre with the spears that had thro' it passed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade her to Obilot bear it, and glad was the little maid,   <span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On her bare white arm soft-rounded the tattered sleeve she laid,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_222">[Pg 222]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And spake, 'Who hath done this for me?' whene'er she her sister saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wrathful her elder sister her maiden mischief bore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then, as weariness it bade them, the knights they craved for rest—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Scherules took Count Lahduman, and Gawain his gallant guest   <span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a knight whom he found there, whom Gawain with valiant hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had o'erthrown on the field of battle tho' strife they might well withstand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burg-grave rich he bade them to sit them in order fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he and his wearied vassals would stand 'fore their monarch there<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till Meljanz his fill had eaten—And they treated him courteously, <span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But Gawain, o'er-much he deemed it, and he spake out, frank and free,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Methinks an the king allow thee, Sir Host, thou shouldst take a seat.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus spake Gawain in his wisdom, as his courtesy found it meet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the host gave his prayer denial, 'The king's man is that gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">My master, this were his office if the king had but deemed it right<span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To take, as of old, his service—My lord thro' his courtesy<br></span>
<span class="i0">Will not see the face of his monarch while exiled from grace is he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An it pleaseth God of friendship to sow here the seed once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then joyful we'll do his bidding with one will, as in days of yore.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then spake the youthful Meljanz, 'Yea, courteous knights and true  <span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Were ye, when I dwelt among ye, nor your rede did I ever rue.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An I now had thy counsel followed, this even had seen me glad;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now give me thine aid Count Scherules, for the trust that I ever had<br></span>
<span class="i0">In thy faith, with this knight my captor, and with him my second sire<br></span>
<span class="i0">Duke Lippaut—for well I think me they will do as thou shalt require—<span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, pray them to show me favour, for friends had we been to-day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had not Obie such jest played on me as no maiden I ween should play!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the gallant Gawain, 'Afresh shall be knit a band<br></span>
<span class="i0">That naught but death can sever'—Then they came whom the Red Knight's hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without had taken captive, on the height would they seek their king,<span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they told him all that befell them; and Gawain must list the thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they told of the arms of the hero, how their strength before his must fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And how he their pledge had taken, and had bidden them seek the Grail;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought how the knight of this venture was none other than Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his thanks uprose to high Heaven that no evil did there befall,<span class="linenum">880</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_223">[Pg 223]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But that God apart had held them, and they met not in strife that day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And courteous I ween were those heroes that they tore not the veil away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But both of them there were nameless, and none knew from whence they came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I wot well the world around them rang fair with their warlike fame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To Meljanz he spake, Scherules, 'Now, Sire, wilt thou list to me?  <span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Look thou again on my master, and such rede as is given to thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">By friends on both sides shalt thou hearken, and thine anger shalt thou recall;'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all deemed it good, the counsel, so they rode to the royal hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The inner force of the city, as the Marshal was fain to pray.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain took the Count Lahduman, and the captives he made that day,<span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he gathered them all around him, and the pledge that to him they gave<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he erst on the field o'erthrew them, must they yield to the Burg-grave brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly they did his bidding—To the palace the heroes fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And rich garments as fit for a monarch did the wife of the Burg-grave bear;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a veil did she give unto Meljanz that should serve him for a sling<span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the arm that Gawain had wounded, when his spear smote the youthful king.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Gawain by the mouth of Scherules, Obilot his lady prayed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fain would the hero see her, his life in her hand he laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And would crave from her lips dismissal—and further the hero spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'I leave the king here, her captive, and I pray her such thought to take<span class="linenum">900</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That she may in such wise entreat him, that her honour shall wax apace!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Meljanz spake, 'Well I know this, Obilot is of maiden grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">And maiden worth the glory; and joyful am I at heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">If her captive I be, for in gladness methinks shall I have my part,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the gallant Gawain, 'Her prisoner art thou alone,   <span class="linenum">905</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis <i>she</i> who hath captive made thee, and <i>my</i> glory is here her own.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Before them rode Scherules—As was fitting for royal court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor man was there nor maiden but had robed them in such sort<br></span>
<span class="i0">That one, in poor guise and scanty, might scarce have been seen that day—<br></span>
<span class="i0">They who sware their pledge to the Red Knight with Meljanz must take their way.<span class="linenum">910</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_224">[Pg 224]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And there in the hall of the castle they sat in their order four,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lippaut, his wife, and his daughters, as the guests passed within the door.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up sprang the host and hastened his lord and king to greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And close pressed the crowd around them as friend with foe did meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">By Gawain's side stood Meljanz. 'Now, an it were here thy will,    <span class="linenum">915</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy friend of old, the Duchess, with kiss would she greet thee still.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Meljanz to his host made answer, '<i>Two</i> ladies I think to see<br></span>
<span class="i0">From whom I'll take kiss and greeting—but the <i>third</i> naught shall win from me.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the parents wept; but the maiden, Obilot, was glad and gay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they greeted their king with kisses; and two beardless kings that day<span class="linenum">920</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They kissed, with the Duke of Marangliess, and the gallant Knight Gawain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they brought him his little lady, and the fair child he clasped again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And e'en as a doll he held her so close to his manly breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As joy and delight constrained him, and to Meljanz his speech addrest:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thine hand hath surety pledged me, of that shall thou now be free,<span class="linenum">925</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In my right arm I hold my lady, <i>her</i> captive thou now shalt be.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Meljanz he stept him nearer, and she held fast to Gawain's hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she took the pledge of her monarch mid the knights who did round them stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Sir King, 'twas ill-done I think me, if a <i>merchant</i> he be my knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">As my sister hath said, to yield thee as his captive on field of might!'<span class="linenum">930</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus spake Obilot, the maiden; then to Meljanz she gave command,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He should yield his pledge to her sister, and swear it hand clasped in hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Thou shalt have her for Love, for thy knighthood, as her Love and her Lord art thou<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforward, of true heart gladly, and ye twain to my will shall bow!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">God spake by the lips of the maiden, her will it was done straightway,<span class="linenum">935</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Frau Minne with power and wisdom again o'er their hearts held sway,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And knit afresh the meshes, and fettered the twain anew;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the folds of her flowing mantle her small hand Obie drew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she touched the arm of her lover, and weeping, her lips so red<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kissed the wound he had won in jousting, since it was for her sake he bled.<span class="linenum">940</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his arm was bathed in the tear-drops that flowed from her eyes so bright—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_225">[Pg 225]</a></span>
<span class="i0">How waxed she thus bold 'fore the people? 'Twas Love bade her claim her right;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fulfilled was the wish of Lippaut, and naught of his bliss should fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since God had willed that his daughter henceforth as his queen he hail!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">How the wedding feast was holden, ask them who took their share    <span class="linenum">945</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of wedding gifts, or wandering, to Beaurosch had thought to fare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If they fought, or were fain to rest them, of that I no word may tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But they say in the hall of the palace Sir Gawain would bid farewell<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her for whose leave he came there, and sore wept the little maid<br></span>
<span class="i0">And spake, 'Now take me with thee,' but Gawain her wish gainsaid,  <span class="linenum">950</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And scarce might her mother tear her from the knight—leave he prayed them there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lippaut he proffered service for the good-will he towards him bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his gallant host, Scherules, with his folk he would not delay<br></span>
<span class="i0">To ride awhile with the hero; and he wended a woodland way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they gave him guides for his journey, and food lest he ill should fare,<span class="linenum">955</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bade them farewell, and sorrow Gawain for the parting bare.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_226">[Pg 226]</a><br><a id="Page_227">[Pg 227]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK VIII<br>

ANTIKONIE</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_228">[Pg 228]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> tells how Gawain came to Schamfanzon, and how King
Vergulacht committed him to the care of his sister Antikonie. How
Gawain wooed the maiden, and of the wrath of her people. Of the
adventure of the chess-board, and how Kingrimursel came to the help
of Gawain. How Antikonie reproached King Vergulacht, and how the
nobles counselled their monarch. Of the oath Gawain sware to the King,
and how he rode forth to seek the Grail.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_229">[Pg 229]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK VIII</p>
<p class="ph2">ANTIKONIE
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_w.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_w.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whosoe'er at Beaurosch had battled, methinks that Gawain had won<br></span>
<span class="i0">The highest fame in both armies, save but for one knight alone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And none knew his red harness glowing, and none knew from whence he came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But high as a banner waveth, so high did it rise, his fame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet of honour alike and good fortune had Gawain in full his share—  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now hence must he ride, for the moment of strife which he sought drew near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And far and wide stretched the woodland thro' which he must wend his way—<br></span>
<span class="i0">No conflict he shunned, tho' all guiltless of the sin men on him would lay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, alas! his charger failed him, Ingliart, with the close-cropped ear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the land of the Moors at Tabronit no better the steeds they rear.<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And diverse the wood around him, here a bush and there a field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so narrow at whiles, that pathway, it scarcely a space might yield<br></span>
<span class="i0">For tent, or for knight's pavilion. Then fair dwellings met his eye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas Askalon, and he prayed them if Schamfanzon at hand did lie?<br></span>
<span class="i0">But many a marsh and moorland and many a steep hillside             <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Must he traverse, ere fair before him in the setting sun he spied<br></span>
<span class="i0">A fortress stand so stately, it gleamed in the sunlight's rays,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he turned his steed towards it who rode here on unknown ways.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now list ye awhile the venture, and mourn ye awhile with me<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sorrow that fell on Gawain—And if old ye shall chance to be    <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or young, yet of this your friendship I pray you his grief to weep;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! were it best to tell ye, or silence a space to keep?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, better to tell the story, how he whom Good Luck did call<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_230">[Pg 230]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Her friend, was by her forsaken, and how grief to his lot must fall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So proudly uprose the fortress that never did Carthage seem         <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So fair to the eyes of Æneas, when Dido, as failed her dream<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of love, turned to death and, seeking, found rest in his cold embrace.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would ye know what countless turrets those stately halls did grace?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Scarce more had Akraton boasted, that city whose walls so wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An man may believe the heathen, with Babylon only vied;             <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So high rose the circling ramparts, and where to the sea they fell<br></span>
<span class="i0">No storm might they fear, but defiance could they bid to their foes right well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Fore the city a plain outstretching lay fair for a mile or more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Sir Gawain rode across it, five hundred knights he saw,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet one, o'er all the others, gallant and fair to sight;            <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Gaily they rode towards him all clad in raiment bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For so the venture telleth—With their falcons soaring high<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would they chase the crane, or other fair game that should wingèd fly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A tall steed from Spain's far kingdom, King Vergulacht bestrode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his glance was as day in the night-time—Aforetime his race abode<span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where Mazadan reigned as monarch, by Fay Morgan's mystic mount,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And amid the roll of his fathers he many a fay might count—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And even as in the spring-tide the May blossom bloometh fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">So rode the king in his beauty, and Gawain he bethought him there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he saw him ride so stately, 'twas another Parzival,              <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or Gamuret, as he came to Kanvoleis, as this venture erewhile did tell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now into a pond so marshy a heron had taken flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">As it fled from before the falcon, and the king, as beseemed a knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sought not for the ford but followed as he saw his falcon's need,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wet he won in the aiding, and lost was his gallant steed,       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And lost too his royal raiment, tho' safe was I ween the bird.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The falconers took his garments, for this, so the tale I've heard,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was their right, and they needs must have them, and no man might say them nay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Another horse they brought him, for lost was his own for aye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fresh garments they put upon him, since such was the chance of fate<span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That his falconers won the vesture that had decked their king of late.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_231">[Pg 231]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Sir Gawain, he rode towards them, and knightly and worshipful<br></span>
<span class="i0">The greeting they gave unto him, not such as in Karidöl<br></span>
<span class="i0">Once fell to the lot of Erec, when after his well-fought fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">He had fain drawn near to King Arthur, and with him his lady bright,<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair Enid, who graced his coming—But the dwarf Maliklisier<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a scourge full hardly smote him, 'neath the eyes of Queen Guinevere.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Tulmein he took his vengeance, where, within the ring so wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">To win the hawk, the heroes in deeds of valour vied.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas Idêr, the son of Noit, a hero true and bold                   <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom he else had slain, whom Erec did there in surety hold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But leave we all other venture, and hearken awhile to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth never fairer welcome shall it fall to your lot to see.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, alas! for ill it wrought him, Gawain, King Lot's brave son—<br></span>
<span class="i0">An ye will I will cease my story ere the tale to its end be run,    <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And for pity's sake keep silence—Yet perchance it were best to tell<br></span>
<span class="i0">The ill that thro' others' treason on a gallant spirit fell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if I yet further pray ye this story strange to heed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in sooth, e'en as I, right truly will ye mourn for its hero's need.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the king, 'Sir Knight, thus I think me, thou shalt to the castle ride,<span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thine <i>host</i> will I be right gladly, tho' scarce may I be thy <i>guide</i>;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet if this on my part shall vex thee the chase will I gladly leave!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Gawain, 'As it best may please thee, that do, nor for my sake grieve,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whate'er thou shalt do shall be well done—No grudge do I bear thee, Sire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But of right good-will I gladly will do as thou shalt require.'     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the king of Askalon further, 'Schamfanzon thou well mayst see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight, there my sister dwelleth, who as yet but a maid shall be;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she hath in fullest measure such beauty as poets sing—<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou as a grace shalt hold it, my knights unto her shall bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such word she shall well entreat thee in my stead, till I come again.<span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And whenever I come, I think me, 'twill be sooner than thou art fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To look on my face, for gladly wilt thou spare me when thou shalt see<br></span>
<span class="i0">My sweet sister, nor e'er bemoan thee, tho' my coming o'er late shall be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nay, gladly again I'll see thee, and gladly thy sister greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' as host never queen has done me such service as host finds meet'<span class="linenum">90</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_232">[Pg 232]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thus spake the gallant Gawain—Then a knight bare the king's behest<br></span>
<span class="i0">To his sister, that she, as fitting, should so care for the stranger guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">That however long his absence the hours should as minutes fly—<br></span>
<span class="i0">(An ye will, I will cease my story that now runneth but mournfully!)<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nay, further I'll tell the venture,—Steed and pathway the hero bore<span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where as one were both Burg and palace, and he held him before the door.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he who shall e'er have builded a house, he shall better know<br></span>
<span class="i0">To tell of this mighty castle, and the strength of its walls to show.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, indeed 'twas a Burg, none better might this earth on its bosom bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">And around it, far outstretching, the ramparts towered high in air.<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Leave we the praise of the castle, and speak of the castle's queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden fair, for of women I shall better speak I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as fitting I'll sing her praises—Was she fair to the eye? 'Twas well;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was she true of heart? Then gladly will men of her praises tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so both in mind and manner might she vie with that lady true,  <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Margravine, who from Heitstein afar o'er her marches threw<br></span>
<span class="i0">A light,—Well for him who dwelleth as friend in her presence fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such pastime as there his portion he findeth not other-where!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I praise but a woman's virtue, as I see, and shall surely know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True and pure must she be, the maiden, on whom I shall praise bestow.<span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he whom this venture singeth is a gallant man and true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no dealing have I with falsehood, or with one who his deeds shall rue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As repentance, slowly piercing, but turneth his bliss to bale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his soul knoweth wrath and sorrow, or ever his life-days fail.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the castle court rode Gawain, and the goodly company            <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To whom the king had sent him, who shamed for his sake should be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the knight to his lady led him, as she sat in her beauty's glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Queen Antikonie—Could the merchants a woman's fame bestow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of such goods had she made rich purchase; 'gainst falsehood she set her face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hers was the crown of honour, and a maiden's maiden grace.     <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! woe's me for him of Veldeck, that death thus cut short his days,<br></span>
<span class="i0">None is there of all men living who so well could have sung her praise.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Gawain, he looked on the maiden, and the messenger spake the word<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en as the king had bade him, and the queen his message heard.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_233">[Pg 233]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then gently she spake to the hero, 'Come thou near unto me, Sir Knight,<span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thyself shalt be my master in courtesy, as is right;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly I'll do thy bidding—If well it shall please thee here,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twill be even as thou shalt order—Yea, since my brother dear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath bid me well entreat thee, I'll kiss thee, if so I may.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll do, or leave it undone, e'en as thou the word shalt say!'     <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Courteous she stood before him, quoth Gawain, 'Thy lips so red<br></span>
<span class="i0">In sooth were made for kissing, be kiss and greeting sped!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">So full and warm and rosy were the lips that Gawain pressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No stranger sure had kissed her as kissed this stranger guest.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unchecked he sat him by her, and sweet words passed between,       <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Soft spake they to each other; and oft renewed, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His prayers and her denials, yea, sorely grieved was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain to win her favour—Then she spake as I tell to ye:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Bethink thee, Sir Knight, thou art wise else, with this I enough have done,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I ween at my brother's bidding mine uncle Gamuret won          <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Less welcome from Queen Anflisé than the welcome <i>I</i> gave to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An our tending were weighed together methinks hers would lighter be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor know I, Sir Knight, whence thou comest, nor e'en what shall be thy name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That, after such short approving, thou shouldst to my love lay claim!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the gallant Gawain, 'Then know here assuredly       <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O! queen, of my father's sister the brother's son am I;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wilt thou give me sweet love's rewarding, for my birth shalt thou not delay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hand in hand, and to equal measure, it paceth with thine alway!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">The maiden who filled the wine-cup she had passed from out the hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the women who sat beside them must now to their mind recall    <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The task that elsewhere did wait them; nor longer the knight stood there<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who erst to the queen had brought him—As Gawain was now aware<br></span>
<span class="i0">That no man was here beside them, he thought how a mighty bird<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is oft trapped by a little falcon—nor further he spake a word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he passed his arm around her beneath her mantle's fold,        <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And love laid such stress upon them, the maid and the hero bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That belike a thing had chanced there, an no eye had been there to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of one mind were the twain—yet heart-sorrow drew near to them speedily.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_234">[Pg 234]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For straight stepped within the doorway an old and grey-haired knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And loudly he called on Gawain, and shouted a shout of might,      <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For well did he know the hero, and fiercely his cry did ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Alas! alas! woe upon us, since the hand that hath slain our king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is fain now to force his daughter!' At the sound of his battle-cry<br></span>
<span class="i0">The folk that within the castle abode to the hall did hie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So it fell out—Then quoth Sir Gawain to the queen, 'Now, Lady mine,<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Say thou how we best may ward us 'gainst this wrathful folk of thine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For sure they will come against us—An I had but my sword at hand!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake the gentle maiden, 'Their might shall we best withstand<br></span>
<span class="i0">An we to yon tower betake us that riseth my bower beside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Perchance they will then bethink them, and the storm shall we override.'<span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Here a knight, and there a merchant, already the maid must hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the cry of the angry townsfolk, as the twain to the tower drew near;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore was her friend beset there, tho' she prayed them from strife to cease,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So loud rose the angry tumult none hearkened her words of peace.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Gainst the portal the foe pressed onward, Gawain stood within the door,<span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And held off the angry rabble; an iron bolt he tore<br></span>
<span class="i0">From its fastenings wherewith to arm him, and before his strong right hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full oft fled his evil neighbours, they durst not his blows withstand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">While the queen, with flying footsteps, hither and thither sought<br></span>
<span class="i0">To find, perchance, some weapon 'gainst the foe that so fiercely fought.<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">At length did she chance on some chess-men, and a chess-board, wide and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hung by a ring of iron; to Gawain she brought it there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a shield four-square it served him; yea, many a game was played<br></span>
<span class="i0">On that board ere 'twas hewn in battle—Now hear of the royal maid;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Were it king, or queen, or castle, she hurled them against the foe,<span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Heavy and large the chess-men, and in sooth I would have ye know<br></span>
<span class="i0">They who by her shaft were stricken must ever a fall abide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Right bravely the queen so gracious now fought by her hero's side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she bare herself so knightly, that never the Burger maids<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Tollenstein at Shrove-tide such dauntless skill displayed.      <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet they but fight for folly, and weary themselves for naught—<br></span>
<span class="i0">An a woman bear trace of battle, on her womanhood shame is brought,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_235">[Pg 235]</a></span>
<span class="i0">(For I know what befits a woman,) unless love shall have bid her fight<br></span>
<span class="i0">To prove her faith—Now faithful and true was that lady bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Schamfanzon might bear witness—Yet, tho' high of heart was she,<span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Many tears that conflict cost her; for in sooth shall it ever be<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Love is brave as steadfast, yet tender and true of heart—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would ye know how in such fierce conflict Sir Gawain would bear his part?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the strife but leisure gave him to gaze on the maid aright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her lips so red and glowing, her eyes so soft and bright—         <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">More slender was she and shapely than ever a lowland hare<br></span>
<span class="i0">That ye truss on the spit, so graceful her limbs, and her form so fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full well might her charms awaken desire in the heart of man.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And smaller, I ween, the maiden, where her golden girdle ran<br></span>
<span class="i0">Around her waist, than ants are, and their slender shape ye know— <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The sight wrought in Gawain courage his foemen to overthrow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she shared his need; his chastising none other than death should be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And help was there none—Then his anger flamed high and wroth was he<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he looked on that gentle maiden, and no fear was his but hate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorely his foemen rued it who met at his hand their fate.      <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Came King Vergulacht, and he saw well how his folk 'gainst Gawain did fight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor do I in this deceive ye, nor can I account him right<br></span>
<span class="i0">That not as a host he bare him, when he saw his gallant guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus stand, as one man against many—But straight thro' the throng he pressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise, I must mourn for Gandein, the monarch of Anjou fair, <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That his daughter, so true a lady, so faithless a son must bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the strife his folk he called not, short space must they stay their hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">While the king would don his armour, he lusted to lead the band.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Too mighty the force for Gawain, nor I ween shall ye count it shame<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he closed the door upon them—Then in wrath and haste there came<span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The knight who to battle bade him 'fore Arthur at Plimizöl<br></span>
<span class="i0">But short time back—They called him the Landgrave Kingrimursel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore did Gawain's need vex him, he wrung his hands amain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in sooth had he pledged his honour his foe should in peace remain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till <i>one</i> man alone o'ercame him—Old and young from the tower he drave,<span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the portal would they force open, as their king commandment gave.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_236">[Pg 236]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the Landgrave he cried on Gawain, 'Sir Knight, I would in to thee<br></span>
<span class="i0">As a friend, that this bitter conflict I may share, if it so must be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For then must my monarch slay me, or leave thee in life to-day.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Peace Gawain would swear unto him, and he made to the tower his way—<span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then doubtful, the foemen thronging, their hand for a space must hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For their Burg-grave he was, and his bidding had they hearkened both young and old.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then, as ceased the noise of battle, thro' the doorway he sprang, Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Landgrave, he stood beside him, swift and bold were those heroes twain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth King Vergulacht, 'Why tarry? Why stand we here as on guard,  <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When of foemen but <i>two</i> shall dare us, and none other the tower gates ward?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Much my cousin doth take upon him, when he dareth to shield my foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, <i>himself</i> should wreak vengeance on him, if his faith he were fain to show!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of true heart then they chose a true man, and unto the king he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now, Sire, upon our Landgrave no vengeance we think to take,      <span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor shall harm at <i>our</i> hand befall him—May God so turn thy mind<br></span>
<span class="i0">That, instead of shaming, honour thou shalt from this venture find.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For shame shall it bring upon thee, and an ending to thy fair fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he who as host doth hail thee shall here at thine hand be slain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy kinsman is he, this other who hath brought him into this land;<span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So, lest cursing and shame be thy portion, we pray thee to stay thine hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And grant thou a truce thro' the daylight, and the fleeting hours of night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then bethink thee for shame or honour, and do as shall seem thee right!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And our queen who hath ne'er known falsehood, thy sister, Antikonie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">See there as she standeth by him and weepeth full bitterly.        <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Canst thou see such sight without rueing, since one mother bare ye both?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bethink thee, sire, thou art wise else, thou didst send him, nothing loth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alone to this gentle maiden, nor further a guardian gave;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>her</i> sake it were well to spare him!' Then the king bade those warriors brave<br></span>
<span class="i0">To call a truce—He'ld bethink him how vengeance he best might take<span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For his father's death—Yet all guiltless Gawain, for another's sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Must he bear the shame; with a lance-thrust by Ekunât was he slain<br></span>
<span class="i0">As to Barbigöl Prince Iofreit, a prisoner, he would have ta'en,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_237">[Pg 237]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Who had ridden erewhile with Gawain—In such wise the chance befell<br></span>
<span class="i0">That they deemed that <i>Gawain</i> had slain him—So men do the venture tell.<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And scarce was the truce bespoken ere of men was the field bereft,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Each betook him unto his lodging, nor one on the ground was left.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen threw her arms around him, and with many a kiss so sweet<br></span>
<span class="i0">She gave to her gallant cousin such rewarding as seemed her meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since so bravely he stood by Gawain, and sheltered the twain from wrong,<span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake, 'Now art thou my cousin, nor unfaith shall to thee belong.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hearken and I will read ye that word which I spake of late,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How a true heart sore was darkened—I ween 'twas an evil fate<br></span>
<span class="i0">That led Vergulacht to Schamfanzon; such deed he ne'er did learn<br></span>
<span class="i0">From sire or aye from mother, with shame did the young knight burn,<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And torment sore and suffering his better self must know<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his sister 'gan upbraid him, small mercy the maid would show.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thus spake the noble maiden, 'Now had it but been God's will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I, a man born, might sword bear, and knightly tasks fulfil,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To strive with me hadst thou come here, methinks thou hadst come too late,—<span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But now am I all defenceless, a maiden, and no man's mate.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet a shield I carry, and fair its device shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And honoured of all—Its blazon would I read here, Sir King, to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou henceforth mayst know it—Pure heart and upright mind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That true man beneath its cover a shelter may ever find.           <span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And that, o'er the gallant hero whom thou sentest unto my care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did I hold, and 'gainst thee, his foeman, I did, as beseemed me, bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For none other armour had I—And if thou repent the ill<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast done to thy guest, me, thy sister, hast thou wronged more deeply still;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this is the right of woman, so ever 'twas told to me,          <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That if ever unto the shelter of a maiden a knight shall flee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they who as foemen follow shall straightway leave their chase—<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise they ever bear them who would not their shield disgrace—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, Sir Vergulacht, that thy guest fled to <i>me</i> as his hope of life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath loaded with shame thine honour, since thou aided, nor checked, thestrife!'<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_238">[Pg 238]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Kingrimursel quoth sternly, 'Yea, Sire, 'twas at <i>thy</i> command,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That on Plimizöl's plain I bade him, Sir Gawain, to seek this land.<br></span>
<span class="i0">On thy royal word safe conduct I sware him, that should he ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hither we twain were pledged him no evil should here betide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save but from <i>one</i> foeman only—Now, Sire, thou hast here done ill<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In that, spite of thine oath so knightly, thy word thou didst not fulfil.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here shall my fellows hearing give judgment betwixt us twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thus thou wrongest <i>princes</i>, what as <i>king</i> mayst thou hope to gain<br></span>
<span class="i0">From us of faith and honour?—If honoured thou fain wouldst be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then, courteous, make confession that near of kin are we;          <span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">True cousin am I, no bastard, and e'en if such chance had been,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Even then, in this thy dealing, thou hadst done me a wrong, I ween!<br></span>
<span class="i0">A knight am I in whom no man hath found a taint of shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I think me that free from falsehood, yea, to death will I guard my fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in God have I ever trusted, and, methinks, He holds not in store<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such fate for the days of the future as I knew not in days of yore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet they who shall hear the story, how the nephew of Arthur rode<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Schamfanzon 'neath my safe-conduct, where'er shall be his abode—<br></span>
<span class="i0">An he come from the land of the Breton, or from France, or from Provence fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Burgundian he, or Gallician, or the arms of Punturtois bear—      <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When he hear of the grief of Gawain then <i>my</i> fame shall be swiftly sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shame be my meed for the danger that threatened that knightly head.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At the tale of this strife shall my glory wax narrow, and blame grow wide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, as joy in the past dwelt with me, so henceforward shall shame abide.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As he made an end of speaking stood a vassal the king before,      <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, as Kiot himself hath told us, Liddamus was the name he bore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I speak here of Kiot the singer, and so sweet was I ween his song<br></span>
<span class="i0">That none wax of the hearing weary, tho' the days of their life be long.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I rede ye to wit that Kiot of old was a Provençal,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who found writ in a book of the heathen this story of Parzival.    <span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And in French again he sang it, and I, if no wit shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would fain in his footsteps follow, and in German would tell the tale.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the Prince Liddamus in his anger, 'Now say, what doth he do here<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the house of my lord, who his father hath slain, and hath brought anear<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_239">[Pg 239]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The brand of shame? My king's courage is known thro' many a land,  <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twould better beseem his honour to avenge him with his own hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">One death for the other payeth—and the need waxeth here as there.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gawain he stood in sore peril, and fear for his life must bear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Kingrimursel, 'Who to threaten is swift, he as swift should be<br></span>
<span class="i0">To mingle in strife, yet but lightly thy foeman he holdeth thee!   <span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An wide were the field or narrow, yet Sir Liddamus, I know well<br></span>
<span class="i0">This man were safe from thine onslaught e'en tho' shame at his hand befell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For ne'er wouldst thou dare to avenge it, who yet dost so loudly boast—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And swifter were we to hearken if ever in battle host<br></span>
<span class="i0">We had seen thee ride the foremost! But strife ever wrought thee pain,<span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And afar from the field of battle to linger thou aye wast fain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, <i>more</i> hast thou learnt—The beginning of strife didst thou ever see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then hence wouldst thou fly as swiftly as a maiden is wont to flee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the prince who thy counsel hearkens, and doeth as thou shalt say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall find that the crown he weareth but loosely shall sit alway!' <span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And fain, in a joust so knightly, were I to have faced Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor feared me aught, for such combat had we sworn fast betwixt us twain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here had we fought, as fitting, 'neath the eye of the king my lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wroth am I now, for dearer, methought, had he held his word!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now swear thou to me, Sir Gawain, when a year from this day be past,<span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To meet me again in combat—If thou 'scape my lord's wrath at last,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy life for a prey he leave thee, yet we twain must fight our fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Plimizöl first I bade thee; at Barbigöl, if it seem thee right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before Meljanz, the youthful monarch, the strife shall methinks be fought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And around my heart till the day come shall sorrow's wreath be wrought,<span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And gladly I'll hail that dawning, and face thee, thou hero bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the guerdon be but of sorrow, that shall there by thine hand be told.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So there, as the Landgrave bade him, the hero Gawain swore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his oath, and his pledge so knightly, he plighted as erst of yore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Duke Liddamus, he bethought him of words that he fain would say,<span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with cunning skill and wisdom his speech did he weave that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus he spake for all men to hear him, for the time of speech was come,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now if strife ever call upon me, if the battle be lost or won,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_240">[Pg 240]</a></span>
<span class="i0">If I fight as beseems a hero, or fly as a coward flies,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If the meed of my warlike bearing be honour in all men's eyes,     <span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then reward me I pray, Sir Landgrave, with rewarding as I shall win;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if honour or praise be withholden I count it not me for sin!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor here did his speech find ending. 'If <i>Turnus</i> thou fain wouldst be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then good, thou shalt find me <i>Tranzes</i>; thou mayst well wreak thy will on me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If so be thou hast aught against me, but 'tis <i>thou</i> who dost boast too loud,<span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, e'en an thou wert the highest of my peers, these princes proud;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Prince am I too, and Landgrave, and I have in Galicia's land<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many Burgs so fair and stately that e'en far as Vedrun stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' thou and this Breton stranger were minded to work me ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet not even a fowl for thy threatening would fly, but abide thee still!'<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'He came from the land of the Breton whom thou hither for strife didst hale.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Take <i>thou</i> vengeance for king and kinsman, if such vengeance may aught avail;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With <i>him</i>, not with <i>me</i>, thy quarrel, avenge thou thine uncle's life<br></span>
<span class="i0">On him who of life hath robbed him, it toucheth me not, this strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I wot well in naught I wronged him, and none for such wrong makes moan.<span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What need to bewail thine uncle? His son sitteth on his throne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ask for no higher ruler, since Fleurdamur, the queen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was his mother, his sire Kingrisein, and his grandsire Gandein hath been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And still in my mind it dwelleth how Galoes and Gamuret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Those heroes twain, were his uncles, nor lie I, nor truth forget.  <span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I think me that in all honour my castles and lands so wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">I may take from his hand, with their banners, and serve him whate'er betide!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Let him fight who hath lust for fighting, for weary of strife am I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' I know well who fame in battle doth win, for his victory<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath reward from the lips of women, yet for never a maiden's sake  <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Will I evil entreat this body, or bid it such ill-road take.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, why should I be a Wolfhart? Since barred is the battle way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no lust of strife hath beguiled me that I know not the thing I say.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou shouldst for aye despise me, yet Rumolt I'll take as guide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who gave counsel unto King Gunther, ere yet to the Huns he hied.   <span class="linenum">390</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_241">[Pg 241]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For he bade him in Worms abide still, where was plenty and e'en to spare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And content his soul with the flesh-pots and the riches of Rhineland fare!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But ready of wit was the Landgrave, and he spake, 'Yea, the tale be told<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en to day, and no man shall marvel, for we know well thy ways of old.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wouldst urge me to strife, yet thy counsel is e'en what a cook once gave<span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To the Nibelung lord, little recked he such counsel, the hero brave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he and his, little doubting, went boldly to meet their fate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And avenged was the death of Siegfried, and sated was Kriemhild's hate!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Sir Gawain, I ween, must give me my death, or himself must feel<br></span>
<span class="i0">The weight of my bitter vengeance as we battle for woe or weal!'   <span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thou dost well,' Liddamus made answer, 'yet I think me of treasure fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All that Arthur might hold, or India, if one such to my feet should bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And say 'twas mine own, he might have it ere I fought e'en for such a prize.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou wilt, win thee fame and honour, I, I think me, am all too wise.<br></span>
<span class="i0">God knoweth, no Segramor am I, whom men must with fetters bind     <span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So keenly for strife he lusted, far other was aye my mind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet mine be my monarch's favour, for Sibech ne'er drew a sword,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever he fled with the flying, yet men hearkened well his word;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many for counsel prayed him, and great gifts and lands enow<br></span>
<span class="i0">The hand of Ermenrich gave him, tho' no helmet e'er felt his blow. <span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Sir Kingrimursel, I rede thee, thou shalt mark me with never a scar!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then out spake King Vergulacht sternly, as he ended their wordy war:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Peace, peace, nor so loudly wrangle, Sir Knights, all too bold are ye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For too near is your monarch's presence, and of speech are ye both too free;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that thus ye should strive before me, tho' your strife be of <i>word</i>, not <i>deed</i>,<span class="linenum">415</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ill beseemeth both king and vassal, so hearken my word, and heed.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This befell in the hall of the palace, 'neath the eyes of his sister fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gawain stood beside the maiden, and heroes and knights were there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the king to his gentle sister, 'Now take thou with thee thy guest<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Landgrave, while I bethink me the word that shall 'seem me best.<span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all ye who wish well unto me, shall follow and give me rede.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the maid, 'Of good faith seek counsel, for better 'twill serve thy need!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gat the king to his council-chamber; the king's daughter had comrades three,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_242">[Pg 242]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Cousin, and guest, and beside them black care bare them company.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gawain, as right well beseemed her, by the hand to her bower she led.<span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she quoth, 'Now shall all lands rue it if here thou shalt be ill-sped!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the son of King Lot, Sir Gawain, with the maiden went hand in hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And none thought them shame, for so gracious was the custom of that fair land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So passed they unto her chamber, the queen and those heroes twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that none 'gainst her will should enter was the care of her chamberlain.<span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Only her bower maidens as befitted them there might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen, in all love and honour, her guest tended royally.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Landgrave in naught gainsaid her, for belike did he bear a part<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the fear for her guest's well-doing that lay dark on the maiden's heart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So the twain with the queen abode there till the strife of the day was o'er,<span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the night and the hour of feasting had come in their course once more.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the slender maidens bare them sweet drinks, and the wine so red,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with fish and fowl in plenty, I ween, was the table spread.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair and white was the bread to look on, and the Landgrave and Knight Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who had passed thro' such deadly peril, to taste of the food were fain.<span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And each as the queen might bid him ate that which should please him best,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no lack did they find, for right queenly the maid did entreat her guest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And vainly the heroes prayed her to cease from her kindly care.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the many who knelt before them no maid but was young and fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, fair with the opening beauty of the rose that is yet unblown, <span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And soft lay their locks as the feathers of a falcon the knight hath flown.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now list, ere they close the council, to the rede they would rede the king<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wise were the men who, wisely, good counsel in need should bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each spake as his mind should bid him, and that which his heart deemed best,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they turned the thing hither and thither, till the king thus his speech addrest:<span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'One of late fought with me, as on venture bent I rode<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the wood Læhtamreis—too proudly, perchance, I my steed bestrode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a knight, who o'er great my fame deemed, in joust smote me such a blow<br></span>
<span class="i0">That, behind my gallant charger, on the greensward he laid me low.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this oath must I swear unto him, in search of the Grail to ride,<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_243">[Pg 243]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And my knightly pledge I gave him, were it other, I there had died.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now give me, I pray, your counsel, for 'gainst death was no other shield<br></span>
<span class="i0">But to swear as my victor bade me, and, as knight, to a knight to yield!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Yea, mighty and strong that hero,—nor sware I that oath alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he bade me, as true man truly, when a year should have come and gone,<span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail I still were seeking, to ride unto Pelrapär<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the queen who the crown there weareth, the child of King Tampentäre.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, as I looked upon her, I should yield me unto her grace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from him should I bear this message in the day that I sought her face.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would say, "An she thought upon him 'twas his joy and his labour's meed,<span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His hand from the King Klamidé aforetime her land had freed."'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the speech to the end they hearkened; and Liddamus spake this word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Give me leave to speak, ye shall follow, Sir Knights, when my rede is heard,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the oath that perforce thou swarest, its fulfiller shall be Gawain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he, captive, his wings shall flutter in the snare wherein <i>thou</i> wast ta'en.<span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For here, where we stand to hearken, shall he swear us the Grail to win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then of free will let him ride hence; for I deem men would count it sin<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were he slain in thine house—Nay, me-seemeth 'twere better to let him live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For but ill would it please thy sister an thou didst not her knight forgive!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sore stress at our hands hath he suffered, and he now to his death shall ride;<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For far as the far sea's water shall circle the earth so wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">There standeth no Burg so mighty as Monsalväsch, its towers shall fear<br></span>
<span class="i0">No foeman, and strait the pathway that wendeth its walls anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore dangers that road encompass—Let him slumber in peace this night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the word that we deem the wisest shall be told him with morning light!'<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Right well did the counsel please them, and ended, I ween, the strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Gawain, so the venture telleth, thus won at their hands his life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So they tended the dauntless hero right well thro' the hours of night;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the Mass came the folk on the morrow when the noontide hour waxed bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the hall was thronged and crowded with townsfolk and warriors good,<span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When before the king, as they counselled, his foeman, Sir Gawain, stood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To naught other would he compel him than to that which ye late did hear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now see ye the gentle maiden as she drew with her knight anear,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_244">[Pg 244]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And her uncle's son came with her, and many a hero brave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the king's men were fain to follow, and thus fair escort gave.  <span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the queen led Gawain to her brother with slender hand and white,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a chaplet of fair flowers woven she bare on her locks of light,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair the flowers, yet the maid was fairer, and no blossom around her head<br></span>
<span class="i0">But waxed pale and dim, if 'twas mated with her lips of glowing red.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he whom of true heart gently she kissed, as beseemed a maid,   <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such lances for her had broken as had wasted a woodland shade.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now hearken to me and heed me, as with gracious words I'ld greet<br></span>
<span class="i0">Antikonie, free from falsehood, a maiden pure and sweet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In such wise did she ever bear her that never a doubting word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were one fain to sing her praises, from the lips of men was heard; <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For no heart but wished her gladness, and no mouth but spake her free<br></span>
<span class="i0">From all thought of guile—Far-reaching, as a falcon's eye can see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shone the light of her gracious presence, as the light of a balsam rare<br></span>
<span class="i0">That burneth, and sheddeth perfume, and sweeteneth the scented air.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her will was ever gracious, as the will of a maid should be,   <span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And she spake to her royal brother of a true heart right maidenly:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'I bring here to thee, my brother, the guest thou didst bid me tend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I would thou shouldst well entreat him, as befitting my knight and friend—<br></span>
<span class="i0">For better shall that become thee, to bear thee as brother true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than to feel the world's hate, or to teach me to hate thee, who hate ne'er knew.'<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the king, 'Nay then, my sister, an I may, so stands my will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt give me here thy counsel, for I think me I did but ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stained thereby mine honour, and dimmed my knightly fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I deem me but little worthy that thou shouldst me as brother claim.<br></span>
<span class="i0">E'en if all lands should do my bidding at thy prayer would I yield them all,<span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest that sorrow of sorrows greatest, thine hatred, on me should fall!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And honour and joy were ended an I said to thy pleading, Nay—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Gawain, I here entreat thee, since for fame thou didst ride this way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An thou knightly fame wouldst honour, so help me, that I may win<br></span>
<span class="i0">Anew from my sister favour, and forgiveness for this my sin.       <span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Far liefer were I to pardon the wrong thou hast done to me<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_245">[Pg 245]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Than to lose her, my sweetest sister—Now list what thy task shall be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Do thou swear to me here that truly thou wilt strive, as I erst was fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To strive, for the Grail's fair kingdom, and the honour thou there shalt gain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In such wise the strife was ended, Sir Gawain far hence must ride, <span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with sword and spear do battle, and woe for the Grail abide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Landgrave forgave his monarch the wrong that he did his word<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he brake his pledge unto Gawain—and no prince of the land but heard.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then their swords they ungirt, and they hung them in their place on the castle wall—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the squires of Gawain came swiftly, and, joyful, he hailed them all,<span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For not one in strife was wounded—for a man of the Burger folk,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere the battle waxed hot, had claimed them, and wise were the words he spoke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their peace he prayed from the foemen, and he held them awhile in ward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were they French, or from land of the Breton, till again to their rightful lord<br></span>
<span class="i0">He might send them in peace—Some were children, and some were lads strong and young—<span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And glad were their hearts when they saw him, and awhile on his neck they hung,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And weeping they kissed Sir Gawain, yet no sorrow I ween was there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But from joy sprang the crystal tear-drops that ran o'er their faces fair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And one came from the land of Cornwall, Count Laiz he, and Tinal's son;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a noble lad was with him whose father his death had won        <span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">At Schoie-de-la-Kurt, Gandelus, the son, and Gurzgrei, the sire—<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Thro' that venture full many a maiden must weep for her heart's desire)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his aunt was the maid Liassé, and fair was the lad of face<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of feature, for Love had touched them, and had wrought them with hand of grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain were all men to see him—Six were there those twain beside,<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Eight lads, all of noble bearing and birth, with Gawain did ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as kinsmen right well they loved him, and they served him for payment fair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">What payment gave he? Meed of honour their guerdon, and tender care!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Gawain quoth unto the children, ''Tis well, for I now have seen,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_246">[Pg 246]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Fair kinsmen, that ye had mourned me, if slain I perchance had been,<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(And well might he see their sorrow, for as yet they mourned full sore,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where were ye in hour of battle? Much sorrow for ye I bore.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then they answered, and none spake falsely, 'As thou sat'st in the high hall place<br></span>
<span class="i0">A hawk flew astray, and we ran thence, and joined for awhile the chase.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then all they who sat or stood there, nor ceased for awhile their gaze,<span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Saw well that Gawain was a true knight, and a man whom all men might praise;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the king gave the leave he prayed for, and he spake unto all farewell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save the queen alone, and the Landgrave, he whom men called Kingrimursel.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the queen took the twain, and the children who followed as Gawain's squires,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she led them where gentle maidens should serve as she should require,<span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And in peace, as became fair maidens, each maid did her lady's will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair were the hands and gracious that did gracious tasks fulfil.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Straightway when the meal was ended Gawain from the feast uprose,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus Kiot hath told the story—and as blossom from root up-grows,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So afresh from a true heart's true faith did sorrow spring forth amain—<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the hero unto the maiden, 'Now, Lady, an God be fain<br></span>
<span class="i0">To leave to me life and wisdom, wherever my way I take<br></span>
<span class="i0">True service, true knight befitting, will I do for thy gentle sake.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The rede did I hear and hearken that spake thee of falsehood free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy fame o'er the fame of all maidens shall high as the heavens be.<span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Heaven Itself shall bless thee, and thy gifts all be gifts of God!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, Lady, thy leave I crave here, since 'tis time on my way I rode.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Give me leave, then, and let me ride hence, for I ween for the future days<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shalt thou be thine own best defender, and thy virtue shall crown thy praise!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sorrow of heart was her portion that the knight thus her side must leave,<span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sore she wept, and her gentle maidens awhile with her grief must grieve.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the queen she spake out freely, 'An more I had done for thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then my joy had o'ercome my sorrow, yet better it might not be;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_247">[Pg 247]</a></span>
