<span class="i0">Little peace for thee here might blossom—but, believe me, be ill thy share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or should deeds of knighthood lead thee where sorrow thou needs must bear,<span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then, Sir Gawain, my heart findeth portion in thy lot, be it loss or gain!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">On his mouth, with her red lips glowing, the maiden she kissed Gawain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then joy fled afar from the hero, and sorrow hath pierced his heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Too early the twain they deemed it, from each other for aye to part.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Meantime had his squires bethought them, and his steed to the palace brought,<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the boughs of a mighty linden might shadow the outer court;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Landgrave's folk they sought him, and together they took their way<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without the walls; ere they parted this grace would Sir Gawain pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since his squires might no more fare with him, that the Landgrave with them in ward<br></span>
<span class="i0">Should ride forthwith unto Beaurosch, 'There Scherules the Burg doth guard,<span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt pray him that these fair children to Dianasdron he bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where many a Breton dwelleth, and shall yield them unto the king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or to Guinevere, his Lady'—So sware him Kingrimursel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, with kindly words and courteous, to Sir Gawain he bade 'Farewell.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Short the space ere both steed and rider were clad in their mail of might,<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Kinsmen and squires, he kissed them, and alone rode that gallant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For, as this his oath had bade him, to the Grail must his pathway wend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a pain and peril must he know ere his task should end.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_248">[Pg 248]</a><br><a id="Page_249">[Pg 249]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>BOOK IX<br>

TREVREZENT</h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_250">[Pg 250]</a></span></p>
<h3>ARGUMENT</h3>
<p>Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> In the opening the spirit of adventure craves admission to
the heart of the poet, who would fain learn from her tidings of Parzival.
The venture telleth how the hero had ridden long in doubt and despair,
and knew not the days of his wanderings. How he met again with Siguné
and came to the forest of Monsalväsch, where he fought with a Knight of
the Grail. How, on Good Friday, Parzival met with a pilgrim knight who
reproached him for bearing arms at that Holy Tide, and bade him seek
the hermit Trevrezent.</p>
<p>How Parzival came to the hermit's cell, and spake of his wrath against
God, of his sorrow for his wife, and of his search for the Grail. How
Trevrezent told him wherein he had sinned, and showed him the way of
salvation.</p>
<p>How the hermit farther revealed to him the mysteries of the Grail, of the
Bleeding Lance, and the knives of silver; how he told him of the wound
of Anfortas, of the race of the Grail Kings, and how Parzival himself was
nephew to Anfortas and Trevrezent. How Parzival confessed that it was
he who came to the Grail Castle and failed to ask the question; how
Trevrezent spake to him words of comfort and counsel, and absolved him
from his sin; and how the two parted in sorrow.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_251">[Pg 251]</a></span></p>
<p class="ph2">BOOK IX</p>
<p class="ph2">TREVREZENT
</p>
<div class="figpoem">
<img alt="" src="images/drop_o.png" width="100" id="img_images_drop_o.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Ope the portal!' 'To whom? Who art thou?' 'In thine heart would I find a place!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay! if such be thy prayer, methinketh, too narrow shall be the space!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'What of that? If it do but hold me, none too close shall my presence be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor shalt thou bewail my coming, such marvels I'll tell to thee!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is it thou, then, O Dame Adventure? Ah! tell me of Parzival,         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What doeth he now my hero? whom Kondrie, to find the Grail<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath driven, with words sharp-pointed, and sore wept the maidens fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the path of his far wayfarings the knight from their side must bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So he passed from the court of King Arthur, where shall he abide to-day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! hasten the tale to tell us, where now shall his footsteps stray?<span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, if fame to himself he winneth, or be ever of joy bereft,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall his honour as fair and spotless as of old so to-day be left?<br></span>
<span class="i0">His renown is it broad as aforetime, or waxeth it small and thin?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ah! tell us, nor stay the story, of the deeds that his hand shall win.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath he seen once again Monsalväsch, and Anfortas, the mournful king,<span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose heart was with sorrow laden? Of thy pity swift comfort bring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And say if his woe be ended—Speak, speak for we tidings pray<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of him whom alike we serve here, dwells Parzival there to-day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Declare unto me his doings, how fares it with Gamuret's son,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the child of fair Herzeleide, is the tale of his wanderings done?<span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he rode from the court of King Arthur has joy been his lot, or woe?<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hath striven, but rides he ever thro' the wide world nor rest doth know?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or loveth he now, outwearied, to linger o'er-long at ease?<br></span>
<span class="i0">I were fain to know all his doings, so speak thou, as thou shalt please!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this hath the venture told me—He hath ridden many a land,      <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_252">[Pg 252]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And hath sailèd many a water; and ever, before his hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were he man of the land or kinsman who would joust with him, he fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor abode his mighty onslaught, and all men of his praises tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever when in the balance the fame of his foe must lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas outweighed by his fame, and his glory uprose to the stars on high,<span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all others paled before it—In many a mighty strife<br></span>
<span class="i0">With sword and lance was he victor, and guarded full well his life.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they who would fame win from him, for such thinking they paid full dear—<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sword that Anfortas gave him, as ye once in this tale did hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sprang asunder onewhile, yet 'twas welded afresh in the mystic spring<span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By Karnant, and much fame and honour the blade to its lord did bring!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who believeth me not, he sinneth, for now doth the venture tell<br></span>
<span class="i0">How adown a woodland pathway, on his way rode Sir Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(But the hour of his riding I wot not, if in waxing or waning light,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">When a hermitage, newly builded, uprose to his wondering sight,     <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a stream flowed swift beneath it, for 'twas built o'er the brooklet's wave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in search of some worthy venture to its door rode the hero brave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor knew that of grace 'twas the portal, and his footsteps of God were led.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the dweller therein was a maiden, and the days of her joy were sped,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the love of God had she offered her youth, and the joys of earth,<span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the root of her old-time sorrow brought ever fresh grief to birth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For he found here Schionatulander, and Siguné, his faithful love,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dead and buried he lay, the hero, and the maid wept his tomb above.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' but seldom Siguné the Duchess might hearken the Holy Mass,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All her life was a prayer, in God's service her nights as her days she'ld pass.<span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And her lips, erst so red and glowing, had faded as life-joys fade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And alone would she mourn such sorrow as never had mourned a maid.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus denial of love's fulfilling made Love, with her love, to die,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dead, as she living loved him, did she cherish him tenderly.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth had she once his wife been, then ne'er had Lunete braved<span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her wrath, and had given such counsel, as she once to her lady gave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And today may we look upon women, who never a willing ear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had turned to Lunete, and such wisdom but little had brooked to hear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this do I know, that a woman who, for love of her lord alone,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_253">[Pg 253]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' virtue of gentle breeding, doth never strange service own,<span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But aye, while her husband liveth, shall be to him wife as true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Heaven giveth in her such blessing as bloometh for ever new!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never shall prayer or fasting robe her with a robe as fair!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, if the time were fitting, this word naught but truth would swear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be he dead, she may do as best please her, but if faithful she still abide,<span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then far fairer such faith than the circlet she beareth at feasting tide!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shall I joy compare with the sorrow that her faith to Siguné brought?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, 'twere better I speak not of it—O'er rough stones, and a road unwrought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rode Parzival to the window (he deemed well he rode too near).<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would ask of the woodland pathway, and the goal of its windings hear.<span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought him, perchance, the hermit might tell of the unknown way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Doth one dwell here?' the voice of a maiden it was that made answer,'Yea!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he knew 'twas the voice of a woman, swift turned he his steed aside<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the greensward beside the pathway, for he deemed he too near did ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sooner had he dismounted had he known that a maiden dwelt       <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Within such a lowly dwelling, and shame, as was meet, he felt.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his horse and his shield, all splintered, he bound to a fallen tree,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he loosed his sword from beside him, for a courteous knight was he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he stepped him unto the window, and asked of the place and road,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the cell of all joy was empty, and bare, as 'seemed grief's abode.<span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He spake, would she come to the window? and the maiden from prayer arose,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She was tall as a virgin lily, and pale as a faded rose,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he deemed not as yet that he knew her—A shirt woven rough of hair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Next her skin, 'neath a flowing garment of grey, did the maiden wear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow was her heart's treasure, and fallen her courage high,   <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the guerdon she won for her service must be paid her in many a sigh!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the maiden she stepped to the window and the knight did she courteous greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In her hand did she hold her psalter, and her voice it was low and sweet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival saw on her white hand the gleam of a ring of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For truly she bare the token she won from true love of old.         <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the stone set within the circlet was a garnet, whose slumbering light<br></span>
<span class="i0">Flashed red mid the dusky shadows, as mid ashes the sparks glow bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the band that her head encircled was black as a mourning band—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_254">[Pg 254]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then she spake, 'Sir Knight, 'neath the window a bench shalt thou see to stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou canst sit there, an it so please thee, and thy journey will brook delay,<span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">God reward thee for this thy greeting Who hath led thee to me this day!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the hero did as she bade him, and he sat 'neath the window small,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he prayed her, 'Sit thou within there!' 'Nay! ne'er did such chance befall<br></span>
<span class="i0">That here by a man I sat me!' Then he asked her, what did she here?<br></span>
<span class="i0">That, so far from the home of men-folk, thou dost dwell in this desert drear<span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Seemeth me all too great a wonder, say, Lady, how shalt thou live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since no man abideth by thee who succour or food can give?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she quoth, ''Tis the Grail that doth feed me, and It feedeth me well I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Its marvels the sorceress Kondrie, (of her own will the task hath been,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doth bring me each Sabbath vigil what serveth me for the week.'    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A little space she kept silence, then further the maid did speak:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'An it otherwise were with me as I would, I need little care<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the food, since the Grail doth feed me I never too ill shall fare!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But he deemed that she lied unto him, and with false words would speak him<br></span>
<span class="i0">fair, And, mocking, he spake,'Now, who gave thee that ring which I see thee wear?<span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ever 'twas told unto me that hermit, or man, or maid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Must forswear all love!'—'Now I think me, if in truth thou these words hast said,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For false maiden thou sure dost hold me! Yet if falsehood I ever learn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou shalt be near to witness, 'twere time <i>then</i> with wrath to burn!<br></span>
<span class="i0">God knoweth, ill ways I hated, and falsehood I never knew;         <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This troth plight that here thou seest I had from a lover true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' never was love's fulfilment our portion while he might live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas the heart of maiden bade me the love of a maiden give.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he lieth in death beside me, and his token I ever wear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the day that Duke Orilus slew him—and grief for his sake I bear—'<span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And true love will I truly give him, thro' my sorrow-laden days,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such love as I sware unto him, when he, whom, all knights must praise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With sword, and shield, and helmet, and prowess of knightly deed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sought my love, and in true love's service won death for his glory's meed!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet tho' ever a spotless maiden, my husband he, in God's sight,    <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_255">[Pg 255]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Shall be, and if thoughts God counteth as deeds then is woven aright<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bond that shall ever bind us, true husband and wife as true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his death wrought my life such sorrow as waxeth for ever new.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this ring shall, I ween, be my witness when I stand in the sight of God<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a marriage vow and the tear-drops that bedew it are tears of blood.'<span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Yea, 'tis I indeed, and none other, and the hero who here doth lie<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is my knight, Schionatulander, and the maid of his love am I!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he knew 'twas the maid Siguné, and her sorrow it wrought him pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he lifted his helmet's visor ere he spake to the maid again.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she saw his head uncovered, and she saw his face gleam white   <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the rust of the iron harness, and she spake to the gallant knight:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Is it thou, Parzival, my kinsman? Dost thou seek for the Grail to-day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or its mighty power hast thou proven? Say, whither dost wend thy way?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he spake to the noble maiden, 'Alas! for my joy is fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail hath but wrought me sorrow, and mischance in fair fortune's stead.<span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the land that as king had crowned me must I leave, and yet more, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fairest of wives, and the sweetest, that ever a man hath seen.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no lovelier form I think me on earth of mankind was born,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I yearn for her tender greeting, and full sore for her love I mourn!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet know I a deeper sorrow and I strive for a higher prize,    <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the day when the Burg of Monsalväsch, and the Grail shall rejoice my eyes!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, Siguné, dear my cousin, thou wast all too wroth with me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For heavy indeed my sorrow, yet thou fain wouldst my foeman be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And she quoth,'From henceforth, my cousin, mine anger will I forswear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For too much of thy joy lieth forfeit since the question thou didst forbear!<span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I would not too sorely grieve thee—Alas I that thou didst withhold<br></span>
<span class="i0">The word that had brought thee honour, and the tale of his griefs had told<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who sat there as thine host beside thee—nor thine host alone was he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Anfortas, for joy and blessing his presence had brought to thee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy question great bliss had brought thee, and thy silence had wrought thee woe,<span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thy spirit shall fail, and heart-sorrow as thy comrade thou well shalt know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet had it been far from thee, nor, a stranger, had sought thy side,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_256">[Pg 256]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Hadst thou asked of that Burg the marvels, and what ill did its host betide!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Yea, I did there as one who wrongeth himself; yet my cousin dear<br></span>
<span class="i0">I prithee here give me counsel, since in sooth are we kinsmen near.<span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And tell me, how fares it with thee? I would sorrow for this thy woe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were my sorrow not all too heavy! Greater grief man may never know!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she quoth, 'May His Mercy help thee, Who knoweth of all men's woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Perchance it may yet befall thee that His finger a way shall show<br></span>
<span class="i0">That shall lead thee once more to Monsalväsch, and thine heart's bliss afresh shall spring.<span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis but short space since Kondrie left me, and I would I could tidings bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of whither she went, but I asked not if she rode to the Burg again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or passed elsewhere; but when she cometh by that streamlet she draweth rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where, from cleft in the high rock riven, the waters flow fresh and clear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">It may be, if thou follow swiftly, that she rideth as yet anear,   <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, perchance, thou shalt overtake her.' Then the knight he made no delay<br></span>
<span class="i0">But farewell did he bid to the maiden; and he followed the woodland way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fresh were the tracks before him, but such pathway the mule must choose<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' the depths of the dusky thicket that its traces he soon must lose.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the Grail he had lost of aforetime, so he lost It again to-day, <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And joy and delight fled with It—Yea, had he but found the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And reached once again Monsalväsch, for better than erst of old<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had he known how to ask the question—thus in sooth is the venture told.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So now let him ride, but whither? Lo, a knight with uncovered head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And blazoned coat o'er his shining harness, full swiftly towards him sped!<span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to Parzival thus quoth he, 'Sir Knight, I must deem it ill<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thus thro' the woods of my monarch thou takest thy way at will!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Begone! or receive such token thou shalt wish thyself far from here!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Monsalväsch doth never brook it that men ride thus its walls anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here must thou strive in battle, and win here a victor's fame, <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or such penance be thine, as without there, in the open, men <i>Death</i> shall name!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he bare in his hand a helmet, and its bands were of silken sheen,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_257">[Pg 257]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Sharp-pointed his spear, and the spear-shaft was of wood new and strong I ween!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wrathful he bound his helmet on his head, not in vain should be<br></span>
<span class="i0">His threat, for his blows should enforce it! Now ready for joust was he;<span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But many a spear as goodly had splintered 'fore Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he thought, 'Now, it well had chanced me, that death to my lot should fall<br></span>
<span class="i0">If I rode thro' the corn upstanding—<i>then</i> reason had he for wrath,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But <i>now</i> hath he none, since I ride here on naught but a woodland path,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I tread here but fern and heather! An mine hand shall not lose its skill<span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I will leave him such pledge for my journey as, I think me, shall please him ill!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then they rode at full speed their chargers, and they urged them with spur and rein,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the bolt from the bow of the archer so swift flew those heroes twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the first joust they rode unwounded; but many a knightly fray<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unscathed had Parzival ridden, and e'en so should it chance to-day.<span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Unto skill and the lust of battle must his father's son be heir.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">His lance-point upon the fastening of his foeman's helm struck fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it smote him where men in jousting their shield are wont to hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And down from his gallant charger did he bear him, the Templar bold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight of the Grail fell headlong down the side of a rocky dell,<span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' couch he had found, I think me, he slumbered not over well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But the victor's steed sped onward, and in vain would he check its flight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere it fell, and well-nigh in falling had borne to his death the knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A cedar o'erhung the chasm, its bough Parzival gripped fast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Nor think ye scorn of my hero, that, as chanceth a thief at last, <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He hung, for none spake his judgment, he hung there by his own hand)<br></span>
<span class="i0">His feet, for a foothold seeking, on the rock found at last their stand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far out of his reach, beneath him, his gallant steed lay dead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Up the further side of the valley the Templar for safety fled.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Think ye that he much might pride him on his token from Parzival?  <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Far better at home in Monsalväsch had he fared with the wondrous Grail!<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the plain once more climbed our hero, there the steed of the Templar stood,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_258">[Pg 258]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For down to the ground hung the bridle and fettered the war-horse good.<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the knight in his flight forgat it so it stood where its master fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Swift Parzival sprang to the saddle, such booty might please him well.<span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a truth his spear had he shattered, yet more than he lost he won—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor Lähelein, nor Kingrisein a better joust e'er had run!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor King Gramoflanz nor Count Laskoit (the son he of Gurnemanz).<br></span>
<span class="i0">Onward he rode, yet wandering, nor further befell mischance,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor strife, from the knights of Monsalväsch, yet one grief must vex his soul,<span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He found not the Grail—Ever further he rode, further fled the goal!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he who my song will hearken, he shall hear that which yet befell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the tale of the weeks I know not, that had flown since Sir Parzival<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had met with the maid, and had ridden on venture as aye before—<br></span>
<span class="i0">One morning the ground was snow-clad, and tho' thin was the cloak it bore<span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet so thick it was that men, seeing, had deemed it the time of frost;<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he rode thro' the depths of a woodland by a knight was his pathway crossed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And old was the knight, and grey bearded, yet his face it was bright and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his lady who walked beside him like mien to her lord did bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And each on their naked body wore a garment of horse-hair grey,    <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For penance and pilgrimage minded they wended afoot their way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their children, two gentle maidens, such as men's eyes are fain to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In like garments they followed barefoot, e'en as pilgrims are wont to be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then our hero the old knight greeted as he passed on his lowly way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And good was the rede, and holy, that he heard from his lips that day.<span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a prince of the land he seemed him—By each maiden a brachet ran,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with humble mien and reverent paced master alike and man.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For both knight and squire they followed on this holy pilgrimage,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And some, they were young and beardless, and some were bent low with age.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But Parzival, our hero, he was clad in far other wise,             <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In fair raiment, rich and costly, he rode in right knightly guise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And proudly he ware his harness, and unlike were the twain I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The old man in his robe of penance and the knight in his armour's sheen!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then swiftly he turned his bridle and held by the pathway side,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_259">[Pg 259]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would he know of their journey, and friendly the knight replied.<span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But a sorrow the old man deemed it that one to this Holy Tide<br></span>
<span class="i0">Should have failèd to give due honour, but in warlike gear should ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For better would it befit him unarmèd this day to greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or like them to walk barefooted, and in garb for a sinner meet!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Nay, I know not what the time of the year may be, <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or how men the tale may reckon of the weeks as they swiftly flee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How the days shall be named I know not, long have I forgot such lore!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of old time I served a master, and <i>God</i> was the name He bore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But He bare unto me no favour, and for guerdon He mocking gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' ne'er had my heart turned from Him—Men said, 'If from God ye crave<span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For succour, He sure will give it;' but I deem well they spake a lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For He who they said would help me, did help unto me deny!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth the grey-haired knight, 'Dost thou mean Him who was once of a Maiden born?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dost believe that a Man for men's sake He died on the cross this morn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this day for His sake we hallow? Then such garb becomes thee ill!<span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For to-day all men call Good Friday, and the world it rejoiceth still<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er the day that her chains were riven; tho' she mourneth her Saviour's pain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speak, knowest thou of faith more faithful than the faith God hath kept with men,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since He hung on the cross for men's sake? Such woe as He bare for thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight, sure must work thee sorrow, since baptized thou shalt surely be!<span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>our</i> sin His life was forfeit, or else had mankind been lost,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Hell as his prey had held us, and Hell's torments had paid sin's cost.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight, if thou be not heathen, thou shalt honour this Holy Day—<br></span>
<span class="i0">So do thou as here I counsel, ride thou on this woodland way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For near here a hermit dwelleth, as thy speech, so his rede shall be,<span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And if ruth for ill deed thou showest of thy sin will he speak thee free!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out quoth the old man's daughter, 'Nay, father, but speak not so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For too chill and cold is the morning, thou shalt bid him no further go.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far better to bid him warm him his steel-clad limbs, for strong<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fair shall he be to look on, and the way is both cold and long.<span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks were he thrice as mighty he would freeze ere his goal he reach,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here hast thou tent for shelter, and viands for all and each.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Came King Arthur and all his vassals thou wouldst still have enough I trow,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_260">[Pg 260]</a></span>
<span class="i0">So do thou as host so kindly, and good-will to this young knight show!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the grey-haired sire, 'My daughters, Sir Knight, here give counsel good,<span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Each year, with tent of pilgrim, I wend thro' this lonely wood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If warm or cold be the season I care not, as year by year<br></span>
<span class="i0">The time of our dear Lord's Passion draweth once more anear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He rewardeth His servant's service—Sir Knight, what I, for His sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brought here, as my guest, right willing, I pray thee from me to take!'<span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And kindly they spake, the maidens, and they bade the knight to stay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with gracious mien they prayed naught might drive him from them away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' cold was the frost and bitter, and it wrought not as summer's heat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet Parzival saw their lips glow so red, and soft, and sweet.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Tho' they wept for the death of the Saviour, such sorrow became them well.)<span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And here, had I cause for vengeance, an such happy chance befell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I never would speak them guiltless, but a kiss should their penance be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor against their will would I take it, of good-will should they give it me!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For women shall aye be women, and tho' brave be the knight, and strong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I ween is he oft the vanquished, nor the strife it endureth long!<span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With sweet words, and ways so gentle, they ever the knight would pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Children alike and parents, and fain would they have him stay:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet he thought, 'It were best I leave them, for e'en if I turn aside<br></span>
<span class="i0">All too fair methinks are these maidens, 'twere unfitting that <i>I</i> should ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">While <i>they</i> by my side walk barefoot—And 'tis better that we should part,<span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since ever I bear Him hatred Whom they worship with lowly heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And they look for His aid, Who ever hath turnèd His face from me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor from sorrow hath He withheld me, but hath wrought with me heavily!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Knight and Lady,' he quoth, 'I think me 'twere better I leave should pray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">May good fortune be yours, and blessing, and fulness of joy alway, <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And may you, ye gentle maidens, find reward in your courtesy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since so well ye had thought to serve me, fair leave would I pray from ye!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">He greeted them, low they bowed them, and greeted the knight again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor might they withhold their sorrow, for parting aye bringeth pain!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So the son of Herzeleide rode onward, well taught was he           <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In all manly skill and courage, in mercy and purity;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_261">[Pg 261]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And his mother had aye bequeathed him her faithful heart and true—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ever his soul waxed sadder, and there sprang up thoughts anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the might of the Maker of all things, Who hath made this earth of naught,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How He dealeth with all creation, and still on His power he thought<span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'How might it yet be if God sent me that which brought to an end my woe?<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ever a knight He favoured, if ever a knight might know<br></span>
<span class="i0">His payment for service done Him—if He thinketh His aid they earn<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who dauntless shall wield their weapons, and ne'er from a foeman turn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let Him aid me, who bear unstainèd shield and sword as befits a man,<span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If to-day be His Day of Redemption, let Him help me, if help He <i>can</i>.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Backward he turned his bridle on the road he had ridden before,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight and his children stood there, and mourned for the parting sore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the maidens, true and gentle, gazed after the passing knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his heart spake, he fain had seen them once more those maidens bright.<span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he spake, 'Is God's power so mighty that He guideth upon their way<br></span>
<span class="i0">The steed alike and the rider, then His hand may I praise to-day!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If God sendeth help from heaven, then let Him my charger show<br></span>
<span class="i0">The goal which shall bless my journey, so shall I the token know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, go thou as God shall lead thee!' and bridle and bit he laid   <span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Free on the neck of his charger and spurred it adown the glade.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Towards Fontaine-Sauvage the road led, and the chapel where once he sware<br></span>
<span class="i0">The oath that should clear Jeschuté—A holy man dwelt there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Trevrezent men called him, and ever on Monday morn<br></span>
<span class="i0">Poor was his fare, and no richer it waxed as the week wore on.     <span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor wine nor bread he tasted, nor food that with blood was red,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fish nor flesh, but his life so holy on the herb of the ground was fed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever his thoughts, God-guided, were turning to Heaven's land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by fasting the wiles of the Devil he deemed he might best withstand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And to Parzival the mystery of the Grail should he now reveal—    <span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he, who of this hath asked me, and since silence my lips must seal<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was wroth with me as his foeman, his anger might naught avail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since I did but as Kiot bade me, for he would I should hide the tale,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_262">[Pg 262]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And tell unto none the secret, till the venture so far were sped<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the hidden should be made open, and the marvel of men be read.<span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For Kiot of old, the master whom men spake of in days of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far off in Toledo's city, found in Arabic writ the lore<br></span>
<span class="i0">By men cast aside and forgotten, the tale of the wondrous Grail;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But first must he learn the letters, nor black art might there avail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the grace of baptismal waters, by the light of our Holy Faith,  <span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He read the tale, else 'twere hidden; for never, the story saith,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might heathen skill have shown us the virtue that hidden lies<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this mighty Grail, or Its marvels have opened to Christian eyes.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Twas a heathen, Flegetanis, who had won for his wisdom fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And saw many a wondrous vision, (from Israel's race he came,       <span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the blood of the kings of old-time, of Solomon did he share,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">He wrote in the days long vanished, ere we as a shield might bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">The cross of our Holy Baptism 'gainst the craft and the wiles of Hell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he was the first of earth's children the lore of the Grail to tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">By his father's side a heathen, a calf he for God did hold,        <span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How wrought the devil such folly, on a folk so wise, of old?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Highest Who knoweth all wonders, why stretched He not forth His Hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the light of His truth to turn them? For who may His power withstand!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the heathen, Flegetanis, could read in the heavens high<br></span>
<span class="i0">How the stars roll on their courses, how they circle the silent sky,<span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the time when their wandering endeth—and the life and the lot of men<br></span>
<span class="i0">He read in the stars, and strange secrets he saw, and he spake again<br></span>
<span class="i0">Low, with bated breath and fearful, of the thing that is called the Grail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a cluster of stars was it written, the name, nor their lore shall fail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he quoth thus, 'A host of angels this marvel to earth once bore,<span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But too pure for earth's sin and sorrow the heaven they sought once more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the sons of baptized men hold It, and guard It with humble heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the best of mankind shall those knights be who have in such service part'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Kiot my master read this, the tale Flegetanis told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sought for the name of the people, in Latin books of old,   <span class="linenum">380</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_263">[Pg 263]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Who of God were accounted worthy for this wondrous Grail to care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who were true and pure in their dealings and a lowly heart might bear.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in Britain, and France, and Ireland thro' the chronicles he sought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till at length, in the land of Anjou, the story to light was brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There, in true and faithful record, was it written of Mazadan,     <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heroes, the sons of his body, and further the story ran,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How Titurel, the grandsire, left his kingdom to Frimutel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And at length to his son, Anfortas, the Grail and Its heirdom fell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">That his sister was Herzeleide, and with Gamuret she wed<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bare him for son the hero whose wanderings ye now have read.   <span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he rideth upon a journey that shall lead him a road unknown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the grey knight but now had wended his way from the fountain lone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he knew again the meadow, tho' now the snow lay white<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the ground that erst was blooming with flowers of springtide bright.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas before the rocky hillside where his hand must wipe away      <span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The stain from Jeschuté's honour, and her husband's wrath allay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet still the road led onward, to Fontaine-Sauvage, the name<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the goal that should end his journey and his hermit host he came.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then out spake the holy hermit, 'Alas, why doest thou so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight? at this Holy Season 'tis ill thus armed to go.         <span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Dost thou bear perchance this harness thro' strife and danger dared?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or hast thou unharmèd ridden, and in peace on thy way hast fared?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Other robe had beseemed thee better! List not to the voice of pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But draw thy rein here beside me, and with me for a space abide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not all too ill shalt thou fare here, thou canst warm thee beside my fire.<span class="linenum">405</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Dost thou seek here for knightly venture, and dost guerdon of love desire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If the power of true Love constrain thee, then love Him who Love may claim!<br></span>
<span class="i0">As this day to His Love beareth witness, be His service to-day thine aim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And serve for the love of fair women, if it please thee, another day;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now get thee from off thy charger, and awhile from thy wanderings stay.'<span class="linenum">410</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival, e'en as he bade him, sprang lightly unto the ground;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Humbly he stood before him, as he told how he folk had found<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who had told of the hermit's dwelling, and the counsel he wisely gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'I am one who hath sinnèd, and rede at thy lips I crave!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he spake the hermit answered,'Right gladly I'll counsel thee,   <span class="linenum">415</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_264">[Pg 264]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But, say, what folk hast thou met with? Who showed thee thy way to me?<br></span>
<span class="i0">'In the wood I met with an old man grey-headed, and fair he spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And kindly, I ween, were his people, he bade me this road to take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On his track my steed came hither.' Then answered the hermit old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">''Twas Kahenis, and his praises shall ever by men be told.         <span class="linenum">420</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A prince of the land of Punturtois, and his sister Kareis' king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath taken to wife—Fairer maidens no mother to earth did bring<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than those maidens twain, his daughters, who met thee upon thy road,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a royal house, yet yearly he seeketh this poor abode!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Parzival spake to the hermit, 'Now say, when thou saw'st me here,<span class="linenum">425</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Didst thou shrink from my warlike coming, didst thou feel no touch of fear?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the hermit,'Sir Knight, believe me, far oftener for stag or bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have I feared than I feared a man's face, in sooth shalt thou be aware<br></span>
<span class="i0">I fear me for no man living! Both cunning and skill have I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' I were loath to vaunt me, yet I ne'er to this life did fly<span class="linenum">430</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For fear, as beseems a maiden! For never my heart did quail<br></span>
<span class="i0">When I faced as a knight my foeman, and ne'er did my courage fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the days when such things became me, in the days when I too might fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I was armèd as thou art armèd, like thee did I ride, a knight!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I strove for high love's rewarding, and many an evil thought   <span class="linenum">435</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the pure mind within me battled, and ever my way I wrought<br></span>
<span class="i0">To win from a woman favour! All that was in time of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my body, by fasting wasted, remembereth those days no more.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now give to mine hand the bridle, for there 'neath the rocky wall<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy steed shall abide in safety, and we, ere the night shall fall, <span class="linenum">440</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Will gather of bough and herbage, since no better food may be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I trust that both thou and thy charger fare not all too ill with me!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Parzival deemed that surely 'twas unfitting a hermit old<br></span>
<span class="i0">Should thus lead his steed, and the bridle he would fain from his hand withhold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Now courtesy sure forbids thee to strive 'gainst thine host's good-will,<span class="linenum">445</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Let not haste from the right path lead thee, but follow my counsel still.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this wise spake the old man kindly, as he bade him, so did the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the charger he led 'neath the hillside where but seldom did sun-rays light.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_265">[Pg 265]</a></span>
<span class="i0">In sooth 'twas a wondrous stable where the hermit the steed would stall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' it, from heights o'erhanging, foamed ever a water-fall.  <span class="linenum">450</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The snow lay beneath our hero, no weakling was he, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Else the frost and the cold of his harness o'er-much for his strength had been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To a cavern the hermit led him where no breath of wind might blow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a fire of coals had warmed it, and burned with a ruddy glow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here might the guest refresh him by the fire and a taper's light,<span class="linenum">455</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Well strewn was the ground with fuel,) then swiftly the gallant knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Laid from off him his heavy armour, and warmed his limbs so cold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his skin in the light glowed ruddy, and his face might the host behold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He might well be of wandering weary, for never a trodden way<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor a roof save the stars of heaven had he known for many a day.   <span class="linenum">460</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In the daylight the wood had he ridden, and his couch, it had been the ground:<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas well that he here a shelter, and a kindly host had found!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his host cast a robe around him, and he took him by his right hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he led him into a cavern where his Missal did open stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as fitted the Holy Season the Altar was stripped and bare;     <span class="linenum">465</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the shrine—Parzival must know it, 'twas the spot where he once did swear<br></span>
<span class="i0">With true hand, true oath and faithful, that ended Jeschuté's woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And turnèd her tears to laughter, and taught her fresh joy to know!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Well I know it this chapel and shrine! Of yore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As hither my wanderings led me, an oath on that shrine I swore;    <span class="linenum">470</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a spear, with fair colours blazoned, that did here by the altar stand<br></span>
<span class="i0">I bare hence, and in sooth, I think me, right well did it serve my hand!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men say it much honour brought me, yet I wot not if it be so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For in thoughts of my wife had I lost me, and naught of the thing I know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, unwitting, two jousts had I ridden, and two foemen I overthrew,<span class="linenum">475</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In those days all men gave me honour, nor sorrow nor shame I knew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, alas! is my sorrow greater than ever to man befell!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, when did I bear the spear hence? The days of my wanderings tell!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'It was Taurian,' quoth the hermit, 'who his spear in my care did leave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And much did he mourn its losing, and I with the knight must grieve.<span class="linenum">480</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_266">[Pg 266]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And four years and a half and three days shall have passed since we lost the spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Knight, an my word thou doubtest, behold! it is written here!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then he showed unto him in the Psalter how the time it had come and gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the weeks and the years he read him that silent and swift had flown.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Now first do I learn them, the days that I aimless stray,<span class="linenum">485</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the weeks and the years that have vanished, since my joy hath been reft away.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'Now indeed me-seemeth that my bliss it was but a dream,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For heavy the load of sorrow that so long hath my portion been!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And, Sir Host, I yet more would tell thee, where cloister or church shall be<br></span>
<span class="i0">And men unto God give honour, there no eye hath looked on me,      <span class="linenum">490</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And naught but strife have I sought me, tho' the time as thou sayst be long,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I against God bear hatred, and my wrath ever waxeth strong.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my sorrow and shame hath He cherished, and He watched them greater grow<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till too high they waxed, and my gladness, yet living, He buried low!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I think were God fain to help me other anchor my joy had found <span class="linenum">495</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Than this, which so deep hath sunk it, and with sorrow hath closed it round.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A man's heart is mine, and sore wounded, it acheth, and acheth still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet once was it glad and joyous, and free from all thought of ill!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere sorrow her crown of sorrow, thorn-woven, with stern hand pressed<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the honour my hand had won me o'er many a foeman's crest!       <span class="linenum">500</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I do well to lay it on Him, the burden of this my shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who can help if He will, nor withholdeth the aid that men fain would claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But me alone, hath He helped not, whate'er men of Him may speak,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever He turneth from me, and His wrath on my head doth wreak!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the hermit beheld him sighing, 'Sir Knight, thou shalt put away<span class="linenum">505</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such madness, and trust God better, for His help will He never stay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And His aid to us here be given, yea, alike unto me and thee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But' twere best thou shouldst sit beside me, and tell here thy tale to me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And make to me free confession—How first did this woe begin?<br></span>
<span class="i0">What foe shall have worked such folly that God should thine hatred win?<span class="linenum">510</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet first would I pray thee, courteous, to hearken the word I say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fain would I speak Him guiltless, ere yet thou thy plaint shall lay<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_267">[Pg 267]</a></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst Him, Who denieth never unto sinful man His aid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever hath answered truly, who truly to Him hath prayed.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Tho' a layman I was yet ever in books might I read and learn      <span class="linenum">515</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How men, for His help so faithful, should ne'er from His service turn.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since aid He begrudged us never, lest our soul unto Hell should fall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as God Himself shall be faithful, be <i>thou</i> faithful whate'er befall;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For false ways He ever hateth—and thankful we aye should be<br></span>
<span class="i0">When we think of the deed, so gracious, once wrought of His love so free!<span class="linenum">520</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For <i>our</i> sake the Lord of Heaven in the likeness of man was made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Truth is His name, and His nature, nor from Truth shall He e'er have strayed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And this shalt thou know most surely, God breaketh His faith with <i>none</i>.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Teach thy thoughts ne'er from Him to waver, since Himself and His ways are One!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Wouldst thou force thy God with thine anger? He who heareth that thou hast sworn<span class="linenum">525</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hatred against thy Maker, he shall hold thee of wit forlorn!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Lucifer now bethink thee, and of those who must share his fall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bethink thee, the angel nature was free from all taint of gall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, whence sprang that root of evil which spurred them to endless strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And won its reward in Hell's torments, and the death of an outcast life?<span class="linenum">530</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ashtaroth, Belcimon, and Belat, Rhadamant, yea, and many more!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pride and anger the host of Heaven with Hell's colours have painted o'er!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'When Lucifer and his angels thus sped on their downward way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To fill their place, a wonder God wrought from the earth and clay:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The son of His hands was Adam, and from flesh of Adam, Eve         <span class="linenum">535</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He brought, and for Eve's transgression, I ween, all the world doth grieve.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she hearkened not her Creator, and she robbed us of our bliss.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two sons sprang forth from her body, and the elder he wrought amiss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since envy so worked upon him that from wrath there sprang disgrace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of maidenhood did he rob her who was mother of all his race!   <span class="linenum">540</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Here many a one doth question, an the tale be to him unknown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How might such a thing have chancèd? It came but by sin alone!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Now, I think me that never such thing might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And 'twere better thou shouldst keep silence, than tell such a tale to me!<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_268">[Pg 268]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For who should have borne the father, whose son, as thou sayest, reft<span class="linenum">545</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Maidenhood from his father's mother? Such riddle were better left!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the hermit again made answer, 'Now thy doubt will I put away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O'er my falsehood thou canst bemoan thee if the thing be not truth I say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the <i>Earth</i> was Adam's mother, of the <i>Earth</i> was Adam fed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I ween, tho' a man she bare here, yet still was the Earth a maid.<span class="linenum">550</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And here will I read the riddle, he who robbed her of maidenhood<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was Cain the son of Adam, who in wrath shed his brother's blood:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as on the Earth, so stainless, the blood of the guiltless fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her maidenhood fled for ever! And true is the tale I tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For wrath of man and envy, thro' Cain did they wake to life,       <span class="linenum">555</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever from that day forward thro' his sin there ariseth strife.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nor on earth shall aught be purer than a maiden undefiled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Think how pure must be a maiden, since God was a Maiden's Child!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two men have been born of maidens, and God hath the likeness ta'en<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the son of the first Earth-Maiden, since to help us He aye was fain.<span class="linenum">560</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus grief alike and gladness from the seed of Adam spring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since He willed to be Son of Adam, Whose praises the angels sing.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet have we sin as our birthright, and sin's pain must we ever bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor its power may we flee! Yet pity He feeleth for our despair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose Strength is aye linked with Mercy, and with Mercy goes hand in hand,<span class="linenum">565</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And for man, as a Man, He suffered, and did falsehood by truth withstand.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'No longer be wroth with thy Maker! If thou wouldst not thy soul were lost—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here for thy sin do penance, nor longer thus rashly boast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he who, with words untamèd, is fain to avenge his wrong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His own mouth shall, I ween, speak his judgment ere ever the time be long.<span class="linenum">570</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Learn faith from the men of old-time, whose rede ever waxeth new,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Plato alike and the Sibyls in their day spake words so true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long years ere the time had ripened His coming they did foretell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who made for our sin's Atonement, and drew us from depths of Hell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">God's Hand from those torments took us, and God's Love lifted us on high,<span class="linenum">575</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But they who His love disdainèd, they yet in Hell's clutches lie!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'From the lips of the whole world's Lover came a message of love and peace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(For He is a Light all-lightening, and never His faith doth cease,)<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_269">[Pg 269]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And he to whom love He showeth, findeth aye in that Love his bliss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet twofold I ween is the message, and His token some read amiss;  <span class="linenum">580</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the world may buy, as it pleaseth, God's Wrath or His Love so great.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, which of the twain wilt thou choose here, shall thy guerdon be Love or Hate?<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the sinner without repentance, he flieth God's faith and Face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he who his sin confesseth, doth find in His presence grace!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'From the shrine of his heart, who shall keep Him? Tho' hidden the thought within,<span class="linenum">585</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And secret, and thro' its darkness no sunbeam its way may win,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(For thought is a secret chamber, fast locked, tho' no lock it bear,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, tho' against man it be closèd, God's light ever shineth there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He pierceth the wall of darkness, and silent and swift His spring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As no sound betrayed His coming, as no footstep was heard to ring, <span class="linenum">590</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So silent His way He goeth—And swift as our thoughts have flown,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere God passed of our heart the threshold, our thoughts unto Him were known!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the pure in heart He chooseth; he who doth an ill deed begin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since God knoweth the thoughts of all men, full sorely shall rue his sin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the man who by deeds God's favour doth forfeit, what shall he gain?<span class="linenum">595</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the world count him honour-worthy, his soul seeketh rest in vain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And where wilt thou seek for shelter if <i>God</i> as thy foeman stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who of wrath or of love giveth payment, as men serve Him, with equal hand?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou art lost if thy God be against thee—If thou wouldst His favour earn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then away from thy wrath and thy folly thy thoughts to His goodness turn!'<span class="linenum">600</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Here I thank thee, from my heart, that such faithful rede<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast given of him who withholdeth from no man his rightful meed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But evil, as good, requiteth—Yet my youth hath been full of care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my faith hath but brought me sorrow, and ill to this day I fare!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the hermit he looked on the Waleis, 'If a secret be not thy grief,<span class="linenum">605</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Right willing thy woe I'll hearken, I may bring thee perchance relief;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of some counsel may I bethink me such as yet to thyself dost fail!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Of my sorrows the chiefest is for the Grail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then for my wife—none fairer e'er hung on a mother's breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the twain is my heart yet yearning, with desire that ne'er findeth rest.'<span class="linenum">610</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth his host, 'Well, Sir Knight, thou speakest, such sorrow is good to bear;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_270">[Pg 270]</a></span>
<span class="i0">If thus for the wife of thy bosom thy heart knoweth grief and care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Death find thee a faithful husband, tho' Hell vex thee with torments dire<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet thy pains shall be swiftly ended, God will draw thee from out Hell-fire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if for the <i>Grail</i> thou grievest, then much must I mourn thy woe,<span class="linenum">615</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O! foolish man, since fruitless thy labours, for thou shalt know<br></span>
<span class="i0">That none win the Grail save those only whose names are in Heaven known,<br></span>
<span class="i0">They who to the Grail do service, they are chosen of God alone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And mine eyes have surely seen this, and sooth is the word I say!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Thou hast been there?' 'Sir Knight,' quoth the hermit, 'Yea!'<span class="linenum">620</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But never a word spake our hero of the marvels himself had seen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he asked of his host the story, and what men by 'The Grail' should mean?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the hermit, 'Full well do I know this, that many a knightly hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Serveth the Grail at Monsalväsch, and from thence, throughout all the land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On many a distant journey these gallant Templars fare,             <span class="linenum">625</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether sorrow or joy befall them, for their sins they this penance bear!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And this brotherhood so gallant, dost thou know what to them shall give<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their life, and their strength and their valour—then know, by a <i>stone</i> they live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that stone is both pure and precious—Its name hast thou never heard?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men call it <i>Lapis Exilis</i>—by its magic the wondrous bird,   <span class="linenum">630</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Phœnix, becometh ashes, and yet doth such virtue flow<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the stone, that afresh it riseth renewed from the ashes glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the plumes that erewhile it moulted spring forth yet more fair and bright—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tho' faint be the man and feeble, yet the day that his failing sight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Beholdeth the stone, he dies not, nor can, till eight days be gone,<span class="linenum">635</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor his countenance wax less youthful—If one daily behold that stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(If a man it shall be, or a maiden 'tis the same,) for a hundred years,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If they look on its power, their hair groweth not grey, and their face appears<br></span>
<span class="i0">The same as when first they saw it, nor their flesh nor their bone shall fail<br></span>
<span class="i0">But young they abide for ever—And this stone all men call the Grail.'<span class="linenum">640</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'And Its holiest power, and the highest shall I ween be renewed to-day,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_271">[Pg 271]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For ever upon Good Friday a messenger takes her way.<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the height of the highest Heaven a Dove on her flight doth wing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a Host, so white and holy, she unto the stone doth bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she layeth It down upon It; and white as the Host the Dove     <span class="linenum">645</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That, her errand done, swift wingeth her way to the Heaven above.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus ever upon Good Friday doth it chance as I tell to thee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the stone from the Host receiveth all good that on earth may be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of food or of drink, the earth beareth as the fulness of Paradise.<br></span>
<span class="i0">All wild things in wood or in water, and all that 'neath Heaven flies,<span class="linenum">650</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To that brotherhood are they given, a pledge of God's favour fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For His servants He ever feedeth and the Grail for their needs doth care!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now hearken, the Grail's elect ones, say who doth their service claim?<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the Grail, in a mystic writing, appeareth each chosen name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If a man it shall be, or a maiden, whom God calls to this journey blest.<span class="linenum">655</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the message no man effaceth, till all know the high behest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But when all shall the name have read there, as it came, doth the writing go:<br></span>
<span class="i0">As children the Grail doth call them, 'neath its shadow they wax and grow.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And blessèd shall be the mother whose child doth the summons hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rich and poor alike rejoiceth when the messenger draweth near,     <span class="linenum">660</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail son or daughter claimeth! They are gathered from every land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever from shame and sorrow are they sheltered, that holy band.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Heaven is their rewarding, if so be that they needs must die,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then bliss and desire's fulfilment are waiting them all on high!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'They who took no part in the conflict, when Lucifer would fight   <span class="linenum">665</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the Three-in-One, those angels were cast forth from Heaven's height.<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the earth they came at God's bidding, and that wondrous stone did tend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor was It less pure for their service, yet their task found at last an end.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I know not if God forgave them, or if they yet deeper fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This one thing I know of a surety, what God doeth, He doeth well!  <span class="linenum">670</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever since then to this service nor maiden nor knight shall fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For God calleth them all as shall please Him!—and so standeth it with the Grail!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'So, since knighthood may conquer, with spear and shield,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_272">[Pg 272]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Both the fame of <i>this</i> life, and the blessing which Paradise shall yield,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since my soul ever longed for knighthood, and I fought where'er strife might be,<span class="linenum">675</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And my right hand hath neared full often the guerdon of victory,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If God be the God of battles, if He know how a man should fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let Him name me as one of His servants, of the Grail let Him make me knight!<br></span>
<span class="i0">They shall own that I fear no danger, nor from strife would I turn aside!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the hermit made answer gently, 'First must thou beware of pride,<span class="linenum">680</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For lightly may youth mislead thee; and the grace of humility<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mayst thou lose, and the proud God doth punish, as full surely is known to me!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tears filled his eyes to o'erflowing, and his sad thoughts awhile did turn<br></span>
<span class="i0">To a story of old, and our hero he bade from its lesson learn.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he quoth, 'Sir Knight, at Monsalväsch a king reigned in days of yore,<span class="linenum">685</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His name all men know as Anfortas, and I weep for him evermore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, and thou too shalt mourn his sorrow, for bitter the woe, I ween,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the torment of heart and body that his guerdon from pride hath been.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his youth and his worldly riches they led him an evil road,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sought for Frau Minne's favour in paths where no peace abode.'<span class="linenum">690</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'But the Grail all such ways forbiddeth, and both knight alike and squire<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who serve the Grail must guard them from the lust of untamed desire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">By meekness their pride must be conquered, if they look for a heavenly prize,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the brotherhood holdeth hidden the Grail from all stranger eyes:<br></span>
<span class="i0">By their warlike skill and prowess the folk from the lands around, <span class="linenum">695</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They keep afar, and none knoweth where the Grail and Its Burg are found<br></span>
