<span class="i0">Save those whom the Grail shall summon within Monsalväsch' wall—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet <i>one</i>, uncalled, rode thither and evil did then befall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For foolish he was, and witless, and sin-laden from thence did fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he asked not his host of his sorrow and the woe that he saw him bear.<span class="linenum">700</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">No man would I blame, yet <i>this</i> man, I ween, for his sins must pay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since he asked not the longed-for question which all sorrow had put away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Sore laden his host with suffering, earth knoweth no greater pain.)<br></span>
<span class="i0">And before him King Lähelein came there, and rode to the Lake Brimbane.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Libbèals, the gallant hero, a joust there was fain to ride,        <span class="linenum">705</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lähelein lifeless left him, on the grass by the water-side,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_273">[Pg 273]</a></span>
<span class="i0">(Prienlaskors, methinks, was his birthplace) and his slayer then led away<br></span>
<span class="i0">His charger, so men knew the evil thus wrought by his hand that day.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And I think me, Sir Knight, <i>thou</i> art Lähelein? For thou gavest unto my care<br></span>
<span class="i0">A steed that such token showeth as the steeds of the Grail Knights bear!<span class="linenum">710</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the white dove I see on its housing, from Monsalväsch it surely came?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such arms did Anfortas give them while joy yet was his and fame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their shields bare of old the token, Titurel gave it to his son<br></span>
<span class="i0">Frimutel, and such shield bare that hero when his death in a joust he won.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his wife did he love so dearly no woman was loved so well      <span class="linenum">715</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By man, yet in truth and honour,—and the same men of thee shall tell<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou wakenest anew old customs, and thy wife from thine heart dost love—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hold thou fast to such fair example lest thy steps from the right path rove!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth thou art wondrous like him who once o'er the Grail did reign,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, what is thy race? whence art thou? and tell me I pray thy name!'<span class="linenum">720</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Each gazed for a space on the other, and thus quoth Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Son am I to a king and hero who through knightly courage fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a joust was he slain—Now I pray thee, Sir Hermit, of this thy grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou, in thy prayers henceforward, wilt give to his name a place.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Know, Gamuret, did they call him, and he came from fair Anjou—    <span class="linenum">725</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Host I am not Lähelein; if ever such sin I knew<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas in my days of folly, yet in truth have I done the same,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here I make of my guilt confession, and my sin unto thee I name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the prince who once fell a victim unto my sinful hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was he whom men called 'the Red Knight,' Prince Ither of Cumberland.<span class="linenum">730</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On the greensward I lifeless stretched him, and as at my feet he lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Harness, and horse, and weapons, as my booty I bare away!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Spake the host as his words were ended, (the tale he ill pleased must hear,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ah! world, wherefore deal thus with us? since sorrow and grief and fear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Far more than delight dost thou give us! Say, is this thy reward alone?<span class="linenum">735</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For ever the song that thou singest doth end in a mournful tone!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he spake, 'O thou son of my sister, what rede may I give to thee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since the knight thou hast slain in thy folly, thy flesh and thy blood was he!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou, blood-guiltiness bearing, shalt dare before God to stand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For one blood were ye twain, to God's justice thy life shall repay thine hand.<span class="linenum">740</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Say, for Ither of Gaheviess fallen, what payment dost think to give?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_274">[Pg 274]</a></span>
<span class="i0">The crown he of knightly honour! God gave him, while he might live.<br></span>
<span class="i0">All that decketh man's life; for all evil his true heart did truly mourn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True balsam was he of the faithful, to honour and glory born.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shame fled before his coming, and truth in his heart did dwell,<span class="linenum">745</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And for love of his lovely body many women shall hate thee well!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For well did they love his coming, and to serve them he aye was fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But their eyes that shone fair for his fairness he ne'er shall rejoice again!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, may God show His mercy to thee whose hand hath such evil wrought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herzeleide the queen, thy mother, thou too to her death hast brought—'<span class="linenum">750</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay! Nay! not so, holy father! What sayest thou?' quoth Parzival,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Of what dost thou here accuse me? Were I king o'er the wondrous Grail<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not all Its countless riches would repay me if this be sooth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">These words that thy lips have spoken! And yet if I, in very truth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be son unto thy sister, then show that thou mean'st me well,       <span class="linenum">755</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And say, without fear or falsehood, are these things true that thou dost tell?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the hermit he spake in answer, 'Ne'er learnt I to deceive,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy mother she died of sorrow in the day thou her side didst leave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such rewarding her love won for her! <i>Thou</i> wast the beast that hung<br></span>
<span class="i0">On her breast, the wingèd dragon that forth from her body sprung,  <span class="linenum">760</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That spread its wings and left her: in a dream was it all foretold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere yet the sorrowing mother the babe to her breast did hold!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And two other sisters had I, Schoisianè she was one;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She bare a child—Woe is me, her death thro' this birth she won!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Duke Kiot of Katelangen was her husband, and since that day        <span class="linenum">765</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All wordly joy and honour he putteth from him away.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Siguné, their little daughter, was left to thy mother's care:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sorrow for Schoisianè in my heart do I ever bear!<br></span>
<span class="i0">So true was her heart and faithful, an ark 'gainst the flood of sin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A maiden, my other sister, her pure life doth honour win,          <span class="linenum">770</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the Grail she ever tendeth—Repanse de Schoie, her name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' none from Its place may move It whose heart showeth taint of shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In <i>her</i> hands is It light as a feather—And brother unto us twain<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is Anfortas, by right of heirship he king o'er the Grail doth reign;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he knoweth not joy, but sorrow, yet one hope I ween is his,    <span class="linenum">775</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That his pain shall at last be turnèd to delight and to endless bliss.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_275">[Pg 275]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And wondrous the tale of his sorrow, as, nephew, I'll tell to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And if true be thine heart and faithful his grief shall thy sorrow be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'When he died, Frimutel, our father, they chose them his eldest son<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Lord of the Grail and Its knighthood, thus Anfortas his kingdom won,<span class="linenum">780</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And of riches and crown was he worthy, and we were but children still—<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he came to the years of manhood, when love joyeth to work her will<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the heart, and his lips were fringèd with the down of early youth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Frau Minne laid stress upon him who for torment hath little ruth.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if love the Grail King seeketh other than he find writ,        <span class="linenum">785</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis a sin, and in sorrow and sighing full sore shall he pay for it!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And my lord and brother chose him a lady for service fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Noble and true he deemed her, I say not what name she bare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Well he fought in that lady's honour, and cowardice from him fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his hand many a shield-rim shattered, by love's fire was he venture led.<span class="linenum">790</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So high stood his fame that no hero in knightly lands afar<br></span>
<span class="i0">Could he brook to be thought his equal, so mighty his deeds of war,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his battle-cry was "Amor," yet it seemeth unto me<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not all too well such cry suiteth with a life of humility.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'One day as the king rode lonely, in search of some venture high   <span class="linenum">795</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">(Sore trouble it brought upon us,) with love's payment for victory,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For love's burden lay heavy on him, in a joust was he wounded sore<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a poisoned spear, so that healing may be wrought on him nevermore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thine uncle, the King Anfortas, he was smitten thro' the thigh<br></span>
<span class="i0">By a heathen who with him battled, for he jousted right skilfully. <span class="linenum">800</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He came from the land of Ethnisé, where forth from fair Paradise<br></span>
<span class="i0">Flow the streams of the River Tigris, and he thought him, that heathen wise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He should win the Grail, and should hold It—On his spear had he graven his name,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From afar sought he deeds of knighthood, over sea and land he came.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fame of the Grail drew him thither, and evil for us his strife,<span class="linenum">805</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His hand joy hath driven from us and clouded with grief our life!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'But thine uncle had battled bravely and men praised his name that day—<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the spear-shaft yet fast in his body he wended his homeward way.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_276">[Pg 276]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And weeping arose and wailing as he came once again to his own,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dead on the field lay his foeman, nor did we for his death make moan!'<span class="linenum">810</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'When the king came, all pale and bloodless, and feeble of strength and limb,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then a leech stretched his hand to the spear-wound, and the iron he found fast within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the hilt, wrought of reed, and hollow, and the twain from the wound he drew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I fell on my knees, and I vowed me to God, with a heart so true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That henceforward the pride of knighthood, and its fame, would I know no more,<span class="linenum">815</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If but God would behold my brother and would succour his need so sore.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then flesh, wine, and bread I forswore there, and all food that by blood might live,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That lust might no longer move me my life I to God would give,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I tell thee, O son of my sister, that the wailing arose anew<br></span>
<span class="i0">When my weapons I put from off me and ungirded my sword so true,   <span class="linenum">820</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they spake, 'Who shall guard our mysteries? who shall watch o'er the wondrous Grail?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tears fell from the eyes of the maidens, but their weeping might naught avail!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'To the Grail, then, they bare Anfortas, if Its virtue might bring relief;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, alas! when his eyes beheld It yet heavier waxed his grief<br></span>
<span class="i0">As the life sprang afresh within him, and he knew that he might not die;<span class="linenum">825</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he liveth, while here I hide me in this life of humility,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the power of the Grail, and Its glory, with their monarch have waxen weak.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the venom, his wound that poisoned, tho' the leeches their books did seek<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet found they nor help nor healing—Yea, all that their skill might learn<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst the poison of Aspis, Elkontius, of Liseis, and Ecidemon,   <span class="linenum">830</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All spells 'gainst the worm empoisoned, 'gainst Jecis or Meàtris;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or all that a wise man knoweth of roots or of herbs; I wis<br></span>
<span class="i0">Naught was there in all might help him; nor rede I a longer tale<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since <i>God</i> willeth not his healing what man's skill may aught avail?'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Then we sent to the mystic waters, in a far-off land they rise,   <span class="linenum">835</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Pison, Gihon, Tigris, Euphrates, the rivers of Paradise,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_277">[Pg 277]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And so near they flow that the perfumes which breathe from its scented air<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall yet to their streams be wafted—If their waters perchance might bear<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some plant from the wondrous garden that might succour us in our woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But vain thought, and fruitless labour, fresh sorrow our heart did know!'<span class="linenum">840</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nor here did we end our labour, for again for the bough we sought<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which the Sibyl unto Æneas as a shield 'gainst Hell's dangers brought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Gainst the smoke and the fire of Phlegethon, and the rivers that flow in Hell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would it guard, and for long we sought it, for we thought, if such chance befell<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the spear in Hell-fire was welded, and the poison from Hell did spring<span class="linenum">845</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That thus of our joy had robbed us, then this bough might salvation bring!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'But Hell, it knew naught of the poison! There liveth a wondrous bird<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who loveth too well her fledglings—Of the Pelican's love we heard,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How she teareth her breast and feedeth her young with the quickening food<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of her own life-blood, and then dieth—So we took of that bird the blood,<span class="linenum">850</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since we thought that her love might help us, and we laid it upon the sore<br></span>
<span class="i0">As best we could—Yet, I wot well, no virtue for us it bore!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'A strange beast, the Unicorn, liveth, and it doth in such honour keep<br></span>
<span class="i0">The heart of a spotless maiden that it oft at her knee will sleep.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the heart of that beast we took us, and we took us the red-fire stone<span class="linenum">855</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That lies 'neath its horn, if the king's wound might its healing virtue own.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And we laid on the wound the carbuncle, and we put it the wound within,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet still was the sore empoisoned nor aid from the stone might win!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And sore with the king we sorrowed—Then a magic herb we found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Men say, from the blood of a dragon it springeth from out the ground,)<span class="linenum">860</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With the stars, and the wind, and the heaven, close-bound, doth it win its power,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest perchance, by the flight of the dragon, when the stars bring the circling hour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the moon draweth near to her changing, (for sorer then grows the pain,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">The herb might our grief have aided—Yet its magic we sought in vain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Then the knights of the Grail knelt lowly, and for help to the Grail they prayed,<span class="linenum">865</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, behold! the mystic writing, and a promise it brought of aid,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_278">[Pg 278]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For a knight should come to the castle, and so soon as he asked the king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of the woe that so sorely pained him his question should healing bring.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But let them beware, man or maiden, or child, should they warn the knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of his task, he no healing bringeth, greater waxeth the sorrow's might.<span class="linenum">870</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the writing it ran, 'Ye shall mark this, forewarning shall bring but ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in the first night of his coming must the healer his task fulfil,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or the question shall lose its virtue; but if at the chosen hour<br></span>
<span class="i0">He shall speak, <i>his</i> shall be the kingdom, and the evil hath lost its power.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So the hand of the Highest sendeth to Anfortas the end of woe,     <span class="linenum">875</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet <i>King</i> shall he be no longer tho' healing and bliss he know.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thus we read in the Grail that our sorrow should come to an end that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">That the knight should come who the meaning of the grief that he saw should pray—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then salve of Nard we took us, and Teriak, and the wound we dressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And we burnt wood of Lignum Aloe for so might the king find rest.  <span class="linenum">880</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ever he suffereth sorely—Then fled I unto this place,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my life little gladness knoweth till my brother hath gotten grace.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the knight, he hath come, and hath left us, and ill for us all that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(But now did I speak of his coming,) sorrow-laden he rode away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he saw his host's woe and asked not, 'What aileth thee here, mine host?'<span class="linenum">885</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since his folly such words forbade him great bliss shall he there have lost!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then awhile did they mourn together till the mid-day hour drew near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host spake, 'We must be seeking for food, and thine horse, I fear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As yet shall be lacking fodder; nor know I how we shall feed<br></span>
<span class="i0">If not God in His goodness show us the herbs that shall serve our need,<span class="linenum">890</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My kitchen but seldom smoketh! Forgive thou the lack to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And abide here, so long as shall please thee, if thy journey shall brook delay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of plants and of herbs would I teach thee much lore, if so be the grass<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were not hidden by snow—God grant us that this cold may be soon o'erpast—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now break we yew-boughs for thy charger, far better its fare hath been<span class="linenum">895</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Erewhile 'neath the roof of Monsalväsch than shall here be its lot I ween!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet never a host shall ye meet with who rider alike and steed<br></span>
<span class="i0">Would as gladly bid share of his substance as I, had I all ye need!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the twain they went forth on their errand—Parzival for his steed had care,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_279">[Pg 279]</a></span>
<span class="i0">While the hermit for roots was seeking since no better might be their fare;<span class="linenum">900</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host his rule forgat not, he ate naught, whate'er he found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the ninth hour, but ever hung them, as he drew them from out the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the nearest shrub, and there left them; many days he but ill might fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">For God's honour, since oft he lost them, the shrubs which his roots did bear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor grudged they aught of their labour: then they knelt by the streamlet's flow,<span class="linenum">905</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the roots and the herbs they washed there, and no laughter their lips might know.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then their hands they washed, and the yew-boughs Parzival together bound<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bare them unto his charger ere the cavern again he found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the twain by the fireside sat them, nor further might food be brought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor on roast nor on boiled they fed them, nor found in their kitchen aught.<span class="linenum">910</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet so true was the love and the honour Parzival to the hermit bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he deemed he enough had eaten, and no better had been his fare<br></span>
<span class="i0">With Gurnemanz of Graharz, or e'en in Monsalväsch hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the maidens passed fair before him and the Grail fed them each and all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his kindly host quoth, 'Nephew, despise not this food, for know<span class="linenum">915</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Lightly thou shalt not find one who shall favour and kindness show,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of true heart, without fear of evil, as fain would I show to thee.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Parzival quoth, 'May God's favour henceforward ne'er light on me<br></span>
<span class="i0">If food ever better pleased me, or I ate with a better will<br></span>
<span class="i0">What a host ever set before me, such fare doth content me still.'  <span class="linenum">920</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Their hands they need not wash them for such food as before them lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas no fish, that their eyes had harmèd as men oft are wont to say.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And were I or hawk or falcon I had lent me to the chase,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor stooped to the lure unwilling, nor fled from my master's face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But an they no better fed me than at noontide they fed, these twain,<span class="linenum">925</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I had spread my wings right swiftly, nor come to their call again!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why mock at this folk so faithful? 'Twas ever my way of old—<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_280">[Pg 280]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ye know why, forsaking riches, they chose to them want and cold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lack of all things joyful, such sorrow and grief of heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">They bare of true heart, God-fearing, nor had they in falsehood part;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus from the hand of the Highest they won payment for grief and woe,<span class="linenum">930</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And alike should the twain God's favour, as of old, so hereafter know.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then up stood they again, and they gat them, Parzival and the holy man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the steed in its rocky stable, and full sadly the host began<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he spake to the noble charger, 'Woe is me for thy scanty fare,  <span class="linenum">935</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the sake of the saddle upon thee and the token I see thee bear!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When their care for the horse was ended, then sorrow sprang forth anew,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Host and uncle, my folly I needs must rue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain would I tell the story if for shame I the word may speak;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forgive me, I pray, of thy kindness, since in thee do I comfort seek,<span class="linenum">940</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For sorely, I ween, have I sinnèd; if thou canst no comfort find<br></span>
<span class="i0">No peace may be mine, but for ever the chains of remorse shall bind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of true heart shalt thou mourn my folly—He who to Monsalväsch rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He who saw Anfortas' sorrow, he who spake not the healing word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas I, child and heir of misfortune, 'twas I, Parzival, alone,   <span class="linenum">945</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ill have I wrought, and I know not how I may for such ill atone!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Spake the hermit, 'Alas! my nephew, thou speakest the words of woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Vanished our joy, and sorrow henceforth must we grasp and know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since folly of bliss betrayed thee: senses five did God give to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And methinks, in the hour of thy testing, their counsel should better be.<span class="linenum">950</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Why guarded they not thine honour, and thy love as a man to men,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the hour that thou satst by Anfortas? Of a truth hadst thou spoken then!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nor would I deny thee counsel; mourn not for thy fault too sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt, in a fitting measure, bewail thee, and grief give o'er.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For strange are the ways, and fitful, of mankind, oft is youth too wise<span class="linenum">955</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And old age turneth back to folly, and darkened are wisdom's eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the fruit of a life lieth forfeit, while green youth doth wax old and fade—<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not in this wise true worth shall be rooted, and payment in praise be paid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thine youth would I see fresh blooming, and thine heart waxing strong and bold,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_281">[Pg 281]</a></span>
<span class="i0">While thou winnest anew thine honour, nor dost homage from God withhold.<span class="linenum">960</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thus might it chance unto thee to win for thyself such fame<br></span>
<span class="i0">As shall make amends for thy sorrow, and God thee, as His knight, shall claim!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thro' my mouth would God teach thee wisdom; now say, didst thou see the spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In that wondrous Burg of Monsalväsch? As ever the time draws near<br></span>
<span class="i0">When Saturn his journey endeth—(that time by the wound we know,   <span class="linenum">965</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet by another token, by the fall of the summer snow)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then sorely the frost doth pain him, thy king and uncle dear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And deep in the wound empoisoned once more do they plunge the spear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">One woe shall help the other, the spear cure the frost's sharp pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And crimson it grows with his life-blood ere men draw it forth again!'<span class="linenum">970</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'When the stars return in their orbit, then the wailing it waxeth sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When they stand in opposition, or each to the other draw.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the moon, in its waxing and waning, it causeth him bitter pain—<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the time that I erst have told thee then the king little rest may gain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His flesh thro' the frost it groweth colder than e'en the snow,    <span class="linenum">975</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But men know that the spear sharp-pointed doth with fiery venom glow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And upon the wound they lay it, and the frost from his flesh so cold<br></span>
<span class="i0">It draweth, and lo! as crystals of glass to the spear doth hold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as ice to the iron it clingeth, and none looseth it from the blade.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Trebuchet the smith bethought him, in his wisdom two knives he made,<span class="linenum">980</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of silver fair he wrought them, and sharp was the edge and keen—<br></span>
<span class="i0">(A spell on the king's sword written had taught him such skill I ween,)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' no flame on earth can kindle Asbestos, as men do tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And never a fire may harm it, if these crystals upon it fell<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the flame would leap and kindle and burn with a fiery glow    <span class="linenum">985</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till th' Asbestos lay in ashes, such power doth this poison know!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'The king, he rideth never, nor yet may he walk, or lie,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he sitteth not, but, reclining, in tears his sad days pass by.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the moon's changes work him evil—To a lake they call Brimbane<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_282">[Pg 282]</a></span>
<span class="i0">They bear him full oft for fishing that the breezes may soothe his pain.<span class="linenum">990</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This he calleth his day for hunting, tho' what booty shall be his share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he vex himself to gain it, for his host 'twould be meagre fare!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And from this there sprang the story that he should but a Fisher be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho little he recked the fable, no merchant I ween was he<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of salmon or aye of lamprey, he had chosen far other game          <span class="linenum">995</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Were he freed from the load of sorrow and the burden of bitter pain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'So I found him; the king's skiff at anchor lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for pastime, e'en as a fisher, the even he wore away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a mile had I ridden that day, since from Pelrapär<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the sun stood high in the heaven, at noontide I forth must fare;<span class="linenum">1000</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And at even I much bethought me where my shelter that night might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then my uncle did fair entreat me, and my host for a space was he.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'A perilous way didst thou ride there,' spake the host, 'one that well they guard<br></span>
<span class="i0">Those Templars, nor strength nor cunning brings a traveller thro' their ward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For danger full oft besets him, and oft he his life shall lose,   <span class="linenum">1005</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Life against life is their penance, all quarter these knights refuse.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Yet scatheless I passed that woodland in the day that I found the king<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the lake,' quoth the knight, 'and at even his palace with grief did ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sure, as they mourned, I think me, no folk ever mourned before!<br></span>
<span class="i0">In the hall rose the voice of wailing as a squire sprang within the door,<span class="linenum">1010</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a spear in his hand he carried, and to each of the walls he stept,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Red with blood was the spear, as they saw it, the people they mourned and wept.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then answered the host, 'Far sorer than before was the monarch's pain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In this wise did he learn the tidings that Saturn drew near again,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the star with a sharp frost cometh, and it helpeth no whit to lay<span class="linenum">1015</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The spear on the sore as aforetime, in the wound must it plunge alway!<br></span>
<span class="i0">When that star standeth high in heaven the wound shall its coming know<br></span>
<span class="i0">Afore, tho' the earth shall heed not, nor token of frost shall show.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But the cold it came, and the snow-flakes fell thick in the following night<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' the season was spring, and the winter was vanquished by summer's might.<span class="linenum">1020</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As the frost to the king brought sorrow and pain, so his people true<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_283">[Pg 283]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Were of joy bereft, as the moment of his anguish thus nearer drew.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Trevrezent quoth, 'In sorrow that folk hath both lot and part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the spear thro' the king's wound pierceth, it pierceth each faithful heart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And their love to their lord, and their sorrow, such tears from their eyelids drew<span class="linenum">1025</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That, methinks, in those bitter waters had they been baptized anew.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Spake Parzival unto the hermit, 'Five-and-twenty they were, the maids<br></span>
<span class="i0">I saw stand before the monarch, and courteous their part they played.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the host spake, 'By God's high counsel such maidens alone avail<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the care of this wondrous mystery, and do service before the Grail.<span class="linenum">1030</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail, It chooseth strictly, and Its knights must be chaste and pure,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">When the star standeth high in the heaven then grief must that folk endure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the young they mourn as the aged, and God's wrath it lasts for aýe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ne'er to their supplication doth He hearken and answer "Yea."'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And, nephew, this thing would I tell thee, and my word shalt thou well believe,<span class="linenum">1035</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They who to the Grail do service, they take, and again they give.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For they take to them tittle children, noble of birth and race—<br></span>
<span class="i0">If a land be without a ruler, and its people shall seek God's Face<br></span>
<span class="i0">And crave of His Hand a monarch, then He hearkeneth to their prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a knight, from the Grail host chosen, as king to that land doth fare.<span class="linenum">1040</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And well shall he rule that people, and happy shall be that land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the blessing of God goeth with him and God's wisdom doth guide his hand.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'God sendeth the <i>men</i> in secret, but the <i>maidens</i> in light of day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Are given unto their husbands; thus none spake to his wooing, Nay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When King Kastis wooed Herzeleide, but joyful our sister gave,    <span class="linenum">1045</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet ne'er might her love rejoice him for Death dug at his feet a grave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But in life had he given thy mother both Norgals and fair Waleis,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Those kingdoms twain and their cities, Kingrivals and Kanvoleis.<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas a fair gift, and known of all men—Then they rode on their homeward way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Death met them upon their journey, and he made of the king his prey,<span class="linenum">1050</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_284">[Pg 284]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And over both Waleis and Norgals Herzeleide, as queen, did reign,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till Gamuret's right hand valiant won the maid, and her kingdoms twain.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Thus the Grail Its maidens giveth, in the day, and the sight of men,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But It sendeth Its knights in the silence and their children It claims again,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the host of the Grail are they counted, Grail servants they all shall be,<span class="linenum">1055</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So the will of God standeth written on the Grail for all men to see.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'He who would to the Grail do service, he shall women's love forswear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A wife shall none have save the Grail king, and his wife a pure heart must bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And those others whom God's Hand sendeth, as king, to a kingless land—<br></span>
<span class="i0">But little I recked such counsel, to love's service I vowed my hand,<span class="linenum">1060</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As the pride of my youth constrained me, and the beauty of woman's eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I rode full oft in her service, and I battled for knighthood's prize.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fain was I for wild adventure, on jousting no more I thought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So fair shone the love-light on me ever fiercer the strife I sought.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' far-off lands and distant, in the service of love I fared,<span class="linenum">1065</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to win sweet love's rewarding right valiant the deeds I dared.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If heathen my foe or Christian, what mattered it unto me?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fiercer the strife that beset me, the fairer my prize should be!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'And thus, for the love of woman, in three parts of the earth I fought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Europe, and far-off Asia, and in Afric' I honour sought.       <span class="linenum">1070</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If for gallant jousting I lusted I fought before Gaurivon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the mystic Mount of Fay-Morgan I many a joust have run.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I fought by the Mount Agremontin, where are fiery men and fierce,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the other side they burn not tho' their spears thro' the shield can pierce.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Rohas I sought for ventures, and Slavs were my foemen then,    <span class="linenum">1075</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With lances they came against me and I trow they were gallant men!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'From Seville I took my journey, and I sailed o'er the tideless sea<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto Sicily, since thro' Friant and Aquilea should my journey be.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! alas! woe is me, for I met with thy father there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I found him, and looked upon him, ere I from Seville must fare.   <span class="linenum">1080</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For e'en as I came to the city he there for a space abode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my heart shall be sore for his journey, since thence to Bagdad he rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there, as thyself hast spoken, in a knightly joust he fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for ever my heart must mourn him, and my tongue of his praises tell!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'A rich man shall be my brother, nor silver nor gold would spare  <span class="linenum">1085</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_285">[Pg 285]</a></span>
<span class="i0">When in secret I forth from Monsalväsch at his will and his word did fare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I took me his royal signet, and to Karkobra I came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where Plimizöl to the wide sea floweth, and the land, Barbigöl, they name.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Burg-grave he knew the token, ere I rode from the town again<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of horses and squires, as failed me, he raised me a gallant train,<span class="linenum">1090</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And we rode thence to wild adventures, and to many a knightly deed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For nothing had he begrudged me of aught that might serve my need.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alone came I unto the city, and there at my journey's end<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did I leave those who had fared thence with me, and alone to Monsalväsch wend.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Now hearken to me, my nephew, when thy father first saw my face  <span class="linenum">1095</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of old in Seville's fair city, there did he such likeness trace<br></span>
<span class="i0">To his wife, fair Herzeleide, that he would me as brother claim,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' never before had he seen me, and secret I held my name.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth was I fair to look on, as ever a man might be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And my face by no beard was hidden; and sweetly he spake to me,   <span class="linenum">1100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When he sought me within my dwelling—Yet many an oath I swore<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a word of denial, yet ever he pressed me more<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till in secret at last I told him, his kinsman was I in truth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And greatly did he rejoice him when he knew that his words were sooth!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'A jewel he gave unto me, and I gave to him at his will;          <span class="linenum">1105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou sawest my shrine, green shall grass be, yet that shineth greener still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twas wrought from the stone he gave me—and a better gift he gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For his nephew as squire he left me, Prince Ither, the true and brave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">His heart such lore had taught him that falsehood his face did flee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The King of Cumberland was he, who, thou sayest, was slain by thee.<span class="linenum">1110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then no longer might we delay us, but we parted, alas! for aye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He rode to the land of Baruch, unto Rohas I took my way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'In Celli three weeks I battled, and I deemed 'twas enough for fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Rohas I took my journey and unto Gandein I came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">('Twas that town from which first thy grandsire, his name of Gandein did take,)<span class="linenum">1115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a deed did Ither, and men of his prowess spake.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the town lieth near the river, where Graien and Drave they meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the waters I ween are golden,—there Ither found guerdon sweet,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_286">[Pg 286]</a></span>
<span class="i0">For thine aunt, Lamire, she loved him, she was queen of that fair land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gandein of Anjou, her father, he gave it unto her hand.           <span class="linenum">1120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lamire was her name, but her country shall be Styria to this day—<br></span>
<span class="i0">And many a land must he traverse who seeketh for knightly fray.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'It grieveth me sore for my red squire, men honoured me for his sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Ither was thy near kinsman tho' of <i>that</i> thou small heed didst take!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet God <i>He</i> hath not forgotten, and thy deed shall He count for sin,<span class="linenum">1125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I wot thou shalt first do penance ere thou to His peace shalt win.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, weeping, this truth I tell thee, two mortal sins shall lie<br></span>
<span class="i0">On thine heart, thou hast slain thy kinsman, and thy mother, thro' thee, must die.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in sooth shalt thou sore bewail her; in the day thou didst leave her side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So great was her love, and faithful, that for grief at thy loss she died.<span class="linenum">1130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now do thou as here I rede thee, repent thee and pay sin's cost,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thy conflict on earth well ended thy soul be not ever lost.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then the host he quoth full kindly, 'Nephew, now say the word,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whence hast thou yon gallant charger? Not yet I the tale have heard!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'In a joust, Sir Host, did I win it, when I rode from Siguné's cell<span class="linenum">1135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In a gallop I smote the rider and he from the saddle fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the steed was mine, I rode hence,—from Monsalväsch he came, the knight.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth the host, 'Is the man yet living who thus with thee did fight?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Yea, I saw him fly before me, and beside me stood his steed.'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, if thou in such wise dost bear thee thou art scant of wit indeed!<span class="linenum">1140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Grail-knights dost thou rob, and thinkest their friendship thereby to win?'<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Nay, my uncle, in strife I won it, and he who shall count it sin<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let him ask how the thing hath chanced thus, 'twas a fair fight we fought, we twain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor was it for naught that I took it, for first had my steed been slain!'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival, 'Who was the maiden who the Grail in her hands did bear,<span class="linenum">1145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her mantle, that eve, she lent me?'—Quoth the hermit, 'That lady fair<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is thine aunt, if her robe she lent thee of the loan shalt thou not be vain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For surely she deemed that hereafter thou shouldst there as monarch reign.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the Grail, and herself, yea and I too, should honour thee as our lord:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_287">[Pg 287]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And a gift didst thou take from thine uncle, for he gave thee, I ween, a sword,<span class="linenum">1150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And sin hast thou won in the wearing, since thy lips, which to speak are fain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There spake not the mystic question which had loosened his sorrow's chain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that sin shalt thou count to the other, for 'tis time that we lay us down.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor couches nor cushions had they, but they laid them upon the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for bedding the rushes served them—too humble, I ween, such bed<span class="linenum">1155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For men of a race so noble, yet they deemed they were not ill-sped.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then twice seven days he abode there, with the hermit his lot did share,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the herb of the ground was his portion—yet he sought not for better fare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Right gladly he bare such hardness that should bring to him food so sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as priest did his host absolve him, and as knight gave him counsel meet!<span class="linenum">1160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth Parzival to the hermit, 'Say who shall he be, who lay<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before the Grail? grey was he, yet his face it was as the day!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Spake the host, 'Titurel thou sawest, and he shall grandsire be<br></span>
<span class="i0">To thy mother, first king and ruler of the Grail and Its knights was he.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But a sickness hath fallen on him, and he lieth, nor findeth cure,<span class="linenum">1165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet his face on the Grail yet looketh, by Its power shall his life endure!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor his countenance changeth colour, and his counsel shall aye be wise—<br></span>
<span class="i0">In his youth he rode far and jousted, and won to him valour's prize.'<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'An thou wouldst that thy life be adornèd with true worth as thy crown of fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then ne'er mayst thou hate a woman, but shall honour, as knight, her name,<span class="linenum">1170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For women and priests, thou knowest, unarmèd shall be their hand,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet the blessing of God watcheth o'er them, and as shield round the priest doth stand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the priest, he careth for thee, that thine end may be free from ill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So treat thou no priest as a foeman, but serve him with right good will.<br></span>
<span class="i0">For naught on the earth thou seest that is like to his office high,<span class="linenum">1175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he speaketh that word unto us which our peace and our life did buy;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_288">[Pg 288]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And his hand hath been blest for the holding of the pledge on the altar laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To assure us of sin's forgiveness, and the price for our pardon paid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a priest who from sin doth guard him, and who to his Lord shall give<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pure heart and pure hand for His service, say, what man shall holier live?'<span class="linenum">1180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now this day was their day of parting—Trevrezent to our hero spake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Leave thou here thy sins behind thee, God shall me for thy surety take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And do thou as I have shown thee, be steadfast and true of heart!'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Think ye with what grief and sorrow the twain did asunder part.<br></span>
</div></div>

<hr class="chap">
<h2>APPENDICES</h2>
<h3>APPENDIX A<br>

THE ANGEVIN ALLUSIONS OF THE 'PARZIVAL'</h3>
<p>One of the most striking peculiarities of this version of the Perceval legend consists
in the fact that the writer closely connects his hero with a contemporary princely
house, and exercises considerable ingenuity in constructing a genealogy which shall
establish a relationship alike with the legendary British race of Pendragon, and with
the hereditary House of Anjou. Now, that Parzival should be represented as connected
with Arthur is not surprising, taking into consideration the great popularity of
the Arthurian legends; the English 'Sir Percyvelle' makes the relationship even
closer; there, Percyvelle is Arthur's nephew, his sister's son; but it is far more difficult
to account for the Angevin connection. It has been suggested that the writer of
Wolfram's French source was Walter Mapes, to whom another of the Grail romances
the <i>Queste</i> is generally ascribed; and who, as is well known, was closely attached
to the Court of Henry Fitz-Empress, Count of Anjou, and King of England. Setting
on one side the great difference, in style and treatment, between the <i>Parzival</i> and
the <i>Queste</i>, which render it impossible to believe that the same man could have
treated the same legend from two such practically opposite points of view, a close
examination of the Angevin allusions found in the <i>Parzival</i> reveals a correspondence
between the characters and incidents of the poem, and the facts, real and traditional,
of Angevin history, which seems to point to a familiarity with the subject scarcely
likely to be possessed by a foreigner.</p>
<p>The following parallels will show that this Angevin element, though strongest in the
first two books (those peculiar to Wolfram's version), is to be clearly traced even in
the presentment of what we know to be traditional features of the story.</p>
<div class="pagenum"><a id="Page_292">[Pg 292]</a><a id="Page_293">[Pg 293]</a><a id="Page_294">[Pg 294]</a></div>
<h3>THE ORIGIN OF THE HOUSE OF ANJOU</h3>
<table style="border-spacing: 0px;padding: 4px;border-width: 0px;" data-summary="THE ORIGIN OF THE HOUSE OF ANJOU">
<colgroup><col span="2" style="width: 50%;">
</colgroup><tbody><tr>
<th><span class="smcap">Wolfram</span></th>
<th><span class="smcap">Angevin Tradition</span></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>In Book I. the origin of the Angevin family is traced to the marriage of Mazadan with the fairy Terre-de-la-schoie. The fairy origin of the race is referred to again in Books <span class="smcap">II.</span> and <span class="smcap">VIII.</span>, the later allusion being in connection with Vergulacht, son of Gamuret's sister, and cousin to hero.</td>
<td>Ascribes their origin to the marriage of one of the early Counts with a lady of surpassing beauty, whose <i>demon</i> origin was discovered by her inability to remain in church during Mass. It was to the influence of this ancestress that the uncontrollable temper of the Angevin princes was ascribed. Richard Cur-de-lion is reported to have frequently said, 'We came from the Devil, and we go back to the Devil.' (In each instance it will be noted that the supernatural element is introduced by the wife.)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th><span class="smcap">Gamuret</span></th>
<th><span class="smcap">Fulk V. OF Anjou</span></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Younger son of the King of Anjou; brought up at the court of French queen; goes to the East where he marries a Moorish queen, and becomes king of an Eastern kingdom.</td>
<td>Son of Fulk <span class="smcap">IV.</span> (<i>Rechin</i>), and Bertalda de Montfort. His mother eloped with, and married, Philip, king of France. She remained on good terms with her former husband, and, Fulk, having already an heir by a previous wife, was allowed to bring up her son at her own court. The elder brother dying, Fulk became his father's heir, and finally succeeded him. In 1129, after the marriage of his son, Geoffrey, with the Empress Maud, Fulk was invited by Baldwin, king of Jerusalem, to become his son-in-law and successor. Accordingly he resigned Anjou to Geoffrey, went to Jerusalem, where he married Melesinda, daughter and heiress to Baldwin, and, after the death of the latter, succeeded him as king, and reigned till his death in 1142. (Here again we note that, in each instance, the Eastern kingdom is won through the wife.)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Gamuret's first recorded deed of valour is the conquest, in single combat, of Heuteger, the Scotchman, who appears every morning before the gates of Patelamunt, to challenge the besieged knights.</td>
<td>A similar incident is recorded of Geoffrey <span class="smcap">I.</span> (<i>Grisegonelle</i>) who, during the siege of Paris by the Danes in 978, overthrew a gigantic Northman named Ethelwulf, who daily challenged the besieged in the manner recounted in the poem. Later historians cast doubts on the truth of this story, but it appears in all the old chronicles, and was undoubtedly firmly believed in by the writers of the twelfth century.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th><span class="smcap">Herzeleide</span></th>
<th><span class="smcap">The Empress Maude</span></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Widow, queen of two kingdoms, and marries Prince of Anjou.</td>
<td>Widow, Empress, Lady of two Lands, England and Normandy, marries Count of Anjou.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Her son is subsequently deprived of these kingdoms by the action of <i>one knight</i>, Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 73, two <i>brothers</i>, <i>Ibid.</i> p. 80. This loss of two kingdoms by the action of Lähelein is insisted on throughout the poem, and the reader should note the manner in which Lähelein, though only appearing in the Second Book, is constantly referred to; which seems to indicate that the writer attached a special importance to this character, cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> pp. 86 and 87; <span class="smcap">V.</span> pp. 150, 154; <span class="smcap">VI.</span> pp. 171, 188; <span class="smcap">VII.</span> p. 196; <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 272. (It may be noted that in no other version of the legend is a previous marriage of the hero's mother recorded.)</td>
<td>Her son is deprived of these two kingdoms by the action of two brothers Theobald and Stephen of Blois. Though Stephen was the principal aggressor, it must not be forgotten that Theobald, the elder brother, was invited by the Normans to become their Duke on the death of Henry <span class="smcap">I.</span>; but on arriving in Normandy, and finding that Stephen had already seized the crown of England, Theobald resigned his claim to the Duchy and threw in his lot with that of Stephen. An <i>English</i> writer (such as Mapes) would probably have overlooked the part played by Theobald. An <i>Angevin</i>, knowing the Counts of Blois to be the hereditary foes of the House of Anjou, would hardly fail to record the fact that both brothers were concerned in the usurpation of the rights of Henry Fitz-Empress.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th><span class="smcap">The Red Knight</span></th>
<th><span class="smcap">The Red Knight</span></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2">The Red Knight as represented in the poem, mounted before the gates of Nantes, in red armour, with red hair.</td>
<td>This character is of course traditional, but the special presentment of it in the <i>Parzival</i> seems to be owing to Angevin influence. In 1048 William of Normandy, being at war with, Geoffrey <span class="smcap">II.</span> of Anjou and besieging Domfront, sent him the following curious challenge: 'If the Count of Anjou attempts to bring victuals into Domfront he will find me awaiting him without the gates armed and mounted, bearing a red shield, and having a pennon on my spear wherewith to wipe his face.'</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><i>Red hair</i> was a distinguishing characteristic of the Angevin Counts. Fulk <span class="smcap">I.</span> derived his name of Rufus from this peculiarity, which was inherited by many of his descendants, among them Fulk <span class="smcap">V.</span>, his son Geoffrey Plantagenet, and his grandson Henry Fitz-Empress. The writer of the <i>Parzival</i> strongly insists on Ither's red hair.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th><span class="smcap">Nantes</span></th>
<th><span class="smcap">Nantes</span></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Nantes, throughout the poem, is always treated as Arthur's chief city. Karidöl is scarcely referred to, the Round Table is kept at Nantes, and in Book <span class="smcap">X.</span> we are told that Arthur's palace was there. This is not the case in other versions of the story.</td>
<td>The possession of the city of Nantes was a constant source of quarrel between the Counts of Anjou and their neighbours of Brittany. Time after time the former claimed the over-lordship of Nantes, which stood just beyond their frontier, and more than once they succeeded in making themselves masters of the coveted territory. To represent Nantes as Arthur's chief city, and Ither as claiming it, would be an alteration of the legend most natural in an Angevin writer.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> relates that Kiot sought for records of the Grail race in the chronicles of Britain, France, and Ireland, and found the history at last in the chronicle of Anjou.</td>
<td>Britain, France, and Ireland were all brought into close connection under Henry Fitz-Empress, Count of Anjou, Duke of Normandy, and King of England, the husband of Eleanor of Provence and Aquitaine, who conquered Ireland in 1172.</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>The peculiar presentment of the Knights of the Grail as Templars (Templeisen),
having their residence in a castle surrounded by a forest, recalls the fact that a close
connection between the Order of Templars and the House of Anjou had existed for
some time previous to the date of this poem, a tax for the benefit of the Order
having been imposed on all his dominions by Fulk <span class="smcap">V.</span> on his return from his first
pilgrimage to Jerusalem in 1120. A community of Knights Templars was founded
by Henry Fitz-Empress fifty years later at Vaubourg, in the forest of Roumare which
became very famous. (The location of Monsalväsch in the Pyrenees hardly seems to
accord with the indications of the poem, which make it only thirty-six hours' ride
from Nantes.)</p>
<p>Finally, the name of the poet claimed by Wolfram as his authority, Kiot=Guiot=Guy,
is distinctly Angevin, the hereditary Angevin princely names being Fulk,
Geoffrey, and Guy.</p>
