<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_296">[Pg 296]</a></span></p></div>
<h3>APPENDIX B<br>

THE PROPER NAMES IN 'PARZIVAL'</h3>
<p>One of the marked peculiarities of Wolfram's poem is the number of proper names
with which it abounds, there being scarcely a character, however insignificant the rôle
assigned, that is left unnamed. In the other versions of the Perceval legend this is
not the case, consequently there are a vast number of names occurring in the <i>Parzival</i>
to which no parallel can be found elsewhere, and which are no unimportant factor in
determining the problem of the source from which Wolfram drew his poem. It
would be impossible in a short Appendix to discuss the question in all its bearings, but
the following classification, based on Herr Bartsch's article on <i>Die Eigen-namen in</i>
<i>Wolfram's Parzival</i>, will give some idea of the wide ground they cover:—</p>
<p>I. Names belonging to the original legend, and met with, with but little variation,
in all versions. To this class belong the names of Pendragon, Arthur, Guinivere,
Perceval, Gawain, Kay, Segramor; and the names of such places as Karidöl=Carduel=Carlisle,
Cumberland, Waleis, Norgals, Dianasdron.</p>
<p>II. Names derived from a French version of the story, which may be divided into
two classes:</p>
<div class="hangindent">
<p>(<i>a</i>) Names of which we find an equivalent in existing French sources, notably
Chrêtien, whose poem offers so close a parallel to the <i>Parzival</i>; examples of
this class are Gurnemanz=French, <i>Gornemant</i>; Peirapär=<i>Beau-repaire</i>;
Klamidé=<i>Clamadex</i>; Kingron=<i>Aguigrenon</i>; Trebuchet; Meljanz de Lys;
Lippaut=<i>Tiebaut</i>; Gramoflanz=<i>Guiromelans</i> or <i>Guiremelanz</i>.</p>
<p>(b) Names formed by a misunderstanding of a French original: such are Soltane,
from forest <i>soutaine</i>=solitary; Orilus de Lalande, from <i>Li orgueillous de la</i>
<i>lande</i>; and similarly, Orgeluse of Logrois, from <i>La orguelleuse de Logres</i>;
Gringuljet, the name of Gawain's horse, from <i>Li gringalet</i>, which is explained
as meaning <i>cheval maigre et alerte</i>. Ligweiz-prelljus, is <i>Li guez perellous</i>, the
Ford Perilous; and a notable instance of this class is the curious name
Schionatulander, which is either '<i>Li joenet de la lande</i>,' 'The youth of the
meadow,' or '<i>Li joenet à l'alant</i>,' 'The youth with the dog,' in allusion to the
cause of the knight's death. Whence Wolfram took this name is unknown.</p></div>
<p>III. Names borrowed or quoted from other romances of the time, of those to
which Wolfram alludes most frequently we know the <i>Erec</i> and <i>Iwein</i> of Hartmann
von Aue; Eilhart's <i>Tristan</i>; Heinrich von Veldeck's <i>Æneid</i>, Chrêtien de Troye's
<i>Cligès</i>, and <i>Le Chevalier de la Charrette</i>; and the <i>Niebelungenlied</i> and <i>Dietrich Sage</i>.
He also refers to other romances which have not come down to us, such are the<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_297">[Pg 297]</a></span>
allusions to adventures connected with Gawain in Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span>; and to the death of
Ilinot, son of King Arthur, of whom we know nothing. (The names derived from
these romances are all noted, and their source given as they occur in the text.) Book
<span class="smcap">I.</span> contains some distinctly German names, such as Eisenhart, Hernant, and Herlindè,
Friedebrand of Scotland and Heuteger, the source of these is doubtful, some occur in
the Gudrun cycle, but it seems probable that in both instances they were derived from
a common source, and, belonging as they do to a North Sea cycle, they may have
reached the poem either through a French or a German medium.</p>
<p>IV. Names of places and people connected with Wolfram himself, such as
Abenberg, Wildberg, Erfurt, the Count of Wertheim, Herman of Thuringia, etc.
These were, of course, introduced by Wolfram, and could not have existed in his
French source.</p>
<p>V. Classical and mythological names such as Antikonie=Antigone, Ekuba,
Secundilla, Plato and the Sibyls, Pythagoras, etc., Jupiter, Juno, Venus, Amor, Cupid,
Lucifer, Ashtaroth, and other of the fallen angels.</p>
<p>VI. Oriental names. In Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> we have the Arabic names of the seven planets,
a curious coincidence, in view of the alleged Arabic source of the Grail-myth as given
in Books <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> and <span class="smcap">IX.</span> Names of cities such as Alexandria, Bagdad, Askalon. This
latter is of course equivalent to <i>Escavalon</i> in the French versions, and the real name is
doubtless Avalon, but it is by no means improbable that the change was made not by
a misunderstanding, but by one who knew the Eastern city, and it falls in with the
various other indications of crusading influence to be traced throughout the poem.
We may add to these the names of Oriental materials such as Pfellel and Sendal.
But when all these have been classified, there still remains a vast number of names
undoubtedly French in origin, yet which cannot be referred to any known source, and
many of which bear distinct traces of Romance or Provençal influence. Such names
are Anfortas, French, <i>enfertez</i>=the sick man, with Prov. ending <i>as</i>; Trevrezent, Prov.
<i>Treu</i>=peace, <i>rezems</i>=redeemed. Schoysiane, Prov. <i>Jauziana</i>, her husband is Kiot
of Katelangen, <i>Guiot</i>=<i>Guy</i> of <i>Catalonia</i>. The son of Gurnemanz, Schenteflur, is
Prov. <i>gente-flors</i>, fair flower. The name of Parzival's wife, Kondwiramur, Bartsch
derives from <i>Coin de voire amour</i>, Ideal of true love; an interpretation which
admirably expresses the union between the two. Itonjè, Gawain's sister, is the French
<i>Idonie</i>, in Chrêtien she is Clarissant. The knight slain by Lähelein at Brimbane is
Libbèals of Prienlaskors, Libbèals being simply the old French <i>Li-beals</i>—<i>le bel</i>, and
probably no more a proper name than Orilus, whilst his country seems derived from
Prov. <i>priendre las cortz</i>, to seek the court. The long lists of conquered kings given in
Book <span class="smcap">XV.</span> contain many names of Greek or Latin origin, which have passed through
a French source, and many others of distinctly Romance form. It is impossible to
suppose that a German poet <i>invented</i> these names, and the only reasonable explanation
seems to be that Wolfram drew largely, if not exclusively, from a French poem
now lost, and that the language in which that poem was written partook strongly of a
Provençal character, the term Provençal being applied, as Bartsch points out, not only
to Provençal proper, but to the varying forms of the Langue-d'oc.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_298">[Pg 298]</a><br><a id="Page_299">[Pg 299]</a></span></p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_300">[Pg 300]</a><br><a id="Page_301">[Pg 301]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2>NOTES</h2>
<p class="ph2">NOTES</p>
<p class="center">(<i>A few Notes signed A. N. are due to Mr. Alfred Nutt.</i>)
</p>
<h3>BOOK I</h3>
<p>Introduction, lines 1-66. This introduction, which is confessedly obscure, both in
style and thought, appears to have been written <i>after</i> the completion of the poem, and to
have been intended by the writer to serve both as a key to the meaning of the poem, and
as a defence of his method of treatment. That Wolfram was blamed by his contemporaries,
notably by Gottfried von Strassbourg, for his lack of a polished style, and
obscurity of thought, we know; and in <i>Willehalm</i> he speaks, in the following words, of the
varying judgment passed upon his <i>Parzival</i>:—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Swaz ich von Parzivâl gesprach,<br></span>
<span class="i0">des sîn aventiur mich wîste,<br></span>
<span class="i0">etzlich man daz prîste:<br></span>
<span class="i0">ir was ouch vil, diez smœthen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Und baz ir rede wæhten.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>and it is evidently to these critics that the first part of the Introduction is addressed.</p>
<p>Lines 1-8 give the key to the whole poem: the contrast between doubt or unsteadfastness,
and steadfast faith and truth, as imaged in the contrast between darkness and light,
black and white. This idea runs throughout the poem, is worked out symbolically in the
character and experiences of the hero, and is shown in a concrete form in the person of his
brother Feirefis. The poet notes that many readers have failed, through lack of intelligence,
to grasp the meaning of this parable, which is too swift and subtle for their comprehension.
A parallel passage will be found in Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> pp. 137, 138, where the figure
employed is different.</p>
<p>The curious lines 15, 16 are explained by Bötticher as allusions to <i>personal</i> assaults
made on the poet, which, by reason of the folly of the assailants, missed their mark, and
are therefore to be treated with contempt.</p>
<p>Lines 29, 30 contain one of the quaint and homely similes which abound throughout
the poem, and refer to the faithless man, <i>valsch geselleclîcher muot</i>, whose honour and
steadfastness are not sufficiently strong to meet the demands made upon them.</p>
<p>There are three distinct divisions of the Introduction: the first, lines 1-30, is addressed
to <i>men</i> only, and draws the contrast between the false and true knight; 31-49 does the
same for <i>women</i>; while from 49 onwards the poet shows how the tale he is about to tell
affects both sexes alike, and gives a slight sketch of the character of the hero. For the
rightful understanding of this the lines 61, 62 are of great importance: 'a brave man, yet
slowly wise Is he whom I hail my hero' (<i>er küene, trâctîche wîs, den helt ich alsus grüene</i>),
and should be borne in mind by the student of the poem.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_302">[Pg 302]</a></span></p>
<p>A full and minute discussion of this discussion of this Introduction will be found in Dr. Bötticher's <i>Das</i>
<i>Hohelied von Rittertum</i>.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_5" class="pginternal">5</a>, line 67—'<i>Now they do to-day as of old-time</i>.' The word employed here <i>wälsch</i>
simply means 'foreign,' but it is evident from the context that France is the country referred
to. The <i>fact</i> was probably in the French source, the remarks upon it due to the German poet.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_5" class="pginternal">5</a>. line 80—'<i>Gamuret</i>.' The origin of this name is doubtful; in Chrêtien we find
a King Ban de Gomeret mentioned, and Wolfram may have derived the name from a
French source, Heinmel suggests that it comes from Gamor, the son of Anguis, a Saracen
prince ruling in Denmark, according to 'Arthur and Merlin;' and that the fact of his
being of the race of Anguis suggested to Kiot the possibility of making him an Angevin.
In the absence of any definite knowledge as to Wolfram's source it is not possible to
do more than <i>suggest</i> possible derivations.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_7" class="pginternal">7</a>, lines 136, 137—'<i>Gylstram and Rankulat</i>.' With regard to the first-named
place, Simrock says it has been identified with 'Gustrate' in the <i>Gudrun</i>, and, according
to Grimm, this latter is to be coupled with Gailate, 'where the sun hath its setting.' <i>i.e.</i> the
West. In Book <span class="smcap">XI.</span> the patriarch of Rankulat is referred to, in company with the Baruch
of Bagdad and the Emperor of Constantinople, and in all probability Armenia is meant.
The king's speech therefore implies, 'Didst thou come from the furthest bounds of the
earth, East or West.'</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_8" class="pginternal">8</a>, line 154—'<i>King Gandein's son</i>.' Cf. Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 285, where the origin of the
name Gandein is given.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_8" class="pginternal">8</a>, lines 159, 160.—'<i>Then the tale it hath told a lie</i>.' Cf. Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 259.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_8" class="pginternal">8</a>, lines 169, 170—'<i>Rich silk of Orient</i>' Eastern materials are referred to frequently
throughout the poem; the principal seem to have been, Samite, Sendal, Achmardi, Pfellel,
Plialt, and Saranthasme. Of these, some were of silk only, others, notably Saranthasme
of silk inwoven with gold, Achmardi, in this poem, is always <i>green</i>. Samite and Sendal
are the two generally named in our English romances.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_9" class="pginternal">9</a>, line 209—'<i>Two brothers of Babylon</i>.' This is Babylon in Egypt, now Cairo,
as is evident from its close connection with Alexandria, cf. p. 12, line 277, and Book <span class="smcap">II.</span>
p. 57, line 684, and p. 59, line 754. Though, from the passage on p. <a href="#Page_57" class="pginternal">57</a>, it seems as if the
poet confused it with Babylon in Assyria; it is possible that he was unaware of the fact
that there were <i>two</i> cities of the name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_15" class="pginternal">15</a>, line 384—'<i>Friedebrand</i>.' The introduction of names of distinctly northern
origin such as Friedebrand, Hernant, and Herlindè, Heuteger, and Eisenhart, has been
already noted in Appendix B as one of the problems of the <i>Parzival</i>. Two solutions
have been suggested, either that they were introduced by Wolfram, or that they reached
the <i>French</i> source through the medium of Normandy. The form in which the names
occur in the <i>Gudrun</i> cycle seems to indicate quotation from a source known also to
the writer of the <i>Parzival</i>, but they are not derived directly from the North Sea saga in
its present form.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_16" class="pginternal">16</a>, line 403—'<i>Wouldst thou know?</i>' <i>etc.</i> It may be interesting to note here that
beyond the <i>colour</i>, which the poet insists on, he apparently recognises no difference
between the heathen and Christian knights and ladies. Both acknowledge the same
chivalrous ideals; both are equally familiar with the eccentricities of 'Minne-dienst' (cf.
line 423); and the speeches put into the mouth of Belakané, or of Rassalig, would be
quite as suitable if spoken by Orgeluse, or by one of King Arthur's knights. This incident
of a Christian knight marrying a Moorish princess is of frequent occurrence in
Mediæval romance.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_16" class="pginternal">16</a>, lines 423, 424—'<i>That which like to a hall doth stand</i>.' The tents of the Mediæval
period were constructed of far more costly fabrics than is usual now, cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 74.<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_303">[Pg 303]</a></span>
and Book <span class="smcap">XI.</span>, and their size was very great, this special tent we find, from Book <span class="smcap">II.</span> p. 36,
was 'thirty pack-steeds' burden.' San Marte quotes the description of a tent captured by
the Crusaders at Antioch which was adorned with walls, towers, and ramparts, contained
halls and galleries, and could lodge as many as 2000 men.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_22" class="pginternal">22</a>, line 620—'<i>The chiming of sweet bells</i>.' Bells were at one time freely used
not only as ornaments to the trappings of the horses but also on the armour of the knights,
cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 70, and Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> p. 163. Gradually they disappeared from use, and the
bells on the Fool's dress are the last trace left of the practice, which from this poem was
evidently very general at the beginning of the thirteenth century.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_23" class="pginternal">23</a>, line 623—'<i>Brave Beaucorps</i>.' This brother of Gawain appears in Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span>
p. 183, he is the only one of Gawain's brothers mentioned in this poem. In Malory, we
find <i>Gareth</i> called 'Beau-mains,' and it is possible that the two are identical. Beaucorps
is evidently much younger than Gawain, and Gareth was the youngest of King Lot's sons.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_24" class="pginternal">24</a>, line 679—'<i>Lahfilirost</i>.' This seems to be a misunderstanding for '<i>Le fils du</i>
<i>Rost</i>,' and may be classed with the misinterpretations of a French source.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_25" class="pginternal">25</a>, line 700—'<i>Frau Minne</i>.' The word <i>Minne</i> is etymologically derivable
from a root 'man,' and is connected with the Latin <i>mens</i>, English 'mind' (cf. 'to have
a mind to.') The original signification was that of tender care, or thought for; in Old
High German it has already taken the meaning of love in its passionate aspects; finally,
in Middle High German (the original language of the <i>Parzival</i>), it has become the standing
expression for love betwixt man and woman. We have it in various forms as a verb,
<i>Minnen</i>; as an adjective, <i>Minniglich</i>. The personification of the passion of Love as
'Frau Minne' is the work of the courtly poets of the twelfth century, and seems rather
to have been derived from classical analogy than to be due to a reminiscence of an early
German goddess of Love. Also, with Wolfram and his contemporaries, 'Frau Minne'
must be regarded less as the personification of Love in the abstract than as the embodiment
of the special love-ideal of the day. This new ideal had its rise, and assumed
definite shape in twelfth century France, from whence it spread throughout the knightly
society of Christendom, finding its fullest literary expression in the Arthurian romances.
The historic causes which led to what was at the time an entirely novel mode of considering
the relations between the sexes, and the true nature and ethical import of the chivalric
conception of that relation will be briefly discussed in an Appendix to vol. II. The
significance of the term is fully apparent from such passages as the present, also cf.
Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> pp. 161, 163, 165, 171; <span class="smcap">VII.</span> 208, 224; <span class="smcap">XII.</span> etc.—[A. N.]</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_27" class="pginternal">27</a>, line 768.—'<i>Morhold</i>,' also in Book <span class="smcap">II.</span> p. 39. This is, of course, the well-known
hero in <i>Tristan</i>. The allusion may have been in the original French source, or
introduced by Wolfram, who would know Morhold from the Tristan of Eilhart von
Oberge, composed before 1180. The most famous German poem on the subject, the Tristan
of Gottfried von Strassbourg, was somewhat later in date.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_31" class="pginternal">31</a>, lines 886, 887—Cf. Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> p. 230 and note.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_31" class="pginternal">31</a>, line 904—'<i>Feirefis</i>.' Bartsch interprets the name as <i>vair fils</i>, 'parti-coloured
son.' Other critics have suggested 'Fairy's son.' The name distinctly indicates a French
origin.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_31" class="pginternal">31</a>, line 905—'<i>A woodland-waster</i>,' 'wald-verschwender,' a hyperbolical term
constantly employed throughout this poem to denote one who shatters many spears in
fight.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_304">[Pg 304]</a></span></p>
<h3>BOOK II</h3>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_35" class="pginternal">35</a>, line 16, and page <a href="#Page_57" class="pginternal">57</a>, line 705—'<i>Waleis and Norgals</i>.' These, the two kingdoms
of Queen Herzeleide, are located by Wolfram in Spain, but they are undoubtedly
Wales and North Wales (the North galis of Malory), the Northern border-land. Parzival's
title throughout the poem is <i>der Waleis</i>, in French versions <i>le Gallois</i>, an evident indication
of the Celtic origin of the story.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_39" class="pginternal">39</a>, lines 117-160. Of the heroes taking part in the Tourney, Uther Pendragon
has been mentioned, in Book <span class="smcap">I.</span> p. 31, in the genealogy of Gamuret. The poet carefully
connects his hero with the traditional royal race of Briton as well as with the princely
House of Anjou. Arthur's mother, Arnivè (not Igraine as in most versions), plays a somewhat
important rôle in the later part of the poem, her imprisonment in the castle of the
Magician Klingsor is fully treated of, cf. from Book <span class="smcap">XI.</span> onwards. King Lot of Norway
(not of Orkney as in the English legend) is frequently alluded to as Gawain's father, but both
he and Uther Pendragon are dead before the real action of the poem commences. This
is the first appearance of Gawain, who, from Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> onward, plays a part in the poem
scarcely inferior to that of the hero, Parzival. The Kings of Arragon and Gascony do not
appear again, nor are they alluded to, but Brandelidelein of Punturtois we meet with in
Book <span class="smcap">XV.</span> as the uncle of King Gramoflanz. The King of Askalon must not be confused
with Vergulacht, in Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span>, this is evidently one of his predecessors. Eidegast of
Logrois is frequently alluded to later on, his murder by Gramoflanz and the desire of his
lady-love, Orgeluse, to avenge him, form the <i>motif</i> of the later Gawain episodes. This is the
only occasion on which Lähelein appears personally in the poem, but he is constantly
alluded to throughout the course of the story (some remarks on the manner in which he is
introduced will be found in Appendix A, p. <a href="#Page_293" class="pginternal">293</a>). Morhold, cf. note to Book <span class="smcap">I.</span> Lambekein,
cf. Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> p. 152. Gurnemanz of Graharz plays an important rôle in the Parzival legend,
he is here introduced for the first time, cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span></p>
<p><i>The Tourney.</i> In this poem we find knightly skill in horsemanship and the use
of arms displayed under three distinct forms: the Buhurd, Books <span class="smcap">XII.</span> and <span class="smcap">XV.</span>, The
Tourney, Book <span class="smcap">II.</span>, and serious Warfare as in the siege of Pelrapär, Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span>, and of
Beaurosch, Book <span class="smcap">VII.</span> The two first were simply intended as displays of knightly skill,
and took their rise in the knightly sports of the ninth century. The Buhurd seems to
have been the original German form, and at first was of a somewhat rough and uncivilised
character, the knights riding in bodies at full gallop against each other, and the
whole being a display of force rather than of skill.</p>
<p>The Tourney, or Tournament, took its rise in France, and here we find the knights, in
full armour, singly displaying their prowess. Gradually the Buhurd changed its character,
and throughout this poem we find Wolfram treating it as a formal display of skill in horsemanship,
generally to do honour to some favoured guest, as in the reception of Gawain
and Orgeluse by the knights of the Château Merveil, Book <span class="smcap">XII.</span>; in honour of Feirefis,
Book <span class="smcap">XV.</span> Still the idea of force was not entirely eliminated, and we find Gawain, in Book
<span class="smcap">VII.</span> when he promises the child Obilot that he will fight for her father, telling her that
<i>she</i> must ride the Buhurd for him, and, as noted above, the fighting here is in earnest.
In the later form of Buhurd the knights wear no armour, and it is thus distinguished
from the Tourney, where they were always fully armed.</p>
<p>The Tourney was much more complicated in its rules, and is not always easy to distinguish
from the real warfare into which it not unfrequently passed. Feirefis, in Book
<span class="smcap">XV.</span>, mentions <i>five</i> modes of attack which seem to have answered to the regular stages of a
Tourney. Niedner explains them as follows: (1) An attack by one troop on another, with<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_305">[Pg 305]</a></span>
lance in rest; (2) An attack from the side, also with lance; (3) The onslaught of <i>one</i> rider
on a troop of horsemen, in which the aim was to strike the one selected opponent while
avoiding the blows of the others; (4) The joust proper, or single combat; (5) The <i>Damenstick</i>,
a stroke for the honour of the knight's chosen lady, which followed on the joust, and
was specially challenged by knights of exceptional valour. In the Tourney at Kanvoleis
(the only Tourney proper in the poem), it is the two first stages in which Gamuret takes no
part, he only mingles in the fray when the time arrives to display the valour of the single
champions. The joust, or single combat, was a feature of earnest, as of mimic, warfare,
and it is not always easy to distinguish between the two.</p>
<p>In each case the great point was the display of skill in horsemanship, and the use of
the lance or spear. The knights rode at full speed towards each other, and the aim of
each was to strike his opponent in the centre of the shield, 'The four nails,' Book <span class="smcap">III.</span>
p. 98, or at the fastening of the helmet, Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 257, and Book <span class="smcap">XII.</span> In either event if
the blow was well aimed, and delivered with sufficient force, the knight was thrown backward
off his steed. It might happen that both knights were struck, and succeeded in keeping
their seat, while their spears were shivered, then a second joust must be ridden. If either
knight were thrown from his saddle, or his steed fell with him, then he was held to be
vanquished, but if, as not unfrequently happened, the girth of the saddle broke, and the
rider were thrown, <i>then</i> the joust was held to be undecided, and, in the case of real warfare,
the issue was fought out with swords on foot. Cf. the combat between Parzival and
Klamidé, Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> pp. 119, 120. In Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> we find Parzival and Orilus fighting with
swords on horseback: this is unusual. In real warfare the knights would fight till one was
slain, or till the issue was indisputably decided by one being felled to the ground. We
occasionally find the combat decided by sheer strength of arm, one knight clasping the
other and throwing him to the ground; so Parzival conquers Orilus, Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> p. 149, and
Gawain, Lischois, Book <span class="smcap">X.</span> Both in Tourney and real warfare the fight was generally
closed by the vanquished giving his pledge or surety to the victor, who not unfrequently
sent him to yield himself prisoner to some favoured lady, so Parzival sends Kingron,
Klamidé, and Orilus to Kunnewaaré. If the vanquished knight refused to yield he
would be slain, but this did not often happen. The death of Ither of Gaheviess is due to
a mischance. Armour and horse were the prize of the victor, though in the case of the foe
being slain it seems to have been thought an unknightly deed to take them, such 'robbery
of the dead' was termed <i>rêroup</i>, and Trevrezent, Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 273, strongly blames both
Lähelein and Parzival for such action.</p>
<p>The Tourney would often be held simply for honour, the prize being something comparatively
trifling, such as a hawk, cf. Tourney at Kanedig, alluded to in Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 77,
and again in Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> p. 155, but occasionally the guerdon was far higher, as at Kanvoleis
where the band and kingdoms of Queen Herzeleide were the prize of the victor. Any
disputes would be referred to a court of judges from whose verdict there was no appeal.
In such Tourneys it was customary not to retain the horse and armour, but to accept a
ransom fixed by the <i>owner</i>. This is evidently alluded to in Book <span class="smcap">II.</span> 45, where we find
these rules disregarded in the heat of conflict.</p>
<p>Opposed to this Tourney 'for honour' was the Tourney 'for booty,' when the aim of the
knights was to capture as many steeds and make as many prisoners as possible, the ransom
being fixed by the <i>captor</i>. Wolfram does not mention such a Tourney, but with the decay
of knighthood such conflicts appear to have almost entirely displaced the nobler strife.
It will be understood, of course, that though a joust or single combat might either be
settled beforehand, as in the case of Kingrimursel's and Gramoflanz' challenge to Gawain,
or be brought about by a chance meeting, as when Vergulacht and the knight of Monsalväsch
fight with Parzival, a Tourney was carefully arranged beforehand, and the knights<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_306">[Pg 306]</a></span>
summoned by invitation. The knights generally assembled on the Saturday, and the
Tourney would be held on the Monday, the interval being employed in careful inquiry as
to the claim of those present to take a part in such knightly sport. The knights were
divided into two bodies of equal strength, headed by the most experienced warriors present,
and single champions would not unfrequently try their skill against each other on the eve
of the Tourney proper. Not unfrequently the passions of the knights were roused to such
a pitch that this <i>Vesper-spiel</i> became a serious encounter, and the combatants were so
exhausted that the Tourney could not be held, as was the case at Kanvoleis. From the
abuses connected with these meetings, which not unfrequently lapsed into serious warfare,
and caused wanton loss of life, they were looked upon with disfavour by the Church,
and in some cases were positively forbidden.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_42" class="pginternal">42</a>, line 236—'<i>Rivalein</i>,' according to Eilhart, the father of Tristan.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_44" class="pginternal">44</a>, line 279—'<i>I have named unto ye a lady</i>.' This is the queen of France, Anflisé,
whose connection with Gamuret is alluded to in Book <span class="smcap">I.</span> p. 9. This episode was probably
suggested by facts in Angevin history, cf. Appendix. A reference to their connection will
be found in Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> p. 233.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_46" class="pginternal">46</a>, lines 351-60. Galoes the king of Anjou has not been named before. The
name occurs in Hartmann's <i>Erec</i>, and may have been borrowed from there. The
name of his lady-love is given in Book <span class="smcap">VII.</span> p. 199. The slayer of Galoes was Orilus,
Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 77.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_48" class="pginternal">48</a>, line 406—'<i>No wife was she but a maiden</i>.' Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 283, where a full
account of Herzeleide's marriage will be found, '<i>Herzeleide</i>.' The modern German
rendering of this name carries with it its own interpretation in the play of words
familiar through Wagner's <i>Parsifal</i>, 'Ihr brach das Leid das Herz und Herzeleide
starb.' But the original form, Herzeloyde, indicates, in Bartsch's opinion, a Southern
French modification, <i>loyde</i> being a variant of <i>hildis</i>, <i>oildis</i>. The name Rischoydè,
we know in its form of Richilda, and Herzeloyde seems to come from the same
root. Professor Rhys (<i>Arthurian Romance</i>, p. 180) has suggested derivation from the
Welsh <i>argelwythes</i> = 'the lady,' but the suggestion has not won general acceptance.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_54" class="pginternal">54</a>, line 614—'<i>The maid and her lands he won</i>.' Readers will doubtless remark
the fact that though we meet with numerous allusions to marriages and marriage festivities
throughout the poem, yet in no single instance is the marriage attended by a religious
ceremony. This is an indication of the original date of the story, which testifies to a very
early stage of social development. The original idea of marriage was that of a contract
made by mutual consent publicly before witnesses, as we find here in the marriages of
Gamuret with Belakané and Herzeleide, or later on in Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span>, the marriage of Parzival
and Kondwiramur. The mutual promise being given and witnessed, the contract was
complete, and the marriage might be consummated at once. The office of the Church
seems at first to have been confined to conferring a benediction on a union already completed,
and therefore we find that, even so late as the thirteenth century, the religious ceremony
followed, and did not precede, the marriage night. San Marte, in his note on the subject,
quotes more than one romance of this date where this is the case, and it was not till the
idea of marriage as a sacrament had displaced that of marriage as a civil contract that the
religious ceremony became essential to a valid union. The fact that Wolfram, with his high
ideas of the binding nature of the marriage-vow, never once mentions the religious ceremony
is a strong argument in favour of the presumption that the subject-matter of the <i>Parzival</i>
is considerably older than his treatment of it. Marriage between a Christian and a
heathen was held to be null and void, and, according to the ideas of the age, Herzeleide
was fully within her rights in claiming Gamuret as her husband and in regarding his
previous marriage as non-existent. The costly presents made by the bridegroom, as for<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_307">[Pg 307]</a></span>
instance the gift of Waleis and Norgals to Herzeleide by her first husband, seem to have
been a survival of the idea that the woman was property, to be bought by the intending
husband. The bride, on her part, gave equally rich gifts, so we find Kondwiramur
bestowing castles and lands on Parzival, and the mutual interchange of these gifts was an
essential part of the marriage contract.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_56" class="pginternal">56</a>, line 674—'<i>The panther</i>.' The badge of the House of Anjou was a leopard.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_59" class="pginternal">59</a>, lines 744, 745. The idea that a diamond might be softened by the application
of a he-goat's blood is very old. San Marte says it is mentioned by Pliny. Hartmann
refers to it in his <i>Erec</i>, and it seems to have been a general belief in the Middle Ages.</p>
<h3>BOOK III</h3>
<p>The first two books of this poem are peculiar to Wolfram. Among the different
versions of the Perceval legend which we possess there is a curious diversity of statement
as to the parentage of the hero; though, as a rule, they agree in the main facts of the death
of his father, either before, or shortly after, Perceval's birth, and his being brought up in
the desert by his widowed mother.</p>
<p>With the Third Book we find ourselves on ground common to most transcribers of the
legend; and in this and the following books a table of the traditional events contained in
the book, with the other versions of the story in which they occur, will be given. The
following are the Romances of the Grail-cycle which deal more particularly with the
Perceval legend.—</p>
<p><i>Li Conte del Graal</i>, poem by Chrêtien de Troyes; left unfinished at Chrêtien's death;
it was continued by three other writers; the poem as we have it, is the work of at least four
different hands.</p>
<p><i>Peredur</i>: Welsh tale found in the Red Book of Hergest.</p>
<p><i>Perceval</i>: A French prose romance, ascribed by many critics to Robert de Borron.</p>
<p><i>Sir Percyvelle of Galles</i>: English metrical romance—author unknown.</p>
<p><i>Perceval li Gallois</i>: French prose romance, also by an unknown writer.</p>

</tbody></table>
<p>(It will be found that, from Books <span class="smcap">III.</span> to <span class="smcap">XIII.</span> inclusive, there is a very close parallelism
between Wolfram's poem and Chrêtien's share of <i>Li Conte del Graal</i>.)</p>
<p>Introduction, lines 1-45. This introduction, like that to Book <span class="smcap">I.</span>, appears to have
been written <i>after</i> the completion of the poem, and to have been intended by the poet as
a defence of his attitude towards women; certainly the lines 12-15 presuppose certain
statements which had aroused the wrath of the lady hearers of the poet. The whole
passage is interesting on account of its strongly personal character. In Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> Wolfram
refers more than once to the lady who has wronged him (pp. 163, 166, 191), and in terms
that show, as here, that he bitterly resented her treatment. The line 'Born was I unto
the bearing of knightly shield and spear,' is the only definite statement as to the poet's
rank in life which we possess, and in the light of his lasting fame as a poet it is curious
to find him holding his gift of song as of less account than his knightly deeds, which do
not seem to have been more remarkable than those of his fellows.</p>
<p>From Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 122, we learn that Wolfram was married, and, from the concluding
lines of Books <span class="smcap">VI.</span> and <span class="smcap">XVI.</span>, it is clear that the <i>Parzival</i> was composed with a view to
winning, or retaining, the favour of a lady, but the only direct personal allusion throughout
the entire poem is that to the Margravine of Heitstein in Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> p. 232, and the
passage is too vague to allow of our identifying the lady named either with Wolfram's
faithless love, or with her for whose sake he composed his poem; certainly the Margravine
was not his wife.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_67" class="pginternal">67</a>, line 61—'<i>Soltanè's strand</i>.' This is one of the many instances in the poem
in which an adjective has been taken as a proper name. In the French source it was
undoubtedly an adjective meaning 'solitary,' 'waste.' In Chrêtien we find <i>la gaste forest</i>
<i>soltaine</i>; other versions speak of the woods, or the desert, none but this gives a proper
name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_69" class="pginternal">69</a>, line 158—'<i>Ulterleg's Count</i>.' <i>Oultre-lac</i>, 'beyond the lake,' cf. Louis
D'outremer. This is again an instance of a qualifying term used as a proper name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_72" class="pginternal">72</a>, line 220—'<i>Meljakanz</i>.' This exploit is quite in keeping with the character of
the knight, cf. Book <span class="smcap">VII.</span> p. 198. In Malory we meet with the same character, as Sir
Meliagraunce; and the story of his abduction of Guinevere, and her rescue by Launcelot
is there given in full.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_72" class="pginternal">72</a>, line 240—'<i>For some cunning wile of woman</i>.' It is curious to note that
nothing comes of these elaborate precautions on the part of Herzeleide. Parzival's fool's
dress seems to excite very little attention, nothing is said of it on his appearance at
Arthur's court, nor do we hear of any one mocking him for it. The effect produced by
his personal beauty is much more strongly insisted upon. There is also a decided discrepancy
between the mother's anxiety to keep her son from danger and her suggestions
to him to avenge the wrong Lähelein has done him.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_309">[Pg 309]</a></span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_73" class="pginternal">73</a>, line 267—'<i>Lähelein</i>,' Cf. Appendix A, and remarks on this character.
Heinzel suggests that Lähelein=Llewellwyn, a prince of South Wales who conquered
North Wales in 1015. But if a parallel between the boyhood of Parzival and that of
Henry Fitz-Empress be intended, as seems probable, the Welsh connection is of too early
a date. The remarks in Heinzel's pamphlet, 'Ueber Wolfram von Eschenbach's <i>Parzival</i>,'
as to Lähelein being undoubtedly an historical personage, are worthy of note. It is
remarkable that we find no equivalent to this character in other versions of the story.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_74" class="pginternal">74</a>, line 287—'<i>Briziljan's wood</i>.' Most probably Broceliande, where so many
of the adventures of King Arthur and his knights take place. Undoubtedly this wood was
in Brittany, but the localities in the poem are much confused.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_74" class="pginternal">74</a>, line 297—'<i>Duke Orilus of Lalande</i>.' This name is again a misconception of
a French original, '<i>Li Orgueillous de-la-lande</i>,' which Wolfram has taken as a proper
name. In other versions the lady is unnamed. (It may be noted that Wolfram almost
invariably names his characters; and often goes to some trouble to connect them with
each other, and the main thread of his story. This tendency to account for everything,
<i>sum motiviren</i>, is a marked feature in Wolfram's writings.)</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_76" class="pginternal">76</a>, line 365—'<i>Thy brother, King Lac's son Erec</i>.' An allusion to the Erec of
Hartmann von Aue (founded upon Chrêtien's Erec and dealing with the same subject as
found in the Welsh tale of <i>Geraint</i> and the late Laureate's Enid) where the tournament at
Prurein is described.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_77" class="pginternal">77</a>, line 374—'<i>Proud Galoes</i>.' The slaying alike of Parzival's uncle Galoes, and
of his kinsman Schionatulander (p. <a href="#Page_80" class="pginternal">80</a>) by Orilus, Lähelein's brother, is also peculiar to
Wolfram, but it is curious that the <i>Rache-motif</i> thus introduced is not followed up, and
when Parzival overthrows Orilus it is to avenge the shaming of Jeschuté, nor, though
Orilus mentions his brother as having won <i>two</i> kingdoms, Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> p. 150, does Parzival
connect the mention with the loss of his own heritage. This seems to indicate that the
special rôle assigned in this poem to the two brothers was not a part of the original story,
and has not been perfectly fitted into the framework.</p>
<p>The name of Orilus' wife, Jeschuté, is supposed to be derived from a misunderstanding,
Wolfram having interpreted the verb <i>gisoit</i>, lay, as a proper name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_77" class="pginternal">77</a>, line 375—'<i>The knight Plihopleheri</i>.' A knight of the Round Table mentioned
in Hartmann's <i>Iwein</i> (founded on Chrêtien's <i>Chevalier au Lyon</i>, the subject-matter
of which is the same as that of the Welsh <i>Lady of the Fountain</i>).</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_78" class="pginternal">78</a>, line 409—This shaming of Jeschuté will strongly recall to English readers the
story of <i>Enid and Geraint</i>.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_79" class="pginternal">79</a>, line 437—'<i>Siguné and Schionatulander</i>.' The loves of these two are related
in Wolfram's unfinished poem of <i>Titurel</i>, where the full account of Schionatulander's fatal
chase of the hound, or brachet, is given. The adventure with the weeping damsel occurs
in other versions of the Perceval legend, but in none does she play so important a part as
in the <i>Parzival</i>, <i>vide</i> Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> p. 141; Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 252; and Book <span class="smcap">XVI.</span> Her parentage
is given in Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 274.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_79" class="pginternal">79</a>, line 466—'<i>Thou art Parzival</i>.' The interpretation here given of the hero's
name betrays clearly its French origin, <i>Perce-val</i>. In the Krône of Heinrich von Türlin
the writer explains <i>Val</i> as <i>Thal</i>=valley, or <i>Furch</i>=furrow. Wolfram seems to have understood
it in this second sense, and has given the name a symbolic meaning peculiar to himself.
In Chrêtien's poem no derivation or interpretation of the name is given, and the
hero himself guesses his name; nor do the special terms of endearment, evidently quoted
by Wolfram from a French source, occur in Chrêtien's version of the story.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_80" class="pginternal">80</a>, line 497—'<i>'Twas a churl</i>.' Wolfram's aristocratic contempt for peasants
may be noted in other passages, cf. Book <span class="smcap">II.</span> p. 43, and <span class="smcap">VII.</span> p. 219.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_310">[Pg 310]</a></span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_81" class="pginternal">81</a>, line 517—'<i>Herr Hartmann von Aue</i>.' Hartmann von Aue was a famous
German poet of the twelfth century. If not absolutely the first to introduce the Arthurian
legends into Germany (Eilhart's <i>Tristan</i> is earlier than Hartmann's works), he was the
writer who first rendered them popular in that country. His principal poems are <i>Erec</i>,
written about 1191; and <i>Iwein</i> 1202, both of which are frequently referred to by
Wolfram. They were founded on two poems by Chrêtien de Troyes, <i>Erec</i> and <i>Le</i>
<i>Chevalier au Lyon</i>, but Hartmann was not a mere translator; he handled his materials
with considerable skill, and with an insight into the characters and motives of his
<i>dramatis personæ</i> which is distinctly a feature of the German presentment of these legends.
Enid and her mother Karnafite are characters in the <i>Erec</i>. The story of another of
Hartmann's poems, <i>Der arme Heinrich</i>, is well known to English readers through
Longfellow's version of it in <i>The Golden Legend</i>.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_82" class="pginternal">82</a>, line 534—'<i>No Kurwenal was his teacher</i>.' Kurwenal is the friend and tutor
of Tristan. In Malory we find the name 'Gouvernail,' and it seems probable that here
again we have a term denoting an office converted into a proper name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_82" class="pginternal">82</a>, line 549—'<i>Ither of Gaheviess</i>.' Ither = Welsh <i>Idêr</i>; Gaheviess = <i>gas-vies</i>, old
wood. Chrêtien calls him '<i>de la forêt de Kinkerloi</i>.'</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_82" class="pginternal">82</a>, line 544—'<i>The Red Knight</i>.' This character is evidently one of the traditional
features of the story; though the circumstances of the meeting differ, there is no
version without its 'Red Knight.' In those romances of the Grail-cycle in which Perceval
has been deposed from his original position as hero in favour of Galahad, we find the
latter wearing the armour, and bearing the title, of the Red Knight. Here again Wolfram
is the only writer who names him, but it is somewhat startling to find the king of
<i>Cumberland</i> claiming <i>Brittany</i>. From Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> pp. 273 and 285, we learn that he was
Parzival's kinsman. It may be interesting here, and may help to the better understanding
of the poem, if we describe the armour of a knight at the end of the twelfth century. The
principal piece of defensive armour was the Hauberk (Halsberg), a coat formed of rings of
steel which reached to the knee, and had sleeves ending in iron gauntlets. Attached to
this, and forming one piece with the Halsberg, was the Härsenier, a cap of chain mail
which was drawn over the head below the helmet. The upper part of the face was protected
by the 'Nasen-band,' a band of iron provided with eye-holes; and the lower part
by the 'Fintäle,' a part of the 'Härsenier' which passed round and over the chin; above
this the helmet was fastened. (The use of the word 'visor' in the translation is an
anachronism, as the visor proper was not introduced till later, but there was no other word
which would express what was meant with equal brevity and clearness.) Foot and leg
were clad in hose of iron, and the knee and elbow were specially protected by plates of iron
or <i>schinnelier</i>. Over this harness many knights wore the <i>Waffen-rock</i>, a long sleeveless
garment of silk on which the badge of the knight was embroidered in gold and jewels.
The sword was girt above this garment. The knight would also bear his distinguishing
badge on helmet, shield, and the truncheon of his spear. The shield was of wood,
strengthened with bands of metal, and often decorated with precious stones, cf. the description
of Feirefis' shield in Book <span class="smcap">XV.</span> The shield was long-shaped, three-cornered, and was
held in the left hand close to the body, the spear was carried in the right, so that the horse
was guided by the <i>knee</i>, not by the <i>hand</i>, of the rider. The spear was a blade of steel, set
into a long heft of wood, or reed, <i>Röhr</i>, probably Bamboo, sometimes even the rough
trunk of a young tree, as in Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 519. Shield and spear were alike painted in the
same colours as the robe of the knight, and the horse had a like covering of silk beneath
the saddle and over the coat of mail with which it was protected. The description
given by Wolfram of the arms and accoutrement of the Red Knight of Parzival, Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span>
p. 19, and Orilus, Book <span class="smcap">V.</span> pp. 147-148, <i>seq.</i>, will give a very clear idea of the appearance
of a knight in full battle-array.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_311">[Pg 311]</a></span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_83" class="pginternal">83</a>, line 570—'<i>To the Table Round I came</i>.' Here we find an allusion to two
methods of laying claim to a property. There seems a difference of opinion as to the
first; Simrock holds that the pouring out of the wine constituted the claim; Bartsch,
that the point of the action lay in carrying off some part of the property claimed. This
seems the more probable interpretation, the pouring out of the wine then, as well as the
sprinkling the queen, would be accidental. In Chrêtien the indignation of king and queen
at the insult is far more strongly emphasised. The burning of a wisp of straw, as a
declaration of rights claimed, is mentioned by Grimm in his <i>Deutsche Rechtsalterthümer</i>.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_83" class="pginternal">83</a>, line 586—'<i>Iwanet</i>.' The diminutive of Iwein, the well-known hero of
Hartmann's poem (the Owain, son of Urien of Rheged, of Welsh tradition).</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_83" class="pginternal">83</a>—'<i>Parzival at the court of King Arthur</i>.' There are some distinctive
features in Wolfram's version of this incident. Parzival's behaviour towards the
King, though unconventional, is far less discourteous than that ascribed to him either
by Chrêtien or by the English 'Sir Percyvelle.' In Chrêtien's poem, Perceval rides into
the hall, where he finds the king and courtiers plunged in grief at the insult offered to them
by the Red Knight. The king does not reply to Perceval's greeting, and the lad rides so
close to him that his horse's head knocks off the king's cap. A reason for the failure of
the Knights of the Round Table to avenge the insult offered by the Red Knight is suggested
in the fact that they are already wounded in battle. [The student of Irish heroic
saga cannot fail to recall the strange disability under which the knights of Conchobor's court
suffered at times and which completely prostrated them. The province of Ulster would
have lain defenceless were it not that the Cuchulainn alone was free from the disability, and
single-handed defied the men of the rest of Ireland. There are many points of contrast
between the <i>enfances</i> of Cuchulainn and those of Perceval—A.N.] The kindly feeling
shown both by Arthur and Guinevere towards Ither is not paralleled in Chrêtien,
where the Red Knight is represented as Arthur's deadliest foe, and Guinevere is like to
die of shame and wrath at the insult offered to her. Chrêtien also places Perceval's
refusal to dismount here, whereas Wolfram places it on his arrival at Gurnemanz' castle.
In Chrêtien the hero tells the Red Knight of his intention to demand his armour from
Arthur, and there is no trace of the courteous and poetical greeting which Ither here
addresses to Parzival. The confusion of the Red Knight with the hero's own personal
foe is of course due to the introduction of the Lähelein episode which is peculiar to
Wolfram; but Chrêtien has a most curious passage connected with Perceval's inability to
disarm his dead antagonist:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Ains auroie par carbonées<br></span>
<span class="i0">Trestout escarbelliè le mort,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Que nule des armes enport;'<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>which as it stands is decidedly difficult of interpretation; while in the English Sir Percyvelle
we find the hero saying:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i4">'My moder bad me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whenne my dart solde brokene be<br></span>
<span class="i0">Owte of the irene brenne the tree,'<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>which evidently indicates the source of Chrêtien's curious remark. An examination of the
different versions seems to show that, while the German is the fuller and more poetical, the
French is here closer to the original form of the story.</p>
<p>Pages <a href="#Page_85" class="pginternal">85</a> and <a href="#Page_86" class="pginternal">86</a>, lines 635, 658—'<i>Kay the Seneschal</i>.' The character of Kay is one of
the problems of the Arthurian legends. In all the tales he is represented as filling the
office of Seneschal, and in all he is represented as a man of rough manners, violent temper,
and bitter tongue. The Seneschal (<i>Senes-schalh</i>), the oldest servant, was master of the<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_312">[Pg 312]</a></span>
ceremonies, one of the chief personages of a royal household, and not unfrequently the
trusted confidant of the king; but such a chastisement as Kay here, and in other versions,
inflicts upon Kunnewaaré, was distinctly <i>outside</i> his office, and, taking into consideration
the standing of Kunnewaaré and Antanor, quite inconceivable. Here, as in other
instances, we have traces of an original tradition dating from a time when a far rougher
code of manners and customs obtained. Wolfram, while adhering closely to his source,
and to the traditional representation of Kay's character, was evidently extremely puzzled
by the undignified and discourteous part allotted to him, and in Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> (p. 169) he
diverges from the story in order to explain what he feels to be a difficulty, and to defend
Kay at some length. The Northern French poets apparently felt the same, and as Kay
is generally represented as Arthur's foster-brother they invented the fable that the
unknightly traits in his character were due to his having been committed to the care of
a peasant nurse when his mother took charge of the infant Arthur.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_85" class="pginternal">85</a>, line 652—'<i>The maiden Kunnewaaré</i>.' The 'laughing damsel' seems to be
an archaic and misunderstood element in the Grail romances. A common incident of
folk-tales is for the hero, fool, lout, or tatterdemalion, to win to wife a princess who has
not laughed or spoken for years by inducing her to do either of these things. Some such
incident has apparently been woven into an heroic romance, the main outlines of which
were already fixed, so that the actual conclusion, marriage of the hero with the laughing
damsel, has been disturbed. Note, however, the homage paid by Parzival to Kunnewaaré,
and her evident affection for him (Book <span class="smcap">VI.</span> pp. 181-185). Her name too is suggestive,
it has been derived from <i>la pucele a la gonne vaire</i> (the maiden with the coloured
robe), but in its present form it is suspiciously like Kondwiramur, and it should be noted
that it is the rejected lover of this queen whom Kunnewaaré eventually marries. Is it
possible that the Perceval romance from which both Chrêtien and 'Kiot' drew contained
doublets of this personage? In the one case in her original, in the other in a modified
form. An instructive parallel may be adduced from the saga of Cuchulainn. He is the
hero of an Andromeda episode and should by rights wed the delivered heroine, but the
story being already fixed before the episode was assimilated, the heroine is passed on to a
companion of the hero.—[A. N.]</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_89" class="pginternal">89</a>, line 766—'<i>Maestricht, or e'en Cologne</i>.' German art, in the early Middle Ages,
reached its highest level in the Rhenish provinces, especially at Cologne.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_91" class="pginternal">91</a>, line 828—'<i>Gurnemanz of Graharz</i>.' The old knight who instructs the hero
in knightly duties is a traditional part of the story, and belongs to most of the versions.
In Peredur, he is identified with the Fisher King, Perceval's uncle. In Chrêtien
his name is given as Gonemans of Gelbort; in Gerbert, Chrêtien's continuator, he is,
<i>Gornemant</i> (one of several points of contact between Gerbert and Wolfram's source).</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_91" class="pginternal">91</a>, line 847—'<i>He bade them lead the guest in</i>.' This is one of the many passages
which afford an interesting glimpse of the manners and customs of a bygone age. It
may be well to summarise here what we know of the reception and treatment of a guest in
the Middle Ages. If a strange knight rode into the courtyard of a castle he was received
by squires and pages, who held his bridle and assisted him to dismount. The guest was
then conducted to a chamber where he was disarmed and provided with suitable robes.
In every important household there was a <i>Kleider-kammer</i>, or wardrobe, presided over
by a chamberlain, whose office it was to see that all guests were provided with garments
fitted to their station. The preparation of these dresses was the work of the women of the
household, and it can have been no light task, as even if a whole company arrived they
would all expect to be provided with the requisite dress. The guest, being robed, was
then conducted to the great Hall, which was in the upper story of the castle. Half-way
on the staircase leading to it, he would be met, and welcomed with the kiss of greeting, by<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_313">[Pg 313]</a></span>
both host and hostess (cf. Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 107), and led by them into the Hall where he
would receive the greeting of the assembled company. When all were seated the guest
would say who he was, and whence he came, but, if he kept silence on this point, it was not
etiquette to ask him till the next morning (cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 95). The evening meal then
followed, after which, on occasions of great festivity, such as that recounted in Book <span class="smcap">XIII.</span>
(marriage feast of Gawain and Orgeluse) there would be dancing, otherwise the time seems
to have been spent in conversation till the appearance of the wine-cup, <i>Nacht Trunk</i>,
gave the signal for separation. Then knights conducted the guest to his chamber, where
pages disrobed him, and apparently waited with lighted tapers till he fell asleep. The
account given here of Parzival's visit to Gurnemanz gives a very good idea of how the
following day would be spent, indeed Wolfram's love for detailed description, and accuracy
of statement render this poem peculiarly valuable to a student of the manners and customs
of the Middle Ages.</p>
<p>From various hints in the Gawain episodes, notably Books <span class="smcap">X.</span> and <span class="smcap">XI.</span>, it seems as if the
privilege extended to a guest might on occasion be construed with a freedom decidedly
repellent to modern ideas.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_96" class="pginternal">96</a>, lines 984, 985—'<i>Full five shall thy senses be</i>.' Cf. Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 200.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_98" class="pginternal">98</a>, line 1055—'<i>The prince bade his daughter hither</i>.' The introduction of
Gurnemanz' daughter, and her incipient love affair with Parzival is peculiar to this
version. There is a curious discrepancy to be noted between the apparent susceptibility
of the hero here and in Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> pp. 260, 261, and his indifference to feminine charms
displayed elsewhere, notably in his rejection of Orgeluse's advances and neglect of the
Château Merveil adventure. The latter presentment seems most in accordance with
Parzival's character; is the susceptibility to be ascribed to the <i>poet</i>?</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_99" class="pginternal">99</a>, line 1080—'<i>I lose once more a son</i>.' The sons of the old knight are mentioned
in other versions, but Wolfram alone names them. The circumstances of Schenteflur's
death are recounted in Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 121; the account given of the other two sons is largely
borrowed from Hartmann's <i>Erec</i>, where the strife for the hawk at Kanedig, and the
venture, Schoie-de-la-kurt (which is not a person, but an expedition), is fully recounted.
Brandigan is Klamidé's kingdom, cf. Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span>; Mabonagrein, his cousin, Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 123.
Mahaut is another form of the name Matilda. From <i>Titurel</i> we learn that Gurzgrei and
Mahaut were the parents of Schionatulander, Siguné's lover, cf. also Book <span class="smcap">VIII.</span> p. 245
and note.</p>
<h3>BOOK IV<br>

TRADITIONAL EVENTS</h3>
<table style="border-spacing: 0px;padding: 4px;border-width: 0px;" data-summary="TRADITIONAL EVENTS">
<colgroup><col span="2" style="width: 50%;">
</colgroup><tbody><tr>
<td>Arrival at besieged city; maiden of the
      castle beseeches the hero's aid; overthrowal
      of her enemies and final marriage
      with maiden.</td>
<td class="bl">Chrêtien and his continuator Gerbert; Peredur;
      Sir Percyvelle.</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>Name of the maiden; Chrêtien, Blanche-fleur; Sir Percyvelle Lufamour; Peredur
unnamed.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_103" class="pginternal">103</a>, line 17—'<i>Who rideth astray, etc</i>.' According to Simrock this passage in
the original contains a play upon words which cannot be reproduced in translation:
Slegel—schlegel, the word employed for <i>axe</i> here, signifying, in some parts of Germany,
'a fallen tree.'</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_314">[Pg 314]</a></span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_104" class="pginternal">104</a>, line 26—'<i>The city of Pelrapär</i>.' In Chrêtien the name of the city is 'Beau-repaire,'
of which this is evidently the German rendering. The substitution of <i>p</i> for <i>b</i> is
still a distinguishing mark of German pronunciation of French. In <i>Sir Percyvelle</i> it is
'the maiden land.'</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_104" class="pginternal">104</a>, line 38—'<i>The King Klamidé</i>.' This character is named by Wolfram and
Chrêtien only; in <i>Peredur</i> he is the Earl; in Sir Percyvelle, 'Sowdane.' Chrêtien
calls him 'Clamadex,' and it is worthy of note that in <i>Perceval li Gallois</i> the son of
the Red Knight slain by Perceval is called 'Clamadas,' evidently a variant of the same
name.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_105" class="pginternal">105</a>, line 78—'<i>My lord the Count of Wertheim</i>.' Wertheim is in Lower
Franconia. Bartsch thinks either Poppo <span class="smcap">I.</span> or his son Poppo <span class="smcap">II.</span> is referred to here.
From the expression used, 'my lord,' it seems as if Wolfram had at one time been in his
service.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_106" class="pginternal">106</a>, line 89—'<i>Trühending</i>.' There are three places of this name in the neighbourhood
of Eschenbach: Hohen, Alten, and Wasser-Trühending. The latter is still
famous for its <i>krapfen</i>, a kind of pancake.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_107" class="pginternal">107</a>, line 119—'<i>Kiot of Katelangen</i> (<i>i.e.</i> Catalonia) <i>and Manfilot</i>.' Kiot is the
father of Siguné, and appears again in Book <span class="smcap">XVI.</span> The account of his marriage with
Schoisianè, her death, and his subsequent adoption of the life of a hermit will be found
in Book IX. p. 274. From Wolfram's unfinished poem of <i>Titurel</i> we learn that Manfilot
was his companion.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_107" class="pginternal">107</a>, line 133—'<i>The twain Isoldé</i>.' An allusion to Isoldé la Belle, the wife of
King Mark of Cornwall, and mistress of Sir Tristan; and Isoldé of the white hand,
Tristan's wife.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_109" class="pginternal">109</a>, line 208, <i>seq.</i>—'<i>Till the cry of heart-sorrow woke him</i>.' This nocturnal
visit of the Lady of the castle to the hero's chamber seems to be part of the original tradition,
and it is evident by the apologetic manner in which Wolfram tells the story that he
is somewhat puzzled by Kondwiramur's conduct. From the Introduction to Book <span class="smcap">VII.</span>,
and also from the blame he bestows on Chrêtien for having done a wrong to the story,
<i>Diese Märe unrecht gethan</i>, we gather that Wolfram set a high value on fidelity to his
source, and these and similar apologetic passages must be explained by the unwillingness
of the poet to depart from the traditional form of the legend, while, at the same time, the
story, representing as it did the manners and customs of an earlier and ruder period, was
somewhat distasteful to him.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_110" class="pginternal">110</a>, line 243—'<i>Kingron the Seneschal</i>.' This character is Aguigrenons in
Chrêtien, elsewhere he is unnamed. Mr. York Powell points out that Wolfram's form
presupposes an Aguigrenons, which would either indicate that the existing MSS. of Chrêtien,
or Chrêtien himself, misread <i>u</i> for <i>n</i>, or that Wolfram did <i>not</i> get his version by ear
as he maintains (or that Wolfram was following a source other than Chrêtien).</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_114" class="pginternal">114</a>, line 365, seq.—'<i>The marriage night</i>.' A similar account is given by Gerbert,
one of the continuators of Chrêtien. (Chrêtien himself does not record the marriage,
which takes place on a later visit of the hero to Beau-repaire.) In Gerbert's version we
have an indication of later influence, as the motive-power is the recognition by both
Perceval and his bride of the superiority of virginity to the married state. Wolfram's
version seems far more in accordance with the character of the hero, and is probably closer
to the original form of the story.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_116" class="pginternal">116</a>, line 420—'<i>Galogandres, Duke of Gippones</i>.' This character and Count
Narant only appear here. Uckerland is probably a corruption of Oultreland, as noted in
Book <span class="smcap">III.</span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_118" class="pginternal">118</a>, line 505—'<i>Gringorz</i>.' The French <i>Gringoire</i>—Gregory. All this account of<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_315">[Pg 315]</a></span>
Klamidé's arms, charger, etc., is peculiar to Wolfram; whose fondness for minute and
descriptive detail is a noticeable characteristic.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_121" class="pginternal">121</a>, line 598—'<i>Dianasdron</i>.' Dinaderon en Gales in Chrêtien, who does not
mention Karminöl. In the roll of King Arthur's knights we find such names as Sir
Dinas, Sir Dinant, Sir Dinadan; all of which seem to come from the same root. The
name is probably Keltic, and belongs to the original version of the story.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_123" class="pginternal">123</a>, line 660—'<i>Mabonagrein</i>.' Cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 108 and note.</p>
<h3>BOOK V<br>

TRADITIONAL EVENTS</h3>
<table style="border-spacing: 0px;padding: 4px;border-width: 0px;" data-summary="TRADITIONAL EVENTS">
<colgroup><col span="2" style="width: 50%;">
</colgroup><tbody><tr>
<td>Hero meets with the Fisher King; visits the
      Grail Castle, sees the Grail, lance, etc., but
      asks no question, and is therefore reproached
      by maiden with dead knight.</td>
<td class="bl">Chrêtien and continuators: Peredur; Perceval;
      Perceval li Gallois. (Sir Percyvelle
      omits everything connected with the Grail.)</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>(The reader will find all this part of the legend, the varying forms of the visit to the
Grail Castle, the Fisher King, the Grail, etc., fully discussed in Mr. Alfred Nutt's <i>Studies</i>
<i>on the Legend of the Holy Grail</i>.)</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_131" class="pginternal">131</a>, line 58—'<i>Abenberg's field</i>.' Castle and town of Abenberg, in the neighbourhood
of Eschenbach.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_131" class="pginternal">131</a>, line 75—'<i>Repanse de Schoie</i>.' This name appears to signify 'Thought of
joy.' The Grail maidens are not named in other versions.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_132" class="pginternal">132</a>, line 87—'<i>Then one to the host would call him</i>.' This was evidently the
Court Jester, always a privileged person.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_132" class="pginternal">132</a>, lines 109, 110—'<i>Lignum Aloe</i>.' Bartsch holds this to be a mistake of the
poet, who has misunderstood the old French word <i>Aloer</i>. Chrêtien has simply <i>seces</i>
<i>boises</i>. 'Wildberg' was the home of the poet, who is here making allusion to his poverty,
as in Book <span class="smcap">IV.</span> p. 106.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_132" class="pginternal">132</a>, line 111—'<i>And the host had bid them lay him</i>.' 'The Maimed King'
invariably figures in the Grail Romances, whether they deal only with the Quest, as here,
or with the early history of the Grail. He is generally wounded through the thighs, either
with a lance, or with a sword, but the circumstances under which he receives the wound
vary greatly. In most of the versions he is met with while engaged in fishing, and is
known as the Fisher King, or the 'Rich Fisher.'</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_132" class="pginternal">132</a>, line 125—'<i>The bleeding lance</i>.' This is a feature in most of the Grail
Romances, and seems to have been an original feature of the story, though it had not the
close connection with the <i>Grail</i>, which the fully developed Christian legend has given to
it. In the earlier versions of the story it is the weapon with which the Maimed King was
wounded; finally, it became the spear with which our Lord's side was pierced on the cross.
Wolfram, who never appears to connect the Grail with the Passion, gives it the first meaning.
The visit to the Grail Castle is told in varying forms, but the King, the Grail, Sword,
and Lance almost invariably appear, and the hero is either Perceval or his companion
Gawain, but Perceval is, undoubtedly, the original hero of the Quest.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_133" class="pginternal">133</a>, line 137 and <i>seq.</i>—'<i>The Grail Procession</i>.' In Chrêtien this is much more<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_316">[Pg 316]</a></span>
simply treated. There are two squires bearing candlesticks, and two maidens, one of
whom carries the Grail, the other a silver dish, <i>tailleor</i>. Wolfram has evidently seized
the opportunity to give play to his love of detailed description, and his account of the
Grail Feast and the Grail Maidens is far more elaborate than any given elsewhere.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_136" class="pginternal">136</a>, line 223—'<i>The food-supplying powers of the Grail</i>.' In other romances of
the cycle we find similar powers attributed to the Grail. Malory, who borrowed largely
from the <i>Queste</i> and <i>Grand S. Graal</i>, gives a like account. There is evidently a connection
between this feature of the Grail, and the food-supplying talismans which figure
largely in the legendary lore of most countries.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_137" class="pginternal">137</a>, line 247—'<i>A squire who a sword did bear</i>.' Cf. p. <a href="#Page_144" class="pginternal">144</a>, lines 472 and <i>seq.</i>
This incident also occurs in Chrêtien, and in varying form in most of the versions. In this
poem the meaning and use of the sword are somewhat inexplicable. In Chrêtien that
sword
will break in <i>one</i> peril, known only to its maker, and then can be made whole by
dipping it in a <i>lake</i>. Wolfram's account seems to be based on a misunderstanding of a
French original. In some of the other versions the sword is already broken, and can only
be made whole by the achiever of the Quest. In Wolfram the sword is a very puzzling
feature of the story, with which indeed it seems to have little or no connection. The sword,
which breaks in Parzival's deadly combat with his unknown brother, is not <i>this</i> sword, but
the one taken from Ither of Gaheviess.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_137" class="pginternal">137</a>, line 267—'<i>The fairest of old men ancient</i>.' Titurel, cf. Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 287.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_137" class="pginternal">137</a>, line 273—'<i>'Tis a symbol good, the bowstring</i>.' Introduction to Book <span class="smcap">I.</span>, line
9, and note.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_139" class="pginternal">139</a>, line 325—'<i>The garden of Paradise</i>.' This is one of the allusions which
seem to connect the Grail in Wolfram's version with an Oriental source, cf. p. <a href="#Page_135" class="pginternal">135</a>.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_141" class="pginternal">141</a>, line 371—'<i>A hidden hand drew the rope taut</i>.' Chrêtien has the incident
of the drawbridge rising, but in no other version are the reproaches addressed to the hero
immediately on his leaving the castle, they are invariably put into the mouth of the maiden
with the dead knight. In the <i>Perceval</i> the maiden's words, 'The Lord hates thee,' recall
Wolfram's <i>Ihr sult varen der sunnen has</i>, which Bartsch says is an ancient formula of
declaring a person accurst, and unworthy of the light of day.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_141" class="pginternal">141</a>, line 381—'<i>Doubled the throw of sorrow</i>.' Cf. Book <span class="smcap">III.</span> p. 100; Book <span class="smcap">II.</span>
p. 47. Similes borrowed from games of chance are not unusual in this poem.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_141" class="pginternal">141</a>, line 397—'<i>A woman's voice make moan</i>.' This meeting with the maiden
<i>after</i> the visit to the Grail Castle is in most versions the only one. In Chrêtien she now
tells the hero his name which he learns or guesses for the first time. It was not improbably
this incident which led either Wolfram, or his source, to place a first meeting
earlier in the story while still retaining one in the original position. Wolfram, with
characteristic love for detail, follows up the history of Siguné far more fully than other
writers of the cycle.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_142" class="pginternal">142</a>, line 427—'<i>Monsalväsch</i>.' Probably 'Mont Sauvage,' in allusion to its wild
and lonely position. A full account of the Grail and its keepers is given in Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span>
pp. 270, 271.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_143" class="pginternal">143</a>, line 463—'<i>Lunete</i>.' A character in Hartmann's <i>Iwein</i>, from which the
episode is quoted. Cf. Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 252, and opening of Book <span class="smcap">XII.</span></p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_144" class="pginternal">144</a>, line 475—'<i>Trebuchet</i>.' This name is also given in Chrêtien; he is alluded
to again p. <a href="#Page_147" class="pginternal">147</a>, and in Book <span class="smcap">IX.</span> p. 281, in connection with the knives of silver mentioned
in line 498 of this book.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_147" class="pginternal">147</a>, line 595—'<i>Tenabroc</i>.' Also p. <a href="#Page_133" class="pginternal">133</a>, line 146. This name is borrowed from
Hartmann's Erec. Chrêtien has 'Danebroc.'</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_147" class="pginternal">147</a>, line 601—'<i>Beàlzenan</i>.' According to Bartsch this name is combined from<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_317">[Pg 317]</a></span>
Provençal, <i>beal</i>, fair; <i>enan</i>, height='the fair height,' which would suit very well with the
position of Angers, the capital of Anjou.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_152" class="pginternal">152</a>, line 760—'<i>Wild Taurian, Dodine's brother</i>.' Cf. Book IX. p. 265. Taurian
does not seem to have been identified, but <i>Dodine</i> appears, in many of the Arthurian
romances, always with the title of 'Le Sauvage.' So we find him named in Malory.
Wolfram seemed to have transferred the characteristic from one brother to the
other.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_155" class="pginternal">155</a>, line 849—'<i>Iofreit the son of Idöl</i>.' This is the French name Geoffrey.
Mentioned again in Book VI. line 168. Most critics identify this character with Chrêtien's
<i>Giflès li feus Do</i>.</p>
<h3>BOOK VI<br>

TRADITIONAL EVENTS</h3>
<table style="border-spacing: 0px;padding: 4px;border-width: 0px;" data-summary="TRADITIONAL EVENTS">
<colgroup><col span="2" style="width: 50%;">
</colgroup><tbody><tr>
<td>Blood drops on the snow and love-trance
      of hero.</td>
<td class="bl">Chrêtien: Peredur.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Overthrows Kay and Segramor.</td>
<td class="bl">(Perceval Li Gallois relates a similar incident
      of Gawain.)</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Hero is cursed by Grail messenger for his
      failure to ask the question.</td>
<td class="bl">Chrêtien: Peredur.<br>
      (In Perceval there is a cursing by Merlin.)</td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_159" class="pginternal">159</a>, line 2—'<i>From Karidöl and his kingdom</i>.' Karidöl=Carduel or Cardoile,
the Anglo-Norman form of Carlisle. This is undoubtedly Arthur's original capital, but
throughout this poem Nantes seems to be regarded as the royal city. Curiously enough
we find the two names combined in Gautier de Doulens, one of the continuators of <i>Li</i>
<i>Conte del Graal</i>, who introduces, as one of his <i>dramatis personæ</i>, Carduel of Nantes.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_160" class="pginternal">160</a>, line 29—'<i>Whitsuntide</i>.' An examination of the Romances will show this
statement to be correct; Pentecost and Christmas seem to have been the two feasts held
in especial honour at King Arthur's court.</p>
<p>Page <a href="#Page_160" class="pginternal">160</a>, line 49—'<i>Blood-drops on the snow</i>.' Both Wolfram and Chrêtien insist only
on the <i>two</i> colours, red and white, and the fact that they are puzzled by, and think it
necessary to explain, the presence of snow at Whitsuntide shows that they are taking
over the incident from an older source. As a matter of fact it is to be found in tales
unconnected with the Arthurian cycle, and of varying nationality. In Peredur (Welsh) a
raven has settled upon the body of a wild goose killed by a falcon, and the hero thinks of
<i>three</i> colours (black, for hair; white, for skin; red, for cheeks); in the <i>Fate of the Sons</i>
<i>of Usnech</i>, an Irish tale written down before the middle of the twelfth century, and
probably centuries older, these three colours are likewise present, but it is a calf instead
of a wild goose that is slain, and it is the heroine, not the hero, who is fascinated by the
colours. The incident has always been a favourite one with Celtic story-tellers (cf. <i>Argyll</i>
<i>Tales</i>, M'Innes and Nutt, pp. 431-34), and curiously it is the slain-<i>bird</i>, instead of the
slain-<i>calf</i> version which predominates, although the <i>Fate of the Sons of Usnech</i> is
